PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:
1.discriminates against low income families and those living in rural areas
2.increases business costs and will cause further unemployment
3.adds further to the price of an already heavily taxed product
4.breaks Mr Keating's election promise not to put up tax.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate oppose these increases in petrol excise.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Kemp (from 149 citizens), Senator MacGibbon (from 20 citizens) and Senator Tierney (from 1,075 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows: That the laws passed in December 1992 counting unrealised capital gains on shares held by pensioners as income for the purposes of the social security income test are unfair, illogical and discriminatory, and should be repealed as soon as is practicable.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should: (1) note that the Liberal and National Parties now oppose the laws after voting for them in December; (2) condemn the government for persisting with the laws; and (3) take whatever steps are necessary to achieve the repeal of the laws mentioned above.

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:
1. The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
2. The implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
3. We regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: HMAS Huon
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Keating Government's decision to close down HMAS Huon is clearly and demonstrably wrong and should be reversed having regard to:
(a)The fact that HMAS Huon has been part of the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania for over 80 years;
(b)It has continually demonstrated itself to be a most efficient shore-based designated Naval facility and Headquarters for the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania;

(c)Its closure will place at risk the immediate future in Tasmania of 25 permanent Royal Australian Navy personnel, 108 active Reservists and 40 inactive Reservists and in addition will deprive the Naval Reserve Cadets of their Tasmanian Divisional Headquarters; and, the fact that only a miserable $250,000 will be allegedly saved out of the National Defence budget of over $9 billion,

and therefore call upon the Keating Government to immediately reverse the decision to close HMAS Huon and to give a commitment that it will continue to be the Headquarters of the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: ABORIGINAL EDUCATION (SUPPLEMENTARY ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

This bill represents a continuation of the Commonwealth Government's commitment to the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy (AEP) which addresses the inequality of education opportunities between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and non-Aboriginal people.

The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act was enacted in 1989 after obtaining joint agreement from all State and Territory governments and the Commonwealth. The Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program (AESIP) which underpins the Policy was introduced in 1990.

The policy sets down 21 agreed goals for Aboriginal Education to be pursued by all governments. The Policy Statement included a commitment by the Commonwealth to supplement its normal provisions of recurrent and capital funding for education in the States and Territories with a dedicated commitment of funds on a forward triennial basis for assisting the implementation of the AEP through the Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program.

Funding provided by this bill will provide the means to continue to build on the gains achieved since 1990. Since that time the Commonwealth has funded strategic initiatives directed at improving the educational outcomes of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
In this second triennium of the AEP which covers the years 1993 to 1995 the Commonwealth has nominated three National Priorities. These priorities are:
1. Responding to the relevant recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.

2. Implementing the National Aboriginal Languages and Literacy Strategy, which provides for specific initiatives for the advancement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages and literacy; and

3. Implementing the National Reconciliation and Schooling Strategy which provides for specific schooling strategies which promote the reconciliation process between Australia's indigenous and non-indigenous people.

In responding to the findings and recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, the Commonwealth Government recognises that a thrust of the recommendations is the elimination of significant social, economic and cultural disadvantages faced by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people through a process of increased self-determination and empowerment. There needs to be continued impetus given to increasing the self esteem and confidence of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

Specific recommendations of the Royal Commission which are addressed by funding under the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989 relate to the increased employment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Workers from 1993 and an expansion of pre-school services from 1994.

In the 1991 Budget a range of initiatives were announced as part of the White Paper on Australian Languages and Literacy. Significant elements of the White Paper are initiatives directed towards the advancement of Aboriginal Languages and Literacy, by the implementation of the National Aboriginal Languages and Literacy Strategy.
The Aboriginal Language Education Strategy (ALES) commenced in January 1993. ALES supports strategies geared at teaching Aboriginal languages in schools.

The Aboriginal Literacy Strategy (ALS), which also commenced in January 1993, supports special initiatives to improve the standard in English Literacy of Aboriginal primary and secondary students, particularly those students whose first language is not English.

The third priority of the Commonwealth for this triennium is the National Reconciliation and Schooling Strategy. This strategy aims to increase the understanding of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander history and culture among school-age children in support of the process of reconciliation.

Much more needs to be done to ensure the continuation of efforts towards achieving our set goals, and to address the vital national issue of ensuring that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are equally as well taught, well educated, highly motivated and successful as any other Australians.

A major review of progress in implementing the AEP since its implementation in 1990 is currently underway. I hope to complete the review in time for consideration, in next year's budget, of funding for the 1996-1998 triennium.

The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1993 provides for a modest increase in Commonwealth funding of the Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program for years 1994 and 1995.

The purpose of the bill is to appropriate funds to enable the Commonwealth to continue to enter into bilateral education agreements with State and Territory governments, non government school systems, Aboriginal education institutions and Aboriginal Education Consultative bodies for the provision of Aboriginal education initiatives consistent with the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy.

The Government has allocated some $244 million as its commitment to the AEP in the current triennium. This amount includes $17.3 million in response to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, specifically targeted to provide additional preschool places and additional Aboriginal Education Workers. In addition, an amount of $16.8 million has been included for Aboriginal Languages and Literacy initiatives.
This bill provides for the appropriation of $82,966,000 in 1994 and $83,919,000 in 1995.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the Senate.
VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993
This bill gives effect to four amendments to veterans' entitlements.

The first deals with the government's budget announcement concerning eligibility for benefits under the Veterans' Children Education Scheme. Children of veterans who receive Extreme Disablement Adjustment will now be eligible for assistance under the Scheme. This measure will align the benefits available to children of Extreme Disablement Adjustment pensioners with those available to children of Totally and Permanently Incapacitated pensioners.
The three remaining measures are non-budget amendments.

It is proposed to extend the sunset clause which governs the operation of Advance Pharmaceutical Allowance. These provisions allow a lump sum payment of pharmaceutical allowance of up to seven payments to be made to chronically-ill pensioners who have a high prescription drug use.

Without this extension, the sunset clause would repeal Advance Pharmaceutical Allowance from 1 January 1994. The proposed amendment will extend the operation of the advance payments for a further 12 months. This will enable a review to take place on the pharmaceutical requirements of chronically-ill persons who access these payments.

The second of the non-budget amendments deals with the assessment of allocated pensions and annuities. These types of investment are similar in structure to a managed investment and can be drawn upon by the purchaser at a rate and amount desired, until the balance of the account is exhausted. An allocated pension or annuity gives the purchaser some control over the amount of return and when it is received.

The Veterans' Entitlements Act does not expressly provide the rules under which this form of investment is assessed. The proposed amendment will align the assessment of allocated pensions and annuities with managed investments.
This amendment will ensure consistency in the method of assessing allocated pensions and annuities with similar provisions in the Social Security Act.

The last of the three is a minor amendment to the definition of `shares and listed securities'. This definition was inserted into the Act to provide that the income and asset value of shares were assessed in accordance with the managed investment rules. It defined shares as only those listed on a stock exchange in Australia. Concerns have been raised that by limiting the application of the definition in this manner, it may be seen as an incentive for pensioners to divest themselves of their Australian shares.

This initiative proposes an amendment to the definition of `shares and listed securities' to ensure that it applies to both Australian and foreign-sourced shares. It will align the treatment of shares and listed securities with similar provisions in the Social Security Act.
I commend this bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: TELECOMMUNICATIONS (INTERCEPTION) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 was last the subject of extensive amendment in 1987 when provision was made for State law enforcement agencies' use of interception. After some experience had been obtained in the administration of the amended provisions, the Act was reviewed by the Attorney-General's Department. The review looked at the experience of the various agencies which are given specific roles to perform under the Act and also took into account the need for the Act to reflect developments in the provision of telecommunications services arising from either technological innovations or the implementation of the industry reforms contained in the Telecommunications Act 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: In December 1991 a discussion paper was published and comments were invited from the public. Copies were sent to organisations that had expressed an interest in the subject. Although few comments were received the review team had regard to those that were in framing its recommendations to the Attorney-General.

This Bill contains amendments to the Act which the Government believes are desirable following its consideration of the review. The amendments address some current practical problems with the Act without disturbing the Act's present balance between privacy interests and law enforcement. While many of the Bill's provisions are of a technical or administrative nature, designed to rectify some minor defects in the scheme of the Act, there are some significant aspects which deserve to be brought to the attention of the Senate.

The most significant change relates to the manner in which warrants are executed. Currently, the sole responsibility for executing warrants issued to a law enforcement agency—State or Federal—lies with the Telecommunications Interception Division (TID) of the AFP. That Division's role was developed in 1987 as a means of strengthening privacy protection and ensuring that there was federal control over interceptions. It is for the same reason that the Act also currently requires that, subject to a limited exception, interceptions may only be done as a result of action taken by employees of the carrier operating the service specified in a warrant, rather than directly by the police.

The Act's requirements that the TID of the AFP execute all warrants has led to the development of a cumbersome and costly set of arrangements. These arrangements require all intercepted signals to be routed from a target exchange, wherever it is located in Australia, to the TID's facilities in Canberra where the signals are recorded at the same time as they are re-routed to the monitoring centre of the law enforcement agency which applied for the warrant. This process can result in loss or corruption of signal quality, involves considerable expense and gives rise to some risk to the security of interception operations.

The Government proposes to replace these arrangements with a new system which will resolve most of the current deficiencies. As is the case at present, the new system will ensure that a law enforcement agency will only be able to receive intercepted signals as a result of the AFP's taking action for the purpose of giving effect to a warrant. The AFP will also retain the ability to disconnect an interception directly when, for example, a warrant has expired. The technology by which this is achieved is a computer controlled cross-point switcher, which was developed by the Victorian Police. Its advantages include better signal quality and reliability at a lower cost. The new system will also provide greater security since intercepted signals will no longer be diverted through Canberra. Existing reporting mechanisms will be enhanced by a requirement for a register of warrants to be kept and regularly submitted for ministerial inspection.

The Bill also provides for the Australian Federal Police, or the police force of a State or Territory, to monitor or record telephone calls without a warrant in certain emergency situations. To respond to certain emergencies, such as sieges, kidnappings or hostage-taking incidents, the police usually communicate with the perpetrators by telephone and often need to provide facilities to allow a second negotiator or medical professional to monitor conversations.

As a general rule, the Act prohibits a person from recording a conversation without the knowledge of the person speaking. Subsection 6(2) of the Act already provides an exception to that rule in cases where a person uses customer equipment for which AUSTEL has issued a permit authorising connection to the telecommunications network, but AUSTEL's usual practice is to authorise such equipment only where the equipment emits at regular intervals a pip-tone that helps to put people on notice that a recording is taking place.

Because of the potential adverse effect on the rights of individuals, the Government does not believe that it is appropriate for the police to record telephone conversations in the types of emergency situations I have described without clear statutory criteria. Accordingly, the Bill provides that the authority to record conversations without a warrant will only arise in specified circumstances, namely, where a police officer is a party to a conversation in situations of emergency involving actual or threatened loss of life or serious personal injury or damage to property, or with the permission of a person who is likely to receive ransom or extortion demands. In the former case, a test to be satisfied by the police is that, because of the urgency of the need to record the relevant conversations, it was not practical to apply for the issue of a warrant under the Act. This test does not have to be satisfied in the latter case as the consent of the innocent party is a prerequisite. Police use of this authority will be reported to the minister and will be recorded in the annual report.

In addition, the Government accepted two Opposition amendments moved in another place. The first extends the requirement of urgency to participant monitoring with the permission of a person who is likely to receive ransom or extortion demands. The second requires the police to seek a warrant as soon as practicable after engaging in participant monitoring in emergency situations. If a warrant is not given, any continuing monitoring must cease. The Government accepts that these proposals will confirm its commitment to the protection of privacy without detracting from the capacity of police authorities to act firmly and quickly in emergency situations.

A further amendment made by the Bill is to remove the current restriction which confines a State agency's ability to seek a warrant to telephone services located in its own State. The Government does not believe such a restriction is appropriate since important investigations may be frustrated by a suspect's moving inter-state. The removal of the restriction means that a State agency will still only be able to seek the issue of a warrant for the purpose of investigating an offence in the course of performing its functions. That means that a State law enforcement agency could only successfully apply for a warrant authorising interception of a service outside the relevant State if it could persuade the issuing Judge that there is a reasonable nexus between the service specified in the warrant application and the agency's investigation of an offence for which it has responsibility.

The Bill provides for a number of other amendments, such as the inclusion of offences against Part VIA of the Crimes Act 1914, dealing with computer crimes, in the category of offences for which an interception warrant may be sought, the inclusion of the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission in the list of State agencies which may, subject to meeting certain statutory pre-conditions, become entitled to apply for warrants and the inclusion in the annual report made under the Act of additional information relating to the costs associated with the performance of interceptions by law enforcement agencies. Details of cost have been included in the 1991/92 annual report in anticipation of this amendment.
It is anticipated that the Bill's financial impact will be to reduce the overall cost of interception by about $2 million.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL TRAINING AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL (No.2)1993

PARA.TAB: This bill makes some minor amendments to the Australian National Training Authority Act 1992 to insert a new provision in relation to the transfer of certain programs from the Commonwealth to the Authority and to correct an unrelated drafting oversight in the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian National Training Authority was established formally in December 1992 following an agreement between Heads of Government in July of that year. The planning and funding arrangements for the new National Vocational Education and Training System, outlined in the agreement, come into full effect from the beginning of 1994.

As part of the new arrangements, the Authority will assume responsibility for administering certain Commonwealth programs, currently administered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training, which `support training activities and services which are national in scope and purpose'.

The Commonwealth-State Ministerial Council which oversees the Authority agreed, in April this year, on the programs to be transferred to the Authority. These `National Programs' provide catalytic and ongoing support for implementation of key aspects of the national training reform agenda. They include measures to support the development of industry-relevant, nationally consistent competency-based training; to encourage involvement of the industry parties in the planning and provision of vocational education and training; and to improve access and equity in our training system.

The Ministerial Council also agreed that, as the transfer of programs will take place mid-way through the financial year, the Authority should take over responsibility for current grants as well as uncommitted funds.
To give effect to the Council's decision it will be necessary to transfer to the Authority responsibility for relevant agreements which the Commonwealth has entered into with grant recipients.

This bill provides a simple mechanism for the transfer which will result in minimum disruption to program clients. Under the new provision, the Minister or his delegate may declare that a specified agreement is to become the responsibility of the Authority. Once the declaration comes into effect, the Authority replaces the Commonwealth as a party to the agreement. The declaration cannot take effect until a copy is given to the other party to the agreement.

The financial impact of this bill is minor. There will be some administrative costs involved in processing declarations made under the new provision, and transferring relevant documentation from the Department to the Authority. However, the mechanism provided by the bill is expected to be more cost-effective than the alternative of renegotiating or varying a large number of individual agreements.

The bill also corrects a drafting oversight in the Act by providing that the definition of `year' in the Act does not apply to Section 27. The definition of `year' as `a calendar year beginning on or after 1 January 1994' was clearly not intended to apply to this Section, which provides for members of the Authority to be appointed for a period of up to three years. The purpose of legislating to create the Authority in late 1992 was to permit it to undertake the planning necessary for full implementation of the new arrangements in 1994. The members were, in fact, appointed shortly after the Act received Royal Assent in December 1992.

The amendments which I have outlined will allow for the Australian National Training Authority to assume responsibility for National Programs and related agreements from 1 January 1994. The Authority, with these and other important responsibilities, will play a key role in the development of a more effective national vocational education and training system for the benefit of all Australians.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT BILL (No 2) 1993

PARA.TAB: The Social Security Amendment Bill (No 2) 1993 gives effect to a number of measures that were announced in the 1993 Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill provides for a $3 a week increase in the rate of Newstart Allowance paid to certain single recipients aged 21 and over without dependent children. The rate increase is an acknowledgment that the relative position of this group has fallen compared with other income support recipients. This increase will take effect from 20 March 1994 and will be additional to the indexation increase that has already occurred on that date. It will not apply to single recipients who are aged 60 or more, don't have any dependent children and have been in receipt of social security benefit continuously for at least 6 months as they already receive a higher rate of Newstart Allowance.

Income and assets tests have previously been introduced for basic family payment to ensure that financial assistance is targeted towards those families with the greatest need. Given the current fiscal situation, the Government decided that the relatively generous limits should be reviewed.

The bill provides that on 1 January 1994, the income ceiling limit for basic family payment for families with one child will be reduced from $64,938 to $60,000. The additional amount allowed for each extra child will be reduced from $3,249 to $3,000.

Also on 1 January 1994, the existing assets test limit for basic family payment will be reduced from $607,250 to $550,000. However, the hardship rules that allow the operation of the assets test to be waived in certain circumstances will continue to apply.

Families receiving a prescribed educational scheme payment are currently exempt from the basic and additional family payment income tests and from the additional family payment assets test simply because they receive a prescribed educational scheme payment. This means that a family receives family payment or additional family payment even if their income exceeds the relevant income test limit or may receive additional family payment even if the value of their assets exceeds the additional family payment assets test limit. The bill removes this inequity from 1 January 1994 by placing such families in the same situation, in terms of their total income assistance and support package, as other families who do not receive prescribed educational scheme payments such as AUSTUDY.

Social security clients must comply with notification requirements so that their payments can be administered efficiently. There can be complications, especially for the regular family payment review, when clients change address without notifying the Department and cannot therefore respond to notices sent to them. To overcome such complications, highlighted by the cases of O'Connell and Sevel, the act will now make it a requirement for a family payment client to notify a change of address. There will also be a new discretionary power to suspend family payment if a person has been informed about having to notify a change of address but fails to respond to a notice because of a change of address. The current limitation on arrears provisions, should a decision to cancel or reduce payments be subsequently overturned on review, is also to be reinforced in light of the O'Connell and Sevel cases.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993EXCISE TARIFF (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993

PROCTEXT.PARA: EXCISE TARIFF (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 20 October.

TALK.START.PARA: —When progress was reported last evening, the committee was considering the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the request for amendment moved by Senator Hill to the schedule, page 9, amendment 13, request No. 10. The question is that the request be agreed to.

—Mr Chairman, can I have a clarification as to whether the figures currently before the committee on the excise rates applicable reflect the August 1993 indexation factor? It is certainly not the intent of the opposition to remove that in terms of our amendments.

—Mr Chairman, while the minister is seeking that reply, you referred to amendment No. 13. I understand that it is amendment No. 10 put by the opposition which we are considering. Is that correct? I just want to make quite sure I am in the right place.
—It is Senator Hill's request No. 10.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Watson, the August indexation is included in those figures.

—I would like to raise a number of issues with the minister in regard to some questions that affect a number of the consequential amendments that are currently being proposed by Senator Hill. Of course, these reflect the impact this legislation is going to have on transport and on the delivery of services in remote and rural parts of Australia. People in remote and isolated rural areas pay disproportionately more now for consumer goods. I have seen various estimates given as to what the impact will be.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, it has been argued that an average basket of groceries will increase by the order of $3 if the full costs of the diesel excise and sales tax are passed on to consumers. Secondly, it has been argued that higher transport costs will threaten the viability of value added processing in regional areas of Australia, as `every stage in the production process receives more expensive transport costs'. Thirdly, it has been argued that the impact of this legislation will undermine regional development, for example, through increases in transport costs, which will reduce the viability of locating industries outside the cities.

The impact is certainly going to be quite significant in all of these areas. It is very interesting to note a quote by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, when he was the shadow minister for minerals and energy in 1980. Mr Keating said at that time, `It is a shocking thing that every petrol pump has become an office of the Tax Department'. That quote, of course, must now be coming back to haunt the Prime Minister in relation to the impact of this legislation.

The first set of questions I expect the minister to address relate to what studies have been undertaken on the impact of this legislation and the effect on transport costs and how they have been taken into account. The second issue I wish to raise relates to those amendments that will impact on mineral processing, and particularly the mineral processing operations dependent on fuel oil with no alternative energy source. For example, in the Northern Territory, Nabalco's Gove alumina plant—the largest Australian consumer of fuel oil—faces an extra cost of $25 million to its operation. Additionally, the higher coastal shipping costs will reduce Australia's international competitiveness across a range of minerals processed in Australia, whether it is alumina from Nabalco or manganese from the BHP Groote Eylandt plant in the Northern Territory on its way to the BHP plant in north-eastern Tasmania.

I would like to pose again the second round of questions. I think it is important for the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) to address them. The questions specifically relate to the impact on the Gove project. Given the evidence that was presented to the Senate committee by Nabalco on this matter, I would like to ascertain from the government what further discussions and consultations have been undertaken by the minister, by the Treasurer, by Senator Collins and by Mr Snowdon with regard to accommodating the major impacts that were highlighted. I also highlighted them in my speech at the second reading stage. Further on this particular matter, I ask the minister, and the Greens, to address this issue with regard to the impact the costs will have at Gove. The unintended consequence is that those costs are going to flow through in a very significant way to the Aboriginal community of north-east Arnhem Land

I would argue that point on two grounds. Firstly, the mining royalties that flow to Aboriginal people are very dependent on the profitability of this particular project, and the chairman of the Northern Land Council—indeed, one of the traditional owners of the Gove area—Mr Galarrwuy Yunupingu, has substantially argued this. He accused the federal government of duplicity. I am referring to a media report about the $25 million oil tax increase. Mr Yunupingu argues that, while the Commonwealth has increased the tax with a stroke of a bureaucratic pen, Aborigines are being cheated of royalties. The impact of that increase is going to be very direct.

Secondly, the Aboriginal community of Gove—where the power is generated by the Nabalco operation, which therefore affects the cost to the Aboriginal communities—will be very closely affected. In Yirrkala, and in Mr Yunupingu's own area and the township of Nhulunbuy, where some 3,500 people live, consumer costs will be directly affected. As I said, the questions I expect the minister to address relate to the transport surveys, to the costs, and to the impact this legislation will have on Nabalco. We have argued before about the sovereign risk and a number of other things. More importantly, what has the government done to alleviate and address the impact this is going to have at Gove? In particular, how will the government compensate, and how, therefore, will the Greens compensate the residents of an isolated and major community?

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. I understand that we are dealing with amendment No. 10, which specifically deals with automotive diesel oil other than for use in rail or road transport services. It seems to me that, while the first part of what Senator Tambling was saying was relevant, the issue of fuel oil, which may come up later on, may be important but is not relevant to this particular amendment.
—Mr Chairman, I appreciate that. I was seeking to—
—Senator Tambling, are you speaking to the point of order?

—Yes. I was seeking to facilitate the debate in this chamber today, as I understand that a number of the principles that apply to the next four or five amendments being proposed by Senator Hill have a consistent theme. Therefore, I am seeking to establish the answers to the questions generally. My first round of questions related to the impact on the transport operations which directly relate to this point. I accept that my second question, with regard to the Nabalco operation, concerns a later amendment, but I am also giving notice that I expect the Greens to explain how they are going to prevent a very direct impact on the Aboriginal community which will amount to millions and millions of dollars.
—Order! The clause which is sought to be amended is relevant to what Senator Tambling has thus far discussed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate and accept that Senator Tambling is trying to facilitate the debate on the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill and I have had a discussion with Senator Hill in the same way. I am not sure that we will totally succeed in that by being able to discuss simultaneously all the matters before us, but I am prepared to cooperate for as long as it looks as if we are actually achieving that purpose of expedition. Senator Tambling would not be stunned to know that I think that was a series of questions scarcely getting to the question but rather full of rhetorical flourishes. Fine, there is nothing wrong with making rhetorical flourishes in the committee; that is part of what we all do in making our points more effectively and I am happy to respond to them. I will try not to be lengthy.

PARA.TAB: There was no proposal, however, for special studies into the impact of this particular change. It is not qualitatively new; all that is changing is the amount. I am not saying that that is irrelevant. I am saying that the studies that have gone on in Australia for decades about transport economics and the implications of fuel prices on transport are as relevant to these changes as to any of the other changes that governments of both political parties have made over the last 20, 30 or however many years one would like to take. There is not anything new that would require a whole new series of studies to learn things which are qualitatively different from all that has gone before.

With regard to the remote communities and the Aboriginal communities, I do not in this matter distinguish between Aboriginal communities and others. I understand that Senator Tambling thought he might dangle a carrot in front of the Greens by saying, `Shock, horror, some of the people who will lose and who will have to pay this tax indirectly by lesser return might be Aboriginal people', but they are still Australians. The situation is that we have the same application of the law to everybody. There is nothing in any proposals we might have in which we seek to assist Aboriginal Australians by saying that, if there is a business they have got some benefit from, we are going to give it special tax treatment to make it a more successful business so that more of the profits can go to Switzerland. We are not going to do that. That is a bit of a red herring.

Senator Harradine's amendment, which has been carried, reduces the impact on some of the people otherwise affected not by this amendment immediately before us but by those to which Senator Tambling is alluding. That is the response we have given to the representations. We were going to initiate an amendment of that sort; when Senator Harradine did so, we indicated in the second reading and by our vote in the committee stage that we supported his amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would also oppose this amendment to the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill but for somewhat different reasons. We are very worried that the opposition repeatedly sees the world in terms of the 1950s and 1960s and assumes that the world of tomorrow is going to be exactly the same. As I pointed out yesterday, the indications both from the bureau of resources and from the petroleum exploration industry itself are that we have seven years supply of petroleum left in Australia and that the prospects and hopes for new oil have been very much downgraded in recent years. We have not found oil in the Timor Gap as we expected.

PARA.TAB: The costs to Australia of imports will rise from $4 billion in the current year to $9 billion by the year 2000. Simply to keep the price of fuel low in order to give some assistance to a transport industry that is based on old technology might be of benefit now but in the long term it will be disastrous for this country. For quite different reasons, we are supporting the government's increase in the excise—to make more economic and to bring on-line more quickly the alternative fuels, which are non-polluting and which will be derived from indigenous sources.

I hope—it is a forlorn hope, obviously—that the opposition will look somewhat beyond just this year and next year and will see that, if Australia is going to have a future at all in the very areas which are of concern, it must accept the fact that we have to write into the costs of the use of resources the proper costs of those resources, which include the pollution costs and the fact that the resources being used are non-renewable. We have to write in a factor which relates to the legitimate demands on those resources by future generations of Australians and others.

Under those circumstances, petroleum is grossly underpriced, and we need to shift the balance for environmental reasons and for very sound longer-term or mid-term economic reasons. It is for those reasons that we support the government. They are different reasons from the government's reasons but we believe they are more embracing than those that have been given by the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek clarification. Initially it was mentioned that we were dealing with amendments 10 to 17 and then, within that, we were going to deal with them one by one. Are we going to be voting on just one amendment or on a bunch of them?
—I cannot predict the future, Senator.
—I am trying to work out whether we have been debating just amendment 10 or the whole lot.
—Just amendment 10.
—Thank you.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I should probably make one further point at this stage. It is not exclusively relevant to this request but it relates to many of the requests moved by the Greens and the coalition in the form—this is the first one we have come to in this form—where we are defining the rate to be imposed on a particular good or category of goods by their use. In both those instances, it starts to raise potentially tricky constitutional questions. If we are proposing to base the rate of tax on actual use rather than intended use—intended use is what happens at the point of sale and actual use is what happens at the point of consumption, and they are quite different, on my advice, in terms of what form of tax it is that we are imposing; if we are in this bill mainly imposing taxes that operate in that first category but we are seeking to add to it taxes the rates of which are determined by the actual end use of particular goods, I think we have a potential problem.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the clause immediately before us, if it is carried—I am confident from what I have heard that it will not be—it probably will not have any immediate effect because there probably will not be a rate differential particularly for this use. But if we carry some of the subsequent amendments, where it seems that the Greens' position and the coalition's position overlap, I think we are starting to get into a potential constitutional problem with regard to combining excises with consumption taxes. I was not aware of this. It has just been drawn to my attention, so I do not want to put a definitive view. Given how conservatively the Senate has up until now wished to pursue any potential constitutional concerns I flag it as a point of concern, but I do not at this stage want to exaggerate it out of its proper significance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think we should refer it to a committee?

—I thought Senator Hill might say that. The most appropriate immediate option is one of the reasons why the government will be opposing all of these amendments. That is not the only reason. We are opposing them for other reasons, which we have articulated plenty of times—I am not going to waste the committee's time doing it again—which have to do with both environmental consequences, as Senator Coulter mentioned, and revenue consequences. I do not blush about that. It is a revenue measure. Potentially serious constitutional concerns have been drawn to my attention and I think we need to consider them. It would be irresponsible not to put them on the table.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators can see the distinction I am making. It is possible to interpret all of those clauses as saying that they are about intended use. Senator Hill's amendment refers to `automotive diesel oil other than for use in rail or road transport services'. I am told that in the past it has been quite possible to interpret that as saying that the intention at the point of sale was that they were for rail or road transport services and therefore it is constitutional and does not raise a problem. But it raises an enormous administrative problem then because it is hard to see who would buy any automotive diesel oil and say that the intention at the time of purchase was to use it other than for rail or road transport services. I think that the use for any other purpose would be nil; that was the intention at the time. Afterwards the person might have changed his mind and used it for some other purpose.

So it is not on its face unconstitutional, but once it is interpreted constitutionally—that is to say, as to the intention—it raises some serious questions that I felt obliged to draw to the committee's attention. I am not going to raise this every time. I am going to say it only once, but it is going to become more significant when we get to deal with some of the later amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps Senator Hill could clarify a matter for the committee. When we are dealing with fuel—that is to say, goods contained in 11(E)—are we not also dealing with an area of marine diesel fuel which was not covered by my amendment?
—That is correct. That is why we have a separate category in my amendment No. 16. Does that make it clear?
—There is 16 per cent usage by coastal shipping.
—Senator Watson is talking about 16 per cent. There are some advices I have got which indicate that it is not that high.
—They use it exclusively when they are in port.

—That is why it is not necessarily that high. I agree that it is used for auxiliary motors and so on. I am not averse to supporting these requests except that, at the end of the day, we do have to have regard for what the government is putting to us about deficit reduction strategies. I understand the arguments that have been advanced by Senator Coulter.
—The deficit will be much bigger if we continue to use more of it.

—I can understand the points that have been made by Senator Coulter, but in my view there is nothing lost by having another think about this matter. Obviously, if the government makes its decision clear, and the matters that have been raised in the last few minutes by Senator McMullan are of some interest as well, we will have another opportunity to look at it. Under those circumstances, I feel that it would be desirable for me to support the amendment for a request to the House of Representatives to reconsider this matter.

—I do not wish to prolong this committee stage, but I think a slightly different angle could be put to the chamber in relation to Senator Coulter's argument. I do not disagree with his argument on all the points. I think there is a very responsible argument to be made for self-sufficiency in the national interest, and that needs to be a reasoned and balanced case. But, wittingly or unwittingly, in the way he has put his argument—I am sure it was unwittingly—he has tended to imply that renewable resources are preferable to non-renewable resources on the basis that somehow or other people get something for nothing. As the honourable senator knows very well, the first law of thermodynamics is that energy cannot be created or destroyed; it can be changed from one form to another. All the non-renewable resources we have do require energy inputs to produce them; it is the accessibility and the economics of the matter that are really the determining point.

—I will just pick up that point. I think the honourable senator is actually referring to both the first and the second laws of thermodynamics. The point about the new technology with the derivation of alcohol from cellulose is that, having separated the cellulose from the lignin in the plant material, the lignin can then be used as a fuel for the separation of the alcohol from the mash. So one does in fact have a technology which is totally non-polluting in terms of greenhouse gases and in which the fuel is derived internally from the initial feed stock and does not use external fuel. That is the really exciting prospect that opens up before us with what the government has agreed to in this package where we could, potentially—
—I accept all that, but you have got to grow your cellulose too. There is an energy input there.
—The energy input there is from the sun, and that is where we should be getting our energy from, of course.

I will just make a comment in relation to the matter of the questionable constitutionality that Senator McMullan has just put on the record. If he has just received that advice, which I understand is the situation, it is his responsibility to put that to the committee. I do not question that, but I do say that I think it is somewhat disappointing that a government, with all the resources government has at its disposal, would come in at the last moment before this vote is taken and raise the constitutional issue.

PARA.TAB: It has been no secret that, in particular, the Western Australian Greens have indicated that they wanted to support a reduction or a maintenance of the existing level of excise on two particular categories, marine and rail. The government has known that for a long time. This is the first suggestion by the government of any constitutional doubt. It is moments before the vote is to be taken in this place, and I think that is pretty disappointing. I would have thought a government that would like to see a debate take place on the basis of the best available advice could have done a lot better than that.

If any of these requests is passed—and I hope they all are—they will no doubt be returned to us in some little time. In the meantime, we will seek further constitutional advice on the issue that has been raised at this last moment by the government. Certainly it has not been suggested to me that to subdivide further the government's own categories as they appear in item 13 of its amendments would be an issue that raised constitutional doubt. If it had, weeks ago, I would have sought to have it sent to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in order that that question might be clarified.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I share some of the points Senator Hill raised. I have just sought to ensure that, if there are any requests passed and they come back from the House of Representatives, I will have some more authoritative opinion available for the committee. Contrary to Senator Hill, I hope that situation does not arise, because I do not want to see any of the requests passed at all. Given that that is a possible eventuality, however, I have asked for arrangements to be made for that to be done.

—Following this argument on unconstitutionality in what is being done here, I would like Senator McMullan to consider also the constitutional aspects of the parent bill, because that same argument would apply in terms of the categorisation applied when it was put on the statute book.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to extend this and start giving any legal opinions, let alone ones that purport to have more authority than any opinion of mine might have. My understanding—this is the point I was making about the distinction between intended use and actual use—is that where such for-use distinctions apply at the moment they are interpreted as being on the basis of intended use and they operate within fairly limited categories where the intention is discernible by the nature of the product. For example, kerosene particularly for use in aircraft is a product discernibly different from others and so the intention is discernible on the face of the product. That is my advice, but it is part of further information I will seek for the committee if we get further discussion on this matter. Without either the desire or the possibility of restricting people's right to comment on this, I think it might be more fruitful if we do it at a subsequent stage.

—The important point to make for the committee is that, in requesting amendment, the chamber does not actually change the bill and that, a request for amendment having been passed, the bill will not necessarily pass in that form. The bill must be returned to the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan makes a point in relation to his constitutional concerns. I share Senator Hill's belief that it is a little strange that they are coming in so late. But let us assume that what Senator McMullan is saying is correct. It is not an impediment to the chamber requesting these amendments to be made. The bill will be returned to the House of Representatives and, once we have the message from the House of Representatives, we will in that period of time be able to take further advice.

The request for an amendment is not binding on the parliament and it is not in the same situation as a bill which has already passed the House of Representatives and which, if passed by the Senate, only requires assent to take effect. I think Senator McMullan was trying to draw a parallel between his concerns over whether the terms should be in relation to the use of a good or the intended use of a good and our concerns in relation to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bills Nos. 1 and 2. With the greatest respect to Senator McMullan, I point out that there is a distinction. Passage of those bills by the Senate meant that they required only assent to become acts of parliament, whereas the passage by the Senate of a resolution requesting an amendment does not necessarily change the bill and does not flow immediately into law.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, I would like to comment on Senator McMullan's comment on intended use and the question of whether it is unconstitutional. I have received some advice, which I would like to put to the committee and to the minister, casting some doubt on that view, especially as end use is a common feature of customs, such as under the policy by-law entry provisions, which actually specify the words `end use' and are a feature of the diesel fuel excise rebate scheme.
—Rebate is different, as a matter of fact; but we will come back to that later.

—Yes. However, I am saying that these terms are a feature of part of the legislation. With respect, the point I really want to make is that to do what the minister is suggesting really would be fraud and subject to audit—that fuel will be used rather than intended to be used. He is really raising a fraud question rather than a constitutional question. I would also like to put the question that the words `end use' are used in complementary legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, you will have to excuse me for entering the debate at this stage but I was tied up in a meeting. I want to go on record again about the amendment that Senator Margetts is either moving or supporting, which gives a differential levy for fuel used on rail and road. It will finish up being 2c extra on road. She has probably had a night to sleep on it and a night to receive a lot of phone calls. I have been getting them and redirecting them to her, because in the final analysis—
—I thought you would be making them.

—I could, that is a thought. Yes, I could start making them as well. But I think I can give Senator Margetts the message enough in here. I put this on record yesterday, and I remind her today, that it is totally unfair to put an extra tax on road that is not on rail. As I said yesterday, sea transport is different. But it is going to start increasing those costs on roads and it provides further unfair competition between road and rail. As I said yesterday, it will not transfer those goods back on to rail simply by doing that, with the safety angle and so on.

PARA.TAB: I know that a lot of people reckon there should be fewer heavy vehicles on roads, that that would make it safer for the motorists. But it has to be worked out whether the roads were made for transporting goods in the first place, or whether it was simply for cars, for people getting to work or for pleasure. People have got to work that out in their own minds. One cannot differentiate between road and rail to give transporters an unfair advantage over each other. I am sure Senator Margetts has slept on it. She has received those phone calls and I think she will vote accordingly, or change her amendment accordingly.

This Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 is going to raise an extra $1.6 billion or $1.7 billion, something like that. After all, this levy was originally imposed in the Malcolm Fraser days, to be spent on roads. But, of course, the government has used every bowser as a tax collector. They are not my words; they are the words of the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he was Treasurer. But with this extra money that has been raised, the money allocated to roads in the last budget has gone down by about $550 million as against what it was last year. I know spending on roads was boosted a certain amount, as Senator West should know, in the One Nation package. But now it has dropped in real terms. I would say we have dropped road spending in Australia by 20 or 30 per cent. So if the government wanted to increase the diesel fuel levy—a levy on all fuel—by a certain amount, the 2c we are talking about now plus what we have already done with 3c now and 2c next year in two stages, then I thought they would have allocated more for roads. With the demand on the road system around Australia, the standard is going down. Senator Woodley should know what the standards are, coming from Queensland. The roads of New South Wales are fortunately picking up, because there is a Liberal government there, aided by the Nats, of course.

TALK.START.PARA: —The worst government New South Wales has ever had.

—The roads are improving, Senator West, because I have had quite a good look around in the last few years. They were left in a disgraceful state by a former government. But one would think that the government would allocate more money for roads out of this. No, they increased the fuel levy and, by the same token, they have brought the roads down. I believe that the government should look at increased spending. It is the only one that can control this, especially with this increased take. With the sales tax legislation that raises $1 billion extra, that affects road transport as well because sales tax is paid on tyres; sales tax is paid these days on oil, on parts and everything with transport. Yet none of that extra is going back to roads, and I believe it should.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I mention a point I heard Senator Coulter make while I was at my meeting. I think I heard him say that Australia has only seven years reserves of crude oil. That might be known, publicly declared reserves; no companies in their right mind, but especially the ones that want to keep the price of oil up, would tell the whole world exactly how much oil reserves they have. I know from the few people I talk to that in the Timor Sea they discover a lot of oil, wells are put down, and then they are simply plugged for another day, when they need it or are looking for higher prices or something like that. So there may be seven years of declared, known reserves, but there are also the unknown reserves, as well as a lot of exploration in the next seven years.

I take the committee back quickly to about 1972, when one of the bright fellows from our local government went to a seminar at the University of Western Australia. At the next council meeting he got on the blackboard or the whiteboard and told us what the oil reserves of the world were and what we would be doing. He said that he was told by this professor—I cannot remember his name—that by 1992 the only oil in the world would be used in medicine. Remember that this was in 1973. We all know that since 1973 there have been big discoveries on the North-West Shelf, more in Bass Strait, and so on.

We are in the same position in 1993, with Senator Coulter telling us that we will run out of oil in seven years. At least this fellow told us at the time that we were going to run out 2291 in 20 years. Senator Coulter's argument

SPEECH.PARA: is totally ridiculous. In a hundred years time, there will be ample crude oil around.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, we will not be supporting this, and I feel that I should explain why. It is really for two reasons. Firstly, I refer to the opposition's motivation in moving this. PARA.TAB: Secondly, and more fundamentally, while it does have a considerable appeal in the sense that, as Senator Margetts has pointed out, rail uses much less energy per tonne kilometre than road does and, therefore, rail should be encouraged, I believe it is not appropriate to provide that encouragement through a differential in the amount of excise paid on the fuel used. There are other ways in which the assistance should be provided to rail. It should be extended through systems which recognise that differential in the energy efficiency. That is more likely to be realised through increasing the cost of energy overall, which, as I have argued consistently throughout this debate, should occur.

The cost of energy from fossil fuels should rise because the true costs, the full costs, the costs in relation to the fact that these are non-renewable resources, the costs in relation to the pollution effects and the costs in relation to greenhouse gases have not been properly factored in. SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Hill said, this is basically the same request for amendment that was foreshadowed yesterday in relation to diesel fuel used for the generation of electricity by people in remote areas who do not have access to electricity coming from either an electricity power station or substation.

PARA.TAB: This request for an amendment is basically to catch those people who live with no reasonable access to electricity from a power station or substation. The number of people so affected is quite small. Those people are predominantly in northern Western Australia and northern Queensland, and we understand that there is a very small number in South Australia, the Northern Territory and the western districts of New South Wales. The greatest number are concentrated in the area of Queensland north of the Daintree River and west of the Northern Territory border. These are predominantly people who cannot get access to electricity because environmental constraints at the moment prevent the introduction of electricity through certain World Heritage areas. These people do not live in World Heritage areas but are affected by them and would be severely disadvantaged.

I understand that the number of users is very small. I was asked yesterday by Senator Woodley outside the chamber what my estimate of the cost of this is. I repeat for Senator Woodley's benefit and for the benefit of all honourable senators that my understanding is that the cost would probably be less than $2 million, but in any event not more than $5 million. We are talking about roughly 5c a litre, so I think $2 million is probably quite generous.

The issue is basically one of geographical equity. Do we discriminate against people who are already suffering a higher cost burden for the basic amenities of life by virtue of their geographical isolation? I think most honourable senators would accept that we should not discriminate where people have no other reasonable access to power. In many cases, alternative power sources are of no substantive value, for either geographical or climatic reasons. I understand that there are some areas where solar power is feasible, but it is certainly not feasible in some areas of Queensland, because of the wet season, and there are similar constraints on the use of wind power.

This amendment would address the very real and pressing need those people have. It was indicated to me yesterday that we have the agreement of the Democrats in relation to the amendment. I hope we will receive in the chamber today the support of other honourable senators, notably the Greens and Senator Harradine. I am not sure of the position of the government, but I assume that, consistent with its position in relation to other amendments, it is not disposed to support this amendment.

I hope honourable senators will recognise the importance of this matter because of the grave disadvantage these people suffer and the need for some of the burden to be alleviated, especially as the cost to the Commonwealth is very small and the cost to these people is very great.

Power generation is dear enough when one has to generate one's own power, without having an increase in the price of fuel. But when we come to the treatment plant, which is part of the mine but is a separate entity, whether it is on the mine site or in a central site for other pits, there is no rebate. The power for those pits has to be generated by diesel, and there are umpteen of these pits, including at Karratha in Western Australia, the chief mining state. All the power in Karratha is generated by diesel, unless I am mighty wrong. If I am wrong, please tell me, but that was so last time I was up there. PARA.TAB: If I heard her correctly, Senator Margetts interjected about alternative energy sources that might be very useful and worthwhile in those areas. My concern with the request is twofold. One is merely to reiterate the potential constitutional problem I referred to before. Secondly, after the end user purchases this diesel and says, `I am going to use this to generate electricity', how do we ensure that that is what happens, unless we have an army of inspectors running around checking?

TALK.START.PARA: —Rebate, the same as for the farm.

—But that is not what this says. It is a matter of what sort of encouragement we should give to people in these circumstances, people whom most, if not all, of us would like to assist in some way, although not necessarily through their electricity costs. PARA.TAB: If, on balance, we did say that these people warrant our assistance and the rest of Australia's taxpayers should in some way provide them with more assistance, it would be safer, better policy and administratively more manageable if we were to do it by way of a rebate of the sort that applies in other related circumstances. PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan raises two points in relation to the request for amendment. The first is the constitutional point, which I do not want to labour too much. I repeat my comments before, that this is merely a request for amendment and does not immediately alter the bill. Upon the Senate's agreeing to this request for amendment, if it is so minded, the passage of the bill does not occur automatically. In fact, the bill has to go back to the House of Representatives; so it would not automatically become law. There is ample opportunity to further examine that constitutional question and maybe find ways to rectify it.

In relation to Senator McMullan's second point, he has concerns about how this is administered. This scheme really is governed by the same administrative principles as applied to other schemes which have been agreed to in this chamber this morning in a successful request for amendment by Senator Hill in relation to similar exemptions. If we are talking about other people, I am really at a loss to work out who we are referring to. If one is referring to people using vehicles, I think the category is very small.
