I am sure that none of them would ever do that. However, if some concession were extended to those people, the cost to the revenue would seem to be very small.

PARA.TAB: It is also my understanding—I may be wrong—that there is no excise on fuel for generating if you are using coal or hydro power. There are some communities—the minister should be aware of this—which are too remote to get their electricity from the mains electricity supply. In those instances, and this is where I have come across them, shire councils run the electricity scheme. It seems a bit unfair that people in those smaller communities have to pay an excise, or a tax, on the fuel that is used to generate their electricity, whereas people who are living in the capital cities, and other parts of Australia, do not have that same tax on whatever fuel they use to generate their power.

If I am wrong, perhaps the minister could explain why I am wrong. But, if I am not wrong, perhaps the minister could explain what is fair about capital city dwellers getting their power supplied with a fuel that does not attract tax, or not always, and people who live in remote communities—who have all the burdens of life, in any case—having to pay this additional tax on fuel that they use for the generation of power?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very sympathetic to this amendment, but the Australian Democrats have some real problems with it. It is causing a fair amount of confusion for us. I would like to make an appeal to the Opposition, in this instance, to not go this way but to go another way. I believe it would be much easier for the Democrats to support this proposition if the amendment were to be to the diesel fuel rebate scheme so that the compensation could be made at that point. My problem is that, in the party room, we discussed the amendment that we had before us yesterday, and this morning, which spoke about fuel oil and not about industrial diesel fuel. Fuel oil is a different kettle of fish altogether. We had real problems because we could see fuel oil applying to a whole lot of uses and not applying to the generation of electricity through small generators, which do not use fuel oil. Honourable senators can see that we were a bit caught out by the change.

PARA.TAB: It seems to us, even if we are excluding pastoralists—they use the diesel rebate scheme to compensate their uses of diesel fuel—that small remote communities, and Aboriginal communities, would also use industrial diesel fuel to run their four-wheel drives and tractors, et cetera. I am assuming this, so I am happy to be corrected on that at this point. Aboriginal communities have all of this equipment, as well as generators. Therefore, we have still got the same problem. The amendment certainly says, `for consumption by commercial and private consumers'. It seems to me that the amendment is still so general that it is difficult for us to support it in this form. However, I think we would be prepared to look at an amendment to the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to allay some of Senator Woodley's concerns, which I think were twofold. The first was in relation to the possibility of misuse by, for example, Aboriginal communities or people who had four-wheel drives or tractors. The use of a tractor would be principally for primary industry anyway and would therefore be caught by the existing diesel fuel excise rebate scheme. In relation to four-wheel drives, in any scheme there is always the possibility of a little bit of slippage, but it is fairly easy to work out exactly how much fuel people are using for what purpose. We are talking about isolated communities and their fuel consumption is fairly normal.

PARA.TAB: I do apologise for the change that occurred overnight. It was brought to my attention only this morning when I came into the chamber. The diligent staff that we have had been looking at it overnight to check that everything was right. Honourable senators would recall that last night the whole debate became very complex. Those on our side sought to make sure that everything was thoroughly in order and had made a number of changes to various amendments; this was one. The whole purpose was to clarify the issue and to alleviate the possibility of misuse of this scheme.

Senator Woodley has concern about the word `commercial'. I will explain why the word `commercial' has been inserted. If, for example, one has a small outback store, one needs to run a generator to provide electricity for the store as well as for the residents, particularly in very hot areas. The electricity is needed to run the refrigeration systems and so on. That is why that is included. There are a number of very small motels that would also have their own generators—again for very good reasons. Because they have no other access, they need to be able to provide electricity to service the guests in the motel and also to meet the other needs of the motel. Again the number is very small and the use by motels and the like would be less than the use by private consumers, because of the way in which this has been worded.

I accept that there may be some benefit from having a rebate scheme, but we are talking about 5c a litre being reduced here. We are not talking about the whole of the excise on fuel. This is only the 5c a litre increase, which we feel is at this point in time an unreasonable burden on those communities. That is why we proceeded to do it in this way. The administrative cost to the Commonwealth of running a rebate scheme would probably be higher than the cost of going in this fashion. Certainly substantiation and so on by private consumers who are claiming only small amounts would be a little difficult to manage.

We do not rule anything out but what we say to the chamber is that this seems to be, at this point in time, the best way to alleviate an urgent need. That is why we reiterate our request to the Senate for its support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are considerable difficulties with this amendment. As circulated last night, the amendment talked about fuel oil for use in the generation of electricity. That has been corrected. The very fact that the words `fuel oil' appeared in there seems to indicate that the opposition has not got clearly in mind whom it is trying to identify in this group. My understanding is that absolutely no-one in the group the opposition has identified this morning would use fuel oil at all. Some would certainly use industrial diesel fuel, but the fuel oil would probably not even be used in any of the remote larger communities. It would only be used in quite large power stations. One was suspicious that the opposition was trying to address the problems which have been raised in relation to Nabalco and its fuel oil.

PARA.TAB: The opposition has corrected that to read `industrial diesel fuel for use in the generation of electricity' and then it goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . where there is no reasonable access to electricity transmitted from a power station or substation for consumption by commercial or private consumers.

I have read that amendment without any intonation or stops because it seems to me that is the way it should be read. In other words, the phrase `commercial or private consumers' is qualifying the generation of electricity transmitted from a power station or substation and not the use to which the electricity is actually put. One has to ask the question: at what point does electricity generation become a power station? If two or three houses in a community decide to share the generation of electricity and that is then transmitted from what is in my view a power station to those various homes, it falls outside this definition anyway. Is the opposition simply trying to capture only those farmers who individually generate electricity through the use of diesel fuel? If that is the case, it seems to me that the opposition needs to define the particular group in a rather different way.

PARA.TAB: The second difficulty I have with this, and I think Senator Margetts has already alluded to it, is that it is precisely in these remote regions, because of the high cost of diesel, that the alternatives are coming on line. I refer to the alternatives that use renewable energy, particularly wind and solar photovoltaics. I remind honourable senators that Australia leads the world in terms of the efficiency of its photovoltaic cells. Because of the high cost of diesel, hybrid schemes are coming in which use part diesel, part photovoltaic systems and so on. That is leading Australia into the wider use of these alternatives.

I also have difficulty with this amendment because it is taking us blindly down a road where we continue to use a fuel which inevitably is running out and which is polluting. If the price is kept artificially low because these other costs are not written into the costs of the diesel fuel, we are simply holding back the inevitable switch which must be made to renewable sources. So I have difficulty with both those things.

I think the amendment is still very poorly drawn and does not clearly identify the people to whom the opposition appears to be trying to direct it. Secondly, I think, it moves us in a direction in which we should not be going. We should be going in the other direction, towards the use of renewable sources, particularly in remote regions. If, as Senator Panizza indicated earlier, the opposition is indeed looking towards larger communities, I again remind honourable senators that in Tennant Creek there is currently being built a two-megawatt station, which is a solar thermal station, which avoids the use of industrial diesel altogether. That is the way we should be going in those remote regions. We have a very sunny country and we should be attempting as far as possible to use these alternative sources, not simply going backwards to a continuation of old technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say in answer to Senator Coulter that I know his concerns are very real. The problem is that diesel fuel used for this purpose is very expensive. It is one of the higher cost solutions. Nobody wants to be on diesel fuel. It is not as though it is a choice that people make because it is a low-cost choice. If there is any feasible way in which they can get off it, they will.

PARA.TAB: I take as an example the area north of the Daintree. That is an area where the state government has spent $5 million doing a survey into alternative power uses; all of them have been looked at and none of them have been successful. This does not mean that we should give up the search. I would love to find other ways of doing it. Having diesel fuel around and transporting it and so on is an enormous difficulty for those concerned. I would love to see a new-tech or low-tech solution to the problem, but none has emerged to date. This amendment does not rule out those things; it merely says, `These people are on diesel because there is no alternative for them. Therefore, we do not think it is reasonable to penalise them by adding the increase in excise'.

Senator Coulter also had a query in relation to the grouping of houses together. These people generally live in very remote areas and to link the houses together means that they have to have reticulation; and reticulation is more expensive than purchasing one's own generator.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not really have much to add to the debate, but I have some responses to specific matters raised by honourable senators. I want to make three points. First, as I picked it up and checked it, I think the factual situation outlined by Senator Ian Macdonald is correct. I do not necessarily agree with the conclusion he drew but, to the extent I have been able quickly to check it, the factual situation as he outlined it is correct.
—On what?
—On the one that the honourable senator asked publicly in the question to me in the course of his contribution about metropolitan generation—
—Metropolitan people get it free and other people have to pay tax.

—As I understand the honourable senator's articulation, I think he is correct. As I say, that does not necessarily lead to the conclusion, because tax is not always the solution to every problem, but I understand that the point he made is a factually accurate description of the situation. I think Senator Woodley, though, is also correct in that, if we were to wish to proceed to resolve this problem, a rebate approach rather than this is a much better approach. I think he accurately describes that, and we cannot do that in this bill. That is a bridge to cross on another occasion.
—A bridge too far.

—It may also be that. The third point I want to make is simply an indication—not in any way designed to be a criticism—of the difficulty of trying to amend on the run in this way. There is a view that specifying industrial diesel fuel might not achieve the purpose. Many people in these circumstances might use automotive diesel fuel or automotive diesel oil. I do not want to be too adamant about that, because the amount I know about the practical application of various diesel fuels to generation is very small, but the advice is that there is quite a substantial possibility that in some circumstances people otherwise covered by the amendment might miss out because of the use of the word `industrial' when they might actually be using something else.

PARA.TAB: I think we should not just do this. What I will give an undertaking to do—I am not going to give an undertaking about the outcome—is refer the special circumstances of the people Senator O'Chee has mentioned to the minister for consideration to try to find an effective constraining approach that does not allow spillover to other uses and is fair and comprehensive. I acknowledge Senator Coulter's point that it may be that the minister will say, `For the reason Senator Coulter and Senator Margetts, by interjection, raised as a policy question, we do not wish to go in that direction'. What I am saying is that I can see some merit, but I think the process is wrong. I do not want to just be clever and have a process win. I will refer it, but I am not giving a guarantee about outcome because there are policy questions, including those raised by Senator Coulter and others, that the minister may wish to consider. But I will draw it to his attention.
Request negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Schedule, page 9, at end of amendment 13, add the following paragraph:

This is for marine diesel fuel, with the same intention of avoiding the government's intended increase in excise, which would have the effect of making marine carriage even less competitive. That is not in the national interest. Long-distance carriage is vitally important to the economic welfare of this country. No good argument has been put for increasing the on-cost to business in these ways. Therefore, I move this amendment, which I acknowledge—as I did in relation to rail—is in the terms of an amendment that has been circulated by the Greens. I trust that it will receive the support of the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a procedural suggestion. I do not think we actually need to debate this. I think everyone knows everyone's position. The government does not support it but I accept there is a majority for it. I suggest to Senator Hill that he move amendments 16 and 17 for debate together. They cover substantially the same issues; they are, I think, supported and opposed by the same people; and it will just speed things up a bit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Schedule, page 9, at end of amendment 13, add the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: fuel oil for marine$0.05512 per litre".

SPEECH.PARA: I am happy that 16 and 17 be voted on together. In amendment 17, I am told, our figure did not include the indexation increase which has just occurred and which increased it to $.05512 rather than $.05441, as appeared in the document as circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support my colleague Senator Hill in this amendment to remove the increase in fuel excise on the marine situation. As I have explained, coastal shipping competes on the long haul and, of course, competes with rail across the continent. We have already removed that from rail, so to remain consistent—since they are in competition with each other—it should be removed from seafaring also. I still maintain that it should have been removed from road, but I suppose we must accept any relief we can get for taxpayers and other people around Australia that are affected. This bears a lot on Tasmania, in that grain taken there is transported by ship and a lot of the heavy produce goes to and comes from Tasmania by sea.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter asked my colleague Senator Hill what industrial fuel would have to do with rail. Senator Hill replied, I think, that he is a solicitor and not an industrialist. Perhaps I can fill in for the industrial side of the equation. There is a difference between industrial fuel and automotive fuel, and to my knowledge railway engines use all industrial fuel rather than automotive fuel. Whether it is industrial fuel or automotive fuel, it goes on what is called the cetane number. Automotive fuel used in road vehicles and diesel cars has a high cetane number and the other one, for industrial use, is determined as a low cetane number.

Diesel engines that are used on road and lighter ones use a higher cetane number because with the smaller cylinders they rely on compression ignition to ignite it. Petrol has octane numbers and it does not immediately ignite, in other words, it ignites when the spark goes through to the cylinder. Diesel relies on the compression. So the industrial diesel fuel is used in the massive engines in the railways and in the ships and in the big power generators. They are all big engines with cylinders that I can stand in compared with the small ones in an automotive situation. That is the difference between industrial and automotive. I think that when we have an excise we should not really differ from one to another because they can virtually be used in the same industry.
Requests agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Schedule, page 9, at end of amendment 13, add the following paragraph:

I thank the Senate for the previous decision. Request for amendment No. 18 deals with `other', which is the word which appears in item 13 of the government's amendment. I think it would particularly include the Nabarlek fuel issue that my colleague Senator Tambling raised. It is consistent with our overall approach that excise increases are really the last thing that the country can afford at the moment. What we should be looking at is building more competitive industry, not less competitive. The further that government forces up on-costs on business the less competitive Australian industry will be. It is just so illogical to any sensible program of trying to build the economic strength of this nation and provide jobs. I hope that the Senate will support our attempt to keep taxes low.

PARA.TAB: I know I will not get support from the Australian Democrats because it is a high tax party. It would like to see taxes very substantially increased in this country. As Senator Coulter reminded us today, Democrat members voted against the tax cuts. The government, of course, lied to the Australian people about tax cuts but after the election the Australian Democrats said, `That's okay; we will support you in your lie. We will allow you to come into the parliament and get away with it', which I found astonishing. But the Democrats are consistent; they want taxes to go up so they will vote for increases in excise no matter what the job consequences are.

That is a tragedy, I think. The government, of course, is increasing revenue in an effort to try to get around the embarrassing situation it got itself into through the One Nation statement and the tax cuts that were not to be funded and the lies to the Australian people at the last election about tax cuts. That is what these increases are all about. But the consequence to Australian industry is that it makes industry less competitive and that is going to make it harder to eat into that tragic unemployment figure of nearly a million Australians out of work. So we strongly oppose this increase in excise and hope we will get some support in the Senate today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I cannot let Senator Hill get away with that. He knows, everybody in this chamber knows, that compared with the other 23 OECD countries Australia is now the lowest taxed country, and I mean all taxes: Commonwealth, state and local. This morning, all over the news we had the absolutely shocking, appalling conditions in which people with mental ill health have been treated in this country because the government has simply cut the services. What the opposition is wanting to do is to give further tax cuts to the middle income groups to reduce services further, and so on.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, we unashamedly say that taxes should be raised in this country because there are crying needs which are not being met in this country. There are crying needs which are not being met and they can only be met through government services; so we make no apology. We are not simply wanting to increase taxes just for the sake of increasing taxes. We want to increase taxes because we see that there are needs in this country that are not being met, and there are needs which the opposition would simply leave even more so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is going to pay for it?

—The community as a whole should be meeting these needs through a taxation system, Senator Hill. Other countries pay much higher rates of tax than we do in Australia, and they provide better services to their communities. We should be absolutely ashamed that we cannot provide decent services for those with mental ill health, with a whole range of other disabilities. The opposition tries to argue that because we want to raise taxes, there is something wrong with Democrat policy. We want to raise taxes for very specific reasons—because there is a desperate need for more money to be spent in very specific areas in this country. Those areas of need are crying out to be met.

PARA.TAB: In relation to this particular one, I think Senator Hill meant Nabalco and not Nabarlek. I see that he agrees. There seems to be a lack of real understanding of what it is we are debating this morning. I understand that the government has made some concession in relation to this, and I would like the minister to outline those concessions which have already been made.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that, on the basis of the figures Nabalco has been using to establish the cost to them of the original proposal, the committee's decision on the request by Senator Harradine—and the government's indication that it will accept the committee's decision—will save Nabalco around $10 million a year.

—This is a small matter, Madam Temporary Chairman, but this figure also should be 0.5512c per litre. It might be academic; nevertheless, we ask that it be voted on in those terms. While I am on my feet, I might say to Senator Coulter that higher taxes do not necessarily lead to better services, either. The one thing on which I do agree with Senator Coulter is that services, particularly in the mental health area he mentioned, are unsatisfactory in this country. If, for example, this government had decided to put the $200 million it is putting into a new foreign affairs department building towards mental health services, then I think the nation would have been better off. The alternative would have been—
—There is a difference between capital expenditure and recurrent expenditure.

—I think it is symbolic of the minister's priorities. That is what it demonstrates. It demonstrates that the minister sees a higher priority in spending $200 million to build a new building for the foreign affairs department when the old building needed some repairs. It is a distorted priority where that happens on the one hand and mental health services are unsatisfactory on the other. I hope the committee will support this amendment.

—I respond briefly to Senator Coulter. He is right in relation to tax rates, but I ask him also to consider framing his response in terms of taxes paid which determine people's living standards—the amount of money in people's pockets. I think you will find we rate in a different category to the one he has just spoken about in terms of tax rates as against taxes paid by Australian people.

PARA.TAB: Request negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: The cost of this amendment is estimated to be in the vicinity of $1 million. It affects the 26c a litre excise component. The purpose is to exclude the diesel component from the increase in terms of coastal shipping. I believe that the amendment complements the Harradine amendment as far as the coastal shipping side is concerned. The committee agreed to that yesterday when it removed 11(E)(2) and 11(E)(3) from table 2, which related to fuel oil. We are concentrating here on the diesel component. The amendment is designed to remove marine diesel from the table but to retain automotive diesel and industrial diesel in the table.

PARA.TAB: I think it is a significant amendment because Senator Collins, to his credit, has spent a lot of time in reforming coastal shipping. What did worry us was that, within five days of signing an agreement to bring down the manning levels of Australian coastal ships, the government turned around and put these imposts on coastal shipping. So what we are doing is removing part of that increase in terms of coastal shipping. There is absolutely no incentive there for people to go out and try to bring that level down to less than 18 per ship if the government is going to take all those cost benefits back into its own revenue.

I think it is very significant in terms of the message it sends to the shipping people and to the unions about their preparedness to negotiate to bring down the costs of coastal shipping when the government turns around and puts on an excise of this manner which effectively removes all those savings. So this amendment is introduced for consistency with what was done with the Harradine amendment and it is done to acknowledge the special circumstances in relation to the negotiations and what has been signed and achieved.

As I said, within five days of Senator Collins signing that arrangement, the government turned around and put this on. It is not a lot of money, but the message it sends is very significant in terms of future negotiations on industrial matters that the government is going to have, not only with the unions but also with the shipowners. At least there will be a recognition by the Senate of some of the work Senator Collins has done. I think it is a small price in terms of lost revenue, but the message it sends is important. The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Order! It being after 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter of particular importance to Western Australia, a matter which affects all of those people who are dependent on wages or salaries for their livelihood. That is a very big group of people. Over 70 per cent of the population depend on wages and salaries exclusively for their livelihood. I refer to the Workplace Agreements Bill, which has been introduced by the Court government in Western Australia and is currently before the Legislative Council of that parliament. A number of amendments have been moved by the opposition but have not been dealt with as yet, and it has implications for the federal government.

PARA.TAB: It runs counter to basic standards which are supported by the federal government and which are reflected in the industrial relations bill which will shortly be considered in this parliament. Those standards essentially support the right of employees to protection from possible exploitation by employers. They support an industrial relations system which recognises that there is an unequal bargaining power between employees and employers, particularly for some employees—particular groups of employees such as women, Aboriginals, ethnic people and employees in remote communities. I say that for Senator Panizza.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are employees whom Senator Panizza might know about and who are exploited perhaps more than average. It is particularly for those employees that recognition is made that there is unequal bargaining power between employees—

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I think that Senator Beahan made an inference about me on the matter of knowing about employees that are exploited. He should withdraw it. He might not have meant what he said, but in the way it came out I thought it was a reflection on me.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I made no such inference. I talked about exploitation and I said that Senator Panizza would know about it, because Senator Panizza is a country person. I was talking about country people. I made no reflection whatever on Senator Panizza.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—I rule that there is no point of order. I did not take that inference either.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to an industrial relations system which recognises that the bargaining power between employees and employers is unequal and the support of a system which establishes and maintains basic standards and protections for employees. That is the position of the federal government, which runs counter to the WA Workplace Agreements Bill.

PARA.TAB: The Western Australian bill ostensibly sets up an alternative to the current state award system by providing for individual or collective workplace agreements. The pre-election statements which were made in relation to the bill suggested that employees would be free to remain in the award system if they wished. The reality, as exposed by a number of eminent industrial lawyers, is that employers are free to force employees out of awards and into inferior contracts with diminished conditions and with no redress.

The disadvantage to employees is further compounded by the absence of any independent body to set minimum conditions of employment. Under other legislation, minimum conditions will be determined by the minister: a minister who has shown that he has little sympathy with workers by the statements he has made frequently; a minister who has plucked the figure of $275, for example, out of the air as a minimum weekly wage with no flexibility about it. That minimum weekly wage would apply to anybody in a rural area; it would apply to somebody living in Karratha just as it would to somebody living in Perth. It is a ridiculous concept with no flexibility and no understanding of what it actually costs to live these days.

Professional opinion and an informed reading of the legislation shows clearly that the apparent protections contained in the proposed bill are illusory; they will not provide the protection they appear to. Let me give some practical examples. Where, for example, a prospective employee's work is covered already by an award—that is, the area in which that person works is covered by an award under state law—the employer can offer the job on the basis that wages and conditions will be those set out in a workplace agreement. It is the concept of take it or leave it—the contract or the job. The second example is where an employee is already on a contract—they are starting to become known in Western Australia as Kierath contracts or Court contracts—and that is up for renewal, an employer can ask the employee to accept inferior conditions in the new contract and can threaten dismissal for refusal to sign.

The apparent protections—the protection against intimidation under section 66 of the act and the prohibition of dismissal for refusing to sign it under section 68 of the act—are overridden by section 71 which provides exceptions to sections 66 and 68. It provides employer immunity from those clauses via sections 73 and 75. In other words, the threat of dismissal or notice of dismissal following an employee's refusal to sign a contract on terms laid down by the employer does not give rise to any right on behalf of the employee to pursue a case for unfair dismissal. The employee is forced to sign or resign or be sacked.

Legal opinion also states that the bill would allow the employer to sack award employees and refuse to re-hire them unless they are prepared to sign a Kierath contract on inferior terms. It is not just an oversight that employers have these powers. It is not just an oversight that the bill is dressed up to look fair even though, as I have already pointed out, the fair parts of it are undermined by other parts that are manifestly unfair. It is a thin veil deliberately placed over the vicious intent of the bill. Neither of these things are oversights because the bill was prepared in consultation with leading anti-employee solicitors—union-busters—and the WA Chamber of Commerce. It is an employer instrument designed to reverse the long history of protections enjoyed under Australia's unique and fair award system.

It is not just me saying this. There are far more eminent and more knowledgeable people than me and, in a sense, less biased people than me. I quote from a joint opinion by Rene Le Miere and Ian Viner. Ian Viner was a minister in the former Liberal government. He was minister for industrial relations at one time. I quote from the summary of that opinion:

SPEECH.PARA: We answer the questions asked of us as follows:

1. The legislation does not protect prospective employees who wish to be employed pursuant to an award rather than a workplace agreement in circumstances where the prospective employer requires that they enter into a workplace agreement as a precondition to employment.

2. The legislation does not protect employees who have entered into workplace agreements in circumstances where their employer threatens to dismiss them from their employment by notice, in accordance with their contract of employment, for the purpose of compelling them to accept less favourable terms and conditions of employment in a new workplace agreement.

3.The legislation does not protect employees in circumstances where their employer threatens to dismiss them from their employment by notice, in accordance with their contract of employment, for the purpose of compelling them to accept the terms and conditions of employment in a workplace agreement proposed by the employer, except in the situation where an employer has not previously entered into a workplace agreement. Whether the employee is actually protected will depend upon the particular circumstances.

4.The legislation does not protect employees if their employer dismisses all its workforce by notice, advertises their jobs and then employs only those persons, including the former employees, who are willing to enter into a workplace agreement on the terms and conditions specified by the employer.

PARA.TAB: That is, as I said, from an opinion by Ian Viner QC, and Rene Le Miere—Ian Viner being the minister for industrial relations in a former Liberal government. The bill is disgraceful in my opinion and a denial of basic industrial rights. I believe also, and this has not been tested yet, that it is a contravention of International Labour Organisation conventions which have been ratified by this country and by the state of Western Australia itself. In contrast, the proposed Commonwealth legislation will protect employees who do not have access to independent tribunals or who have no redress against unfair dismissals.

The state minister has proceeded with legislation in the full knowledge that it will be overruled by the Commonwealth. This is a good thing for workers, of course, because they will get the protection, denied to them in the state act, under Commonwealth law. But it makes the exercise in Western Australia a cynical exercise. There is no rational basis for the legislation. The whole thing is ideologically driven by the Court government in consultation with union busting lawyers and WA Chamber of Commerce zealots. It does no credit to any of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a way I am glad that my colleague Senator Beahan raised the issue of compulsion in relation to unions, because it is an issue that relates to the topic I wanted to speak to in the matters of public interest debate today. That is, the issue of voluntary membership of unions on tertiary campuses in Australia, and particularly in Western Australia. I wanted to raise this today. I have raised it on some other occasions, and look forward to raising it when we address ourselves to the states grants legislation. This federal government intends to penalise the state of Western Australia to the tune of something like $5 million when the legislation to ensure that students in Western Australia have the freedom to choose whether or not to join a union on campus is passed through the Western Australian parliament, hopefully in the very near future.

PARA.TAB: The reason I rise today is that a few weeks ago I had the opportunity to debate Ken Fowley from the National Union of Students on the afternoon program hosted by the former member for Stirling, Ron Edwards, who is making a very good show of becoming a radio host. He is doing a very good job, if a little biased on the subject of things such as voluntary student unionism. He was not a fair and impartial adjudicator in the debate I had that afternoon, Senator Panizza.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was fairly biased when he was a university lecturer, too.

—Yes. But he is being a good talkback host. One of the issues that Ron Edwards raised was the fact that student unions are an integral, intrinsic and important part of university life. There is absolutely no doubt about that. Certainly, we expect that, under a regime where students do have the freedom to choose to join or not to join a union, student unions will become an even more important part of student life.
—It will encourage bludgers, like it always does.

—I hope Hansard got that interjection. During that debate—a transcript of which I have, thanks to my staff—Ron Edwards suggested that we will be destroying this part of student life. He referred to the great universities of the United Kingdom, particularly Oxford and Cambridge which I think Ron had had some association with. Indeed, I have had some association with those universities. I went to Oxford and to Cambridge, and it was raining on both days I was there.
—Did you get a T-shirt?
—No, I did not. I could not afford one on a backbencher's salary.

PARA.TAB: I would like to get back to the subject of my speech instead of being distracted by people who are being a bit flippant about what is quite a serious topic. Ron Edwards referred to this matter and the importance of it. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: But Ian, the great universities of Oxford and Cambridge, their student unions or guilds were really . . . they were the basis of those universities in some respects, and why try and do away with that? I mean, the university vice-chancellors also hold that view . . .

I argued with Ron on the radio. Since that interview I have found out from my friends in the Adam Smith Institute in London and from contacts in the United Kingdom government that the secretary for education in Great Britain is introducing student reforms in England which will ensure for the first time in hundreds of years in Great Britain that our friends in Great Britain will have the same freedoms as Norman Moore, the Minister for Education, is hoping to allow the students of Western Australia to enjoy. So the student bodies at those great universities of Oxford and Cambridge will, in a short time, enjoy the same freedoms as the students at campuses in Western Australia will enjoy.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to read a summary of the government's proposals for the reform of student unions in Great Britain. There is a similarity to the objectives of and motivations for introducing voluntary student unionism in Western Australia. Let me quote briefly from a July 1993 summary paper from the Department of Education in London. One of the motivations which is specifically put forward is `to avoid public funds being used for affiliations to external organisations such as the NUS'. Great Britain is blighted with its own NUS, I understand.

This is a matter which I will refer to in the debate on states grants. One of the problems we will face if we have public funding of student unions, which Mr Dawkins and Mr Beazley have now put into legislation, is that we will see taxpayers' money going to fund bodies like the NUS but the taxpayers will have no choice as to how those funds are spent. That is something we need to avoid. This is why, when the states grants legislation comes before the Senate, we will be trying to convince the Australian Democrats that we should avoid the situation occurring where taxpayers' money will be given to organisations like the National Union of Students without the taxpayers having any control over how that money is spent.
I will refer to one other point made in this British government document. Point 3 of the objective of the act states:

SPEECH.PARA: The reform package means that all students will for the first time be able to choose whether they wish to be aligned with their campus union's activities outside the core.

That is a crucial thing. Students across the globe should have the freedom to decide whether or not to join a student union. That is an objective that the Western Australian government shares and an objective which is very much at the core of the federal opposition's philosophical basis and part of its policy for the 1993 election and, I am sure, for the 1996 election or any election before that.

PARA.TAB: I turn to another initiative of John Major's United Kingdom government which also seeks to enhance students' rights and which is very similar in intent to the reforms being proposed by the Hon. Norman Moore, the Minister for Education in Western Australia. That is the document published by the Adam Smith Institute in London called the Students' Charter. It is a part of the citizens' charter initiatives of the United Kingdom government which seeks to guarantee to the consumers of government services some minimum rights and minimum expectations when they go to receive a government service.

It is an interesting initiative which is being pursued in the United Kingdom and which I have a specific interest in because I think it has great application to government service in Australia, where many taxpayers go to government departments and get shoddy service. There are many government departments which will give good service, but there are many citizens, I am sure, who have gone to government departments from time to time, be they federal or state government departments, and received shoddy service; and they feel betrayed as taxpayers, having paid good money to government only to see the services delivered in a shoddy manner.

What the United Kingdom government has set out to do is to create a charter of consumers' rights for those who consume government services. One of the charters that has now been published—and it has been published by the Adam Smith Institute in particular in this case—is a charter for students which sets out the sorts of rights that students should be able to expect when they go to a university or a tertiary institution. Under the Students' Charter, again student unions are referred to.

What hit me when I read this charter was the incredible similarity in the objectives of trying to make student unions voluntary. On page 6 of the Students' Charter document, authored by Peter Yorke, Mr Yorke says that student unions play a significant role in campus life at UK universities and colleges—again agreeing with the former member for Stirling, Ron Edwards, in that respect. He goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: In many places they are responsible for the running of the student bar and the welfare of students. The provision of these services is laudable and shows what they are capable of.

Of course, that is the situation on university campuses in Western Australia. The guilds, the student unions, provide many services, some of which are essential, some of which are not so essential, but all of which provide good services to students. Indeed, we argue that, when student union membership is made voluntary, many of those services will absolutely flourish because they will become more responsive to the needs of the individual members and the student unions will have to work a lot harder to ensure that the service provided is good, that they attract membership and that, indeed, the membership is not just given to them of right and they just do not receive the fees, or receive the memberships, without having to work to achieve them.

PARA.TAB: Mr Yorke, in the Students' Charter document, goes on to talk about the problems of compulsion. One of the problems referred to, of course, is what he calls the `unnatural swelling of the National Union of Students funds'. That is one of the problems we have in Australia. People are compulsorily required to join student unions and, therefore, pay a compulsory fee to the National Union of Students on those many campuses where they are affiliated to the National Union of Students. That is unnatural because the National Union of Students ends up with a treasury of funds from students who may not necessarily want their money to go to the National Union of Students. They may not, in fact, want their money to go to any student union at all. They have no choice in this.
The other problem, which I have already referred to, is the closed shop. I quote again:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the closed shop causes the union to fall too readily into the hands of a small number of extremists. As most of those compelled to join a student union have no interest in politics, the likelihood is that they will take no part in the way things are run and take no interest in the decisions made by the controlling group.

There is no doubt that that is the case on campuses around Australia. Whenever there is a referendum on affiliation issues or things like that, there are extremely small voter turnouts. A hell of a lot of students go to university just with the objective of—believe it or not—being educated. Some of us go to campuses and are interested in taking part in student political activities, and that is tremendous to see. The more people get involved in student political activities, the better for politics in Australia and the better for education, I believe. The point at issue, of course, is whether or not these student unions should be funded by those who wish not to be members; and that is most important.

PARA.TAB: I will conclude my contribution with a quote from the Wealth of Nations by Adam Smith, of course, where he refers to another instance where the funding of a body is remote from the performance. Specifically, I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The endowments of schools and colleges have necessarily diminished more or less the necessity of application in the teachers. Their subsistence, so far as it arises from their salaries, is evidently derived from a fund altogether independent of their success and reputation in their particular professions.

The importance of that principle, espoused by the great economist and philosopher, is that, where the derivation of a body's funds does not depend on the performance of that body, then the performance will not be what it should be. It is the opposition's argument—this relates to either a student union or a trade union—that the funding needs to reflect the performance of the union, and of the management and the office bearers of that union.

PARA.TAB: If the union can rely on the same funding year in year out, regardless of performance, it will not be motivated in the correct way. That is the opposition's argument. We will be pursuing that argument in relation to the states grants bill, which comes before the Senate next week. I certainly hope that we are able to use these sorts of arguments to convince our friends and colleagues in the Democrats to support the view that Commonwealth taxpayers' money should not be channelled into student unions in this way. In the end, it will ensure those student unions become unrepresentative, and bureaucratic, and that they do not have the proper incentives required to ensure that they represent the students.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my grave concerns about the upheaval and trauma which have been visited on the remote South Australian town of Woomera in recent months. The drama now being played out at Woomera is a litany of retrenchments, of wage cuts, of workers being stripped of their accrued benefits and effectively evicted from their homes. The effect on the town has been devastating. Morale and community spirit have plummeted. Families have broken up and others have been strained to breaking point. Children have been forced out of school mid-term as their families join the exodus of up to 300 people from the town. All of this may sound melodramatic, but it is an accurate picture of what has been going on.

PARA.TAB: I visited Woomera on 22 and 23 September to see for myself. I spoke to workers, to union officials, to the town doctor and to the chief Defence employee. For hours I listened to the grievances of people whose lives have been torn asunder. The anger was so strong you could almost touch it. Woomera is a defence town. It exists for virtually no other reason than to service the US/Australian base at Nurrungar. All jobs at Woomera are directly or indirectly funded by our Department of Defence and the United States Air Force. Almost all housing is owned by Defence, and to lose your job in Woomera means losing your home. So you get hit with a double whammy.

The citizens of Woomera have vastly fewer democratic and economic rights than other Australians. There is no local council, like most Australian communities have. The Area Administrator Woomera, who heads up the Defence Support Centre at Woomera, runs the town with the powers of a feudal landlord. He has extraordinary control of peoples' lives and livelihoods, and he cannot be voted out of office. In Woomera, town services which would normally be provided by a local council are instead supplied by private contractors and the Defence Support Centre Woomera. This is where the current saga begins.

For the last 17 years, the private contractor has been basically the same firm, which now goes under the name of SERCo. Its most recent contract expired on 30 September. Tenders were called before that date for the new contract that began on 1 October. The range of services to be provided under the new contract was expanded under the commercial support program. In other words, some services previously supplied by Defence were commercialised. So far, so good.

I want, however, to contradict claims made by Senator Ray when I recently asked a question on this subject. The Democrats do not object to cost reductions through improved work practices, nor are we opposed to the commercialisation of selected defence functions. What we do object to is the callous way it was done at Woomera. The contract handover has been a classic example of how not to implement change. It is a saga of grossly insensitive management, serious conflict of interest and a repudiation of the industrial relations principles which this government claims to stand for. I am not going to give all the details here—I have supplied quite substantial details to Senator Ray and I believe he will respond to those in due course—but I do want to outline the main problems.

Defence Support Centre Woomera has had an unacceptable conflict of interest in this affair. On the one hand, it monitored the old contract and drew up the requirements for the new one, in its role as town administrator. On the other hand, it bid for and won parts of the contract. It does not take a genius to realise that DSCW was in a hopelessly compromised position. It could not and did not impartially administer the previous contract, when it had a commercial interest in containing costs under the new contract. The information passed to DSCW in its role as town administrator gave it a commercial head start in bidding for the new contract. Evidence that I was given suggests strongly that DSCW won a transport contract in this way.

Another major problem is the way in which workers in the town have been stripped of pay and conditions by the use of a loophole in the Industrial Relations Act. The villain of the piece in this case was not DSCW but Australian Defence Industries. As part of its successful bid for major parts of the new contract, ADI concluded a so-called greenfields agreement with the minority union at Woomera, the Federation of Industrial Manufacturing and Engineering Employees Union. By calling it a greenfields agreement, ADI escaped the no disadvantage test for certified agreements, which would have ensured that workers were no worse off.

The major union at Woomera, the AMEU, was totally excluded from this agreement. Even local FIMEE officials were not properly consulted, and the agreement was signed despite their opposition to it. If this is how enterprise bargaining is done, Australian workers have a lot to worry about. At Woomera there was no bargaining and no agreement with the workers. Cuts in pay and conditions were imposed, and workers were told to take it or leave it. In some cases, disposable income was cut by up to $12,000. The fiction peddled by ADI—that this was a greenfields site—is now the subject of an appeal to the Industrial Relations Commission. I hope that the commission is able to see through ADI's argument.

What we have here is a government authority imposing negative cost cutting on workers, many of whom will have to do more work for less pay. Negative cost cutting is a practice that this government claims to oppose, yet it has done nothing to stop it from being carried out at Woomera. The award safety net so beloved of the industrial relations minister has a huge hole in it, through which the workers of Woomera have been dropped.

Former employees of the previous contractor, Serco, have been hit particularly hard by the contract handover. Former Serco workers continuing with ADI—in some cases on lower pay—will not be allowed to take their accrued benefits with them, nor will those benefits be paid out through a redundancy package. Again, they have been failed by the so-called award safety net. This government has announced that it will legislate for greater fairness in the termination of employment, yet a clear case of unfairness has been allowed to occur without the government raising a finger.

The minister has made it clear that the issue of accrued benefits and redundancy pay for continuing workers is a matter for Serco and ADI, but the fact is that the people who will lose out through this stand-off are the workers, not the companies. It is the government's responsibility to insist that this matter be resolved fairly. As I said before, Woomera is a Defence town, and Defence has never been shy about influencing the conditions of Serco workers. So it cannot just wash its hands of the whole affair and leave the workers of Woomera in the lurch.

The redundancy issue is also before the Industrial Relations Commission, but that should not stop the government acting to rectify a clear-cut case of unfairness. It is my view that the minister's hands-off approach to the dire situation at Woomera is inappropriate; and I must express my disappointment at the answer he gave on Tuesday to my question on notice on this subject. I appreciate that the minister cannot get involved in every case of shonky management and worker exploitation. There are other ways of dealing, however, with isolated cases.

But the situation at Woomera is not a small or isolated case. It has had an impact on the entire town and it is too serious to ignore. The minister, surely, has an interest in repairing morale at a facility that he claims is vital to our security. It must be appreciated that no-one is directly accountable to the people of Woomera. The Area Administrator, Woomera, and his Defence Support Centre Woomera, cannot be voted out of office by the people whose lives have been torn apart by this contract handover. The person to whom the DSCW is ultimately accountable is the minister. If he refuses to help the people of Woomera, then DSCW is accountable to no-one. That is why I urge the minister to act. In the interests of fairness, morale and good management, his intervention is overdue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to a matter of public interest in my home state of Tasmania. I want to highlight the very serious consequences to Tasmania if the jobs of 800 teachers, health workers, librarians and other public sector employees are axed as part of the Groom government's budget strategy. As a result of the reduction in these services, there will be disastrous long-term effects for Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: It is my aim today to focus specifically on education cuts. But before I do, I feel it is important that I expose how unnecessary the overall cuts are in light of the budget forecasts for the state. It is, therefore, necessary to look briefly at the situation in terms of the state's net debt servicing ratio taken over by the Field government during the 1990s, which was irresponsibly left by the Gray government.

Tasmania had, indeed, reached a crisis point at that time. State debt had to be confronted. The cost of servicing the debt needed to be reduced as a percentage of the annual budget. Without any action, it was forecast, the debt ratio would have blown out to a staggering 30 per cent by the year 2000.

Clearly, the strategy adopted by the then Field government reversed that trend, ensuring that the debt ratio would peak at 12.5 per cent and drop back to 10 per cent by the year 2000. I am the first to admit that a series of very unpopular steps was taken at that time, including significant cuts to the public sector. The Field government was left with little or no choice. The state was going broke, and the facts have been well documented with commentators and economists agreeing that the steps taken were necessary and well thought out.

In the short term, that contributed to the defeat of the Field government. The point is that the measures taken, together with various other factors, including lower interest rates and federal funding, have reduced the state debt ratio to 10.3 per cent. That figure will continue to drop to a forecast 9.7 per cent and will continue down. There is no good or sound need to further cut the public sector in Tasmania. We have the highest unemployment rate in the country, with 28,000 Tasmanians seeking employment. It must be remembered that Mr Groom campaigned very strongly on jobs, jobs, jobs, no redundancy schemes and maintaining funding to education.

The Tasmanian public has been shattered by his duplicity. Nineteen months after the election, we have higher unemployment, lower business confidence and a growing crisis in the community. The polls accurately reflect this. It really is a case of higher unemployment and fewer services. Despite this, the Groom government is attempting to cut 166.5 teachers out of the school system. I doubt seriously whether the government has any idea of the devastating impact its decision will have. My background is in teaching. I am very aware of the difficulties and stresses teachers face. I am also aware of the reduced quality of education as a result of reducing staffing. It is inconceivable to me that a government would cut teachers from a system already reduced to a minimum to save $2.8 million in 1993-94. This is less than one per cent of the education budget, and the community is screaming out for the quality of education they have paid for.

The Minister for Education has described the cuts as marginal, but in my view they are literally the final straw. Many schools are being forced into making untenable decisions about dropping special education, music, art, physical education and library time. These cuts lead also to increased class sizes, decreased curriculum diversity, and fewer subject choices for students who are looking to specialise in years 7 to 12. I would like to read from a newsletter that went to parents of children attending a primary school in Tasmania. The principal said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our school is to be badly affected by the State government decision to cut 166.5 teachers in 1993-1994 state budget. Our school's staff and school council have not yet finalised the school plan for 1994, however I feel that it is important that parents realise the most likely impact of the cuts. They are:
1.57% less senior teacher time which will reduce the direct supervision and support for class teachers and children and cut or reduce several special programs.
2.Support reading for grades 5 and 6 will go.
3.Support reading for middle primary classes will be reduced by 25%.
4.The home assisted reading program will need to be reduced from 3 to 1 session per year.
5.Curriculum development work will get less support.
6.There will be 25% less time for Music.
7.40% less time for PhysEd will mean that no PE teacher involvement in the Inter School sport program for Grades 5 and 6.

This is an example of one primary school's predicament. Senior and secondary schools and colleges face even tougher times. The tragedy is, of course, that there is no need to go ahead with cuts, and that is the point I want to emphasise. It is obviously the belief of Mr Groom and his government that there is no real need to give as much support as possible to our teaching institution and staff.

PARA.TAB: High unemployment and the recession are hurting our urban and rural communities. Young families with school-aged children are the first to feel the brunt. An example of this is the dramatic rise in school loan issues which are means tested on student families. Loan issues have risen from 23 per cent of students in 1991 to 35 per cent in 1993. That is a frightening indication of some of the underlying problems schools face.

Teaching staff are often the first point of call for families in crisis with the strain of unemployment and reduced income. Schools are having to commit significant resources for counselling parents and students. They are becoming a social clearing house. Stress for teachers becomes a factor as a result. It shocked me to find that in the years between 1989 and 1993 there were 58 stress-related retirements of teachers across Tasmania. That gives an indication of the stress-related problems teachers now have. How much worse does it have to get before some relief is given? Staff reductions force up class sizes; large class sizes mean less time for teachers to give to individual students. In the meantime, the workload for teachers goes up, quality education goes down, and the social problems are compounded. We can see why over 1,000 teachers, students and parents marched through the streets of Hobart recently.

I would like to finish by making a couple of points. The first one relates to students currently completing diplomas within our state university. The forecast reductions mean that no graduates will be recruited into the school system for at least the next two years and only very few from that point on. The average age of teaching staff throughout Tasmania is 41 years. A large block of teachers started in the 1970s, and in 15 years time at least 15 per cent of those staff will have retired. Without an influx of new graduates each year, a large hole in terms of experience will appear.

The second point is this: teachers in Tasmania recently received a salary rise. The state government almost immediately announced a significant tax increase—in particular, tobacco tax—to compensate for the rise. It had, incidentally, been comprehensively beaten on the argument run in the industrial commission claiming incapacity to pay for the teachers' increase, which says something in itself.

The Treasury estimate for the additional tobacco tax was an extra $21 million on top of the $34 million, assuming a drop in consumption of 20 per cent. The budget papers reveal annual receipts of $40 million and predict a revenue increase of $17 million. The teachers' pay increase, unveiled as part of the budget papers, is $15.5 million. So I ask: why on earth cut the teaching service by four per cent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I wish to raise three issues with the Senate. The first concerns the regulation of private pension developments in the UK and Australia. I rise to inform the Senate that the Goode committee in the United Kingdom has handed down its report on the regulation of pensions. It was an important event because it provides a reference point to compare and contrast recent events in Australia. It is therefore worthy of special report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The Goode report was prepared in the wake of the Maxwell scandal, where close to $A800 million was stolen from the Maxwell pension fund, thereby adversely affecting the retirement security of thousands of employees and retirees. Some commentators have said that the loss of funds was just, to use their words, `a drop in the ocean'. My colleagues on the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and I believe otherwise. It has made many Australian people think again about the security of pension funds. For many Australians, it is their only form of saving.

The Goode report is instructive for a number of reasons. First, as the Australian private pension system evolved out of the British system, the trustee structure, which is the foundation for the management of pension funds, is a common feature in both countries. Interestingly, Goode recommends that the basic structure remain. The SIS bills package, to be debated shortly in the parliament, also upholds the trust structure but takes it out of the hands of the law of equity and clearly spells out the duties of trustees. Professor Goode has recommended that there be a single regulator of superannuation assets. The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, under the chairmanship of Senator Sherry, made a similar recommendation 16 months previously in its first report, Safeguarding Super. I am pleased to inform the Senate that the SIS bills have taken up the single regulator idea.

Professor Goode recommends that fund members have the right to appoint at least one-third of the trustees. The select committee recommended that there be equal employer-employee representation. This, I believe, is a surer means of safeguarding super assets. Again I can report that the SIS bills also include equal representation. Having regard to the imbalance of trustee representation that may exist in the United Kingdom, it may have been appropriate for there to be a recommendation that a custodian be appointed to hold the fund assets. In that way, future Maxwells would be thwarted in their attempts to seize fund assets. As I understand it, Professor Goode has not recommended that custodians assume such a role. I hope that he takes on board the comments I am making here today.

In Australia, pension funds should be fully funded—except for public sector funds, of course—whereas in the UK and the US there exists a degree of underfunding of employer contributions. Should an employer sponsoring a superannuation plan become insolvent, there is therefore the chance that employees can be short-changed and not receive their full entitlements. The Goode report recommends that funds meet a 90 per cent minimum solvency standard and that it be monitored by the actuary, the auditor and the regulator. Essentially, the SIS bills accord with this recommendation, with the exception that full funding should occur. Under SIS it will be the job of actuaries, auditors and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to keep an ever-watchful eye on the adequacy of fund assets relative to pension liabilities.

Perhaps the most striking similarity between the Goode report and the SIS bills is the notion that, in the event of fund failure through fraud or dishonesty, there be a retrospective levy on all funds to make good any losses. Senator Sherry, the previous chair of the superannuation committee, was a champion of this approach to secure pension assets, and I am sure that he will be interested to hear that the UK is on the threshold of embracing it as well.

I trust that this speech has assisted honourable senators in understanding some of the complexities of regulating pension funds. The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation has spent considerable time and effort in coming to grips with the superannuation industry supervision package of bills which will greatly assist in placing a security blanket over the $170 billion in pension assets. I expect that the committee will hand down a detailed report on the SIS bills late next week, and then the Senate will be able to debate those bills in an informed and thereby effective manner.

During the past fortnight, the committee has conducted a number of public meetings on the bills and, in a departure from its previous modus operandi of examining legislation, it has convened informal meetings with the Insurance and Superannuation Commission on a number of occasions to clarify certain matters. I have found these to be a highly productive exercise. I commend the minister, Senator McMullan, and the parliamentary secretary, Gary Johns, who both have responsibility for Insurance and Superannuation Commission matters and I thank them for their assistance in this way.

The second matter I wish to raise today concerns an issue that arose during the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration involving technical aspects of tax law. Officers from the Australian Taxation Office gave their view as to the scope of work related counselling. The section at issue was section 58M of the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act, which exempts from tax work related counselling. Section 136 defines work related counselling as counselling which is to improve or maintain the quality of the performance of employees' duties, or prepare employees for retirement, and which relates to any of the following: safety, health, fitness, stress management, personal relationships, retirement problems, drug and alcohol abuse, rehabilitation or prevention of work related trauma, or other diseases or injury, first aid and any similar matters.

Mr Robert Richards, a well-respected tax practitioner and a regular contributor to several professional journals, is concerned about two issues. He has asked that his position be placed on the public record. Mr Richards's view is that outplacement counselling does not fit into any of these categories, as it is essentially about assisting in finding a job and in writing resumes. Mr Richards was also concerned about the manner of the response and is of the belief that the response from the tax office impinges on his professional reputation.

Further, Mr Richards believed that the answer given by the tax office was wrong, in that it represents the Australian Taxation Office view of the law rather than, as he put it, the technically correct position. I refer all those who read the Hansard to the proceedings of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in terms of the technical aspects of taxation law. I hope they will be aware of this contribution so that Mr Richards's standing among his peers is not diminished.

I take this opportunity of calling on the government to introduce, by way of legislation, the amendments necessary to clarify its intent as expressed through its taxation officers. The government should ensure that its view of the law is expressed correctly through legislation, so that the practice adopted by the tax office is technically correct. This will require an amendment to tax law.

The third issue is a concern by another person who felt that tax officers had put him in an unfortunate position. I refer to the tax office's response in terms of a contribution made by Mr Ray Regan, of the National Tax Agents Association. I believe that he deserves the opportunity, through this chamber, to have his points of view put in response to some comments made by officers of the revenue collection branch of the Taxation Office during the 21 September hearing. Because of the shortage of time, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard comments made by Mr Regan to ensure that his side of the story is also placed on the public record.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: ATO HANSARD, 21ST SEPTEMBER 1993
Re: Tax Audit Statistics—Pages 122 and 123

Mr Matthews has endeavoured to malign the National Tax Agents' Association Ltd (NTAA) by stating on page 123 ". . . the report in the newspapers incorrectly presented the position as though it were a basis for extrapolating and generalising for the population as a whole". Moreover, he states "I simply reiterate that the sorts of comments that have been made in the media picking up on those themes are in themselves incorrect in almost every major aspect.

The Tax Office has clearly tried to discredit the NTAA's statement of fact which was presented to the media and reported, for example by Michael Dwyer of the Financial Review on the 20th September 1993 (copy attached). The media report clearly refers to the "study conducted by the ATO's Dandenong Branch Office which found that the average additional tax payable on eligible termination payments after audits was $7,200.
Once again, our own press release was clearly drawn from and expanded on by the Tax Office's audit statistics issued to all Tax Agents in the Dandenong area.

The Tax Office has endeavoured to distort the truth, which is that the audit adjustment levels on tax returns are producing an unacceptably high amendment rate which, given the legislation has existed for many years, suggests the real problem exists with the Tax Office's inability to explain to taxpayers all the information they need prior to lodging returns under self assessment.
The Taxation Office should be severely censured for the manner in which this distortion of the true facts has been handled.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993BOUNTY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 31 August, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks on behalf of the opposition in relation to the Customs Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 and the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. The opposition supports both bills, noting the amendment to be moved by the government to the Customs Legislation Amendment Bill.

PARA.TAB: The Customs Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus measure proposing amendments to four acts. There are four key proposals. The first relates to the Timor Gap and the Australian Customs Service barrier control and enforcement in that area; the second is in relation to ship arrival reports and the details of possessions of crews; the third concerns the clarification of the rules of the origin of preferential goods; and the fourth and most significant for the purpose of this debate is for the anti-dumping arrangements.

As I said, the opposition does not oppose this bill now that section 23 of the original legislation, which deals with the availability of reports of the Anti-Dumping Authority, is going to be removed by the government by way of amendment. At present, reports from the Anti-Dumping Authority are available to the public as soon as practicable, after presentation to the minister, but before ministerial decision. The government's original proposal in this bill was that those reports would be publicly available only after the minister had made his decision.

The government put an argument that the existing arrangements put too much pressure on the minister to consider arguments or recommendations before making his decision and thus duplicating the work of the ADA. The opposition and the Democrats reaction to that was, `Well, so what?'. We did not support that proposition. We believe that interested groups should be able to put their case to the minister after the report is released but before the minister makes a decision. We also believe that, under the changes originally proposed by the government, it was possible for the minister to sit on the report and that dumping could potentially continue. That would have set a very bad precedent. We are pleased that the government has accepted the case put by the opposition and the Democrats that that particular amendment should not proceed. Therefore, with the amendment to delete that section, the opposition supports the bill.

The Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill is a bill to amend a number of bounty acts and, again, the opposition supports this bill. I wish to address a few remarks to it because it is a significant matter. The bill is significant because it represents the implementation of the recommendations of the Industry Commission report on book production, released in October 1992. The opposition would like to congratulate the government on accepting all of the recommendations of this Industry Commission report. Indeed, we look forward with great anticipation to the government accepting future recommendations from the Industry Commission.

In particular, we would welcome the government adopting the latest Industry Commission report on impediments to regional industry adjustment. Unfortunately, the government has made noises antipathetic to that particular report, which is very regrettable. That report calls for much greater labour market flexibility to enhance employment opportunities in regional Australia but, unfortunately, the Labor Party's union bosses have said, `No way, Jose'. That report will obviously be shelved, and that is regrettable.

The Industry Commission report on book production and this bill acknowledge the need for orderly reduction in assistance to book producers. The opposition supports orderly progressive reduction in protection, either by tariff or by way of bounty. The issue here is that taxpayers should not have to continue subsidising book production or subsidising any other forms of production any longer than absolutely necessary. We are talking about not insignificant sums of money in this area.
