The proposition involved in this bill is that there will be an expenditure of some $55 million over the next four years to subsidise book production. That is a not an insignificant amount of money.

Of course, from our perspective, it is only necessary to continue subsidising book production because of government imposed costs on book producers. Book producers, like most other businesses in this country, are suffering from the lack of action on economic reform by this government. There is absolutely no evidence of any sense of urgency by this government in relation to economic reform. We continue to have a gross foreign debt of over $200 billion; a net debt of some $170 billion; and unemployment stuck at between 10 and 11 per cent. However, no sense of urgency is demonstrated by this government to take the measures necessary to solve those problems.

We have debated at length the fact that the 1993-94 budget does nothing to address those economic problems. The tax system that this country is lumbered with does nothing to address those problems. Book producers, like most other businesses in this country, find it extremely hard to be internationally competitive. Businesses are faced with federal government taxes and charges, and state taxes and charges. Other issues, such as the super levy, the training guarantee levy, and payroll taxes, et cetera, make it extremely difficult for businesses to be internationally competitive. Hence, we find we have to subsidise book production in this country.

On one major area of reform where the government could move—industrial relations—we are about to be presented with legislation which again demonstrates that this government has no idea of what is required to be done to make Australian businesses internationally competitive and able to employ more Australians. In this context, I refer the Senate to the report of the Committee for Economic Development of Australia, which was prepared by Fred Argy, called A long term economic strategy for Australia. Argy is a former director of the government's Economic Planning Advisory Council.

Among that distinguished gentleman's recommendations to the government through this CEDA report were four very critical ones which I think are relevant to this issue. Argy recommended that governments need to adopt a more productive, pro-active, even aggressive role in addressing Australia's competitive weakness, especially in facilitating trade related activities and investments. Secondly, he recommended that industrial relations reforms need to be adopted which markedly enhance workplace and structural wage flexibility. Thirdly, business regulations that impede employment, competitiveness and investment must be exposed to much more critical evaluation. Fourthly, and probably most importantly, the tax system must be restructured so as to facilitate growth.

It is reasonable for the opposition to ask in relation to this bill where the government is on those four essential issues. We see no evidence of real tax reform; we see no real evidence of industrial relations reform, to the detriment not only of book producers but also of most other businesses in this country. What we are really saying is that the bounty arrangements in this bill which the Industry Commission has recommended to the government and which it is adopting are necessary, from our point of view, but only because of the government's inaction on the question of micro-economic reform.

We do not oppose the bill, but we call on the government to get on with an aggressive program of economic reform so that book producers can be competitive. I conclude my remarks on behalf of the opposition by quoting from that Industry Commission report which this government has accepted and which I hope it will note. As the Industry Commission said:

SPEECH.PARA: Improvements in competitiveness are needed if the industry is to prosper in the future. With gradual reduction of the cost burdens imposed by the existing tariff structure in Australia, the main opportunities for future advance seems likely to lie in the general areas of management and work practice. For example, the industry (both employers and unions/employees) might usefully direct attention to the relationship between the level of utilisation of capital equipment and other conditions of employment presently incorporated in relevant industry awards. Improved flexibility in these aspects would bring benefits to the book production industry, and to the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Customs Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. This is an omnibus bill which seeks to make a number of amendments relating to rules of origin, increasing the customs reach of Australian authorities to the Timor Gap, and the publication of Anti-Dumping Authority reports. The rules of origin are clarified for deciding where tariff preferences actually apply. The Australian Democrats certainly support the provisions contained in this bill for this purpose. However, that we express the hope that this clarification of the origin of product also will be transferred into Australian laws regarding labelling and packaging. We would expect that the current very unsatisfactory situation, which does not clearly show whether the goods have been totally produced in Australia from Australian products or whether they have simply been assembled here from imported products, does a lot of damage to Australian industry. I am looking forward to the Australian government taking appropriate action to improve our labelling provisions.

PARA.TAB: The second group of amendments in this bill relate to the extension of customs controls to the oil rig platforms in the Timor Gap. In itself, this is a measure that the Australian Democrats support. However, it should be noted in this context that the Australian Democrats were the only party to oppose the conclusion of the Timor Gap oil treaty with Indonesia on the basis that this in effect is the 30 pieces of silver that we are collecting for the betrayal of the East Timorese. This position the Australian Democrats have adopted consistently remains. I simply remark that this provision continues the implementation of the collection of the blood money that we have earned over the years.

I turn to the last segment of the bill, which relates to the publication of Anti-Dumping Authority reports. At the moment it is provided that such reports, when they are handed to the minister, should also as soon as practicable be provided to the public. That includes those people who have made an application for anti-dumping and countervailing provisions. The amendment that the government seeks to bring in is to legalise the practice which now obtains where these reports are provided to the public usually after the minister has received them and very often, and more importantly, after the minister has made a determination.

It is quite clear that, once the minister has made a determination, that determination can be overcome only by court action. It is also clear and on the record that very often reports from the Anti-Dumping Authority have contained factual errors and a line of argument which the Australian manufacturers seeking protection from the dumping of cheap imports on our markets have sought to rectify and bring to the minister's notice.

The Australian Democrats drafted an amendment to ensure that these reports are provided to the public at the same time as the minister receives them. To the opposition's shame, its members have rejected this amendment. They have not offered support for a measure which would have given Australian manufacturers the chance to have a greater influence on anti-dumping measures. Clearly, the government would not have supported it either. However, I do acknowledge that the government has done the next best thing and has decided by amendment to withdraw that provision. We are now returning to the prior bill situation where the authority is obliged to provide to the public the report as soon as practicable after the minister receives it. I call on the minister to give instructions that this be done, indeed as soon as practicable, but certainly before the minister makes his determination, to enable the industry to have some influence.

I turn to the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill and simply note that, in the case of both the book bounty and the computer bounty provisions, the rates are reduced but they are reduced after consultation with industry. To the Australian Democrats, this is the most hopeful sign, namely, that the government has decided that it is necessary in each industry to proceed with such legislation in consultation with and with the agreement of industry. The Australian Democrats will support both bills.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —All I want to do, to save time in the committee stage, is to acknowledge Senator Spindler's remarks. We will be moving an amendment to maintain the status quo under section 28 of the Anti-Dumping Authority Act. In other words, the Anti-Dumping Authority will continue to be required to make reports available to the public as soon as practicable after giving a report to the minister. That will be maintained. With those remarks I now commend the bill for its second reading.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
Debate interrupted.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Hong Kong: Comments by Prime Minister

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to a report today that, during his visit to China in June, the Prime Minister told Chinese leaders that Australia does not support Governor Patten's push for greater democracy in Hong Kong. I ask the minister whether he can confirm the accuracy of this report. I also ask him what exactly the Prime Minister meant when, according to the record of conversation between him and Premier Li Peng, he stated—and I quote from what purports to be the record of conversation:

QUESTION.PARA: Australia is not particularly impressed with Patten's modus operandi or his taking an interest in Hong Kong's political situation so late in the piece.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been no change whatever in Australia's position on political reform in Hong Kong. That position has been clearly stated on the public record on a number of occasions by me, and I and the government fully stand by everything that has been said. I certainly cannot believe that the Prime Minister would have said anything different.

PARA.TAB: As a democracy, Australia naturally supports the values of an open society which are, in fact, reflected in the 1984 Sino-British joint declaration on the question of Hong Kong. The rule of law and independent judiciary, both of which are embodied in that declaration, have certainly been key elements in Hong Kong's prosperity. We have consistently expressed to both China and Britain our support for democratic reform which is consistent with the terms of that joint declaration and also the basic law of 1990 and which is, of course, moreover, manifestly acceptable to the people of Hong Kong.

We do hope that China and Britain will be able to agree on a more democratic and responsive political system being introduced before 1997, although it does have to be acknowledged that the present signs are not ones that give much cause for optimism in that respect, and that is a matter for considerable regret.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question as that did not answer the question at all. Was the statement of conversation correctly quoted by me? Is it accurate that Mr Keating said:

QUESTION.PARA: Australia is not particularly impressed with Patten's modus operandi or his taking an interest in Hong Kong's political situation so late in the piece.

Given what the minister has just said, does it now mean that Mr Keating did not understand his own government's position? Was it that his personal position differed from that of the Australia government? Or was he simply seeking to impress China's leaders?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not appropriate for me to confirm or deny what purports to be a record of a prime ministerial private conversation. Those records are confidential and should properly remain so. I will say, however, just this: even as reported, those remarks do not carry the weight that both the headline of this report and Senator Hill seek to place upon them.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I understand that during the minister's recent visit to Germany and Japan he held discussions with Dr Mennicken, Executive Director of DARA, the German space agency and with Mr Yamano, President of the National Space Development Agency of Japan. Was any interest expressed in joint space ventures during these meetings and, if so, what potential could this have for the re-activation of the Woomera launch site in South Australia?
—I thank Senator Beahan for his question on, and interest in, Australia's space program.
—And the South Australian election.

—If Senator Vanstone had kept her ears open over the last six months in this place, she would have realised that I have spoken on several occasions about my desire to reactivate Woomera—long before the South Australian election was contemplated. I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure when it dealt with this report some two years ago and I know that Senator Panizza and Senator Chapman had a bipartisan approach to this issue, which seems to be something that Senator Vanstone does not wish to have.

PARA.TAB: In the discussions with Dr Mennicken and his officials from DARA, the German space agency, we were able to indicate that by February of next year we would complete the signing of a treaty to enable a German satellite under the express program to be recovered in the Woomera area. It will need to be at a treaty level and it will need to cover such issues as indemnity for Australia for any damages. We believe those issues can be dealt with by February. By August of next year the express satellite will be recovered at Woomera. It will involve some expenditure from the German side and some activity at Woomera, which we would all welcome.

I also had discussions with Dr Mennicken about the precise range and range rate equipment program, or Prare, which is another satellite program to pick up signals in Australia. An exchange of letters of agreement will take place sometime in the near future to enable Australia to be involved in that program. In the longer term there is some interest from Germany in further reactivating Woomera. It is not impossible to conceive that some time in the future the Germans may be interested in launching low orbiting or lightweight satellites from Woomera as it expands its space program.

As far as the Japanese are concerned, we had very useful discussions with the Japanese space agency, NASDA. As a result of that discussion, by February of next year we hope to have a team of Japanese engineers and scientists involved in the space program visit Australia to have a joint meeting with Australian interests involved and interested in space and satellites to look at ways in which both countries can collaborate together to expand our interests in space for a mutual benefit.

In both of these areas we have achieved a further interest in collaboration under our S&T agreement with both Germany and Japan. In both of these areas I am sure all honourable senators, particularly those opposite, would welcome an expansion of Australia's space program, because this is all in line with the themes of the Senate report on satellites which was tabled in this chamber some 18 months ago and supported by this chamber unanimously. I welcome the bipartisan support for these initiatives which came from that Senate report.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. I draw the minister's attention to the fact that one in five Australians suffers some form of mental illness at some stage in his or her life and that around 30 per cent of all hospital beds are occupied by people with mental illnesses. I also draw his attention to the link between dysfunctional families and mental health problems, confirmed in the Burdekin report, and to the facts that 40,000 marriages end each year, that youth suicide is now the No. 1 killer of young men aged 18 to 24, and that the number of homeless people is around 40,000. Why, after more than 10 years, has this government, in its areas of responsibility, not given a higher priority to a national strategy with sufficient resources to minimise family breakdown, thereby helping to prevent mental health problems? Finally, given that the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which Australia ratified in 1980, and other relevant international instruments are incorporated in the Commonwealth Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986, why is this government in breach of its own legislation in relation to the human rights of Australia's mentally ill?
—That is a quite extraordinary question. I shall attempt to cover some of the matters—
—Because you can't answer it!

—I think I might manage it. Even without Senator Vanstone's assistance, I could just about do it. When one reads the Burdekin report and looks at the scope of its recommendations and findings one realises how great the problem is and how much is being done and, I suppose, how little is being done in other areas. To then try to apportion blame to any particular place is, to my mind, difficult.

PARA.TAB: Last April I got the states to agree for the first time in our 90-odd years of federation to have a national health policy. Obviously, when managing any form of mental illness or anything else, it is difficult to have a coordinated national approach when six states and two territories are running a hospital system and, by and large, being responsible for the organisations that deliver community care. Therefore, the tone of Senator Newman's question—that in some way the Burdekin report reveals some massive failure on the part of the federal government—is quite extraordinary.

When the Burdekin inquiry began, which was in June 1990, mental health services were the responsibility of state and territory governments. The federal government had no direct role at all—none. Fortunately, because of the tenure of my predecessor, Brian Howe, that was turned around. A landmark agreement for a five-year national mental health strategy was reached in March 1992 between the federal government and the states. That strategy involves expenditure from the Commonwealth of $135 million to assist the states in building stronger networks of community care. That seems to me to be an excellent start, but I would not suggest for a second that it is the end.

Clearly, from listening to the comments this morning of state ministers around the country of both political persuasions, there remains much more to be done. Clearly, governments of all political persuasions have used some sections of the Richmond report from the 1980s to save a lot of money by closing institutions, but have never observed the second part of the Richmond report to spend that money in creating more opportunities for community care, and that is sad.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was absolutely doomed to failure and you should have realised it.

—If it was doomed to failure, the government that Senator Boswell used to support in Queensland went in the same direction, so why did it not realise it? Why did not governments right around the country of both political persuasions—
—Because you took the funding off them; that is what happened.

—That is just not true. Senator Boswell demonstrates ignorance too often. Nonetheless, I believe that the Burdekin report has brought home to us all what those weaknesses are. The Commonwealth, under the auspices of the Attorney-General's Department, is setting up an IDC so that we can form a response. We will go through the Burdekin report line by line and respond appropriately. In the interim, Brian Howe and I will be taking up some of the more obvious issues with the states and talking to them about how we can address what is an extremely serious problem as quickly as possible.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his all-purpose answer on the Burdekin report to a question that I did not ask. Nevertheless, I will repeat for the minister the two items of my question. Firstly, after 10 years of government, why has the government not put in sufficient resources to minimise family breakdown where we have this serious mental health problem within families? Secondly, does the minister deny that his government is in breach of its own legislation in relation to the human rights of Australia's mentally ill as spelt out in the Burdekin report? Can I have specific answers to those specific questions.

—I do concede that I had not finished that answer but it is difficult, within the time constraint of four minutes, to answer all these things. I do not regard the Commonwealth government as being responsible for family breakdown. Any suggestion of the same is, of course, a nonsense. There is certainly an increase in the rate of family breakdown occurring in Australia at the moment, so much so that I am told that, within only two decades, the most common family will be a family where one or both partners is marrying or partnering for the second time. That changes the concept we have always had of what families are. So there is a change going on in society to which we must react. Whether that means that that is, in some way, the sole cause, as Senator Newman seems to suggest, of mental illness is not only debatable but a nonsense. What I intend to do is continue to make sure that sufficient resources are put in place to sort that situation out.

—My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer the minister to the article in today's Canberra Times headed `Women's own health department?' which arises from findings of the evaluation of the national women's health program. Does that evaluation in fact recommend the establishment of a separate department?

—Yesterday I released the evaluation report of the national women's health program. That does in fact make reference to the establishment of a separate branch devoted entirely to women's health. It does not make reference to the establishment of a women's health department. So, to that extent, the report is not quite accurate.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased to have the opportunity to tell the Senate about the report. The evaluation of the national women's health program occurs as the program has come to the end of its first four years. One of its recommendations is for that program to continue for another four or even eight years. I am happy to say that we pre-empted the report in our budget by funding the program to $30 million for another four years. That $30 million is actually almost double the funding that was given to the first four years of the program, which was $16 million. What is also important is that it is a matched dollar for dollar program from the Commonwealth to the state, so the Commonwealth commitment of $30 million means that there will be $60 million available over the next four years to devote to continuing women's health.

Minister Richardson referred a moment ago to getting a national agreement between the Commonwealth and the states for a national health program at the recent Commonwealth-state health ministers conference. We were also supported by the states in their commitment to another four-year continuation of the national women's health program. So, in fact, we have in principle commitment from the states to that extra $30 million. I think that the commitment by the states and the Commonwealth to the ongoing programs for women's health is very encouraging.

The report also pointed out a number of benefits of the program. It has been particularly successful in establishing a range of innovative primary health care services for women at the local and state level and in ensuring that a significant number of rural, non-English speaking background and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women have been reached by those services. Indeed, the evaluation quite clearly shows that the program has been filling gaps in services, particularly for those categories of women and particularly for women in rural and isolated areas remote from major capital cities. It also highlighted that, although there has been some work done on young women, young unemployed women, women with low incomes and women as carers, there is considerably more work to be done in that area. That is one of the intentions of the next phase of the program which is now under way.

Another thing that the evaluation highlighted was the need for reliable and accurate data about women's health. I am pleased to say that the announcement of funding of $3.5 million for a major longitudinal study into women's health was an election promise that was actually kept in the budget. That is a very significant step—it is the first ever longitudinal study into women's health—and that will actually provide us with accurate data about women, instead of data adapted from men, to allow us to better plan and continue services for women. Finally, one area that was targeted was community services for women with mental health problems. I am certain that, in the light of the Burdekin report, that will continue to be a focus of the national women's health program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the minister to the appalling treatment mentally ill Australians are subjected to, as evidenced in the Burdekin report. Firstly, does the minister acknowledge that current government funding at all levels of government is inadequate to protect these most vulnerable members of our community? Secondly, will the government address some of the underlying causes and review its economic deregulation policies which erode its capacity to fund services and its will to safeguard the well-being of Australian citizens? Thirdly, is the government prepared to again intervene in the allocation of resources, which it now takes such pride in leaving to the market economy, to enable it to address the increasingly disastrous social consequences of its economic policies?

—The government will be providing a considered and comprehensive response to the Burdekin report when parliament resumes sitting in February next year. We will no doubt address specifically then the financial issues that are raised by it. I make the point, however, as Senator Richardson also intimated, that this year's 1992-93 budget committed $135 million over six years to improve mental health arrangements through the national mental health policy. The commitment is there, the funding is there and the task is ahead of us; it just has to be done.

PARA.TAB: I do not accept that our capacity to fund efforts of this kind has been reduced by the strategy of privatisation or deregulation of government services, as Senator Spindler suggests. The real stress and strain upon our capacity to fund these things is coming, as much as anything else these days, from the disposition of honourable senators in this place to make our life difficult on the revenue side. I would ask Senator Spindler and others minded like him, when making lots of hot suggestions about where we might be spending the next taxpayer dollar, to devote at least as much attention to helping us resolve the problem of where precisely that dollar is coming from. Senator Spindler cannot have it both ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Health aware of the paper given at the ANZAAS conference which claimed a cover-up of new information on the risk of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease to participants in the Australian human pituitary hormone program? What impact is the publicity given to this program likely to have on the people who receive the hormone treatment?

—I am aware—as I think anyone who has been reading the papers would be aware—of the Dumble and Klein paper of allegations of some sort of massive cover-up at government and departmental level about the human pituitary hormone program and the risk of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. I am pretty disturbed by it. It is important to get on the record how Australia has dealt with the challenge of CJD rather than letting the version that was given at ANZAAS become some part of accepted wisdom.

PARA.TAB: Because we have the responsibility of providing as much information and support as possible to people on the program, who are naturally anxious about their prospects, we owe it to them not to let sensational claims and headlines distort proper judgment. I will not deny at the outset that Dumble and Klein have done a lot of work in looking at the link between the human pituitary hormone treatment and CJD. But its reliance on anecdotal evidence is extraordinary, to say the least, and its use to sensationalise their paper, seemingly in search of headlines, does not help anyone. Indeed, it has succeeded only in distressing many patients. We know it had this effect because the 008 line on CJD that we set up some time ago received a lot of calls. The newly established national counselling service has also been taking calls from people who are concerned.

Just to put this in context, when this program began in the mid-1960s Robert Menzies was Prime Minister. Since then we have had changes of government, four Liberal prime ministers and a couple of Labor prime ministers. The world has moved a lot in 30 years. To think that information 30 years old could be easily turned up now is a bit spurious.

Despite the claims, Australia did act quickly in 1985 after overseas deaths had been recorded and notified. Not only did we stop the program but we also advised former patients in the program not to donate blood or organs. Despite the fact that there is as yet no confirmed clinical evidence to suggest that the disease can be passed on by blood or organs, we acted quickly.

Tragically, four Australian women who received the hormone treatment for infertility are known to have died from CJD. Therefore, I announced a public inquiry to be conducted by Professor Margaret Allars of Sydney University. That inquiry is investigating exactly how the program was set up and operated and how satisfactory government and departmental responses were. It will also report on things like the need for counselling and support services.

Dumble and Klein were also critical of the government's efforts to trace former patients and claimed that 40 per cent of them had not been contacted. In fact, we have now contacted 78 per cent of patients on the program. I think any statistician will tell honourable senators that after such a period has elapsed between the start of the program and now, it is absolutely extraordinary that we could have done so well. More importantly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Match the batch numbers, minister.

—We have no objection to that when we can reliably inform people about batch numbers, but it is often very difficult to do. I am happy to take that question up with Senator Coulter if he wants to talk to me about it later.

PARA.TAB: The other point I wanted to make in relation to this matter is that there are lots of claims from Dumble and Klein about the incidence of the disease in England and France. The suggestion is that there has been a 50 per cent increase in the UK and there is a new case in France each week. If there is a new case a week in France, that simply adds up to the normal incidence in the population of one per million. Women who were on the program over that 30-year period should not believe that in some way an epidemic is breaking out because of these figures. That is simply not true. It is that kind of claim that upsets and worries a whole lot of innocent people. It ought to stop now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given the Prime Minister's intention to legislate to allow conversion to native title of existing pastoral leases held by Aborigines or Aboriginal organisations, I ask: will those lands continue to be available for pastoral pursuits? Will the new titleholders be permitted to terminate pastoral pursuits on these lands? Will the new owners of former pastoral leases converted to native title be bound to adhere to all state and local authority rules, regulations and by-laws such as the payment of state lease fees and local shire rates?

—It is intended that the Commonwealth's proposals essentially formalise for Aboriginal owned leases the reality, as we perceive it, that in terms of their practical operation—I am not talking now about legal issues—many native title rights can co-exist with pastoral operations. Certainly we are intending to continue to provide significant financial and other assistance to Aboriginal pastoralists who want to continue pastoral operations on the land in question. We will continue to support the strong land management initiatives already being taken by Aboriginal interests.

PARA.TAB: I have not got any specific briefing in front of me on the question of the applicability of state, territory and local government laws and by-laws that govern the operation of pastoral operations. But I would not conceive that it is at all likely that there would be any question of the non-applicability of those laws to this situation. If one is operating a pastoral lease, there are obligations that go with that which have significance for the wider pastoral community and it is very difficult to imagine circumstances in which the applicability of those laws would not be appropriate. In the event that there is a qualification that needs to be placed on that of which I am not aware, I will add something to that answer. But at the moment I do not think that is likely.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the minister said that he can see pastoral industry continuing on the same grounds, even with the change in native title, can the minister see the converse applying; that is, native title as is being turned into pastoral industry land? Does the minister get what I mean?
—Frankly, no.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the fact that an unpublicised humanitarian tragedy of monumental proportions is taking place in southern Sudan. Is the minister in a position to advise the Senate what precisely is happening in Sudan? What is the Australian government committed to do to assist? What proposals constitute Australian policy in response to this appalling tragedy?

—The Australian government—and I know this is also the case with a number of honourable members and senators—has been very gravely concerned for some time about the worsening situation in Sudan. We deplore in particular the resumption in July this year of bombing in the south by government forces, which has led to the displacement of tens of thousands of people.

PARA.TAB: The long running conflict in Sudan has its roots in profound historical and ethnic differences between the largely Christian and animist population of the southern provinces and the government in Khartoum. The Sudanese government's determination to impose Islamic sharia law on the south continues to meet with resistance. The conflict has led to widespread devastation and dependency. The UN estimates that 2 1/2 million people are currently in need of emergency assistance.

In September this year the East African regional heads of state established a committee to promote a peace settlement, but a solution to the conflict, through that or any other means, does not yet appear in sight. Some responsibility for the continuation of the conflict can be attributed to both sides. Disunity among the various factions in the south is another factor that has been complicating any move towards settlement. I acknowledge the many representations that the Australian government has received from Christian church leaders in Australia and members of their congregations, who have expressed their deep abhorrence of the suffering that is being endured by the Sudanese people.

We continue as a government to give emergency aid while maintaining such pressure as we can for a just and lasting settlement. In 1992-93 we gave $4.52 million in aid to Sudan, channelled through international agencies and Australian NGOs, including Operation Lifeline Sudan, World Vision and Tear Australia. This financial year, 1993-94, up to $4 1/2 million will be channelled through aid agencies again to alleviate the plight of innocent civilians who are caught up in the conflict. Recommendations will be put to the responsible minister, Mr Bilney, quite soon.

We consider that the best prospects for bringing about an end to the suffering in Sudan lie in continuing pressure from international and regional organisations. We, like many other countries, are maintaining such pressure as we can on the Sudanese government. We continue to make known to it, both bilaterally and through multi-lateral forums, our censure of its indifference to suffering and the human rights violations that it has been inflicting on the Sudanese people.

In February this year we supported some successful efforts to move debate on Sudan from the closed to the open session of the UN Commission on Human Rights and to appoint a special rapporteur to investigate and report to that commission on conditions in Sudan. That did give some greater exposure to the human rights and humanitarian crisis there.

Finally, our delegation to the current session of the UN General Assembly, which is currently taking place in New York, is working closely with interested delegations to secure a strongly worded resolution of the situation in Sudan, and we expect to be co-sponsoring that resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. If compensation is awarded to any Aboriginal or islander group for the extinguishment of native titles, who exactly will that money be paid to? What rules will operate in relation to the expenditure and distribution of that money amongst the group or community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The money will be paid to the Aboriginal native titleholders. I have indicated previously—and honourable senators ought to be well aware of this—that native title, by its nature, can be held by a community, a group or, in some instances, even by an individual, depending on the content of the relevant traditional laws and customs for the area or group in question. How precisely moneys will be paid, whether into trust funds and things of that kind, obviously remains to be determined. That is

ANSWER.PARA: a matter of detail, but the basic principle is clear.

PARA.TAB: I also want to make clear that many of the provisions in the legislation make provision for the possible granting of non-monetary forms of compensation, and that will also require some detailed attention as to how that works out in any individual case. The questions about determination of compensation, quite apart from the administration of any moneys payable, are all matters for the courts and tribunals concerned. It is not possible in advance to specify with any precision precisely how this will work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister: will any money or other benefits received by individuals be taken into account in assessing eligibility for other government benefits and payments?

—Senator Archer is going to have ample opportunity in the estimates committees of the future to pursue these issues. It is absurd to be putting questions of this kind at this stage. Everything will depend on the particular circumstances. There is, of course, underlying Senator Archer's position a rather unhappy little current of flavour that maybe it is just inappropriate to be paying compensation at all to Aboriginal people for the extinguishment of the rights in question. If that is the underlying current—and I may be doing Senator Archer an injustice—then I think that is a very unhappy flavour indeed. I hope that is not the case.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. I ask: firstly, does clause 29 of the 1986 Federal-State Memorandum of Understanding on Tasmania's Woodchip Exports require an environmental impact statement on any new major forest based industry, such as the proposed Hampshire woodchip mill in north west Tasmania? Secondly, has the Commonwealth government Environment Protection Agency written to the minister recommending that an EIS be conducted into this project? Thirdly, if so, why has the minister granted approval in principle without an EIS? Fourthly, what further approvals are required from the federal government before the construction phase of this project is completed, which will be Australia's largest and Tasmania's fourth woodchip mill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chamarette for giving me sufficient indication of the content of her question to enable me to give a response, which I clearly would not have otherwise been able to do. The answer, I am advised, is as follows: the decision by the Minister for Resources relevant to the Hampshire woodchip mill was to approve in principle the export by North Broken Hill of up to 170,000 tonnes of woodchips per year from Burnie. This volume is not additional to the company's existing long-term approval to export up to 1.065 million tonnes of woodchips per year from northern Tasmania. The minister's decision will simply allow chips which would otherwise have been exported from Bell Bay to be redirected for export from Burnie.

PARA.TAB: Clause 29 of the 1986 Commonwealth-Tasmanian memorandum of understanding relating to woodchip exports from Tasmania goes on for some lines, so perhaps I can seek leave to incorporate that particular passage of the answer in Hansard, or does the honourable senator want to know it now?

TALK.START.PARA: —Provided I can have a copy.
—Of course.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: In the event of any major new forest-based industrial development, whether based on the Southern Forest resource, or any other relevant resource, involving woodchip export, a further EIS in accordance with the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 will be undertaken to cover environmental impact thereof to the extent that it is not covered by or differs significantly in respect of any area from the current or any subsequent EIS.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister's decision to change NBH's export licence relates to the port of shipment. No new sources of woodchips were approved for export as part of the decision. Current sources for woodchips produced by the company are consistent with its long-term export approval subject to annual licences which was granted on the basis of the existing EIS for woodchip exports from Tasmania undertaken in 1985.

PARA.TAB: In the circumstances the minister decided that there was no need to designate the proponent under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Designation under the act would require the minister for the environment to determine whether or not any additional environmental assessment of the project was required. In taking this decision, the minister was aware that the proposed project had undergone environmental assessment in accordance with Tasmanian government requirements.As to the latter parts of the honourable senator's question—and there are still quite a number of them—is the honourable senator happy for me to incorporate the rest of the answer or does she want to hear the whole thing?

TALK.START.PARA: —Incorporate it.
—I seek leave to incorporate the rest of the answer in Hansard. It is a very long answer but it is a very good one.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency (CEPA) did not write to the Minister for Resources recommending that an EIS be conducted into this project
as part of normal consultations in respect of woodchip export approvals the Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) consulted CEPA on the Hampshire proposal.
CEPA subsequently wrote to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy recommending designation of the project proponent under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.
However, the decision as to whether to designate a project under the Act rests solely with the Minister for Resources
based on the issues raised by CEPA, the Minister decided that designation was not warranted.
There are no further approvals required from the Commonwealth Government before the construction phase of the project is completed.

I understand that the Company is now prepared to commence construction of the mill, pending resolution of an appeal against State environmental licences and formal approval by the North Broken Hill Board.
North Broken Hill has indicated that it will be seeking to expand its exports of chips from Hampshire in the future

The Minister has told the company that any expansion in the export of woodchips from the mill would need to be consistent with arrangements agreed in the 1986 Memorandum of Understanding between the Commonwealth and Tasmania for the export of woodchips.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. It relates to the recently released National Bank and other business confidence surveys which show a slight improvement in confidence. There is serious concern in rural Australia that these surveys, based only on the top 500 public companies, will give the wrong signals to policy makers. My question is: can the minister confirm that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has recently undertaken farm surveys which show that between 20 and 25 per cent of farmers intend to leave the land within the next 10 years and another 20 to 25 per cent believe they are likely to leave the land within the next 10 years? Given the scale of the exodus over the next decade, which could be as high as 50 per cent, will the minister confirm the existence of this survey and will the minister immediately release this survey?

—I am advised that a survey of farmers was recently undertaken as part of the Commonwealth-state national drought policy. That survey was designed to develop a baseline for an assessment of the effectiveness of the property management planning program and to identify the attitudes and practices of farmers in their management of risk. It was conducted by a consultant in the field of market research, the so-called Solutions Through Research Group, in May 1993. The survey showed that 15 per cent of the farmers interviewed agreed with the statement that `The ways things are, I will be forced to leave the industry'. The survey also showed that 20 per cent of the surveyed group had serious doubts about their ability to survive on the land.

PARA.TAB: It has to be clearly understood that this survey is a snapshot of the attitudes of farmers at the time of the survey. These attitudes may well change over time. The results of the survey have been released to the relevant state and territory government bodies. The executive summary is available from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. However, I am happy to table the executive summary of that report now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. I remind the minister that in December last year the Senate passed an Australian Democrats' amendment which provided for the Commonwealth and the states to agree to a set of national health goals and targets during the first year of the Medicare agreement. What stage has this process reached? Secondly, what provisions has the government made for consumer input into this process? Finally, will the minister consider setting aside additional funds to enable the states to meet national mental health goals and targets in the light of yesterday's Burdekin report?

—The Commonwealth is moving on a number of fronts to try to look at more outcomes based assessments of health care. National health goals and targets is one of them. I mentioned earlier that in April-May of this year we had agreement from the states to have a national health policy. We have looked at four areas in particular where we might show some advance during the course of one year. They were: accident and injury, cardiovascular disease, cancer—breast cancer will be given some special attention within that—and mental illness.We are trying to get some progress on national policies, including goals and targets, during the course of that year.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, we set up a group on each of those four areas and we invited consumer input into them. As I understand it, the Public Health Association and the Consumers Health Forum were invited to send nominees to have an input into those groups. Otherwise those groups contain not only officials from the state and the Commonwealth, but also experts in each field. A report is due next May. We are trying to show some progress in a set of four areas so that, firstly, we know that it can be done and then, hopefully over a decade, we can make progress across the whole range.

Senator Lees also asked whether we will be setting aside additional funds to enable the states to meet national health goals and targets in the light of yesterday's report. I think it would be very difficult for any government, state or federal, to look at the Burdekin report and not realise that more money has to be spent. If more money has to be spent on a national mental health strategy or health goals and targets within it, it is inevitable that there will be some additional Commonwealth funds as a part of that. That is something we will have to look at in terms of our response that I referred to earlier and discuss with the states. In my view, the possibility of offering no extra funds in the light of the Burdekin report would be nil.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Is the minister aware that deaths from suicide exceed deaths from road trauma among rural youth? What is the association between suicide and youth unemployment, which has soared to record levels under this government?

—Certainly, I am aware that, by way of interjection, Senator Herron made that point in the last couple of days. I heard him say it. I have not had time to check the figures since. Senator Herron has now slightly qualified what he said by way of interjection by mentioning the word `rural'. I am glad of that because the statement did not sound right when he made it. That having been said, there is no question that there is a relationship—

PARA.TAB: Senator Herron—You didn't hear it, minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I may not have. I am only making a personal assessment. What I heard did not sound quite right; what the honourable senator now says does—I am not disputing it.

PARA.TAB: Undoubtedly, there must be a relationship between youth unemployment and suicide. I do not think any of us will ever know how to quantify it and say, `This many or this percentage of suicides are caused by unemployment'. Some will attempt to make estimates; I am not sure that any of us could ever be satisfied.

That there are high suicide rates amongst rural youth is a tragedy. Some areas in Victoria have experienced particular difficulties and I know that the Victorian government has sought to address them. For my part, I would be happy to engage in any program that can, first, research what the link might be and, secondly, see what we can do to ameliorate it. Undoubtedly, the best way to ameliorate any such link would be to get the economy moving again. If we can make sure that all of the budget bills get through, that will contribute to making that occur even faster.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware that nearly all rural youth who suicide are unemployed?

—The fact that a person is unemployed and commits suicide is significant. Nonetheless, one cannot then extrapolate and say that every person who committed suicide did so because he or she was unemployed. A whole range of family and personal considerations could cause individuals to take that kind of decision. I do not deny that there is a link but to try to suggest that in every case that must be it seems to me to be a pretty shallow analysis of the facts.

—My question is directed to Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. The minister would be aware that the recent Mabo debate has revealed a distinct lack of understanding by many people about the dispossession suffered by our indigenous people, about their cultures and about the strong association that they have with the land. What is the government doing through its cultural organisations to address this lack of understanding in the community?
—This is a very important question and it relates to a very important issue.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pity that nobody is prepared to allow it to be answered properly. Many honourable senators would know that a large number of cultural activities have been undertaken. These cultural activities are contributing to the reconciliation process and enhancing Australian recognition of the strength and value of Aboriginal culture. We all know about visual arts activities, performing arts, music and, probably most of all, the museum activity.

PARA.TAB: But I think what has been underestimated—this has just come to light in an exhibition which was launched yesterday—is the significant potential and role of the Australian Archives in this. In other countries, archives are recognised as a very important national collecting institution, but in Australia they have been ignored. One of our colleagues, Senator Reid, represents the Senate on the Advisory Council on the Australian Archives and she would be aware of this.

Yesterday, the exhibition Between two worlds was launched in Sydney. This is an Australian Archives exhibition about the Commonwealth government's removal of Aboriginal children of part descent in the Northern Territory. None of us can be proud when we look back and see what occurred. This very important national travelling exhibition of records, through oral histories, documents and photographs, presents a very small piece of a story of the dispossession of the Aboriginal people. The exhibition is another way of cultural institutions telling Australians in a relevant and effective manner the story of our land, the way it has developed and our history.

The exhibition shows, for example, how earlier this century thousands of Aboriginal people were taken away from their families and placed in institutions. Some were never to return home. It follows, in particular, six of those children. It also follows the development of Commonwealth government policy and practice in relation to the removal of Aboriginal children in the Northern Territory; and it reflects upon the practical and emotional difficulties which are directly attributable to that separation.

This is merely one way, but an important way, in which the government is furthering the process of reconciliation within Australia by providing an opportunity for Australians to learn about aspects of the social and political history of indigenous Australians in the 20th century. It can increase understanding of the issues affecting indigenous Australians today.

It is a question of learning more about our history to gain more capacity to understand the present and what we should do for the future. It is one of the things that I think informs intelligent judgment about matters like Mabo. It gives an insight into the impact of Commonwealth government administrations on indigenous Australians and may give some recognition of why compensatory measures are needed now. It will also give indigenous Australians a better understanding of the records that exist about them and their people and how they can get access to them.

Dates have already been scheduled for this exhibition to go to Canberra, Alice Springs, Darwin and Adelaide, and other states will also see the exhibition. It is just another example of cultural activities contributing to the social development of the nation and integrating with other areas of government policy and social policy in a way that reinforces the centrality of cultural activities in our life.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that the pilot who carried out the landing of the RAAF 707 at Fairbairn on Tuesday, and seriously damaged it in the process, was not the captain? If that is so, what was the status of the pilot? Was he fully endorsed on the aircraft type or was he under training or under supervision in any way?

—It would not surprise anyone in the Senate to learn that I am not personally acquainted with the qualifications of every pilot, but I will seek some clarification from the Royal Australian Air Force and give Senator MacGibbon an answer in due course.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that this was a special circumstance in so far as the aircraft was required next day to take the Prime Minister to Cyprus; that the conditions were very difficult, with a better than 20-knot cross-wind blowing; and the known fact that a 707 is hard to handle—not impossible, but hard to handle; and if, indeed, the pilot was not the captain, why did the captain allow someone else to land that aeroplane? While the minister is looking into the matter, could he provide the Senate with all the details pertaining to that particular flight?
—That was not really a supplementary; it was an amplification of the previous question and it could have been asked all at once; but, yes, I will.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the minister aware of recent media reports of increased non-smoking flights on international air services between Australia and the United Kingdom? Can the minister advise of any other developments in relation to the further extension of non-smoking international flights to Australia?
—Yes I have, and yes I can.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Smoking is only the start; we are going to lower the boom on booze and in-flight catering next. Qantas and British Airways have announced an increase in the number of smoke-free flights between the United Kingdom and Australia from 1 January 1994. Qantas has indicated that the announcement will enable passengers to travel to Singapore and in most cases all the way through to London in smoke-free aircraft. It is always encouraging to travel in smoke-free aircraft!

PARA.TAB: Qantas will introduce an additional 72 weekly smoke-free flights over a six-month trial which follows on from decisions announced last year that Qantas would ban smoking on several Sydney-Los Angeles flights. In addition, Qantas and Air New Zealand have over 200 smoke-free flights per week across the Tasman. British Airways—and this is significant—has announced that all of its flights between London and Australia will be smoke free for a three-month trial period commencing on 1 January 1994. I will certainly be interested to see what that does to the loadings on those aircraft.

Cathay Pacific is another international carrier which has established smoke-free flights to Australia from Hong Kong. On 1 August this year, Qantas introduced smoke-free flights on all flights of four hours or less to and from Australia, including services from the east coast to Fiji, Papua New Guinea, New Caledonia, and Perth-Bali services.

Australia is providing a great deal of leadership in this area. Honourable senators may recall that last year Australia and Canada successfully sponsored a resolution at the International Civil Aviation Organisation assembly which called on member states to restrict smoking on international air services with the objective of implementing a complete ban on smoking on international flights by 1 July 1996. Since that time, I am pleased to advise the Senate that the United States administration has proposed an agreement between the United States, Canada, New Zealand and Australia to ban smoking on all flights between these four countries. Australia is currently examining the best means of giving effect to this proposal ahead of the schedule set down by ICAO.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Given that the unemployment rate in the Glenroy region of Melbourne at 16.7 per cent is one of the highest in urban Australia and that only $1 of the Office of Labour Market Adjustment money has been spent on each unemployed person in Glenroy, why is it that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training has not responded to a request at the beginning of June this year by the Chief Executive Officer of the Broadmeadows Council to explain this imbalance?
—I am not acquainted with this issue, which would not surprise anyone here. But I will seek an answer from the minister and forward it to Senator Troeth.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs. Malaria, as the minister knows, is one of the major causes of high morbidity and mortality rates in less developed countries, including many in our area. In view of this, why has the government not given a higher priority to malaria control and to the development of vaccines or anti-bodies to alleviate this very serious problem?
—I am afraid that I do not have a brief on that matter before me. I will seek an answer and give Senator Harradine a very early reply.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the minister to the Prime Minister's four-page press release outlining the government's proposed Mabo package. Although the Prime Minister gushes eloquent about how historic the package will be, he makes no reference at all to the many thousands of kilometres of stock routes which are absolutely vital to the pastoral industry, and which are also an important part of Australia's heritage. As stock routes are crown land and may very well be subject to claim under the High Court's Mabo decision, why has there been no decision to specifically protect Australia's stock routes from claim? Is this an oversight? Does the government intend to protect the stock routes or not? Or is the package merely superficial?

—I do not believe there is any ground for anxiety on this front. Obviously, that is an interest that will need to be specifically protected and I am sure the legislation will address it, if legislation is necessary to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General and relates to the key role of Australia's corporate regulator, the Australian Securities Commission, in combating international securities market manipulation and other securities fraud. Could the minister inform the Senate of any action which has been taken by the government to assist the Australian Securities Commission in this task? In addition, could the minister advise what the Australian Securities Commission has done to facilitate future action in this important area?

—I am pleased to inform the Senate that in the last 24 hours the commission has entered into an historic mutual assistance agreement with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission. The effect of that agreement will be to strengthen the ASC's ability to pursue investigations across the Pacific and into one of the world's largest financial marketplaces. The agreement is especially significant, given the size of US investment in the Australian capital market already, and given the fact that that investment is poised for substantial growth as the balance of global economic power shifts towards the Pacific rim and, particularly through bodies such as APEC, forms closer economic links into the region. The government, of course, welcomes this commitment to fostering international cooperation in the regulation of securities markets, particularly as international barriers break down in the financial markets across the world.

PARA.TAB: The legal basis for this agreement, without which the agreement would not have been possible, is the Mutual Assistance in Business Regulations Act 1992. That act has already been the basis for a number of other agreements giving the ASC greatly improved access to other key markets, such as the United Kingdom last year and Hong Kong in the last month. This act complements the significant reforms to the regulation of companies and securities markets in Australia over the past three years. It also enables the ASC to play a greater role in the international market regulation.

We should note that the extent of the ASC's operation under this act is quite wide. The ASC can use its powers to gather information to help foreign securities regulators to combat market manipulation and other security fraud in their jurisdictions.

The government is appreciative of the work done by both the ASC and the Attorney-General's Department. We believe they should be congratulated on the work that has gone into the agreements, such as the one that was signed last night. We believe that they can only enhance Australia's reputation as a place to invest in the highly competitive world of securities markets. We believe that these steps represent a further move towards the creation of a more effective Australian market in which investors can be confident of the market's integrity and in which there are prospects of substantial growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the supplementary question asked of me by Senator MacGibbon on Monday of this week. The issues raised in his question are complex. I believe there have been some misunderstandings involving Senator MacGibbon's question as it relates to the requirements and administration of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: There are two elements to Senator MacGibbon's supplementary question. The first is the payment of a deployment allowance. This was reduced from $65 to $40 under a determination by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) on 8 October 1993 under section 58B of the Defence Act. It will be subject to normal parliamentary scrutiny and will be tabled in parliament within the prescribed statutory period. I am advised that it is due to reach the Table Office today and will be tabled soon.

This determination is made as a result of an approach from the ADF to the Department of Industrial Relations after a threat assessment by the Defence Intelligence Organisation. Therefore, the quantum of deployment allowance may change with any altered threat assessment made by the Defence Intelligence Organisation. I have asked the ADF to advise me on the frequency and regularity of such changes, but at this stage any change to a threat assessment would be likely to result in a review of the allowance quantum.

Currently, conditions for service for overseas deployments are authorised by different legislation—taxation through the Treasurer; the deployment allowance and additional recreation leave for remote locality through the Minister for Industrial Relations; and compensation through the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Earlier this year, cabinet agreed to a new framework of conditions of services for future overseas deployments of the ADF. The purpose of this change was to ensure that consistent and timely conditions of service could be established for ADF personnel employed in the future.

In future deployments, the Minister for Defence will consult with the Prime Minister and make a declaration that an ADF deployment is warlike or non-warlike. The conditions of service will then be set in accordance with that declaration. A centralised process will ensure simplicity and flexibility and enable a timely announcement of benefits to those involved in a deployment. No existing deployment is subject to the new framework that I announced.

In terms of the second issue raised by Senator MacGibbon—the amendment of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which was passed by the Senate last year—it is normal for a certificate associated with overseas deployments to be issued by the Chief of the Defence Force retrospectively. For the Cambodian deployment, this certificate will be to the effect that the member's allotment by the ADF relates to that member's service as part of elements of the United Nations forces in Cambodia. It is the intention of the CDF to issue such a certificate on completion of the withdrawal of the Australian forces from Cambodia.

As a certificate has not been issued, the question of revoking the certificate cannot apply. However, it is my intention that, when the certificate is provided, I will meet the spirit of the Opposition's amendment to the tax act by tabling the certificate in the Senate, though it will not be subject to disallowance.

Honourable senators should note that it is normal practice for the provision of tax exemptions to be done on the basis of the government's initial decision regarding a deployment and not when a certificate is issued. This is done in the interests of the service person getting timely access to the benefit that is involved. I would not want to change that process as it could be to the detriment of the individuals concerned.

I point out again that these issues are complex. I am happy to offer a full briefing from the ADF to Senator MacGibbon pertaining to any aspect of these matters that he cares to raise so that he can understand the proper sequence of events in relation to all these procedures.

Finally, I will deal with Senator MacGibbon's notice of motion. Ordinarily, it would be totally unacceptable to expect any minister to comply with a return to order within the time frame that Senator MacGibbon has attempted to impose on me. In fact, at 3.30 p.m. yesterday I gave leave for him to give notice of a motion which involved a return to order after question time today. In the event of Senator MacGibbon proceeding with his motion, which I assume he probably will not now do, I make the point that in nearly all circumstances I would strongly resist such a move because of the unreasonable timetable that was involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —At question time yesterday, I undertook to obtain further advice for Senator Reynolds on the progress of negotiations on the Wik land claim. I am advised that the situation is as follows. Commonwealth officers have been holding exploratory discussions with Queensland government officials, representatives of the Wik people and Comalco to determine the willingness of the parties to negotiate and the matters which might be the subject of negotiation. These discussions are continuing with a view to entering into formal negotiations as soon as practicable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), to a question without notice asked by Senator Newman this day, relating to mental health and the Burdekin report.

SPEECH.PARA: The response of the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) to my question about the Burdekin report and mental illness indicated that he seemed to have misunderstood the question. I was drawing attention to the relationship between family breakdown, dysfunctional families, and mental illness, which is very clearly spelt out in Mr Burdekin's report. I asked why the government, in areas of its responsibility, had not given higher priority to developing a national strategy to minimise family breakdown.

PARA.TAB: The minister told the Senate that we could not hold the government responsible for family breakdown. I did not say that the government was responsible for family breakdown, although—

TALK.START.PARA: —You implied it.

—I did not, if the minister wants to have a look at my question. Now that he puts it on the agenda, I have to say that I do hold him responsible to some extent, because any government that has held the financial reins for 10 years, and has allowed so many families to be in such dire financial difficulties as a result of the recession and this extraordinary unemployment rate which will not go, has to be held accountable for the stress and the mental illness that flow from financial strains. Many Australian families—over 40,000 in a year—break up simply because of the financial stress on them. So while I was not in my question making that point, I certainly do now in response to what the minister said.

PARA.TAB: The minister went on and gave the Senate some information that I was not really asking about. I remember his mentioning a figure of something like $135 million that was being spent on mental health. The unfortunate thing for the minister—and maybe I will give him the benefit of the doubt; he does not really know—is that that $135 million was already committed to being spent. It was just repackaged so it looked as though the government was doing something new. Perhaps the minister ought to look at that issue while he is learning his new job.

Another thing is that if this government were really concerned about the problems of the mentally ill, perhaps it would start giving some meaningful resources to those organisations in the community which are trying to do something for the mentally ill and which have been trying to do that without much support from government for a very long time. I am concerned, particularly because of the portfolios that I hold of both family and health, at the relationship between family breakdown and mental illness.

Mr Burdekin has spelled it out in great detail. In the report he said there was a great deal of evidence concerning the distressing and disturbing effect that parental arguments and domestic violence have on children. He said that not only was it distressing for children but also it might lead to mental illness problems such as depression. He said that family disharmony was a major contributor to child mental illness. He said that poor parenting, lack of involvement with and supervision of children, household disorganisation and marital disharmony all increased the risk of mental illness. That was for adults as well as for children. He said that there was an obvious link between the dysfunctional families and mental illness.

I wanted to know why it was that this government, over 10 years, had not put more resources into the area of protecting and supporting these families, helping them to stay intact; in other words, preventing mental illness. That was the essence of the first part of my question; it was totally ignored by the minister.

The second part of my question related to our responsibilities to the mentally ill in terms of protection of their rights. The minister twice was given an opportunity to address that issue. Twice he failed totally to refer to it. It is interesting to note that in 1980 we ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and we incorporated that instrument and others in the Commonwealth Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act in 1986. Yet the Burdekin report itself demonstrates that this government is in breach of its own legislation, in breach of that act. Senator Richardson would not even address that. That says a lot, I guess. He is guilty by virtue of the fact that he would not come to grips with it.

I draw the Senate's attention to principle 1.4 of the United Nations principles of the protection of persons with mental illness and for the improvement of mental care. That principle says that every person with a mental illness shall have a right to exercise all civil, political, economic, social and cultural rights, et cetera; I do not have time to go on. This government, which likes to talk about independence, is constantly telling us of our responsibilities under international covenants and treaties. Given half a chance here, it will not do it. In relation to Mabo we are told that it is very important that we do not breach our international obligations on racial discrimination. When it comes to looking after the rights of the mentally ill this government has failed them utterly. Why? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did say when Senator Newman asked her question that it was an extraordinary question. It was disappointing, to say the least. I noted this morning that Dr Brendan Nelson from the AMA, when commenting on this report, said he hoped it would not become some kind of political football, that we would not seek to point fingers of blame everywhere and that we would see what we could do about it. As usual, when it comes to Senator Newman, I do not think she is big enough to understand that this is not the kind of argument where one simply points the finger.
—I am not as big as you, and you are trying to get smaller, aren't you?

—That kind of interjection sums Senator Newman up in almost every respect. What really disturbs me is that I could have made a partisan attack against a number of states that have been particularly poor in their provision of services. I did not because to do so would detract from the kind of response that the community needs to have to the Burdekin report.

PARA.TAB: I could have pointed out that the only mention of mental illness in Fightback is where it suggests that we should have a national mental health policy which, in any event, the governments of Australia agreed to a year ago. As usual, the train pulled out of the station and members of the opposition were still sitting on the platform. They have not managed to do a thing, and that is normal. I chose not to make such a partisan attack because I hope most of us, including most people in Senator Newman's party, can think with a little broader vision than Senator Newman.

I hope that others do not seek to run around and say that the government is to blame for family breakdown, which is a nonsense. Obviously, in economically difficult times, extra strains will be placed on families. But strains come on families for a whole range of reasons. It just disappoints me that Senator Newman has to think along those lines. She spoke about the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. If any group had a real hide and gall even to even mention it, it would be the opposition. The opposition has bucketed the concept of international covenants for years and years. Every single time we have sought to sign up with a United Nations covenant, the opposition has opposed it. Its record is 100 per cent. The fact that that occurs is obvious to us all.

What worries me is that whatever covenants we sign, when it comes to attempting to implement them, there is often a great barrier to implementation in Australia—the constitution.
