It is a barrier because very often the Commonwealth can cajole, push and shove but it does not necessarily control, obviously, in a whole range of areas. The one about which we are speaking now is a classic example.

Over the coming years, the Commonwealth's role in mental health, as we work towards trying to implement a national strategy—particularly with some states that are slacking off in their efforts—will be to embarrass them and try to make them take further steps along the road to delivering proper funding. It is no secret that there have been savage cuts in a whole range of community services in virtually every state during the 1980s. It is one of the areas that was easiest to cut because the mentally ill were easier to forget than others. That has happened right around Australia.

Instead of pointing any partisan bone at any state government, the Commonwealth ought to be looking at them all and seeing how we can do better—just for once. This is a bit more important than that kind of basic ordinary response of Senator Newman's. What is required now is a bit of vision. Vision is in short supply on the other side of the house; there will still be a bit of it over here.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), to a question without notice asked by Senator Herron this day, relating to youth suicide rates in rural areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson is a great one to pontificate about the opposition and attack us because of questions that are asked of him. He gives out this aura of a complete knowledge of his subject. He did not have a clue today; he was not aware that a very tragic situation of youth suicide exists in rural towns in this country. It is mentioned in the Burdekin report that he pretended that he had read. I refer him to page 638 of the Burdekin report under the heading `Rural young people', which states:
The most alarming increase in male youth suicide rates has been in rural areas and small towns:

The rural rates have gone up substantially, particularly in the smaller country towns and farming communities. They have gone up about four-fold, from about 1.4 per 100,000 to about 5.7 per 100,000 . . .
I relate that to research that was done by the Child and Adolescent Psychiatric Unit of the Prince of Wales Hospital in Sydney. On the Daybreak program, it was stated:

It's one of the more tragic aspects of the fallout from the collapse in our rural sector and the growth in joblessness; that is the soaring increase in Australia's youth suicide rate, particularly in Australia's country towns. There's been a five-fold increase in teenage suicides in country towns, over the past 20 years . . . girls, young Australian women, between the ages of 15 and 19, are more likely to attempt death than any other age group in this country.

As I mentioned in my question, the actual number of deaths of young people from suicide in rural towns is higher than the number of deaths from road accidents. The minister cannot wash his hands of that evidence and say that it is unrelated to joblessness. Professor Brent Waters says of suicides among children or teenagers in country towns:
. . . almost all of them were unemployed.

There are obviously other factors as Senator Richardson said. The Burdekin report mentions that suicides with guns and the availability of guns in rural areas is associated with depression in rural areas, which in turn is associated with unemployment. Again the Burdekin report mentions the levels of domestic violence, parental alcohol consumption and higher personal alcohol consumption by youth in country towns. There are obviously other factors involved.

PARA.TAB: In addition to that, the Burdekin report says that there is a lack of access to health services including mental health resources. That was the point that Senator Newman was referring to—the lack of access to mental health services in rural areas. There is a direct relationship between that and unemployment and depression in rural communities. There is an association. More than 90 per cent of youths who suicide in country towns are unemployed. To quote Professor Waters again, `almost all of them were unemployed'. The Burdekin report refers to this as `a socioeconomic factor'.

This is a tragedy of our community. It is something that needs to be addressed. I am hoping to highlight this tragedy so that when the Burdekin report is replied to—as Senator Gareth Evans indicated it would be at the beginning of next year—this aspect of suicide can be dealt with. Interestingly enough, the suicide rates in Australia have not changed much overall in the 50 years since the Second World War, but there has been a differential increase in youth suicide.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledged in the answer that I gave to Senator Herron in question time that there was a link. I do not dispute that for a second. I repeat what I said in question time that none of us will ever be able to directly correlate the two. Certainly there is a link and that is a matter of concern. It means that there does need to be access to services in rural Australia but at the moment there is precious little access. That is the chronic problem.

PARA.TAB: How do we address that problem? I suggest that there are probably two ways. The counselling services are provided by the states. Some states provide those services better than others. Some states hardly provide them at all. We will certainly need to talk to the states about better provision of those services. It is inevitable that that will be included in the response to the Burdekin report that the government will bring down next year.

Also a matter of considerable concern I would have thought is how many psychiatrists, for example, we have in rural areas. We have precious few. I am going to talk to the Royal College of Psychiatrists, as I talk to other colleges, in order to try to make sure that we get a better distribution and we have a rostering service by which we get people out to rural areas. I am encouraged by the responses of colleges to this. Over the next few years we can do a lot better than we have done by taking a cooperative approach with them. Hopefully that can be delivered in psychiatry too. It is the provision of those services that we will have to worry about in responding to the Burdekin report.

I intend to push as hard as I can, given that I am not directly responsible for mental health policy—that is the responsibility of my colleague Brian Howe—to get these services out of the cities and into the bush. That raises another question: there are not enough services in the cities either. The Burdekin report shows that there is a paucity of services right across the nation. That is something we will have to address with every state and territory.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), to a question without notice asked by Senator Denman this day, relating to the human pituitary hormone program and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson will be pleased to know that in no sense do I wish to attack the government over this matter. As he quite rightly pointed out in his answer, the supply of the particular hormone preparation to these patients goes back a very long time and covers very many governments.

PARA.TAB: I make a couple of points. The minister may have been told that patients have found it relatively easy to get information about what they have been treated with, the batch numbers and so on. My experience with the spouses of those who have died from this disease is that they have not found it so easy to get that information. While I believe that no claim should lie against CSL—it prepared this material in good faith at the time and it did not know that a potential for disease was associated with the product—I think that, when there is a new treatment such as this which could possibly carry a long-term risk, there should be a responsibility on CSL to keep proper records of the patients who were treated, the batch numbers and so on, so that they could be followed up.

That bears on the second point I want to make. While, as far as I am aware, nobody has identified the agent which is responsible for the Creutzfeldt-Jakob syndrome, it seems to be behaving rather like the slow viruses. There is a very long interval between the exposure to the agent and the appearance of the disease, although when the disease appears it progresses quite rapidly.

Under those circumstances, not only it is necessary to keep those records for a long time, but it is extremely dangerous to either give assurances of safety or give assurances that the material is unsafe. We do not know yet how many patients may subsequently go on to develop this disease. I simply caution against giving overly optimistic assurances of safety when many of these patients are still alive and may go on and develop the disease or, alternatively, saying that the risks are very high. The most honest thing to do is to say that we do not know. It is a situation which is very similar to that of exposure to cancer causing agents, where in some instances there is a long interval of 15, 20, 25 or 30 years between exposure and the appearance of the disease. Very often records are not properly kept. Therefore, very often we do not have the data. Assurances of safety are based on ignorance rather than real knowledge.

It comes back to this matter of patients being given the correct information. They should be told: yes, they have been treated with this agent; yes, it was batch number so and so; so far there have been no patients appearing associated with that batch number; yes, there have been; this is the current assessment of risks. It should then be left to them. I do not think that doctors, the government or anybody else should be paternalistic in this matter. Patients should be given the full information. It is for them to determine whether they become concerned about it or whether they accept that the risks are well worth while. I know of one woman patient who, before she subsequently died from the disease, said that, despite the effect of the treatment, having children made it well worth while. I think it is for patients to make those decisions—not governments, doctors or anybody else.

TALK.START.PARA: —When batch numbers are requested, we will give them out when we know which ones are appropriate. The difficulty is that we know which batch numbers were approved for use on some individuals—not for all—and we can give those out. However, we cannot guarantee that they were the batch numbers that were actually used on them. It would appear that the way this exercise was conducted so many years ago was probably not up to the standard that we would expect today. So there are uncertainties about what batch numbers were used. That is why I find it difficult to say to someone, `You do not need to worry; nothing has happened with your batch number'. There is no guarantee that that was the batch that was used.

PARA.TAB: So exactly in line with what the honourable senator was saying about trying not to be overly optimistic or overly pessimistic, we have tried to explain to people that simply knowing a batch number does not necessarily mean very much. One of the most difficult things is trying to explain to women, in particular, because they are mostly the ones who are affected. They are concerned and worried. When they come in to talk, one cannot really allay their fears. All I can do is, through the inquiry, expose them to all of the information that we have and then, as the honourable senator says, allow the patients to make up their own minds.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Faulkner) to a question without notice asked by Senator MacGibbon on 18 October 1993 relating to defence force personnel in Cambodia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Faulkner was quite right when he said that this was a very complex issue. If he finds it complex, with all the resources of a ministerial department behind him, he should try dealing with this matter without any extra staff and as a backbencher who knows nothing about anything. I can assure him that it is very much harder for us.

PARA.TAB: Putting this in context, last year we passed through this parliament certain conditions applying to service of the Australian defence forces in Cambodia. The principal point there was the provision of an allowance of $65 a day tax free. This was changed a week or so ago to $40 taxable. When Senator Faulkner made his response, he talked about threat assessments and the reasons why the determination was changed. That is a very important point and something that we do not have time to look at today.

I want to stick to the point as to how the change was legally made, not the reasons for it. The legislation went through on 17 June 1992. Page 3843 of the Senate Hansard shows that Senator Newman moved two amendments. The first amendment required a certificate establishing the tax-free status to be tabled in the Senate; and the second provided that, if the conditions were changed, the certificate which changed those conditions had to be tabled. The clear intent of that—this was supported by the Senate and it therefore became law; it is part of the act—was that the Senate had a right to override the decision of the executive government. That seems to be the point that has been frustrated by the procedures outlined by Senator Faulkner.

As I understand it, Senator Faulkner is telling the Senate that the conditions for allowances that the government declared earlier in the year somehow do not apply to the contingents that are currently overseas. The Cambodian deployment clearly was overseas. If one reads the Hansard report of Mr Bilney's contribution last year in the House of Representatives, this is quite clear. The words `the force in Cambodia' are used all the time. So Senator Faulkner's argument is in conflict with the facts.

Senator Faulkner also put to the Senate that somehow or other the Chief of the Defence Force can issue a certificate retrospectively. I understood him to say that at some time in the future the CDF will issue a certificate which validates the fact that the ADF was in Cambodia and therefore entitled to tax-free status. What is the point of having in the act the requirement that the certificates be tabled if at some time 12 or 18 months in the future one can comply with that requirement by tabling a certificate? I always understood that law was based on facts, not on intentions. If we are going to operate this way, on the basis of the government having the intention of doing something, then I think the Auditor-General ought to look at what is happening.

The very important point here relates to the morale of the troops. The Australians in Cambodia really feel that they were tricked by a bit of smart politics. The 110 or 120 volunteers who stayed behind after 12 months service to man the rearguard post believed, rightly or wrongly, that their conditions of service would be precisely the same as they had experienced for the previous 12 months. Indeed, it is an extraordinary coincidence that on the day that the great majority of the contingent left, on 7 October, the new requirement—the change from $65 tax-free to $40 taxable—was put in place. They feel tricked.

It is not the money so much that those troops are concerned about, they are really worried about their entitlements under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. They do not know where they are. If they are injured on service, are they covered for compensation? A whole host of things like that is very important to these people. Finally, while the minister is at it, I may be quite wrong in this, but after reading subsection 58B of the Defence Act 1903, I wonder whether the minister has any legal entitlement to make the determinations that he has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —I did try to clarify this for Senator MacGibbon a little earlier. I did say that it was complex and that is why I offered Senator MacGibbon a briefing by the ADF. I think he would have genuinely benefited from that. I am not being critical in saying that. It is extraordinarily difficult to determine—
—But I only heard your invitation for a briefing this afternoon.

—I am aware of that. The amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 that Senator MacGibbon refers to were moved by Senator Newman on the date that he gave. They are there in black and white. These particular amendments, as I have tried to explain to him, relate to a certificate of revocation. There were two amendments. The first, 23AC(2A), concerns a certificate of revocation:

SPEECH.PARA: `(2A)A certificate issued in accordance with paragraph (2)(cb) shall cease to have force only in accordance with a certificate of revocation signed by the Chief of the Defence Force.

The second amendment moved by Senator Newman was to make such a certificate of revocation a disallowable instrument. That is the import of the two amendments which, as Senator MacGibbon said, were passed by this Senate and the parliament as amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act.

PARA.TAB: What I have tried to explain to Senator MacGibbon is this: a certificate of revocation of a certificate of allotment does not have any basis in this particular circumstance, because a certificate of allotment will only be issued by the CDF after the troops return home from Cambodia. A certificate of revocation is to revoke a certificate of allotment. The only disallowable instrument is the certificate of revocation. Hence, when the instrument is provided, in the spirit of what Senator Newman attempted to do, I have said I will table the certificate from the CDF as soon as is practicable and, I might say, in accordance with the way and within the time it has always been done in the past. For example, when the troops returned from the Gulf War, the last return to Australia was on 9 June 1991 and the certificate was issued by CDF on 19 June 1991. This is the usual procedure. It is done retrospectively and it is done so that the entitlements of the Australian personnel are protected.

When making its decision to commit members of the ADF to serve with UNTAC, the government clearly did recognise that those members would be in a high risk situation. The decision was made to designate Cambodia an operational area from 20 October 1991. Service in an operational area attracts the highest possible coverage under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. All Australian Defence Force personnel who were allotted for service in Cambodia with UNTAC and who served in Cambodia while it was an operational area are certainly eligible to apply for disability pension and service pension under the VEA. Any claim for disability pension for injury, disease or death which occurs while a member of the ADF is on operational service is decided on the more generous reasonable hypothesis standard of proof.

When Cambodia ceases to be an operational area members of the ADF who remain there will be on hazardous service. They will still be eligible for the disability pension with the reasonable hypothesis standard of proof applying also under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Members on hazardous service are also eligible to apply for compensation benefits under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. I do offer, again, to provide a briefing on these complex issues. I suggest to Senator MacGibbon that he take up my offer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have a couple of concerns about this. My recollection—and I must say it is now more than a year, 15 or so months, since I moved those amendments—is that we were drawing on the experience of the troops who were allocated for service in Namibia. My recollection is that, while we had had 10 years to prepare for the troops to go to Namibia, it was only on the eve of their being sent away that their package of conditions was finalised. They were allocated for service not very long afterwards.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, I acknowledge that they are not always allocated just before they go away, but it is usually not very long afterwards. It is quite extraordinary in this case that a long time has passed since the troops were first posted to Cambodia and we do not have a certificate of allocation yet.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the way it has always been done.

—No. It does stretch the bounds of credibility. It was the very intent of the parliament that these service people be protected—because of experience in the past. My speech in that debate was very clear: we did not believe that financial considerations would not be the driving ones. We did not believe that the government decision would not be made.
—You thought a certificate of revocation ended a deployment.
—Or change the terms of the employment; one or the other.
—You thought it was issued at the end of a deployment.

—No. This was a second certificate. The minister is obviously under a misapprehension. It was a revocation of the allocation. Therefore, for the government to tell us now, all this time later, that the certificate of allocation has not been made leads the Senate, quite reasonably, to suspect that this is a device designed to get around the amendments that were passed by the parliament to that income assessment act. It confirms the very real concerns that I expressed in the debate on those amendments.

PARA.TAB: The government has justified our concerns. If the government is proceeding down this track, the servicemen would have every reason to feel totally cheated by the government. Those amendments were made to protect them, so that it was their Chief of the Defence Force who determined that the situation was no longer hazardous and, therefore, their conditions should change.

TALK.START.PARA: —You moved a meaningless amendment to the act.

—The minister mumbles, but I am trying to explain to him the background to this when he was not the minister, why I am now concerned at the explanation that was given today, why servicemen feel cheated and why we should, quite reasonably, feel that a device has been used to get around those amendments of last year.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —To give Senator Hill time to arrive, I will explain to the committee what I understand to be perhaps the best procedure for dealing with this bill. I spoke to Senator Hill earlier. As the committee would be aware, a lot of amendments to the previous bill were considered. A lot of the amendments before us are different in wording but mirror in substance and intent exactly those which were considered in relation to the excise tariff bill.

PARA.TAB: I understand the agreement to be—Senator Hill can confirm this—that he will move his amendments in two batches. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on matters which are not to do with requests; they are matters which I raised yesterday when opening the debate in relation to both these bills. I would seek some clarification from the minister on four matters.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday we discussed the size of the bounty per litre. The government has agreed to a 17 1/2c per litre bounty on the ethanol which would be used to make gasohol. I put to the minister yesterday that, since that agreement had been struck, I had received from industry an indication that that amount was sitting right on the very border of profitability; and I also got a guarantee from the industry which is currently producing gasohol that 18c would certainly cause it to go into production. I made a request then that the government give consideration to moving from the 17 1/2c bounty to 18c, but keeping the actual amounts in each year—the $6 million, $8 million and $11 million in 1993-94, 1994-95 and 1995-96—at the same level. That is the first question, and I hope the minister has received a response back.

I also said that all the indications are that a 2c differential between leaded and unleaded fuel was the level of difference which everybody advised us was necessary to get a change in behaviour. I suggested, without in any way changing either the impact on those who use leaded fuel or the revenue to government, that the government give some consideration to modifying the timing of the introduction of these changes so that the 2c might come in all at once. One way I suggested that that might happen is that in February next year the 1c increase in the price of unleaded fuel would not proceed and that at some time, probably about 1 June, the increase of 2c on both fuels be adopted so that the price differential of 2c be maintained right through.

The third matter on which I would seek some assurance relates to the last two points in the letter which was incorporated in Hansard yesterday. Those points are a direct reflection of the government's own letter to me. The first point is that the government will give favourable consideration to further funds being provided in the next budget for lead abatement programs, the amount to be subject to further investigation and discussion. I would like an assurance that the government will give a firm commitment to that.

The second point is that the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services (Mr Howe), the Minister for Transport and Communication (Senator Collins) and the Minister for the Environment, Sports and Territories (Mrs Kelly), in conjunction with the states, will give consideration to ways of improving the efficiency and effectiveness of public transport. I think we would certainly seek some assurance from the government on that one, particularly in view of the fact that, as we understand from a meeting last night, the five-year allocation to public transport has been completed. We would like to see the government give very serious consideration to a continuation of that assistance to the public transport program. So those four matters are: the 17 1/2c to 18c; the 2c all at once; the public transport; and the lead abatement.

Finally, earlier in debate I raised with the minister the fact that throughout Australia country people are paying more for petrol than city people. The experience in South Australia is that although a fuel freight subsidy scheme has been put in place by the state government, country people are still paying a lot more. I understand that the government is carrying out an investigation into this differential. After the figures are in, the government should give very serious consideration to attempting to legislate in such a way that country people at least enjoy exactly the same price as city people pay. They should not be used simply as pawns, as it seems they are at the moment, in a price war game in the metropolitan areas.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can provide some advice on all those four matters, although not on everything that I think Senator Coulter would like. But we think the two increases will come into effect sufficiently quickly and, with the education and the public awareness that has already been generated, we think that should have the desired impact.

I cannot give any forward commitments about expenditure in next year's budget; it is never possible to do that. There is a lot of interest and debate in the government and across the nation about certain matters, particularly public transport. But, even if the budget were to be brought down tomorrow, I could not give a commitment. Given that that is at least seven months away—depending on one's view about when it is to be introduced; it may be 10—I certainly cannot do that.

There are a couple of inquiries, as Senator Coulter said, that are relevant—the Industry Commission inquiry into petroleum retailing; and a continuing Prices Surveillance Authority brief on freight differentials. We will continue to look at those. I do not think it is conceivable that we will legislate to abolish differences. There are some reasonable differences and there are some unreasonable differences. What we do is monitor whether the differences are reasonable, and we will continue to do that. Where we see that there might be an unreasonable distinction, we would be disposed to take some action.

Anybody who lives in Canberra and listens to the ABC must know that such differences are always a cause of some potential for publicity and agitation. But it does not necessarily mean that the government can in some way—even if the Commonwealth had the power, which I think is a bit arguable—legislate to abolish the difference. But we will continue—the Industry Commission inquiry in particular may well raise some interesting points about petroleum retailing, and we will have a look at that when the report comes down—to see whether there is some action that we can take.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments are similar in impact and intent to the amendments I moved to the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. I was at the same meeting that Senator Coulter attended last night. I want to reiterate that it is of concern to the Greens that the funding for real programs in terms of car use is winding down. The same kind of thing is happening to the better cities program.

PARA.TAB: The debate in relation to petrol and fuel excise during this budget program has largely centred on levels of lead, but it would be difficult for anyone to be blind to the fact that the problems that exist with car use are general emissions, the level of greenhouse gas, the whole value system in which we continue to allow cars to be the major form of transportation, and the fact that we continue to design our cities to make more and more people dependent on cars.

The government's current policy and the opposition's continued emphasis on deregulating wages and conditions and on competing in the international market mean that fewer people have the income to support small businesses. Therefore, as a consumer I often find that I have to go further and further to get to goods and services of a specialised nature, whether it is clothing or articles for the household. So our economic and social policies are working in exactly the wrong way.

We have to go to centres to get specialised goods. Often companies cannot afford to hold stocks any more because in the last few years we have so much emphasised that what we are doing is pushing economic policy towards an export market and forgetting that the people who are workers are also the people who buy our goods and services on the local market. We are actually requiring people to be more dependent on cars. People who cannot afford expensive cars continue to buy cars which have higher levels of emission, including higher lead emission rates.

We emphasise that it is not good enough for the government to mainly concentrate on the consumer side. Last night the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) said that the petroleum industry in Australia was not prepared to put the money in to fund a comprehensive program for lead abatement; that it was providing some services towards it but could not be talked into providing funding for a more comprehensive program. So it has come back to the consumer and to an education program.

I get particularly annoyed with the fact that we will put up with lower standards than other countries would put up with. Whether or not it is a highly industrialised, highly capitalist oriented country such as the United States or Japan, the standards that industry is expected to produce are often much better than the standards that we in Australia are prepared to put up with. I think that is disgraceful. Like the Australian Democrats, the Greens will be watching very closely. We will continue to push for proper levels of funding to be provided for a real continuation of the better cities program to look at the equity considerations of housing, public transport and infrastructure that actually assist in providing a strategy in the medium to long term for a decrease in the dependence on car transport in Australia.

A lead education program certainly has some benefits, but it is not enough—and it is taking the heat off industry, which also has a responsibility. Industry is not going to do it unless we ask it to. I was also shocked to find that the minister for the environment indicated that if the levels could be reduced simply by consumer behaviour, there was no need to put pressure on industry to improve its act. I think that is accepting second best on behalf of the health and environment of Australia. It certainly is not indicating that this government currently believes that these considerations are important. We will be watching very carefully. I moved my amendments because I would like to think that the government will endorse its own policies. We have done nothing here except ask it to commit itself to its own policies.
