TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Japan's defence and security in the 1990s. I seek leave to incorporate the document and a tabling statement in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Statement on Tabling the Government's Response to the Report by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Senator the Hon Gareth Evans QC, Minister for Foreign Affairs

SPEECH.PARA: I hereby table the government's response to the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Japan's Defence and Security in the l990s. The report was released on 30 June.

The report's findings and recommendations make a valuable contribution to the debate about Japan's future defence and security role in the region and to policy formulation with regard to the development of Australia's bilateral relationship with Japan in these areas. The report also contributes to the continuing efforts of the government to encourage the further consolidation of a security dialogue among the countries of our region.
The government agrees with the general conclusions of the committee in describing the emerging regional security environment and the response of Japan to these developments.
In general, and in accordance with the current objectives of Australian foreign and security policies, the government accepts the recommendations of the committee calling for Australia to:
continue actively to encourage the development of a regional security dialogue.
expand dialogue with Japan on regional security issues including on UN peacekeeping, secure access to sea lines of communication, regional arms control and peaceful uses of nuclear energy,

PARA.TAB: -but maintaining military exchanges between Australia and Japan at about the current level.

SPEECH.PARA: encourage the United States to maintain and articulate a strong commitment to the security of Japan and the region.
facilitate more constructive political and economic engagement between Japan and the rest of the region, and to allay regional concerns about Japan's role.

The government accepts a wider role for Japan on regional issues. For the foreseeable future, this role is likely to be confined to strengthening the resilience of regional countries through trade, aid and investment, peacekeeping and participation in the emerging regional security dialogue process. In this regard, Japanese objectives are consistent with Australian policy, which is to encourage an enhanced Japanese role in international and regional affairs more commensurate with its status as the world's second economic power and in line with Japanese domestic opinion and regional sentiments. Australia will continue to reflect this in its closer dialogue with Japan on regional affairs and in the gradual increase in bilateral defence contacts.
JAPAN'S DEFENCE AND SECURITY IN THE 1990s
Government's Response to the Report by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade
presented by Senator the Hon Gareth Evans QC, Minister for Foreign Affairs

PARA.TAB: The decision by the Senate in September 1992 to direct the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to conduct an inquiry into Japan's defence policies, with reference to Japan's security concerns, defence force size and structure, constitutional and other limitations and Japan's role in United Nations peacekeeping, was welcomed by the Government. The inquiry was undertaken at a time of increasing public debate, both in Japan and elsewhere, with Japan increasingly being encouraged to take on a more active role in the Asia-Pacific region commensurate with its economic status and in line with its increasing assumption of international responsibilities, and at a time when the role of UN peacekeeping operations as a tool in addressing conflict was taking on growing importance.

The Committee's findings and recommendations make a valuable contribution to the debate about Japan's future defence and security role in the region and to policy formulation with regard to the development of Australia's bilateral relationship with Japan in these areas. The Report also contributes to the continuing efforts of the Government to encourage the further consolidation of a security dialogue among the countries of our region.
The Government agrees with the general conclusions of the Committee in describing the emerging regional security environment and the response of Japan to these developments.
The Japan-United States military alliance has become more significant in maintaining a balance of power in the region in the post-Cold War era;

Japan will continue the modest expansion of its defence forces and its regional security profile, although it acknowledges the ambivalence of other regional countries to this until it is seen to atone fully for its wartime behaviour. Japan is also likely to continue to raise its regional security profile to guard against any weakening in the United States' commitment to its defence and in response to ongoing pressures for burden-sharing, but it will do this without developing threatening military capabilities that would provoke regional sensitivities. Japan is also likely increasingly to pursue other political and economic means to enhance its own and the region's security, drawing on its powerful economic connections and as a major source of development aid in the region.

The Government also acknowledges the overall conclusion of the Committee that the expected changes in Japan's defence policies and activities should be directed to global and regional peace and security objectives and in identifying a role for Australia in helping shape the region's approach to security and in facilitating dialogue with Japan and between Japan and the region.
In general, and in accordance with the current objectives of Australian foreign and security policies, the Government accepts the recommendations of the Committee calling for Australia to:
continue actively to encourage the development of a regional security dialogue.
expand dialogue with Japan on regional security issues including on UN peacekeeping, secure access to sea lines of communication, regional arms control and peaceful uses of nuclear energy,

TAB.TAB: but maintaining military exchanges between Australia and Japan at about the current level.

PARA.TAB: encourage the United States to maintain and articulate a strong commitment to the security of Japan and the region.
facilitate more constructive political and economic engagement between Japan and the rest of the region, and to allay regional concerns about Japan's role.

A wider regional role for Japan, including a security dimension, should not give rise to concern. This role is, for the foreseeable future, likely to be confined to strengthening the resilience of regional countries through trade, aid and investment, peacekeeping and participation in the emerging regional security dialogue process. In this regard, Japanese objectives are consistent with Australian policy, which is to encourage an enhanced Japanese role in international and regional affairs more commensurate with its status as the world's second economic power and in line with Japanese domestic opinion and regional sentiments. Australia will continue to reflect this in its closer dialogue with Japan on regional affairs and in the gradual increase in bilateral defence contacts.
Following is the Government's response to the individual recommendations of the Report by the Committee on Japan's Defence and Security in the 1990s:

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 1

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government continue to actively encourage the development of regional security dialogue aimed at confidence building, promoting greater transparency, strengthening arms control measures and developing cooperative regional security activities in the Asia-Pacific region. In this context the Committee particularly welcomes:
the recent commitment by the United States to multilateral regional security dialogue;
statements by Japanese leaders supporting regional security dialogue;
the growing acceptance in the region of the importance of the ASEAN-PMC dialogue process; and
ASEAN's invitation to Russia and China to participate in future security discussions.
Response

The Government attaches great importance to encouraging the further development of a regional security dialogue. In December 1989, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, delivered a Ministerial Statement on Australia's Regional Security to the Senate. While a number of events affecting the region's overall security environment have taken place since then, the analyses and responses outlined in that Statement remain valid and continue to form the basis for efforts by Australia to promote security in the Asia-Pacific region.

The security outlook in the Asia-Pacific region is much more fluid now than it has been for almost four decades. The end of the Cold War, the rapid economic growth of North-East and South-East Asia and the continued impact of nationalism have brought about major changes. This new fluidity has created many opportunities, but it has also given rise to a number of uncertainties.

On the positive side, recent reaffirmation by the United States' Administration of its strategic commitment to the region is most welcome and should allay regional fears of a precipitate draw-down of forward-deployed US military forces in the Asia-Pacific region. Japan too has made adjustments to its post-Cold War situation and to growing expectations of a more active role in regional affairs. Settlement of the Cambodia conflict removes a long-standing source of tension and division. Both Australia and Japan played an important part in that settlement. Recent moves toward closer links between the Indochinese states and the ASEAN countries also open the way for the political and economic reintegration of the Indochinese countries into the region. Although current progress in lacking, recent steps toward rapprochement on the Korean Peninsula are an encouraging development which, if fulfilled, should promote regional stability.

Nevertheless, the failure by the Democratic People's Republic of Korea to end suspicions about the intent of its nuclear program by allowing unfettered access by international inspectors poses a serious threat to regional security and threatens to undermine the integrity of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT). This problem underlines the importance of international action to prevent proliferation of weapons of mass destruction (WMD), an area in which Australia has committed significant effort in encouraging continuing commitment to the NPT, conclusion of the Chemical Weapons Convention and effective WMD export controls.

Unresolved territorial disputes, including in the South China Sea and over the Northern Territories, and transnational issues, including smuggling, piracy and the uncontrolled movement of people, are other sources of uncertainty.

Asia-Pacific countries have, however, begun to work together in responding to these new challenges and there is a rapidly growing sense of regional community. In 1992, the region's preeminent multilateral political body, the ASEAN Post-Ministerial Conference (PMC), was endorsed as an appropriate forum in which regional security matters could be canvassed. Regional security issues are now firmly on the PMC agenda, indicative of a general trend toward more regular and open dialogue on security questions among regional countries.

Moreover, there was agreement at the last PMC meeting in Singapore in July to establish a Regional Security Forum in which not just the ASEAN countries and their traditional dialogue partners would participate, but also Russia, China, Vietnam, Laos and Papua New Guinea. All the major security players in the region are now included in a forum where discussions can take place across the whole range of significant politico-security issues.

Australia has been active in further broadening bilateral defence links with regional countries and in developing proposals for practical confidence building and cooperative measures, including encouraging transparency in the fields of weapons acquisition, force structure and defence policy generally. More specific examples of these practical proposals include exchange of maritime information and training for UN peacekeeping operations. We firmly believe that these sorts of measures, coupled with enhanced dialogue among Asian-Pacific countries, including on economic development and regional trade liberalisation issues, offer the best opportunity to manage regional security concerns over the longer term.

These new patterns of cooperation need consolidation. Existing security arrangements, which have served the region well, should be maintained, but the Government wishes to encourage the dialogue process among regional countries on security and related issues through a combination of multilateral and bilateral contacts, both formal and informal, in order to foster a regional sense of shared strategic interests. The Government welcomes the support of the Committee in its efforts in pursuing this objective.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 2

Noting the Constitutional requirements applying to Japan's defence arrangements, the pivotal role of the United States-Japan Security Treaty in enabling Japan to fulfil those requirements, the contribution of the Treaty arrangements continue to make to global and regional security, as well as the importance regional countries attach to these arrangements, the Committee recommends that the Australian Government:

PARA.TAB: continue to encourage the United States to maintain a strong commitment to the security of Japan and to the security and stability of the Asia-Pacific region;

encourage the Governments of Japan and the United States to continue to formulate, develop and publicly articulate the rationale for their continued cooperative security ties and commitments under the Treaty;

encourage the United States to maintain a regular dialogue with its Asia-Pacific regional partners and to consult them on any changes contemplated in the deployment of United States military forces in the region.
Response

The Clinton Administration has clearly reaffirmed the United States' defence and security commitment to the Asia-Pacific region. This commitment was addressed in President Clinton's speech to the National Assembly of the Republic of Korea on 10 July 1993, and again in his speech to the United Nations' General Assembly on 27 September 1993.

In the speech to the ROK National Assembly, President Clinton elaborated his view of the security components of his proposal for a new Pacific Community which had been launched earlier in the week in Japan. Key points made by President Clinton were:
"I believe there are four priorities for the security of our new Pacific community.

First, a continued American military commitment to this region. Second, stronger efforts to combat the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Third, new regional dialogues on the full range of our common security challenges. And last, support for democracy and more open societies throughout this region.

The bedrock of America's security role in the Asian Pacific must be a continued military presence. In a period of change, we need to preserve what has been more reliable. Today we, therefore, affirm our five bilateral security agreements with Korea, with Japan, with Australia, with the Philippines and with Thailand.

The United States subsequently committed itself to participating in regional security dialogue under the auspices of the ASEAN Regional Forum. All of these undertakings are, of course, most welcome to Australia.

Australia maintains regular dialogue, at Ministerial and official level, with the United States on defence and security issues. Australia's dialogue with Japan on defence and security issues has developed in recent years with the first exchanges of visits by Defence Ministers and the establishment of more frequent dialogue at senior officials' level. The issues raised in this recommendation have been and will continue to be addressed in these contacts.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 3

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that the issue of peacekeeping be included on the agenda of future US-Australia Ministerial Defence Talks and that the Australian Government convey to the United States Government Australia's belief that:
pressure should not be put on Japan to make a narrow military contribution to UN peacekeeping;
Japan is particularly well placed to provide technical expertise for peacekeeping operations in areas such as improvement of mine-clearance technologies;
Japan's financial contribution to UN peacekeeping operations is significant and highly appreciated.
The Committee further recommends that the above views be conveyed to the Japanese Government and to the Secretary-General of the United Nations.
Response

The Government accords a high priority to the further development of an effective peacekeeping role for the United Nations and consults closely with our allies and friends on this issue. Peacekeeping has regularly been on the agenda in Australia's Ministerial and senior official discussions with both the US and Japanese Governments. The United Nations' peacekeeping role has been discussed in meetings this year between the UN Secretary-General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, and both Prime Minister Keating and Senator Evans.

The Government has encouraged Japan to take a role in regional and international affairs commensurate with its economic power and this has included involvement in multilateral peacekeeping operations. The nature of Japan's contribution to peacekeeping activities remains a sensitive one, both within Japan and internationally. Passage of the United Nations Peacekeeping Operations (UNPKO) legislation in Japan in 1992 was only secured after long and difficult negotiations. The legislation provides essentially for the dispatch of Japanese Self Defence Force personnel, civilian police and seconded officials for a range of non-military, support duties. The issue is still problematical in Japan, notwithstanding the successful conclusion of the first overseas mission of Japanese PKO personnel in Cambodia. There are various views within the new Japanese Government on approaches to peacekeeping and it is unlikely that the present level of activity will be increased in the near future.

The Australian Government has made clear, in its public statements, its support for and appreciation of Japan's contribution to UN peacekeeping operations and our readiness to cooperate with Japan in peacekeeping activities. Our capacity to work effectively together has already been demonstrated in the conduct of the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC).

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 4

PARA.TAB: Recognising the increasing linkage between economic and security issues, the Committee recommends that the Australian Government continue its highly commendable efforts to develop further the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) process. The Committee welcomes Japan's constructive contribution to the process. The Committee considers that APEC has the capacity to contribute to regional security by:
helping to improve the economies of individual members;
strengthening economic links; and
defusing trade frictions between member states.
In particular, the APEC process is a vitally important means of encouraging opinion leaders and decision makers in the United States to focus on the economic importance of the Asia-Pacific region.
The Committee recommends that the Australian Government convey these views to all those participating in the APEC process.
Response

The Government welcomes the Committee's support for its approach to the development of Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC). APEC can make an important contribution to the maintenance of a stable regional environment by fostering greater interdependence among economies of the region. The Government does not, however, consider that APEC, at its present stage of development, is the appropriate forum to address regional security problems.

APEC's approach to building closer regional integration is helping to foster a deeper sense of community in the region. The integral nature of economic cooperation in nurturing this keener sense of mutual interest is now clearly recognised. The Minister for Foreign Affairs Senator Evans, at a conference in Indonesia on 9 August 1993, said:

"To my mind no community would be complete without the development of two parallel sets of edifices . . . these would comprise an economic sector which would have APEC as its centrepiece, and the politico-security sector for which we have the excellent infrastructure of the ASEAN PMC, now supplemented by the ASEAN Regional Forum.

APEC's further development as the preeminent regional forum for economic cooperation will strengthen the emerging notion of an Asia Pacific Economic Community. The proposed APEC Leaders' Meeting in Seattle in November 1993 will add political weight and status to APEC and strengthen its economic cooperation and trade liberalisation work.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1993 meeting of APEC Ministers in Seattle will also play a key role in moving APEC to a more substantive stage of its development. Ministers will aim to identify a specific program for the promotion of greater regional economic integration and a mechanism to carry this forward. The Australian Government will continue to emphasise the contribution APEC is making to a stable regional environment through developing cooperative outcomes based on mutual benefit, its capacity to build a sense of regional community, and its role in dealing with trade issues among its members.
Recommendation 5

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government further strengthen bilateral consultations with Japan on security issues in the Asia-Pacific region. In particular, the Committee recommends that the Australian Government:

a. include in its bilateral dialogue with Japan the identification of common security interests, such as secure access to Sea Lines of Communication (SLOCs), regional arms control, nuclear non-proliferation and peaceful uses of nuclear energy. Consultations with Japan should be carried out prior to the 1995 Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty Review and Extension Conference;
b. endeavour to establish closer links with Japan regarding United Nations peacekeeping operations:

TAB.TAB: Japanese representatives should be invited to participate actively in the Peacekeeping school recently established at the Australian Defence Force Warfare Centre at Williamtown;

Australia and Japan should jointly investigate ways in which more technologically advanced countries such as Japan and Australia can make the most effective contribution to United Nations peacekeeping activities.

PARA.TAB: Response

In recent years, the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Defence have been building up contacts with Japan on Asia-Pacific security issues. The visit in September 1993 by Defence Administrative Vice Minister Hatakeyama demonstrated Japanese interest in pursuing dialogue with Australia on these issues. Such contacts allow exchanges on developments in the defence policies of Australia and Japan in light of changes in the international situation in recent years, sharing of perceptions of Asia-Pacific security issues, the importance of a continued United States military presence in the Asia-Pacific region and United Nations peacekeeping operations. Australia and Japan do share a number of common interests on secure access to sea lines of communication (SLOCs) due to their large bilateral trade. The SLOCs issue does, however, encompass the interests of most, if not all, regional countries. The interests of member countries of ASEAN are, in particular, directly involved in the sea lanes through the region. These countries must be involved in consideration of secure access to these sea lines. The wider international community has a stake too for strategic and commercial reasons. The United States' forward military presence in the Western Pacific contributes to a sense of security about sea lines of communication. Australia already has regular and ad hoc consultations with Japan on international and regional arms control issues, including the Chemical Weapons Convention and measures to control the spread of weapons of mass destruction. We have maintained close contact on nuclear non-proliferation issues and on the peaceful uses of nuclear energy in day-to-day diplomatic contacts, in international forums and through regular meetings held under Australia's bilateral nuclear cooperation agreement with Japan. The bilateral dialogue is one of substance and constitutes an important element in the growing political relationship between Australia and Japan.

As part of these ongoing discussions, Australia is in regular consultation on developments relating to Japan's attitude to the indefinite extension of the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty (NPT). Australia particularly welcomed the public statement of the Japanese Government on 25 August and again on 27 September at the UN General Assembly that Japan supported the NPT's indefinite extension.

Consultations with Japan on UN peacekeeping operations have evolved considerably since the passage of the Japanese PKO legislation in June 1992. The participation of both countries in the UN Transitional Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC) has enhanced our commonality of interest with Japan in this area and provided a firm basis for future cooperation.

Japan has been invited to send a participant to the first international peacekeeping course at Australia's Peacekeeping Centre at Williamtown planned for February/March 1994 and is expected to be invited regularly to such courses.

A current issue of United Nations peacekeeping is how the UN itself organises and conducts such operations. Australia and Japan are engaged in the process to improve the UN's delivery of peacekeeping services. Countries such as Australia and Japan are set apart in the contribution that they can make to UN peacekeeping because they provide the logistic support to make their contingents almost self-supporting in particular UN peacekeeping operations. As Australia has done in UNTAC and the UN Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara (MINURSO), there is capability to provide the UN with a vital service such as a communications system for the UN peacekeeping force.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 6

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that, in promoting dialogue with Japan, the Australian Government takes appropriate steps to allay any concerns that might arise in regional countries, including the ASEAN countries.
Response

This recommendation is consistent with the Government's open approach to the discussion of political and security issues on a regional basis. The Australian Government will continue to be sensitive to the views and attitudes of regional countries, including the ASEAN countries, in developing Australia's bilateral relations with other key countries, including Japan. Australia participates actively in the ASEAN Post-Ministerial Conference and ASEAN Regional Forum processes and the evolving regional security dialogue, which will involve a discussion of inter-regional relationships, including the role of Japan.

The Australian Government is aware of the importance some Asian neighbours attach to receiving an unconditional apology from Japan for its acts of aggression in the period leading up to and during World War II. The Government has been encouraged by the more forthright apology made by Prime Minister Hosokawa in his first statement to the Diet on 25 August and hopes that it will assist in improving relations between Japan and its Asian neighbours.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 7

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government facilitate a range of exchanges aimed at promoting increased awareness and understanding of constitutional processes in Australia and Japan as one means of encouraging the strengthening of civilian control of the military in Japan. Exchanges of constitutional experts as well as more extensive reciprocal participation by senior Australian and Japanese defence personnel in staff college courses should be encouraged. In particular, Japan should be invited to send both civilian and military participants regularly to Australian Joint Services Staff College courses.
Response

The Australian Government does not consider that there is any problem relating to the strength of civilian control of the military in Japan. The Japanese Government explicitly states civilian control as a fundamental national policy (for instance at p. 67 of the Japan's Defence Agency's 1992 White Paper "Defence of Japan"). Public opinion and the constitutional situation with regard to the role and position of the military is totally different from that which prevailed in the pre-war period.

The Staff College exchanges involving the Joint Services Staff College and Japan's National Institute of Defence Studies are working well. There have been invitations to Japan to send a civilian officer to the Joint Services Staff College, but these have not yet been taken up due to funding problems on the Japanese side. The Department of Defence is endeavouring to identify availability of these places further ahead, so that Japanese funding can be obtained to take them up.

Japan has been invited to send an officer to the Army Command and Staff College and to the Royal Australian Navy Staff College, but to date these invitations have not been taken up by Japan, apparently because of its budgetary lead times.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 8

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that military exchanges between Australia and Japan other than those noted in Recommendation 7 be maintained at about the current level and that the views of regional countries, particularly ASEAN, be canvassed on any proposed changes in the nature or level of exchanges. If a limited enhancement of the present exchanges were to be considered priority should be given to exchanges of personnel involved in the development of defensive capabilities such as defence-related information technologies, simulation technologies and over-the-horizon radar. Recognising Australia's and Japan's strong common interest in the security of Sea Lines of Communication, the development of maritime surveillance capabilities should be emphasised in any future consideration of bilateral military activities.
Response

As noted in the submissions to the Inquiry by the Departments of Defence and Foreign Affairs and Trade, future defence contacts with Japan will develop at a measured pace. Contacts with Japan on defence and security issues are concentrated on dialogue and visits, rather than cooperative activities between the military forces of the two countries, apart from ship visits. Japan's exclusively defence-oriented policy will perforce encourage emphasis on defensive capabilities in any enhancement of current defence exchanges. Japanese Defence Vice Minister Hatakeyama inspected the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar facility in Alice Springs during his visit to Australia in September 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 9

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government, through an organisation such as the Australia-Japan Foundation, sponsor:
the addition of a Japanese soundtrack to the film "Kokoda—the Bloody Track" and facilitate distribution of the film in Japan; and

the writing of an accurate history to be published in an accessible format in both Japanese and English; to give a comprehensive account of the involvement of Japanese and Australian forces in Southeast Asia and the Pacific in World War II.
Response

The Australia-Japan Foundation (AJF) Executive Committee considered the Committee's recommendation. It agreed to raise with the Australian Army, which has copyright to the film "Kokoda, the Bloody Track", the addition of a Japanese soundtrack and to approach NHK and Japanese commercial television networks to ascertain their interest in buying broadcast rights. This approach, if successful, would have the advantage of gaining a wide audience for the film.

The AJF Executive Committee decided, however, that the Foundation would not address the second part of this recommendation relating to the writing of an accurate history of the Pacific War, as significant advances have been made in this area. The AJF has developed an educational kit for use in Japanese secondary schools, which comprises a 20 minute video and teacher's manual and provides a general introduction to Australia including the fact that Australia and Japan were enemies during World War II. The kit will be introduced into Japanese schools in 1994. Moreover, a book on the Burma-Thailand Railway by Professor Gavan McCormack, who appeared before the Committee during the inquiry, will shortly be published in Japanese. The Australian Embassy in Tokyo will be assisting in obtaining publicity for the book in consultation with the Japanese publisher. Because there are many works on the Pacific War published in Japan, the challenge is not publishing the works, but in getting them read by the general public.

It is significant that the Japanese Government has recently publicly acknowledged the waging by the former Imperial Army of an aggressive war and the suffering caused by Japan's actions to the Asia-Pacific region.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 10

PARA.TAB: The Committee believes that there is inadequate knowledge and understanding of the important Japan-United States relationship in Australia and recommends that the Australian Government commission and publish a study of that relationship, including a comprehensive and detailed analysis of:
the trade and investment relationship between the two countries;
the interface between the economic and security aspects of the relationship; and
the importance of the relationship to the region as a whole and to Australia in particular.
Response

The Government agrees with the recommendation for the commissioning and publication of a study of the Japan-United States relationship as a means of promoting public awareness in Australia of the importance of the relationship to Australia and the region. It is proposed that the study be published within one year of this reply to the Committee's report.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 11

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that the issues canvassed and the recommendations made in this Report be taken into account in the formulation of the Government's current Strategic Basis Paper and proposed update of the 1987 Defence White Paper.
Response
The Report has been drawn to the attention of the team conducting the 1993 Strategic Review and to those who will conduct the proposed update of the 1987 Defence White Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pleasing to have such a positive response from the government to the 10 recommendations contained in the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Japan's defence and security in the 1990s. It is important to note that the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), has just presented to the Senate the government's response to the committee's report, and I believe that it is essential that the committee set aside time to study it in detail.

PARA.TAB: I will deal firstly with the tabling statement presented by the minister. It is worth while to draw attention to the fact that the government agrees with the general conclusions of the committee and its description of the emerging regional security environment and the response of Japan to trade development. There is also acceptance by the government of the committee's recommendation to call for Australia to continue actively to encourage the development of regional security dialogue; expand dialogue with Japan on regional security issues, including on UN peacekeeping; secure access to sea lines of communication, regional arms control and peaceful use of nuclear energy, but to maintain military exchanges between Australia and Japan at about the current level; encourage the United States to maintain and articulate a strong commitment to the security of Japan and the region; facilitate more constructive political and economic engagements between Japan and the rest of the region; and to allay regional concern about Japan's role.

I believe that at subsequent meetings the committee needs to look further in some detail at the government's response. It is not my intention today to go through all the recommendations and responses. However, I want to draw attention to one recommendation and response which I think are fairly important. The recommendation states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government, through an organisation such as the Australian-Japan Foundation, sponsor:
.the addition of a Japanese soundtrack to the film "Kokoda—the Bloody Track" and facilitate distribution of the film in Japan; and

. the writing of an accurate history to be published in an accessible format in both Japanese and English; to give a comprehensive account of the involvement of Japanese and Australian forces in Southeast Asia and the Pacific in World War II.
The first part of the response by the government certainly goes a long way towards meeting recommendation 9 of the committee. The government's response states:

The Australian-Japanese Foundation (AJF) Executive Committee considered the Committee's recommendation. It agreed to raise with the Australian Army, which has copyright to the film "Kokoda, the Bloody Track", the addition of a Japanese soundtrack and to approach NHK and Japanese commercial television networks to ascertain their interest in buying broadcast rights. This approach, if successful, would have the advantage of gaining a wide audience for the film.

The second part of the recommendation talks about the writing of an accurate history of World War II. It is reasonable to say that the response from the government is that some action is being taken on that. While it is not possible to meet the exact recommendation of the committee, the action that has been taken goes a long way towards meeting the requirements of the committee under that recommendation.

PARA.TAB: It is significant that the Japanese government has recently acknowledged the waging of an aggressive war by the former imperial army and the suffering caused by Japan's action in the Asia-Pacific region. That in itself shows that the present Japanese government is going a long way towards redressing the problems that have been shown over a number of years in relation to its version of World War II and what happened in the Pacific. Finally, I believe that the committee should go through the remaining recommendations and the government's responses to them in some detail.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—I call Senator Teague.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. As you, with me, were one of those involved in writing this report, I am sure that you will welcome the carefulness and positive tones of the government's response to our report and the 11 recommendations that are set out in it.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the statement that has been made here today on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans. I will quote a few phrases in the government's response which very positively endorse the findings of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. The first states:

SPEECH.PARA: The government agrees with the general conclusions of the Committee in describing the emerging regional security environment and the response of Japan to these developments.
In another place it states:

The Government also acknowledges the overall conclusion of the Committee that the expected changes in Japan's defence policies and activities should be directed to global and regional peace and security objectives and in identifying a role for Australia in helping shape the region's approach to security and in facilitating dialogue with Japan and between Japan and the region.

We are not just speaking here about motherhood or slapping each other on the back for being in favour of peace and amity in our region. The report and its 11 precise recommendations are quite specific. It is my judgment that this report could not have been written five years ago, and certainly not 10 or 20 years ago.

PARA.TAB: It is a measure of the maturity of the bilateral relations between Australia and Japan that it has been possible for the Australian government, in the last few years, through the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Minister for Defence, the Prime Minister and, indeed, opposition spokesmen—who have been very complementary and reinforcing of the initiatives the Australian government and its ministers are taking—to move to an agenda which is reflected in the Senate committee report and the government's response to it.

I speak of the precise stage that we have now reached in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation process; the foreshadowing of the important meeting in Seattle next month; the ASEAN post-ministerial conference; the security dialogue that has emerged with a great stride forward in the middle of this year, 1993; and the appropriateness of that forum, having evolved over a number of years, to be a very practical and viable forum for regional countries on security matters.

I also refer to the early stages of the term of office of the new United States president, President Clinton. Some doubts, worries and anxieties have been expressed about whether this generational change in the United States will deny some of the personal and very positive commitments that the United States has made in past decades to our region and to understanding our region. President Clinton and the new administration have made a positive transition and are bringing freshness to the United States' views of the Asia-Pacific.

The United States has made a firm commitment to the Japan-US defence treaty, which is one of the most important treaties in the world today. It is certainly fundamental to the economic prosperity of Japan and the other economic tigers—Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and others—in the east Asian region.

There is no vacuum in security matters in our region because security is largely made complete by the US's relationship with the region, not least in the triangle of the United States, Japan and Australia. President Clinton's response to the visit of Prime Minister Keating in Washington in recent weeks is a very positive instance of what I have been referring to and it is writ large and specifically in the Senate's report and the government's response.

I refer to the increased focus on UN peacekeeping in the world and the rather delicate discussion in recent years in Japan about its making a contribution to peacekeeping. The Senate committee endorses Japan's moves not only to make a financial contribution, which it did very substantially to the international allies in the Gulf War for peace enforcement, but also to allowing non-combatant—unarmed—engineering and other support personnel from Japan to be a part of the peacekeeping group deployed in Cambodia and Somalia.

I also refer to the bilateral relations between Australia and Japan. Not only is Japan Australia's most significant trading partner, but increasingly, on a wide range of issues, Australia and Japan now have a very mature level of bilateral discussions. This includes defence, as it ought to, with the limits that are set out in the Senate committee's report and which are endorsed by the government.

A dialogue has been established between the Senate committee and the government, in particular with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Defence, in this area of discussion. It is difficult to give any bouquets to one side or another in relation to who initiated which idea first. This dialogue has been mutually helpful to members of parliament and, I hope, to ministers, but certainly to the senior officers of these departments.

I wish to conclude my remarks by, for a couple of minutes, referring to the importance of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Some months ago—probably five months ago—at the beginning of this parliament, there was pressure in terms of getting sufficient numbers to service various committees. It was, God forbid, actually proposed that this committee be abolished. I was most grateful when, after some discussions, the committee structure still retained a Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I take this benchmark of late October to give an instance of the ongoing life and value of this committee, which is very active in the Senate.

A meeting was held today between 8.30 and 10 a.m. of 11 senior public servants who were put together as a task force to work on our report on Latin America and on the implementation of 63 recommendations to which the government has also positively responded. That task force is in the middle of its two-year life of implementing, according to government guidelines, the response to the Senate committee. In the private meeting of the committee today, we had before us a draft of our own annual report on the annual reports that the Senate receives in the areas of foreign affairs, defence and trade. It is right that all of the reports that come before us in these three areas be addressed by one of our standing committees.

We made arrangements today for hearings on Monday and Friday next week on our next major inquiry: China-Australia relations. We also discussed today the details of some ship visits with regard to another inquiry which was actually referred to us by the two defence ministers—the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Senator Faulkner). That inquiry relates to the Swan and to the issue of sexual harassment in the three defence services.

I also note that another of our most recent reports on the United States presidential election debate and the repercussions of that debate on Australia and this region might well have been in the Prime Minister's pocket when he met with President Clinton in recent weeks. From all of the reports of the very positive discussion that flowed between our Prime Minister and the President of the United States, it was entirely consistent and followed through the kinds of conclusions and the kinds of priorities that we in the Senate were urging upon the government of Australia in its dialogue with the United States. I refer to APEC, to NAFTA, to GATT, to the defence relationship and to this triangle between the United States, Japan and Australia.

I instance these half dozen matters as reinforcement of my belief that the Senate continues to do positive work on a number of fronts. It is with some real satisfaction that I warmly receive the government's response to our report on Japan's defence and security in the 1990s.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advance to the Minister for Finance

Debate resumed from 7 October, on motion by Senator Zakharov:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training has undertaken a most comprehensive inquiry since May 1992. It has received 66 submissions from a vast array of conflicting interests and has interviewed some 34 witnesses. Owing to the pressure of business that came before the Senate last week, I missed the opportunity to speak to this report. I thank the secretary of the committee, Brenton Holmes, and his assistants, Doug Hynd and Kathleen Griffiths, who should be congratulated. I think all members of the committee would share that sentiment because of the way in which they have handled the material and the administrative arrangements for this inquiry.

PARA.TAB: As a result of this inquiry into the operation of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act, it is quite clear that three central points stand out: firstly, that actions and court proceedings relating to sections 45D and 45E clearly belong in the industrial arena, not the trade practice or corporate arena; secondly, that the use of sections 45D and 45E in the courts by employer and business groups has been to limit industrial action not directly related to secondary boycotts, thus giving employers additional power and advantage in regard to legitimate industrial action involving workers; and, thirdly, that the use of these sections is in direct conflict with Australia's obligations under ILO conventions.

To understand how the committee arrived at these conclusions, we need to look at the history of sections 45D and 45E, their application, other constraints available, and the international industrial environment in which we are working at the moment. In 1977 section 45D was inserted into the Trade Practices Act by the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr John Howard. It was clearly Labor's view at that time that Mr Howard, who had a close association with the business community, was seeking to do what he could to strengthen the hand of business in industrial relations.

In 1978 the Trade Practices Act was further amended to outlaw primary boycotts which interfered with interstate and overseas trade. In 1980 section 45E was inserted to target deceptive business practices. It prohibited a contract or arrangement between a union and a business or a person to prevent the supply of goods and services to a third person. It was clear from the way these sections were used that a much broader agenda was operating than was originally intended when the act was established. That became abundantly clear to me in the course of our inquiry.

It became obvious to me that the use of sections 45D and 45E was closely associated with organisations and political groups which had a set agenda to discredit the industrial relations scheme of things as we currently know it. They clearly had a hostility to the existing arrangements of awards and tribunals for setting industrial relations that have developed throughout this country's history, which up until recently have existed throughout every jurisdiction in this country except Victoria, where the industrial relations system has been thoroughly gutted.

Mr Tim Abey, the director of the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, was asked whether he observed any reluctance by employers to use sections 45D and 45E. He said that that was the case with employers who had some commitment to the industrial relations system. But when he was asked whether it was his experience as an industrial relations practitioner that some other employer organisations did not have the same commitment to the industrial law process and therefore were more willing to use this sort of measure, Mr Abey replied, `Yes, I think that would be a fair comment'. He also indicated that in the course of his work as an industrial relations practitioner this particular measure had been threatened hundreds of times through the industrial relations practices and the day-to-day work of organisers who work for him.

A threat was being used in a punitive way—a bludgeon which, as he indicated, was clearly designed to assist one particular side in the resolution of industrial disputes. If we look at the history of these things, we see that the use of the proceedings before the courts is somewhat more complicated. Of the 206 injunctions that have been issued under these proposals, only 81 have been granted and only two have gone through to full damages. The ideological presumption behind the use of these measures cannot be underestimated. It is a punitive measure designed to bludgeon industrial opponents, and designed and used quite particularly by people who were closely associated with New Right industrial organisations.

The evidence presented by Mr Freeburn on behalf of the ACTU also indicated that the same sorts of processes occurred in Victoria, as in the case of the National Farmers Federation. We have seen fighting funds established not to assist innocent third parties but as a vehicle for the political expression of a political and ideological view as to the way in which unions and workers should be treated in the industrial relations scheme. We have seen this happen on many occasions and we have also seen it fail desperately many times. The case of Seymour Meats is one example that was referred to in evidence. Mr Brian Noakes, speaking on behalf of Victorian employers, indicated that that essentially was the case. However, on occasions employers had got it wrong—they had picked the wrong targets—and fallen very badly. That has been the case with the use of those provisions against the meat workers in Victoria in recent times.

My view is that this issue has been a vehicle for the expression of ideology rather than a legitimate weapon in the industrial relations machinery. It is not an appropriate means by which one should seek to resolve industrial relations disputes. However, members of the H.R. Nicholls Society, the National Farmers Federation, Kroger and Kroger, and various other soldiers in this war may find the committee's proposals reprehensible. The main point is that there need to be changes in view of the changed industrial and political circumstances this country finds itself in at the moment.

The Commonwealth government has sought to remove these particular provisions before. In 1984 it sought to repeal sections 45D and 45E and to give enhanced conciliation powers and responsibility for boycotts to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That proposal was defeated in the Senate. In 1987 a similar attempt was made. Again, that motion failed due to the election. In 1988 the Hawke government sought to remodel the Industrial Relations Act, and that failed as well. In 1989 the Democrats sought to amend the Industrial Relations Act and that failed as well. Essentially, it has failed as a result of either the lack of political will or the lack of the sort of political coalition necessary to actually get the proposals through the Senate. I do not believe that that is the case any more.

It is particularly significant, and ironic in a sense, that it was the employers who went to the ILO. The employers said that we needed an investigation into Australia's international obligations on the question of the size of unions. The ILO said that the proposals of the Australian government relating to the size of unions were inappropriate. At that point the ACTU was able to say, `If that is the case, we can then look at the question of Australia's other industrial obligations'. It is ironic that it was the employers who initiated the involvement of the ILO in these processes, and it is at this point, given the number of failures that have occurred in recent times, that we now see the possibility of real change in this area.

In 1991 the ILO formally requested the Australian government to bring the provisions of the Trade Practices Act into conformity with the ILO convention. In 1992, on motion by Senator Bell, seconded by Senator Cooney, this inquiry was established. It is quite clear from where I stand on these issues that this inquiry has been most welcome, as are its findings. We have to understand the ILO's position, given its central importance in this whole issue. The ILO, through its Committee of Experts on the Application of Conventions and Recommendations and Committee on Freedom of Association of the Government Body of the ILO, indicated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the right to strike is one of the essential means available to workers and their organisations for the promotion and protection of their economic and social interests. These interests not only have to do with obtaining better working conditions and pursuing collective demands of an occupational nature, but also with seeking solutions to economic and social policy questions and to labour problems of any kind which are of direct concern to the workers.

This right is based on article 3 of convention No. 87, the Right to Organise, which protects the rights of organisations of workers `to organise their administration and activities and to formulate their programs'. I would be the first to recognise that this is not an unrestricted right. The committee also pointed out that that right may be restricted in relation to a number of other matters relating to the way in which governments function.

PARA.TAB: There are fundamental principles at stake here. The recommendation of the ILO indicates that quite a balanced approach is being taken. The fundamental question is the right of workers to actually organise and protect themselves. Quite clearly, the arrangements under 45D and 45E infringe upon the basic commitments the Australian government has entered into. The government understands that the opposition does not support such a view. Given where it stands in the political scheme of things, one would not expect the opposition to agree at any point with this report. Therefore, it followed that there would be a minority report on these issues.

What has to be understood, however, is that this is a matter that will be debated throughout the community, and I look forward to that. It will give Australians an opportunity to understand just where the opposition stands on these fundamental human rights issues. It will give the public an opportunity to understand exactly what the industrial relations policies of the Liberal Party mean.

It was apparent that, when the quite draconian propositions of the Liberal Party were put to the electorate at the last election, those propositions were not accepted. It is quite apparent that the industrial relations attitudes reflected in the opposition's policies essentially hark back to what it sees as a brighter time, a golden age when the right of management was clearer, when it was clear that workers had a place in society which was to be at the beck and call of employers. It is quite clear that the freedom of contract debates of the 19th century sit quite easily with the current industrial relations policies of the conservative coalition.

I believe that the people of this country will continue to reject that sort of attitude because it stands in sharp contrast to the great history and traditions of this nation. One of the earliest industrial relations policies of this parliament was the establishment of the conciliation and arbitration machinery which reflected the fundamental values that exist within the Australian body politic: that is, the capacity for people to organise, to express themselves industrially and to defend themselves, coupled with the capacity of the state to intervene to ensure that disputes are settled and that there is a proper and legitimate expression of industrial and economic concerns along with genuine industrial and social justice.

That has not always been the case in this country. It is very interesting to note, in terms of Australia's history of industrial relations, that the employers in this country turn away from arbitration in times of depression when they believe their position will be strengthened, when the army of unemployed are there as a threat to be used against workers who remain in work. However, in boom times they turn back to arbitration because it is a device by which they seek to control wages and conditions. The Labor Party's attitude is that in both good times and bad there should be a floor in our industrial relations scheme to protect ordinary conditions, community standards, and to provide for basic decency in industrial relations.

However, we also recognise the need to organise industrial affairs to allow for direct discussions between bosses and workers. We do not believe that the state should be used in a draconian way to cripple industrial organisations or to even up the score on behalf of employers in such a way as to prevent workers from expressing their legitimate rights and concerns about their social and economic conditions.

The problem with sections 45D and 45E is that they do exactly that. Many now understand their full implications when they are applied to social and industrial questions. It is quite possible that community groups are directly affected. In the case of green bans, for instance, conservationists have been complaining to our committee about the way in which 45D and 45E fundamentally infringe democratic rights and the right to defend basic issues such as the heritage of this country—for example, old buildings—and prevent the expression of legitimate political views about the way in which our society should be controlled.

The minority report argues that 45D and 45E are needed. The opposition is constantly arguing that it is necessary to enforce union compliance with industrial law. That is simply not the case. If one looks at the various penalties and provisions that exist within industrial practice in this country, one finds that there are a host of opportunities for the enforcement of compliance with industrial awards and industrial agreements.

I will outline some of the compliance mechanisms that can be used in industrial action. These are penalties under the Industrial Relations Act; penalties under state arbitration statutes; various injunctions and damages at common law; various sanctions under the state and federal essential services legislation; the state equivalents of 45D and 45E which exist in Victoria and New South Wales; the issue of deregistration; the capacity to suspend or cancel awards; the application of a `no work as directed, no pay' principle or the termination of employment; penalties under grievance handling arrangements and other informal measures agreed to by the parties themselves; and informal sanctions imposed by tribunals.

What we see within the existing industrial relations framework is that there are many other options available to employers. Only a minority of employers turn to 45D and 45E as a vehicle for bludgeoning workers and they are mainly those employers who are tied in with a political agenda and have no concern for the interests of so-called innocent third parties. We have yet to see a case where the innocent third party has popped up in an industrial dispute and presented material to the court.

What we have seen is that by and large where organisations have engaged in this sort of action—small companies that are often the vehicle for the National Farmers Federation—they have immediately collapsed upon the settlement of the matters in the legal process. In the case of Mudginberri, the so-called injured party was the pawn of other political forces who had other political agendas aimed at furthering the interests of New Right organisations and pursuing particular factional interests within the National and Liberal parties of Australia.

We need to address the mechanisms that will actually lead to the settlement of industrial disputes rather than furthering the political objectives of minority ideological groups within employer organisations. I am afraid that the opposition has failed to understand that it has now been some time since the Australian industrial relations system has matured and that the crude models it has been pursuing since the 1970s have been doomed to failure as a result of a fundamental political rejection at the hands of the Australian electorate. It has policies that do not reflect the attitudes, the aspirations and the values of Australians. As a consequence, the use of punitive clauses and various other common law actions by New Right legal firms will ultimately fail to attract the necessary community and public support that a political organisation needs if it is ever to seek the broad support within the community that is necessary to actually win an election. As far as I am concerned, that is the name of the game in terms of maintaining government. It gives us the capacity to talk to others about removing such draconian and undemocratic propositions that are fundamentally in breach of the human rights concerns we have as a country and as a labour movement.

This parliament must recognise that there is a need for a process of continuing dialogue and a mechanism which allows parties to work towards common goals in industrial relations. I believe it is essential that we recognise that working men and women have legitimate social and economic interests and that they have legitimate methods of pursuing them through their unions and other means. Fundamentally, it has to be recognised that these interests are just as legitimate as the rights of owners of capital.

This fundamental dichotomy has to be understood by the courts and by the various state apparatus that exist within this country. It has to be recognised that these are fundamental principles of a social democracy. They are fundamental human rights issues which are the hallmarks of a civilised society. At the moment, we do not have that clear understanding within this country. We do not have a clear and agreed understanding of the legitimacy of working people. We have a view expressed by some that the freedom of contract means the freedom of employers to do as they wish; the unfettered right of business to pursue its particular objectives. In this debate today, I expect that we will hear that view expressed. I am sure that discussion will be ongoing within this country as the whole framework of the industrial relations package is rewritten.

The government has embarked on a policy that encourages enterprise bargaining. It will introduce a whole series of new industrial relations legislation. It is in that context that the outmoded Trade Practices Act has little value in achieving a productive and cooperative industrial climate which will help strengthen the economic recovery and Australia's position with respect to other industrial societies. I hope this report is widely read and I trust that it is widely debated. I look forward to participating in that debate and I hope many other honourable senators in this chamber do too.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training dealing with sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. I will address my comments to the minority report because I think there are some things that need to be put fairly and squarely on the table.

PARA.TAB: I want to comment on a couple of things that were said by Senator Carr, the previous speaker. I think they are very relevant to this debate. In his last comment Senator Carr made reference to the new industrial direction in which we are moving. The capitulation of the government to the ACTU and union power has turned the clock back many years. The discussion document bears no resemblance whatsoever to the types of things the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) were saying some two, three or four months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —You obviously didn't read it.

—Yes, I did. I read it very carefully. It bears no resemblance. When the legislation comes before this place and the other place, we will see that. We are moving down an enterprise agreement path, as the government puts it. Yet even when there are no union members in the workplace, the union movement is given the effective power of veto over those enterprise agreements. This means that there will be very few enterprise agreements—I would suggest none—in the non-union sector of the work force, which comprises 70 per cent of the work force.

PARA.TAB: I do not argue that employees in the work force do not have legitimate rights; nor do I argue that employers do not have legitimate rights. I reject entirely the suggestion Senator Carr made that, in effect, employers want open slather. That is a nonsense. That thought needs to be thrown right out of the system because it is just not true.

I will deal with a couple of other matters before I refer to the substance of our minority report. It is important to understand Australia's current situation and where Australia might want to be in the next one to six years. We have a wonderful opportunity to modernise our industrial relations system in order to bring it more into line with our international competitors and to look at what is happening in other countries. It is obvious that that is not being done. An important point in the debate and this inquiry is that Australia is the only country that maintains a compulsory arbitration system. No other country does that.

TALK.START.PARA: —We led the world, and we still do.

—If we lead the world, why are our unemployment levels so high? Why is our national debt blowing out of proportion? Why do we continue to see the balance of our current account rise each month? We need to ask some fundamental questions. When our financial systems were deregulated, we were not prepared to deregulate the labour market. We blew most of the benefits we could get out of a deregulated financial system. It is not compatible to have a regulated industrial system and a deregulated financial system. It simply will not work.
—And you say you don't want open slather!
—I am not saying open slather. There is no open slather in our financial system, as Senator Zakharov well knows. The Reserve Bank continually intervenes, for example, with the value of our dollar.

PARA.TAB: I want to refer to the substance of the report and to explain why we put in a dissenting report. It is essential that there is balance in a system. Sections 45D and 45E were brought in because of the irrational actions that a number of unions were involved in. It is interesting to hear the NFF's name mentioned; it is interesting to hear Mudginberri mentioned; it is also interesting to hear the New Right mentioned. I certainly was an active member of the NFF, I have been branded as being part of the New Right, and I was certainly involved in Mudginberri. Senator Murphy, my colleague on the other side of the house, has also been involved in 45D and 45E matters. As we all know, he currently has a case in court, but I am not sure of the exact detail of it. I am not very interested in dealing with that at this time.

The misleading comments about Mudginberri in the report, which were made by Senator Carr, need correcting. Senator Carr was absolutely wrong in saying that the meat works collapsed as a result of what happened at Mudginberri.

TALK.START.PARA: —After.

—No. The truth of the matter is that Mudginberri was sold to another operator. The owner of Mudginberri, Mr Pendarvis, moved to Serpentine in Western Australia. Mudginberri was always a terminal works. The buffalo were running out for a commercial operation and the person who bought it—
—Pity the court didn't understand that; that was the point of the court case.

—Senator Carr has it entirely wrong. I want to correct that so it is understood. It was sold to the other operator. The equipment was taken from Mudginberri and put into other meatworks in the Northern Territory or sold. I do not know the finer detail, and I do not want to know. But it is absolutely incorrect for Senator Carr to refer to it in the way he did.

PARA.TAB: I would like to deal with some of the reasons why we put in a minority report. First we identified what we believed were the key issues and what the report was about. The first of those key issues related to whether or not under sections 45D and 45E employees were able to exercise their legitimate rights to take action to protect their wages, working conditions, terms and conditions of employment and so on. In a precedent in court—and I am glad Senator Carr mentioned the Victorian situation—in a case between MATFA and AMIU, just to give one example, it was held up in court. It was found that those individuals who were taking action with regard to the detail of accord mark 6 were not in breach of sections 45D and E. In terms of the application of section 45D and whether it interfered with the legitimate rights of employees that was a very important case.

Of course, that is not the only case. The majority chose to ignore that piece of evidence, and I think it is very sad that they did. Their position on this matter is one of ideology. We knew what the outcome of the majority report was going to be before we went in. The position that was put by the witnesses in terms of the report—whether arguing one way or another—was put very passionately and with a lot of feeling. We as members of the committee have to look even more carefully at the facts that are put before the committee in that inquiry and try to avoid being swayed by the passion that comes through.

Senator Carr spent some time on employer behaviour. He made the point, which I was going to make, that only two actions have gone through. A point that I think needs making about the use of sections 45D and 45E is that they have not been used extensively. In all parts of the law that relate to interference with trade and the actions that could be taken in this area—and there are a number of jurisdictions in which you can operate—they have probably been used less than any other. One thing we all agreed on was that sections 45D and 45E were very effective in protecting the interests of an employer. In saying that, one has to recognise what they are about. They are about protecting the legitimate rights of individuals or businesses to go about their business without interference, whether it be industrial or political interference.

We must remember that prior to the introduction of sections 45D and 45E, businesses in this country were held to ransom in many instances and so was the country, and a lot of economic harm was done. I particularly refer to the bans on the Chilean and Indonesian ships back in the mid-1970s. At that time the silos in Western Australia were full and we could not get the wheat out and it put at risk a harvest. It put at risk the livelihoods of a whole host of people. Unfortunately, that case had to be resolved by going to the Crimes Act, which was much more cumbersome and much more draconian. You can get put in gaol under the Crimes Act for interference with trade. It was equally strong in terms of damages that could be extracted. The problem with it was that it was very slow and cumbersome. One should recognise that business has a right to protect itself from damage. It should not be put in a position where it can be damaged on the one hand and not have recourse to cover those damages on the other hand. Sections 45D and 45E overcame those problems.

I wish to touch on whether sections 45D and 45E unfairly impeded individuals' civil liberties. Once again, one has to go to the courts to get a precedent to show that this does not occur. When I looked at the cases involving sections 45D and 45E I did not find a case where a 45D or 45E action had impeded people's civil liberties. We did find a case, the J-Corps case in Western Australia, where the BLF took action against J-Corps but where, when it was taken to the courts, the courts found that because the target of that boycott action was the Western Australian government—it was the Burke or Dowding government; I am not sure which one—and Homeswest, sections 45D and 45E did not stand up. Their protest action and their target in terms of exercising that civil liberty was the Western Australian government. Once again, in that important precedent the court found the situation as I have outlined it.

The next point I make is whether Australia was in breach of its obligation under the International Labour Organisation conventions. We can all find little bits and pieces that we can quote to make our case, but when we look at the totality of the decision with regard to ILO conventions we find that the restriction there was one of a very limited nature, and that was borne out in the evidence. We also found that they went on to say that under a compulsory arbitration system there was a good case to disallow strikes while an award was in place.

I throw out the challenge to the other members on the committee who put down the majority report to recognise the point, which I have recognised, that there was a restriction, but it was a very limited restriction. I think it is a very grave mistake to use a convention such as that and a judgment that has been made on that just to try to make a case with regard to one's point when the decision that was made was much broader. In terms of the ILO conventions and the evidence that was given to us, and having read those decisions very carefully, I do not believe that sections 45D and 45E as they stand contravene our conventions.

I want to say a little more about conventions. It is about time that Australian parliaments, and this parliament in particular, recognised that it is our responsibility to make Australian domestic law and not to be controlled by the types of conventions we are talking about now. We make reference to that in our report. When we talk about ILO conventions and how they sit I think that Australia, for whatever reason, is placing far too much weight on those conventions and not looking at the domestic situation. One must also note that when the limitation of 10,000 to form a trade union was brought in—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are quite capable of making laws that suit the Australian situation. If honourable senators opposite have to rely on international conventions to make their brains tick, that is their problem, not mine.

PARA.TAB: The next point I want to raise is whether businesses or organisations who have had boycotts brought against them have found sections 45D and 45E effective in having the boycotts removed. I believe the committee agreed that the answer was yes. The committee found that the knowledge that sections 45D and 45E existed was also very effective. I believe that the international bans that occurred in the days prior to the enactment of sections 45D and 45E would have continued to occur if those provisions had not been in place. If the government goes down the line that it is suggesting, we will see a return to those bad old days.

Sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act are about the constraint of trade and they are appropriately placed. If we go down the government's route, as is outlined in Mr Brereton's paper, and have periods of 72 hours before action can be taken, I believe that will just be—and mark these words—a licence to damage. It is not a path that this country should go down; it is not a path that should be necessary in a nation where we have compulsory conciliation and arbitration. If we are going to maintain that particular system, then that system should be used.

The recommendations made in the committee's majority report were disappointing. I do not believe that they are in the best interests of this nation.
