We made clear in the minority report that the overwhelming evidence was that the concerns could not be substantiated. The direction in which we are now heading with our industrial relations system, moving back to where we were 10, 15 or 20 years ago in terms of transference of power from the elected government to the union movement, is regrettable. In fact, one could even say today that the current government is becoming a subsidiary of the ACTU.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing this report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I join Senator Carr in congratulating the staff of the committee on the array of witnesses that they arranged to appear before us. I would also like to congratulate the chair, Senator Zakharov, on the way in which she conducted the hearings.

PARA.TAB: I wish to draw attention to the committee's terms of reference, the first of which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)whether sections 45D and 45E are unduly harsh and restrictive when compared with International Labour Organisation conventions on freedom of association and the recently clarified right of free speech apparently implicit in Australia's constitution.

Senator Crane in his remarks asked why we needed to direct our minds to international influence in order to draft legislation in this area. It seems that he takes a contrary view to that put by Senator Newman this morning when she called on Senator Richardson to implement United Nations conventions. It seems that the opposition wants to pick and choose among the international rights issues that set standards around the world for various other countries. We in Australia should take note of that. The government certainly intends to try to ensure that we keep pace with standards that are set around the world in civilised countries.

PARA.TAB: In looking at the question of whether sections 45D and 45E are unduly harsh and restrictive compared with ILO conventions, the majority of the committee found that to be the case, and clearly it is. Substantial evidence was given to the committee on both sides of the argument. In particular, I would like to turn to evidence given by Mr Noakes on behalf of ACCI and his responses to questions by me.

We have to look at that in the context of the sort of industrial relations system that Australian employers want. One that was being pursued by the opposition prior to 13 March was a system called Jobsback. We called it `Jobsack' which was a more appropriate name for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, you are so witty!

—I can assure Senator O'Chee that it was a more appropriate name. That is why he and his colleagues are sitting over there and we are still in government. The employers said that they wanted a more flexible industrial relations system—one that, in their view, did not necessarily involve compulsory arbitration and did not envisage compulsory union membership. I do not know how they arrived at that view because there never has been compulsory unionism in this country.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the answers given by Mr Noakes on the issues that relate to the type of industrial relations system that employers wanted. The fundamental question is: `What rights would workers have under the opposition's Jobsack program, and what rights would employees have if employers achieved what they wanted?'. I asked Mr Noakes, `Okay, if the employers had the system that they wanted free of everything else, what protection would workers have to negotiate in enterprise agreements?'. In his reply Mr Noakes said there should be some degree of immunity. I will read from the Hansard report of the committee on 20 August 1993 in respect of some of these matters. In particular, I put a question to Mr Noakes relating to the executive summary of ACCI's submission which states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is not and there never has been in Australia a `workers' right to withdraw labour' . . . In practice, as opposed to theory, industrial action is unlawful under the common law or statute law, and there can be no `right' to engage in unlawful conduct. It is therefore not possible for the Committee to set out to do what the terms of reference direct it to do, and `clarify' a right which does not exist.
That is the ACCI's view. I put this question to Mr Noakes:
Do you think there should be a right?
His response was:

I do not think there should be, under the present industrial relations system that we have generally in this country. I do not think there should be a right to take industrial action with impunity, and I say that in respect of employees and employers. We must not forget that we have a rather peculiar system. It is the only system of its type in the industrialised world. Both through the operation of the common law and statute law, there has not been given any degree of immunity from the consequences of industrial action.
I then asked a further question of Mr Noakes:

I am not asking you in the context of what you have written there, because you do say that. I am asking you if you believe there should be some right. Let me put it in the context of there being another industrial relations system—the one that you would prefer.
Mr Noakes:
We would prefer a system in which there was no compulsory arbitration, and in which there was no award system as we know it at the moment,—
No award system—

but a voluntary system in which trade union membership was free and open and not restricted, in the way it is at the present time by statutory provisions, in the sense of freedom of choice. We would prefer a single, integrated system across the country, instead of the seven different systems which it seems are in a constant state of conflict with each other. Under that sort of system, which would be a bargaining system, as we see it—a true bargaining system, as is common in most countries of the world—we would see the need to revisit the packet of sanctions and the question of strike action or lockout action and to provide some degree of immunity in certain circumstances.
I asked Mr Noakes:
What do you believe those circumstances ought to be?
Mr Noakes replied:

Certainly, during the negotiation period for an agreement, when the parties were in the course of negotiating a fresh agreement—when their existing arrangements had expired—we would see the need for there to be some degree of immunity. But that is not unusual in a bargaining system and even, in some cases, in this country. It is true in Victoria, for example.

I asked him a question with respect to the degree. The representatives of a major employer group were unable, during the course of that process, to identify any degree of protection. Yet, they said they had a specific view of what type of industrial relations system they wanted. The major employer group in this country could not say what degree of protection workers would have to negotiate any arrangements in respect of their employment.

PARA.TAB: The committee's term of reference (B) states:

SPEECH.PARA: What revisions to either the Trade Practices Act 1974 or the Industrial Relations Act 1988 should be made in order to clarify a worker's right to withdraw labour and under what conditions such withdrawal may or may not be pursued . . .
Again, the committee found, as it did throughout, that the current Trade Practices Act and sections 45D and 45E were restrictive in allowing workers a right to protect conditions of employment.

PARA.TAB: Overall, of some 206 cases that have occurred from 1977 through to 1 July of this year under sections 45D and 45E, the overwhelming majority related to primary and industrial action being taken by workers. In particular, of the 206 actions commenced, 81 injunctions were granted, even though those actions were primarily related to industrial action for the protection of working conditions and, in fact, jobs in many cases. Information that was provided to us by the Department of Industrial Relations in section 8.1 of the contents of a very large submission outlined all the 206 cases.

I guess I can speak with some degree of knowledge about sections 45D and 45E. As Senator Crane said, yes, I am the subject of an action by a company. That action arose out of the protection of workers' jobs. It took place as a result of the admission of a company that it intended to import paper for the very purposes of denying workers the right to take industrial action over certain changes that had taken place within the company that related very specifically to their terms and conditions of employment. Yet, the company never sought, during the course of the action being taken by the unions at the request of their members, to resolve anything through the industrial relations system. It took action after the event. Quite clearly, that is a very good example of sections 45D and 45E being used purely as a punitive measure—not to settle an industrial dispute.
Term of reference (C) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether sections 45D&E provide security in law for the legitimate rights of individuals, and small and large businesses, to have freedom in the movement of goods and services and to trade without interference.

Again, this is a very relevant point. In fact, that was the major intention of sections 45D and 45E in the first place. The intention was to provide protection; it is about trade and trade restrictions. But the majority of times the legislation has been used it has been used to crush workers and their rights in protecting their employment and employment conditions.

PARA.TAB: In saying that, Mr Howard, in his second reading speech back in 1977, said, among other things:

SPEECH.PARA: Primary boycotts by employees are not, of course, dealt with by this Act.
It seems to me that out of 206 actions commenced, the vast majority relate to primary actions relating to industrial matters. He went on to say:
Secondary boycotts by employees do, however, have some unique features. Accordingly, the Bill has some special provisions which are appropriate only to employee secondary boycotts.

PARA.TAB: Where employees are taking action for a dominant purpose substantially related to the remuneration, conditions of employment, termination of employment, hours of work or working conditions of those employees, or fellow employees of the same employer, the secondary boycott is not prohibited.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet, if one looks through the case studies of all of the actions taken, the vast majority of those 206 cases, again, relate to those specific things. We should not lose sight of the fact that 81 injunctions were granted. So sections 45D and 45E have clearly been used as a punitive measure against workers and their legitimate pursuits to protect working conditions.

PARA.TAB: Term of reference (D) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether sections 45D&E are a satisfactory means of preventing and settling disputes.

The majority report found that clearly they are not, and history has shown that to be the case. Quite frankly, in a lot of circumstances, sections 45D and 45E actions have exacerbated the cases. Senator Carr pointed out that, in many circumstances where businesses have been used as a front to run a sections 45D and 45E action by a major company, the smaller company has ended up going broke. Whether Mudginberri was sold to somebody else is beside the point. What Senator Crane did not say was that, if it had not been sold, it would have gone broke anyway. It was just used as a front.

PARA.TAB: Term of reference (E) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The extent to which Sections 45D&45E might unduly restrict civil liberties, particularly by way of impeding the legitimate exercise of protest action by citizens

Again, a number of actions have been taken against conservation groups and others to protect either the environment or buildings that have ultimately ended up being protected under other legislation. It was clearly found by the committee that that is the case—that it does restrict the civil liberties of people to take action. I have heard Senator O'Chee argue the case very strongly for civil liberties, particularly in China. I am quite sure that where we have a legitimate protest action, he will clearly defend the right of Australians to take it and not be subject of punitive measures by way of such legislation as it stands in sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act.

PARA.TAB: Overall, the majority report of the committee clearly is correct. The sooner we look at the legislation that will come before this parliament the better. If those opposite knew anything about industrial relations they would not even be sitting here—the five wise monkeys! Quite frankly, they really do not understand the industrial relations system of this country. Since we came to office we have had the lowest level of industrial relations problems for 30 years. Where were those opposite in 1982? There were real problems then. We have taken industrial disputes to their lowest level for 30 years—in fact, probably in the history of this country. That is why we are going to make the changes.

We are going to deal with industrial relations matters where they should be dealt with, and they should be dealt with in the Industrial Relations Act. It does not deny the right of employers the opportunity to take action. If those opposite look at the way in which the legislation will be drafted, they will see that it does provide for very clear protection. It provides for protection for both parties and it is in the right area, and that is in the Industrial Relations Act.

The Trade Practices Act will also be amended to reflect what it should truly reflect; that is, the trade between businesses where there is action being taken by certain companies against other companies. That is how it should be. We surely must protect the rights of employees and we surely must deal with them in the right area.

Senator Crane made strong comment about the evidence given being overwhelmingly in favour of maintaining sections 45D and 45E as they stand in the Trade Practices Act. I would have to say that a number of employer groups—one of them, in particular, being the Business Council of Australia—have said that if we had a more flexible labour market system we would not need sections 45D and 45E, and they were not the only ones who said it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which union are you in?

—I am actually in the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union, and it is a good union. It is a pity a few more of those opposite do not know a bit more about the union. Some of them might be in the AMA—that is probably more their style. It is the strongest union in the country, screwing the guts out of ordinary Australians.

PARA.TAB: I would like to finish because I do not see a lot of point in continuing with my remarks. We will see legislation that will change the face of Australian industrial relations and set them in a position that will clearly provide a greater amount of flexibility; give the opportunity for non-unionists to enter into enterprise bargaining; and certainly give a much needed boost to the industrial relations front. It will clearly put industrial relations issues where they ought to be dealt with, and that is in the Industrial Relations Act; unlike what is being sought by the opposition, and that is not only to maintain sections 45D and 45E, but also to strengthen them.

Like the employers who said, `if we had a free market system', those opposite do not know. They do not want to provide any protection for workers. The whole intention of Fightback—Jobsback or Jobsack—was to reduce wages. That is what it was about. This government will not tolerate that and I am quite sure the Democrats and the Greens will support that legislation. It will be implemented to the betterment of this country and the betterment of the workers within this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The majority findings and recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training inquiry into sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act, the so-called secondary boycott provisions, fly in the face of the overwhelming nature of both the quantum and the logic of the evidence presented to the inquiry.
—Not a surprise.

—As Senator Parer says, it is not a surprise because the committee was dominated by either former unionists or those sympathetic to unions. As the minority report of the Liberal senators concludes, the majority report presents a grossly misleading picture. Senator Murphy, who addressed us for the last few minutes, talked repeatedly of the report's findings, but we need to remember that these findings are by no means unanimous findings. The findings he was referring to were the findings of the majority members—the government and the Democrats—on that committee.
—Most of them are.

—Senator Zakharov interjects that most committee reports are only majority reports. I have been on a number of Senate committee inquiries where we have been able to reach a unanimous conclusion and unanimous recommendations, but that does not seem to be the way with this particular committee.

PARA.TAB: Senator Murphy, in his concluding remarks, made the assertion that the Business Council of Australia had said that if we had a more flexible labour market we would not need these boycott provisions. Of course, the reality is that we do not have a more flexible labour market and under these proposals, and under the proposals that Minister Brereton has put forward in his discussion paper, we are not going to get a more flexible labour market. Indeed, we are going to get a much more restricted labour market than we already have. This government is about turning the clock back as far as industrial relations is concerned and entrenching more and more union power to the detriment of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be nice.

—Senator Burns said that it will be nice when we go back to the 19th century of industrial relations. I can tell him that this country is heading towards the 21st century. We need a much more flexible industrial relations system than we now have and we are not going to get it.
—We'll have two million unemployed.
—As Senator Parer says, unless we do get it we will have two million people out of work in this country.
—Tell us about industrial disputation in 1982.
—George Campbell with all those dead men around his neck; I remember that well.
—That was Paul Keating's remark.

—That is how Paul Keating described him. One of the government's own described him like that. Those opposite have suddenly gone quiet. The implementation of the majority recommendation to remove the secondary boycott provisions from the Trade Practices Act and to incorporate similar provisions in industrial relations legislation would, as we have been debating across the chamber for the last few minutes, simply entrench union power. It needs to be remembered that that is power that now represents less than 30 per cent of workers in the private sector. It would entrench the us and them mentality which has bedevilled industrial relations in this country for far too long. In the speeches we have heard this afternoon from Senator Murphy and Senator Carr we heard that us and them mentality exemplified par excellence. That is what we have to get rid of in this country if we are ever going to compete in the international marketplace.

PARA.TAB: Evidence to the committee demonstrated that the use of sanctions under sections 45D and 45E are usually last ditch resorts, used when all else has failed; used when no resolution has been possible between employer and employee; used when industrial jurisdiction—and Senator Murphy recommends that these provisions should be taken out of the trade practices jurisdiction and put into the industrial relations jurisdiction—has failed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the case and the evidence does not support it.

—The evidence does sustain it. The fact is that employers do not race out and take out injunctions every day. They are not all that easy to obtain and they are certainly not inexpensive. Employers often stated to the committee that if you have reached for the use of this sanction, the situation is pretty explosive and confrontationist anyway. The single action of resorting to the use of the secondary boycott provisions is not likely to make much difference to the moods of the parties involved. Indeed, it was indicated in evidence that the use of such sanctions often has a very positive impact on the resolution of disputes because it does, indeed, lead to their resolution. Employers are not encouraged by their own organisations, such as the Chamber of Commerce and Industry, to race out and take out such an application. They are, as I said, usually remedies of final recourse.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the impact of sections 45D and 45E on the individual's exercise of individual rights, particularly as lauded in International Labour Organisation conventions, such security already exists in Australia and is not circumscribed by the secondary boycott provisions.

Furthermore, the matter of individual and particular freedoms and personal rights which currently exist or may exist in Australian law is an area for the Australian Parliament, nationally, and Australian state parliaments to address and make decisions about, not necessarily a matter for international conventions. Both sections 45D and 45E concern the prevention of illegal boycotts which interfere with the ability of businesses to trade and go about lawful activities.

Trade unions have long campaigned to obtain a repeal of these sections. Their own protector, and indeed enhancer of union power, this Keating Labor government, supports them. Both seem blind to the fact that such action may financially cripple companies, thus resulting in company closures and significant loss of jobs. In fact, a repeal of these provisions has been attempted at least twice by the Labor government, in 1984 and 1987. Sensibly, the Democrats did not support the proposals in 1984 and, with our opposition to them very clear, that legislation was defeated.

In the latter example, 1987, the Labor government attempted to seriously delay employer access to the remedies and prevent use of most aspects of the common law tort injunction. But on deciding to call an early election in 1987, it abandoned these proposals in the face of enormous public opposition which threatened its re-election. Now, of course, with another election safely out of the way, Labor clearly believes that it can fly directly in the face of public opinion which is so opposed to these moves.

In other avenues of industrial legislation, the Labor government has lent its great weight to assist trade unions at the expense of the greater national interest. Trade unions have been encouraged to hamstring and hinder business operations. It seems that the Luddite mentality is still alive and well.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sure is; I'm looking at it.
—Yes, I am looking at it right across the chamber.
—And it is not a pleasant sight.

—No, it is not. It is quite distracting to look across there and see that Luddite mentality exemplified. It is a well known fact that across a range of industries—including the building, waterside and manufacturing and transport industries—this is the case. Of course, the Dollar Sweets and Mudginberri cases immediately come to mind as particularly explosive and damaging circumstances which would not have been solved without the 45D and 45E provisions where again, as I have emphasised earlier, they were used as last resort measures.

PARA.TAB: Responsible employers around Australia, through their peak body the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, strongly believe that this Labor government has sought to significantly increase trade union power and its capacity to inflict damage on Australian industry. They believe that sections 45D and 45E have played a key role in ensuring that the outbreak of disruptive national industry campaigns, including coercion and threatening campaigns, has been reduced to a minimum. Without these provisions, we would have seen much more national disruption in the industrial sphere.

It is a shame that the Labor government that has now been in office for a decade—previously, the Hawke government and now the Keating government—could not invest a similar effort in much needed restructuring for efficiency improvements. Evidence from the Business Council of Australia to this inquiry similarly supports the view that the Trade Practices Act has been highly successful in discouraging secondary boycotts and in creating a positive environment in industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one takes you seriously, Grant.
—No-one takes Minister Bolkus seriously, do they?
—Telecom does.

—Telecom, of course; he has a noted history with Telecom, but apart from that. Similarly, the National Farmers Federation, which represents industries contributing about 30 per cent of Australia's export income, argued that businesses within the rural sector of Australia could not afford to be exposed to anti-competitive forces from within the country. It gave the example of the Tasmanian Transport Workers Union's 24-hour dispute. Senator Murphy is a Tasmanian; he ought to know all about this.
—I do, actually.
—He does; he says he knows all about it. Let me remind him of what happened there. There was a 24-hour dispute potentially involving milk tanker drivers.
—And you say—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Order! Senator Murphy, I think you have had a fair go with interjections and you have also spoken on this topic. I would ask you just to tone yourself down, please.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for your assistance, Mr Acting Deputy President; it is certainly appreciated, although I think I can cope with what Senator Murphy might have to say across the chamber.

PARA.TAB: I was referring to this potential Transport Workers Union strike in Tasmania where, in the circumstances, the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association issued a statement alerting members to record their milk losses and a threat to prosecute under section 45D of the Trade Practices Act. As a direct result of that, the drivers did not strike. So again this provision protected a very important industry from disruptive and costly industrial action.

Such examples serve to reinforce that a weakening of protection from these sections could very well inflict irreparable and serious damage on Australian businesses and the Australian economy overall, and consolidate an increase in union power as a consequence. In addition, as is obvious from evidence from the Australian Chamber of Shipping to the inquiry, real and harmful economic problems would result from a weakening of both sections. It referred to the $415 million invested into the waterfront reform process by both industry and by taxpayers through this government's funding of that reform process, and indicated that that process could be severely jeopardised by continual disruption between tugboats and waterfront labour, often costing some ships up to $30,000 a day. The government ought to know that efficient and effective ports, waterfront and shipping sectors are absolutely crucial to enhancing Australia's export performance.

Pioneer Concrete also provided evidence that reinforced the value of retaining sections 45D and 45E in the Trade Practices Act. A dispute there involved Pioneer employed lorry drivers and Ibis lorry owners. Pickets were withdrawn and industrial action ceased when Pioneer commenced proceedings under section 45D. Effectively, the Ibis drivers were attempting to prevent Pioneer employees from engaging in Pioneer's own cartage.

This government in the current financial year allocated over $10 1/2 million to the Trade Union Training Authority. Some of this money at least ought to be put to good use by being spent on educating employees and union members of their own obligations, responsibilities and liabilities under the law. It is clear that many trade union members or officials have little or no meaningful understanding of the Trade Practices Act, or indeed of sections 45D and 45E of that act—or, if they do understand it, they certainly have little respect for it.

The major thrust of the majority report is incorrect. Employer preference for 45D and 45E has no relation to the ineffectiveness of arbitration because it is a secondary action; the use of these secondary boycott provisions is a secondary action, not a primary one. Boycott provisions are useful tools of arbitration and resolution. Boycott action must be curtailed and employers given a remedy which is effective, immediate and responsible, both for the company and for those who derive an interest from its continuing operation, whether they be company employees who have secure employment or shareholders who derive an income from their investment in the company.

This country simply cannot afford to leapfrog into expanding trade union power given that at present, as I said earlier, less than 30 per cent of Australians working in the private sector are trade union members. There is absolutely no justification for the recommendations made by the majority on this committee. The wider business community does not want to be hamstrung by a determined minority who would seek to narrow the vision for this country and make the national interest fully expendable.

Sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act must not be removed from that act and the secondary boycott provisions transferred to the Industrial Relations Act, and they must not be limited only to primary boycotts. Should this happen, not only will businesses and companies suffer, but the secure employment of thousands of employees will be placed in jeopardy.

It is regrettable that even the language used in the Labor government's working paper on legislative reform detailing proposed changes to the Industrial Relations Act strongly reinforces a divisive spirit rather than a conciliatory one. The use of the word `target' in that paper, to refer to a business or company with which a union was dealing, does not augur well for the future of industrial relations, trade practices or the long term economic wellbeing of this country. It portends a churlish and immature attitude to negotiation and conciliation and constructs a difficult path for all parties to tread.

I will reinforce the points I have made by quoting from the Crawford report, which was commissioned by the Fraser coalition government in the late 1970s and which emphasised the many opportunities within the grasp of Australian industry. Though it is around 15 years old now, it clearly has a solid shelf life. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The choice is clear. Australia can attempt to preserve past patterns and attitudes.
In that event, Australia is likely to continue to slip down the table of world living standards. In these circumstances, unemployment at quite high levels might be a long-term problem.

Is that not exactly what we have seen under a decade of Labor government, which has attempted in many respects, but most particularly in the field of industrial relations, to preserve past patterns and attitudes? Clearly, we have not really learnt from the last decade of lost and squandered opportunity under Labor. The fact that this government is seeking to return industrial relations and trade practices to a battleground forum with its current views on this issue is not without significance in the light of that report.

PARA.TAB: Unless both employer and employee groups see industrial conflict resolution clearly, without recourse to crippling and disabling legislative changes, Australia is destined for international industrial insignificance. To conclude, I can do no better than to quote from the submission to this inquiry from Mr John White, Managing Director of Delta Hydraulics in Tasmania, which said:

SPEECH.PARA: The industrial relations system in Australia has resulted in a `them and us' culture which is the backbone of the union movement. They are doing whatever they possibly can to maintain this culture.
The future for Australia is the removal of the them and us culture, a total change in management philosophy to create a new structure in Australian companies.
The company structure that is based on power and subordination, manager and subordinate must in time be replaced with mutual understanding and responsibility.

This can be done with the development of a shared vision of where the company is positioning itself for the future but we need to maintain the protection from those outside our company who do not share our vision. Sections 45D and 45E provide some of that protection.

In proposing to remove sanctions against secondary boycotts from the Trade Practices Act, this Keating Labor government is setting its face against the transformation of industrial relations in Australia into a cooperative enterprise-based system—a system which this country desperately needs. This system is essential if we are going to optimise our economic performance and provide jobs for those whom unions seem to represent least of all—the one million unemployed created by this government's inept policies and inept management.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the opposition has a hide to be critical of the government's legislative program in relation to industrial relations, given that during the opposition's years in office there were an enormous number of industrial disputes and since the election of the Labor government in 1983 the incidence of those disputes has been reduced very considerably. I think that is a good thing, as do people in the trade union movement.

PARA.TAB: At that time there was a pre-negotiated agreement, called the accord, between the unions and the Australian Labor Party. That accord was made public during the election. On that basis, among other good policies, the Labor Party was elected. That has resulted, as everyone knows—or certainly could not argue against—in redirecting quite a lot of money, in terms of wages, to profits of companies, which ran into billions of dollars over time. It resulted in a fairly big reduction in wage claims. That cannot be denied, given that on some occasions wages went up as much as $30 in a year. It cannot be argued against. The facts are there. It is very clear.

I believe that one has to look at the merit of each piece of legislation. I have a bias towards the trade union movement. I guess I could get quite excited about those who would oppose it and try to take away from it its right to defend its members. I do not know that that would do much good in a debate that should be rational. I suggest that we do not want a situation in which we have a chance to revert to depending only on the law to regulate and to deal with industrial problems. We did that in the last century, and the Tolpuddle Martyrs were sent to Australia because they dared to get together and ask for a shilling a week increase, I think it was, from the farmers for whom they worked.

Everyone knows—it is clearly on the record—that, in the main, over the years the law has been directed to protecting property rather than individuals. I know we have come a long way. There has been quite a shift in that direction and now there are laws which protect individuals. I think that is a good thing. I believe that we should nurture that idea and protect people's rights.

These provisions were developed in an act which talked about commerce. It was not really intended to look at or to regulate industrial matters; rather, it talked about commerce in terms of competition. People in commerce believe in competition. They talk about `no regulation' and `free competition'. The trade unions do not. They always try to maintain some equality for people who are paid a wage to produce goods or services. We do not suggest that because people have blue eyes they should get an extra $5 a week. We suggest that for a job done everyone should get a reasonable wage and a reasonable set of working conditions. The way the trade unions operate and the way business operates in seeking a profit are quite different. At no stage were these provisions suitable for determining industrial matters.

If people think that on a really important issue, one which is fundamental to the trade union movement, any provision in the law will stop it defending the rights of its members, if they think there are enough police in this country, or that the army is big enough, to stop it moving to protect that position, they are quite mistaken.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are above the law?

—That is not the way to go either. I just make the point that the law will not do the job. If it is an unfair and unjust law and if it is used unjustly, it will not do the job. What we should be doing is getting together and trying to create all of those things that go to create wealth in this country—commodity goods, manufactured goods and services—so we can all get a bigger share of it. If we try to do that, we will be much better off. That is one of the reasons the government moved to the area of negotiating industrial agreements with companies. We think that is the way to go.

PARA.TAB: There are some problems with that. We could have people in a particular industry who can use higher levels of technology and who become very efficient, both in management and at the job face. They could make quite large earnings, whereas others may do their best and yet their earnings will never match those of these people. We will have great differences in the community. There would have to be government action to try to redress that in some way through the social wage. The report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training talks about disaffection with section 45D and 45E arising from a number of considerations. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that it is wholly inappropriate that sections 45D&E of Trade Practices legislation should be used in relation to industrial disputes, and that industrial legislation should be the core mechanism for resolution of industrial disputes.
.that the sections attack basic rights guaranteed by international covenants;
.that the sections are used harshly and inappropriately, beyond the "innocent third party" intention, and against "legitimate" union action.

Many people hide behind 45D and 45E so that they do not have to negotiate meaningfully. This is not new. For a long time the penalty provisions in the act and the penalty provisions that affect federal awards in this country suppressed trade union activity. People would be called into the arbitration court and asked whether they were on strike. They were never asked what the strike was about, whether there was any reason for it, or whether it could be negotiated; they were asked whether they were on strike. If they said yes, they could be found guilty and fined quite large amounts each day of that dispute. They did not get to the bottom of it or try to solve it. That approach never solved anything. We saw what happened with the O'Shea matter. Those legislative provisions were never used again. People who in other cases would normally have negotiated meaningfully did not negotiate.

PARA.TAB: I refer in passing to an example in Queensland. For many years, the National Party government banned marching, unless those who wished to march went to the inspector who was in charge of traffic and put in a submission to do so. That inspector had the right to deny them the right to march. They had the opportunity to appeal, but the outcome of the appeal was determined by that person, who was hardly about to reverse his decision.

That law resulted in many marches, division within the community and the accusation of assault by police. I myself experienced some rather nasty moments with the police. Most of them, but not all, were quite insulting. All this friction was occurring because of the implementation of a bad law in a bad way.

Since the Labor government was elected in Queensland, people have felt very little need to march on particular issues—probably because they have good government. They now have the right to march, but they have not done so. There is no division in the community. The matter has been dealt with by proper reason, government and legislation. I suggest that we take a lesson from that. We should look at it and say, `Let's move sections 45D and 45E into the Industrial Arbitration Act'.

Anybody who suggests that the giving of three days to try to resolve a dispute industrially—three days would be a national disaster—is being mischievous. We will only pull this country up to the level that it is capable of by working together, with management making a contribution sensibly and intelligently. During the many years that I was a trade unionist, I met many such managers. Giving that example and creating trust through providing information to the workers and the people who represent them can transmit into support. That is much better than wanting to bludgeon people with a law that is seen by them to be unjust.

In closing, such a law will not do the job if the issue is fundamental enough and important enough. I suggest that the opposition should rethink its position and support this very forward looking proposal that is before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the minority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. I raise these very serious questions: will the recommendations of the majority report of this committee, if implemented, lead to increased wealth in Australia? If these changes are implemented, will they help Australia become a more competitive, wealthy and prosperous country? Will it lead to increased investment and more jobs and incomes for our young people in the future? Will the 800,000 businesses in Australia—most of them small—be helped or hindered in their goals of wanting to either expand or commence new businesses?

PARA.TAB: It is only from the expansion of existing businesses or the starting up of new businesses—which is what investment is all about—that new jobs will be created. The answer is unequivocally that the majority recommendations of this report, if implemented, will have a deleterious effect on investment, the expansion of business in Australia and, hence, on jobs. It will certainly discourage investment.

Already we have been told that the government, in its announcements about the industrial relations package, is proposing to weaken the boycott provisions that are currently in the Trade Practices Act. The critical thing that the government is proposing is a 72-hour period before one can seek injunctive relief from a boycott.

The main point about section 45D and section 45E of the Trade Practices Act is that the threat of action against secondary boycotts has been more important as a deterrent than the actual implementation of these sections of the law. In other words, the law now prevents undesirable events without recourse to legal remedies. It is a good preventive measure. Therefore, these sections act as deterrents, which is what we want; we do not want people appearing before the courts. The evidence that was placed before this committee is quite unequivocal: these sections act as an effective deterrent in the business community against unfair boycott action.

The majority report is really about the government's intention to increase union power. In Australia, we need economic growth. It has been quite clear for many years now that what is required—it has even been enunciated by many government ministers—is a freeing up of the markets within Australia, the lowering of costs and our being internationally competitive in everything that we do. We need more competition in every market, particularly in the labour market.

Prosperity certainly comes from healthy, active competition. In recognition of this, the Labor government commissioned this year a major report on competition by Professor Hilmer. The Hilmer report was tabled only a few weeks ago, and it is very interesting. I will from quote page 42 of that report under the title of `Boycotts':

SPEECH.PARA: The operation of the secondary boycott provisions is currently the subject of a Senate Inquiry. On the basis of submissions received by this Inquiry, the Committee—
that is, the Hilmer committee—
has not been persuaded of the need to amend the current provisions dealing with boycotts.

In other words, an independent inquiry into what direction the government should be pursuing with regard to competition in general terms has looked at the same evidence and reached a quite different conclusion from the majority report. This shows quite clearly that the majority report of this committee has been basically a political decision; hence the importance of the minority report, which basically sets out the true facts of the evidence placed before the committee.

PARA.TAB: A couple of other key points arose from the Hilmer committee. Page 43 of the Hilmer report states this about overseas approaches:

SPEECH.PARA: International experience indicates support for prohibiting boycotts through competition or industrial relations policy.

In other words, Hilmer agrees with the policy that is here in Australia. The report then talks about the US, New Zealand, the UK and Canada. The prime conclusion of this section on boycotts is on page 46 of the report:

The Committee did not receive any compelling evidence supporting reform of the primary or secondary boycott provisions, which appear broadly consistent with overseas practice. In these circumstances, the Committee does not propose any amendment to the current provisions.

So another committee that has been set up by the Labor government to give it advice about which way it should go has looked at exactly the same evidence and come to a conclusion that is identical to the conclusion of the minority report.

PARA.TAB: The coalition is not worrying about the actions of responsible unions. That is not a concern. We agree with what Senator Burns said before. We are about working together; we all have to do that in order to be competitive and to succeed. There is absolutely no future for confrontation and the old style of `them and us'. Effective competition within Australia and in the world is the key to making that work.

What the law currently does under sections 45D and 45E is an effective deterrent to unreasonable union behaviour. The submissions and the evidence given to the committee have been excellent and comprehensive. I commend the minority report to the Senate. I express my disappointment that the majority report was not consistent with the government's other report, the Hilmer report, which was recently tabled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The majority report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act was about as predictable as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Labor Party keeping election promises. It represents the response of a bunch of monkeys dancing to the tune of the trade union organ grinders. It is a slavish response to the powerful trade union bosses to further entrench their powers and put them above the law.
—You do not believe that.

—Senator Bolkus says that I do not believe it—no, I know it. It is not a matter of belief. I know it and he knows it, as well as everybody else. Since 1977, which is a period of fifteen years, only 206 civil actions have been commenced by employers; of that, only 81 injunctions were granted; there were only three orders for damages; and there have been no applications for the maximum monetary penalty of $250,000. If my memory is correct, not one moderate trade union was involved in any of these actions under the Trade Practices Act. The very militant left wing unions were involved in every instance. The majority report was predictable because it was based on ideological grounds; all the Labor members, as far as I could see, were members of trade unions, so there was a vested interest involved.
—You do not have an ideology?
—I have beliefs but I do not have the fanatical ideology of the left wing of the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order! Senator Burns, if you must interject, please do so in your correct place.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Burns knows, I have worked in industry all my life in a very cooperative fashion, both with my own employees and with the trade unions involved. It is worth drawing the attention of the chamber to the submission made by the Small Business Coalition to the Treasurer in regard to the budget. It has some fairly strong words to say. We are talking about the people who represent the vast work force out there in the small business sector—the one that this government says we must support because this is how we are going to get growth and employment. The submission states:

SPEECH.PARA: Sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act have long been a bulwark against the misuse of union power in dealing with small business.

Think about those words: `the misuse of power'. We are not talking about people with legitimate reasons being able to withdraw their labour. No-one objects to that, for instance, in the case of a genuine safety measure—not a phoney one that Senator Burns would know about. This is in relation to the misuse of union power. The submission continues:
Their retention is regarded as critically important to ensuring a stable industrial relations environment.
This is coming from the small business coalition which I think represents 40 small business groups around Australia. It further states:
Sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act have played, and should continue to play, a central role in ensuring industrial harmony in Australia. Without this harmony—
and this is the critical part—

investor and business confidence will be diminished. Any proposal to remove these sections from the trade practices legislation can only have disastrous effects on the fragile recovery now taking place.

These people are not the wild, extreme right—I think Senator Carr referred to the new right—of the business sectors in Australia. These are the small business people of Australia who need these sorts of protections. They are protecting themselves against the abuse of union power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Moderate business people.

—Even Senator Burns recognises that the vast majority of them are people who would just like to get on with their job and have a happy employee-employer relationship. I would also like to refer—because it relates to my old industry, the coalmining industry—to the submission by the Australian Coal Association. The Australian Coal Association is Australia's biggest single export earner. Senator Burns, of all the people in this place, would know the conditions under which people in this industry work. Those conditions would be the envy of any worker, not only in this country but throughout the world. I refer to their housing conditions and to their conditions of work: everything is air conditioned—the bulldozers, the draglines and so on.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Coal Association put in the best submission that I saw, for its ease of reading and so on. The submission refers to the Utah Development case against the Seamen's Union. I want to talk about that because I was the one who initiated the section 45D and 45E proceedings back in 1977 or thereabouts. I will outline the background.

In the mid-1970s, Australia relied almost entirely on Japan and, initially, Korea for the sale of its raw materials. It was decided that this was not a very healthy situation, that we should diversify that market. This was coking coal to go to Europe in the percentage of about 30 per cent as against 70 per cent to Japan. That was fine. So markets were developed in places like Britain, France, Italy, Holland, Belgium and so on. That was not easy because the traditional suppliers to those markets were the United States, Canada, Poland and there were some indigenous coals which were subsidised then and which continue to be subsidised.

One of the problems that arose was the wildly fluctuating sea freight. It got to the stage where, particularly with the oil crisis, it was unpredictable. So the decision was made to set up a company to purchase bulk carriers—not to make money, simply so the freight rate could be predicted between Australia and Europe.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was to make money.

—Senator Carr has that cynical approach, but he has no understanding. He is a typical left wing union radical who has brought this country to its knees. If he would listen to what I had to say instead of closing his eyes, he might understand what it was about. I made the remark that the decision was made to diversify markets for the benefit of this country. The freight market was unpredictable, so the decision was made to buy these carriers. There were ten carriers—two new ones, purchased out of Japan, and the others existing carriers from a fleet. The only way this could work, because of the distances involved, was to take ore from either the Bowen basin or the Pilbara to Europe and then, on the way back, pick up oil. Without that, it was totally uneconomic. In other words, the freight rate was over the top and we would have to give up the European market.

PARA.TAB: This is what happened: one of those ships, the Lake Berryessa, called in at Port Stanvac, on its way from the Middle East, and it was impounded by the Seamen's Union. The Seamen's Union wanted to have Australian crews on those ships. Nothing would have given me greater pleasure than to have Australian crews on those ships. The trouble was, the then work conditions—which have now changed—were such that, instead of having a crew of 18 or 19 on the ship, which was the norm in international markets, the Australian Seamen's Union demanded a crew of 45. It had other conditions that were not in keeping with the rest of the world too, like six months on, six months off, and so on. At the time, I put it to those people in the Seamen's Union that if they were prepared—and this was not a way of cutting back on wages and conditions—to match—

TALK.START.PARA: —For convenience.
—Not convenience type things but the ones that operated out of the British system.
—The international ones.

—Yes, the international ones. If they had been prepared to do that, we would have been happy to go along with it. Elliott V. Elliott was then the leader of the Seamen's Union. Because of the actions he took, he has the record of almost destroying the coastal trade in Australia. He said that the Lake Berryessa could stay at Port Stanvac until its bottom fell out. In fact, I think his remarks were cruder than that but I will not repeat them here.

PARA.TAB: We were in total dismay. The ship was impounded by the Seamen's Union. What could we do? It was there for six months. The cost of that—about $30,000 a day, apart from the missed opportunity costs of not being able to haul ore from Queensland to Europe—was enormous. The only recourse we had was to use sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. No other method could have been used. If anyone can tell me of one, I will be delighted to hear about it.

Because of sections 45D and 45E, the Lake Berryessa was allowed out of Port Stanvac—but after six months. Once that happened—there was an unsuccessful jurisdictional challenge to the High Court—the union dropped its boycott action. Looking back, I wonder why the company did not proceed to sue for damages. It was not, as I think Senator Murphy indicated, some sort of vindictive measure.

The sad part about this matter is that we had in our hands in this country an island continent and the beginnings of a merchant navy which, with the passage of time and with a more reasonable approach by a more reasonable union, may well have turned into an Australian merchant navy fleet. In the end, notwithstanding the fact that the original intent was to purchase vessels to have a predictable freight rate between Australia and Europe, the company sold the whole lot. It sold the ships simply because the freight rates around the world became cheaper. It had nothing to do with the unions or sections 45D and E. I have often looked back on that and thought to myself, `Here was an opportunity'. Agreements were reached at the same time—this was very difficult—for partial shipments out of the Pilbara to go on those ships to Japan. This is notwithstanding the fact that when the Japanese enter into long-term agreements they have back to back agreements with their own shipping companies—mainly crewed by the Koreans, I might mention as an aside. Yet we were able to get that little niche in there back in the 1970s. The thing that distresses me is that that was a great opportunity lost because of the militancy of the trade union movement, specifically the Seamen's Union.

My colleague Senator Gibson mentioned the Hilmer report, which I will touch on briefly. Professor Hilmer said that the committee—I know this has been quoted before—did not get any compelling evidence supporting the reform of the primary or secondary boycott provisions. In regard to secondary boycotts, he went on to say, `In fact what we did find was that in every country there are provisions against this sort of action'. When Senator Carr talked about this matter, he gave the history—going back to 1983 or thereabouts—of the attempts by the trade union movement to remove sections 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act. There have been attempts by the unions to do this, simply to make them more powerful. I have already mentioned that sections 45D and 45E have never really been used much, but they sit there as a very important deterrent. If it were not for that deterrent, there would have been a lot more disputation. Earlier one of my colleagues remarked that these sections of the act have prevented disputes ending up in the courts and going on and on. That is entirely correct.

Naturally, I support the minority report. I have been on committees like this before. Every time I see a majority report which does not reflect the weight of logic and the weight of evidence given by people to that committee, but rather reflects the political opinions of the majority, I think it is a great disservice to this place. It was never the intention of Senate standing committees to do that. If this sort of thing continues, people will ask why it is worth spending all that time and all that money preparing evidence to bring before a committee when the result is known before the first witness gives evidence.

I said it was not the first time this has happened. The last time this happened to me—I was not on this committee—was when I was a member of the committee that inquired into the third runway in Sydney. We took evidence for more than six months. The overwhelming evidence was to build that third runway and build it fast. The majority report by the Labor Party recommended that the third runway not be built. I can remember saying to Senator Collins—a humble backbencher in those days—`I never expected that you would sign your name to a dishonest report'. He said, `Do you want to stand in the way of a potentially brilliant political career?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was right.

—Yes, he was right. But within six or 12 months of the majority report coming out saying, `No, let's not build the third runway', moves were being made to build it. I raise that because it has concerned me for quite some time. I understand that there are differences in interpretations and that there are political necessities. But the more this happens, the more it denigrates the real role of these committees when, quite obviously, the weight of logic in the evidence points in one direction and yet the majority report comes out the other way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer said that the weight of logic is in favour of the minority report. That would mean that sections 45D and 45E would remain in the trade practices legislation. It might be interesting to see why it is logical to have sections 45D and 45E in an act which, apart from the provisions of those particular sections, deals with the marketplace in goods and services—an act which has two main purposes: the encouragement of competition in the marketplace and consumer protection. Those two very laudable aims are aimed at fairness of contract, fairness of dealings between competitors who produce goods and services, and fairness of dealings between consumers and those who provide them with the goods and services they consume.

PARA.TAB: I therefore ask—and this point has been made again and again but never logically answered—why should provisions which deal fundamentally with industrial relations be dealt with in such an act unless—I am sure Senator Parer does not take this position—we are to consider that there is no distinction to be drawn between the provision of labour and the provision of other goods and services?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before the dinner suspension, the contribution people make to this nation—whether economic, cultural or social—through either physical or mental work, should not be measured in the same way as any other commodity. To have people's labour contributions dealt with by the Trade Practices Act, which deals in all its provisions with goods and services, is most unfortunate to say the least. I think the people who wrote this report were correct in saying that things ought to be changed.

PARA.TAB: I will give an illustration of how, unfortunately, the provisions of this act, as they presently stand, operate. The Odco case relied on sections 45D and 45E. That case was taken through to its conclusion and a finding was made against the two unions—the BWIU and another union. The full title of that case was the Building Workers' Industrial Union of Australia and Others v. Odco Pty Ltd. In the first instance the case was heard by Mr Justice Woodward. The unions appealed that decision and it was then heard by Mr Justice Wilcox, Mr Justice Burchett and Mr Justice Ryan of the Full Court of the Federal Court. In the Full Court the Justices said:

SPEECH.PARA: His Honour—
this refers to Mr Justice Woodward—

also found that the rates of pay offered to its workers were adjusted unilaterally each year by Troubleshooters without consultation with the workers who were nevertheless advised of each adjustment shortly before or immediately after it occurred.
This case dealt with workers who had their rates of pay unilaterally adjusted each year. The point was that the workers were not receiving wages but remuneration as independent contractors.

PARA.TAB: It is a very liberal interpretation of `independent contractors' when the people who are supposed to be independent contractors accept an offer made to them by the agent Troubleshooters and then do not have the ability to seek better conditions or better wages. This was a situation where sections 45D and 45E were used to protect a system where workers were given wages each year at the determination of Troubleshooters without any assistance from the unions and where, in theory if not in practice, the workers could be treated in a most shameful way. When some protest was made to stop that system continuing, even though at that stage it may have been continuing with the approval of some—but not all—of those employed by Troubleshooters, and attempts were made to change the system, the law stepped in and stopped that happening.

That is the problem with the way sections 45D and 45E presently operate. They do not operate in the interests of employees. They do not operate in the interests of workers. They operate in the interests of commerce. The interests of commerce are taken to transcend any concern for the conditions of workers.

That is understood in section 45D. There is a provision in that section which gives some weight to the fact that people might be taking action in an attempt to get better wages and conditions. But section 45E does not contain that protection. We have a system that operates on a basis that is hostile to the sorts of things that workers might want to obtain, such as fair wages, proper conditions, reasonable time off and other provisions that the government says make things acceptable for the people who produce the wealth of this country.

Where the underlying concepts of 45D and 45E are in their very nature hostile to the sorts of things that workers need, then it is proper that they should be taken out of that act. If some protection is needed for employers, then that should be provided in some other way. The majority report on the operation of sections 45D and 45E makes a great contribution not only to the workers of this country but also to the general way this society performs. It would be a very backward step if the approach recommended in this report were not accepted.

The problem with sections 45D and 45E is that they are built on the concepts of free trade which ignore the great social, cultural and fairness concepts of how people should be treated in the workplace. All section 45E is concerned with is the protection of trade and commerce.

That comes directly from the common law system which we inherited from England. England passed awful legislation in 1798 and 1800, the combinations acts, which punished workers who simply struck in a desperate attempt to get better conditions. It was an offence, punishable by imprisonment for up to three months, for people to join together to obtain an increase in wages, a reduction in hours of work or a decrease in the rate of production.

I am not saying that that is the situation today, but I do say that the philosophy that gave birth to the Combinations Act and the provisions of the common law, as they then operated, are the concepts behind 45D and 45E. Just as in England those concepts were set aside by acts such as the 1906 Trade Disputes Act, so sections 45D and 45E should be set aside in the interests of a better workplace—although that is only part of the equation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other part of the equation is that the sort of society that we live in ought to demand that sections 45D and 45E be replaced with a more humane and better conceived system. I am sure that Senator O'Chee does not want a nation of people who work in awful conditions, at low rates of pay and for long hours. He does not want to see family life, the very pillar of society, set aside by these sorts of attitudes that are behind sections 45D and 45E.
—I don't like the union thugs who cost my brother his job, either.
—That is the problem with arguments put forward on the other side of the house. Opposition senators quote examples, but they do not quote statistics; they do not quote general concepts. They quote—
—Facts.

—Of course, they do, but they are facts that are very limited, in the sense that those opposite give two or three examples. Senator Parer was the same. Opposition senators say, `Look, we can point to two or three examples where there has been an injustice; therefore, the whole system has to change. Injustice has to be brought to the workplace. Workers have to be put at a disadvantage. People have to cop what we give them simply because my brother was badly treated' or `the mines I worked for at such and such a date were badly treated' or `I know of a shipping company that suffered because of the way the workers performed on that occasion'.

PARA.TAB: It is similar to the school class. Because one little boy or girl does something wrong, the whole class is kept in. That is a very strange concept on which to base policy. What has happened with this report is that the majority has looked at the overall concepts, the interests of the community as a whole and the interests of the people who work as a whole—and that is all of us—and it has come up with this conclusion. They do not say for one minute that there ought to be thuggery in the union movement or anywhere else. Sections 45D and 45E are not directed at thuggery; they are not directed at violence; they are not directed at the commission of crime. We might use sections 45D and 45E where those sorts of things occur, but the section is not directed at that. The sections attempt to boycott—

TALK.START.PARA: —Victimisation of the innocent.
—No. It attempts to boycott. If I stand outside a factory and invite a person in a most reasonable way not to take goods into that factory because—
—That wasn't what was happening at Burnie.

—This is what this section hits at. I say, `My family is in all sorts of trouble because I am not getting enough wages. My friend had his arm chopped the other day because of bad conditions in the factory. It is up to you whether or not you go in there, but I invite you not to'. Proceedings could be taken against me and those other people who accompanied me on the picket line for doing simply that. A lot of the debate has been devoted to a concept that there is violence, trouble and agro, if I can use that expression, surrounding the picket line. But that is not what either section 45D or 45E is directed at. They are directed at a situation where people can otherwise go around in a very peaceful picketing action.
—If only they were as reasonable as you, there would be no trouble.
—Something Senator O'Chee would be familiar with is a work by Patricia Hewitt entitled The abuse of power: civil liberties in the United Kingdom.
—I have read it.
—Listen to this then. Page 128 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The freedom to strike is an essential part of the right of workers to bargain collectively with their employers. The organization of a picket is, in turn, an essential part of the freedom to strike—
I am sure that Senator O'Chee would agree with that—

But industrial pickets are also a particular form of the use of a general right, the right to assemble peacefully. For most of this century the law has given to industrial pickets a different status from that of other demonstrations. But in its most recent proposals for a new public-order law, the Government has proposed extensive new restrictions on the exercise of the right to picket—
it did not remove it during the Thatcher era—
by simultaneously proposing new controls on demonstrations on outdoor meetings and re-defining most industrial pickets as demonstrations.
It goes on to say:

The 1906 Trade Disputes Act made it lawful to picket a workplace or home for the purposes of persuasion or peaceful communication, provided that the picket was undertaken `in contemplation or furtherance of a trade dispute'.

That is the sort of thing that sections 45D and 45E strike at—that peaceful, reasonable action to persuade. If Senator O'Chee, as part of a picket line of trade unionists, sports people or young farmers, simply went up to a car with some people inside and said, `We have a concern; we would prefer you did not go in to that particular place', then sections 45D and 45E would be relevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —But standing in the way of the car and stopping them going in is not reasonable; that is the problem.

—That is exactly the point. If we stood in the way of the car, if we assaulted somebody or if we broke the law, we can be arrested and taken away without sections 45D and 45E. Sections 45D and 45E are not aimed at that. Those sorts of things might happen in circumstances where sections 45D and 45E operate, but they are not necessary for the operation of sections 45D and 45E.

PARA.TAB: This report is saying that the sorts of things that Senator O'Chee, with his great perspicacity, has picked up, such as standing in the way of a truck, throwing stones, fighting or using abusive words, should be dealt with. I do not understand how Senator Carr, Senator Zakharov, Senator Aulich, who was part of this, Senator Bell or Senator Murphy could dispute that. They are saying that it is a most oppressive situation to have a law which forbids people from being able to peacefully picket and which prevents people from gentle persuasion. That is a most extraordinary thing.

Senator O'Chee says that sections 45D and 45E ought to be kept and not changed in any way. From their arguments, I understand that the others are saying that there ought to be a better and more peaceful way of settling disputes in the workplace. That is absolutely right. Reference D asks whether sections 45D and 45E are a satisfactory means of preventing and settling disputes, and they say that they are not.

When we look at the arguments and think of the concepts behind sections 45D and 45E, we can do nothing but agree with what was said. Senator O'Chee gave examples where there is violence and criminal action. The majority would say, `Let the law take its course. That is not what sections 45D and 45E are all about'. Accordingly, it is time that industrial relations were conducted outside the Trade Practices Act, which deals only with concepts of trade and commerce.

TALK.START.PARA: —And goods and services.

—Yes, but goods and services are different from human beings. Senator Teague there, a man of great compassion, is not the sort of person who would treat a human being like a sack of wool or a bag of wheat or an aluminium bar. All we are saying is, for heaven's sake, let us, in the laws we make, acknowledge that there is a difference between human beings and other sorts of things that exist in the world, whether they be inanimate or whether they be animal.
—Persons need to be responsible.

—Yes, that is right. Senator O'Chee is a different sort of thing to the animals in the fields, no matter how much we love them, a different sort of thing to the seat upon which he sits, a different sort of thing to the suit that he wears and the tie that he has around his neck. He is a human being, with emotions, strengths, ambitions and a desire to live a social life. All we want the opposition to do is to acknowledge that, and to put industrial relations into a setting of its own. If the opposition did that and helped us on this, it would be making a great contribution to the country.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to take note of the report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission entitled, Human Rights and Mental Illness—report of the national inquiry into the human rights of people with mental illness—volumes i and ii.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Debate resumed from 30 September, on motion by Senator Reynolds:
That the Senate—

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)endorse the findings of the committee contained in paragraph 3.7 of the 42nd Report, as recommended in paragraph 3.8; and
(b)adopt the recommendations contained in paragraphs 3.8(2) and (3) of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 42nd report of the Senate Committee of Privileges deals with the possible adverse treatment of a witness before the corporations and securities committee. It deals with a lawyer employed by the Australian Securities Commission at that time. The terms of the reference of that inquiry given to us by the Senate—I speak as the Deputy Chairman of the Senate Committee of Privileges—are well known to the Senate. Indeed, our report's careful argument, its findings and its recommendations, which follow on the 45th page of the report, are also well known to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: We have in front of us this evening the motion to adopt those recommendations moved by the then chair, our former colleague Senator Pat Giles, who for many years was a most competent and charming chairman of the Senate privileges committee. Following her initial speech and the circulation of the report, during the last sitting week significant contributions were made in the debate on the motion by Senator Cooney, my very good colleague across the chamber, and then, when we had determined the 42nd report, a member of the Senate Committee of Privileges.

Of course, Senator Cooney's eloquent, very careful and sincere speech was towards the minority report which he alone wrote and signed as one member of the seven members who make up the Privileges Committee. His speech sets out his case. Even more comprehensively, it is set out in the text of the minority report that all senators have received.

The other contribution made in the debate in the last sitting week was from my colleague Senator Short, who had some informants with regard to some elements arising from the Senate committee's report which Senator Short felt incumbent to bring to the Senate. So, based upon the information that he had received, he raised a number of concerns again best understood in the terms of Senator Short's own speech.

Following those two speeches and following a private conference with me, Senator McMullan adjourned the debate. I rose seeking leave only to make a brief statement. I said at that time, and I reiterate it now, that it was appropriate, given the degree of dissent that was expressed by Senator Short and, of course, the quite well-known views of Senator Cooney on a quite different matter, that these speeches ought to be able to be considered by all senators—indeed by anyone in the public—so that when we came to conclude the debate, as I expect we will do now, all of those matters could be taken into full consideration.

I also said in that brief statement in the last sitting week that, on the basis of the two speeches I have referred to, I was not moved in any way to accept or change in any way the findings or the recommendations of the Senate report, which I fully support. I am still very confident that the six majority members of the Senate Committee of Privileges still support those findings in exactly the form that we had determined.

So I come now to make some remarks mostly with regard to the new material that Senator Short introduced in his speech. But first I must refer to my good friend Senator Cooney. Senator Cooney is foreshadowing an amendment to the motion that is before us. His amendment is exactly to achieve the minority report that he wrote in conclusion. Again, like his speech in the last sitting week, there is nothing at all surprising about Senator Cooney's position.

It happens to be the case that Senator Cooney's minority position was very well known to the individual members of the privileges committee, that is, the other six out of seven who had been through all of the items of correspondence and all of the submissions, and who had attended every minute of the public hearings, which had been considerable.

When we were evaluating the submissions and hearings on this quite important matter, Senator Cooney was very conscientious in putting his own personal position, which only in this respect disagreed with the majority. I am not trespassing on the confidence of our committee discussions to say that all of the rest of us carefully considered Senator Cooney's views, both as verbally given by him and as eventually given in a draft written form and we did not subscribe to his individual view.

Rather, we took the view that there were two officers of the Australian Securities Commission, Mr Trevethan and Ms Waters, who were seen by the ASC—their employer—as being the responsible officers in this action.
