They were both named in our finding, along with their employer, the Australian Securities Commission.

I turn quickly to Senator Short's statements. The matters raised by Senator Short in mitigation of the behaviour of Mr Ron Trevethan do not challenge the factual basis of the committee's findings. Senator Short's speech reiterates an explanation of behaviour which the committee took into account before making the findings that it did.

My colleague Senator Short and his informants appear to have misunderstood what the committee has found. He said that the view the committee has put is misconceived. The committee did not find that Mr Trevethan intended to commit contempt. Rather, the committee found that Mr Trevethan, by laying a charge of misconduct, intended to perform an act which had the effect of penalising Mr Gaffey as a consequence of his giving evidence before a parliamentary committee. The committee, in determining that no penalties should be recommended, explicitly stated in paragraph 2.62 that the officers concerned:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . did not advert to the consequences of their actions in terms of parliamentary privilege and protection of witnesses before committees.

Under the privilege resolutions, the committee is required, after determining findings to be included in its report and before presenting the report, to acquaint the person or persons affected by the findings with the findings. Persons are then able to make submissions on the findings. The committee interprets this requirement broadly so that any adverse comment, and any comment explaining the findings, are forwarded to the persons adversely affected. The committee did this; the committee received the final submissions of those people concerned.

PARA.TAB: The Senate should note two important matters of fact. First, the Australian Securities Commission, before the committee's comments and findings were made known to it, accepted responsibility on behalf of the commission and on behalf of the two `senior officers of the commission who were directly involved in the laying of charge F'. (Extension of time granted) It was only in its final written submission, which presumably is the submission to which Senator Short has referred, that any attempt was made to spread responsibility among other officers and to exclude the two officers concerned from the finding of contempt. The submission was included in a volume of documents tabled with the report.

Second, in determining its findings that individual officers should be held responsible, the committee had extensive discussions as to whether the organisation as a whole should take exclusive responsibility for its actions. The committee concluded that it should not do so, for the reasons discussed at paragraphs 2.13 to 2.17 of its report, both before and after taking into account the written submission of the ASC made to the committee after it had determined findings to be included in its report.

My third observation is that this report, our 42nd, is the first occasion on which the Committee of Privileges has joined an authority in the responsibility for the actions of its officers. On all other occasions, including the only other time when the committee has found that a contempt has been committed, the committee has made findings on the actions of individuals rather than the organisations as a whole.

I now turn to some unfortunate misstatements of fact in Senator Short's remarks. First, he said that charge F, on which the committee has made the findings of contempt, was initiated by the Australian Government Solicitor. This is not true. While the committee was unable to conclude on the evidence which of Mr Trevethan and Ms Waters suggested the inclusion of charge F in the list of charges, and thus made no comment in its report on which one of these two officers was responsible for initiating the charge, it is clear that it was raised in discussions between them before advice was sought from the Australian Government Solicitor. This is detailed in paragraph 1.38, including relevant Hansard references.
A second misstatement of fact was when Senator Short said that Mr Trevethan, when he was advised of the contempt implications:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . eight days after the charge [F] was laid . . . apologised and caused it to be withdrawn. The other five charges remained standing.

This is not true. In addition, charge C was withdrawn by letter from Mr Trevethan to Mr Gaffey eight days after it was laid, at the same time as charge F was withdrawn, without comment or explanation. It would be interesting to know the form of this `apology' and to whom it was made at that time. It was not made to Mr Gaffey and it was not brought to the committee's attention that there had been such an apology.

PARA.TAB: The third misstatement of fact was that Senator Short said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee [of Privileges] has made an example of Mr Trevethan to encourage the others. That is what the privileges committee report said.

This also is not true. The committee's report does not say that. The finding of contempt stands on its own. The committee has gone on to make general comments which have led to the recommendation contained in subparagraph 3 of paragraph 3.7 of its report.

PARA.TAB: A fourth matter, which is also a misstatement of fact, was that Senator Short said:

SPEECH.PARA: The unintended contempt implication of that charge [F] was appreciated almost immediately.

This is not literally true. The chairman of the ASC became aware of the charge and its implications when he was advised by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, following Mr Gaffey's raising the matter with that committee. Mr Gaffey claims that he had apprised Mr Trevethan of contempt implications soon after the charge was laid, but that this had not led to an `immediate' withdrawal. It took the intervention of the parliament's committee to do that.

PARA.TAB: The fifth point of misstatement was that Senator Short said:

SPEECH.PARA: He [Mr Trevethan] also appreciated and acted at all times in accordance with the Public Service regulations, which are not framed with these circumstances [i.e. witness protection, rights of public servants, etc.] in mind.

This is not literally true. Mr Trevethan, as a senior manager, could be expected to have access to all relevant documents and guidelines relating to public servants, notably the publication entitled Guidelines for Conduct of Witnesses before Parliamentary Committees.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, as an officer of a regulatory authority with a direct relationship with a parliamentary committee, Mr Trevethan should have been expected to have better than normal knowledge of rights and duties of public servants in this regard. While the authority takes responsibility for not educating its managers appropriately, there is a duty on individual public service managers to inform themselves of at least the rudiments of their legal responsibilities.

Finally—and this the sixth point—it is interesting that Senator Short, on behalf of Mr Trevethan, has pleaded that no `additional' penalty should be imposed. As the committee has specifically recommended that no penalty should be imposed by the Senate on the organisation or individuals, I am left to conclude that the persons affected now regard a finding of contempt as a penalty additional to the laying of the charge; a view with which the committee agrees, as noted in its report in paragraph 2.62. It is perhaps a pity that the persons who laid the charge against a witness before a parliamentary committee, which subsequently led to the committee's findings, did not similarly regard such a charge as a penalty.
Matthew 7:2 very wisely states:

SPEECH.PARA: For with the judgment you make you will be judged, and the measure you give will be the measure you get.

I do not wish to be pompous. I am aware that all of us, in making judgments, have to be assured that we are credible in the judgments that we make and that those same judgments can be brought back to us.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I reiterate the points I made at the beginning: I support the Senate committee findings and recommendations, and I express that support, as deputy chairman of the committee, confident that the then chairman, Senator Giles, has expressly that view. Clearly, it is the majority view of six of the seven senators who undertook the inquiry.

In expressing this view, I am very conscious of the careful, sincere arguments of Senator Cooney, who took the minority position, and also conscious of the remarks of Senator Short which, as I say, are quite misinformed on at least a half a dozen points. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard paragraphs 3.7 and 3.8 of the report.
Leave granted.
The paragraphs read as follows—

TAB.TAB: (a)That the Australian Securities Commission, as the body responsible for the actions of two officers directly involved, and these officers, Mr Ronald Claude Trevethan, Regional Commissioner, and Ms Margot Diana Waters, Regional General Counsel, Victorian Regional Office, have taken action which constituted a contempt, in that the laying of charge F against Mr James Matthew Gaffey for having given evidence in a private capacity before the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities which was "at variance to submissions made by the representatives of the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission" could deter other witnesses from appearing before other committees. SPEECH.PARA: Patricia Giles Chair

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of the motion, add:
"but with the following amendment to recommendation 1: at end of recommendation, add:

", except in so far as those findings relate to Ms Margot Diana Waters, Regional General Counsel, Victorian Regional Office, in whose case the evidence does not support the serious finding of a contempt of the Senate'.".

The reason why I differ from the majority report is that the basis of a finding of contempt against Ms Waters is that charges were laid against Mr James Matthew Gaffey for having given evidence in a private capacity before the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, as set out in 3.7 of the report. That is the correct basis for the charge of contempt in this matter—that the charges were laid in respect of evidence given before a parliamentary committee. I differ with the majority on the basis that Ms Waters did not lay the charges. That is made quite clear by the terms of the charge itself, which appears on page 83 of the Hansard for this matter—that is, charge F, under section 61, signed by Ronald Claude Trevethan and him alone. I seek leave to have that charge incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

TALK.START.PARA: —To make it quite clear that it was Mr Trevethan, and him alone, who laid the charge and committed this contempt, I go to page 199 of the Hansard, paragraphs 31, 32 and 33 of the opening statement of Mr Trevethan. Giving his version of the facts, Mr Trevethan states:

SPEECH.PARA: After some reflection, I decided that the only course open to me was to lay charges against Mr Gaffey . . .
I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard paragraphs 31, 32 and 33 of the opening statement of Mr Trevethan.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The paragraphs read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 31.After some reflection, I decided that the only course open to me was to lay charges against Mr Gaffey under section 61(2)(b) of the Public Service Act. I believed that I had placed my authority on the line by initiating the counselling process, under section 61(2)(a) of the Public Service Act, on 12 March 1992; I had further committed myself (and my authority) to that process on 16 April, 7 May and 8 May 1992; and Mr Gaffey had challenged me and my authority.

32.In deciding to lay charges against Mr Gaffey, I was not seeking to be vindictive, nor to impose a penalty on him: I simply believed that, once my authority as the manager of the Victorian Regional Office had been challenged, I had to take the next logical step to assert that authority. I knew that, if charges were laid under section 61(2)(b), those charges would be heard and determined by an independent inquiry under section 62 of the Public Service Act. I believed that, because of Mr Gaffey's conduct on 11 and 12 March and 11 May 1992, he had a case to answer; and I knew that the independent inquiry would determine whether the charges were substantially correct or whether Mr Gaffey had an answer to the charges.

33.On 14 May 1992, I told Ms Waters that I had decided to lay charges against Mr Gaffey. I instructed Ms Waters to prepare the charges and to get some advice from the Australian Government Solicitor's office. (As these were the first charges that I had laid in my public service career, I thought that legal advice would be an appropriate safeguard against error.) Ms Waters told me that Mr Cafarella had recommended that she contact Mr L. Dobelsky of the Australian Government Solicitor's Melbourne office, because he was experienced in drawing charges under the Public Service Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Trevethan said:

SPEECH.PARA: On 14 May 1992, I told Ms Waters that I had decided to lay charges against Mr Gaffey. I instructed Ms Waters to prepare the charges and to get some advice from the Australian Government Solicitor's office.
Ms Waters, in her opening statement, at paragraph 27, said:

On 14 May 1992, Mr Trevethan told me that he had decided to lay charges against Mr Gaffey under section 61(2)(b) of the Public Service Act and instructed me to prepare those charges. Mr Cafarella recommended that I contact Mr L Dobelsky at the Australian Government Solicitor's office in Melbourne. (Mr Cafarella told me that Mr Dobelsky had undertaken this type of work for Mr Cafarella on several occasions and had performed the work in a very satisfactory fashion.)
In paragraph 28 of the statement, Ms Waters states:
On the same day (14 May 1992), I telephoned Mr Dobelsky. I asked him to draw charges against Mr Gaffey under section 61(2)(b) of the Public Service Act.

She goes on in that manner. It is quite clear on the evidence that the person that decided to lay the charge was Mr Trevethan; the person that instructed Ms Waters to prepare the charge was Mr Trevethan; and the person that saw these charges through against Mr Gaffey was Mr Trevethan. Because, and only because, Ms Waters obeyed his instructions, we now make a finding of contempt against her. So, Madam Acting Deputy President, on that basis, if your staff—and, may I say, excellent staff, too, although they could sometimes be better at quiz nights, but I leave that aside—did what you told them to do, they would be punished for obeying orders.

PARA.TAB: If the majority report in this matter had said that the Nuremberg defence does not work, that would have been all right. But the majority did not say that. It is unfortunate, and not for one minute do I say that the seven people who sat with me on that committee—was it seven or six?

TALK.START.PARA: —There were seven altogether.
—I do not say that they were anything but the most outstanding and honest people of the highest integrity.
—Don't lay it on too thick.

—It is true. And they gave their decision according to their conscience. But they did not, and could not, have found on the evidence that Ms Waters had laid those charges. And it was on the basis of the laying of the charges that this finding of a breach of privilege has been made.

PARA.TAB: In saying that the laying of the charges was the basis of the contempt, they were correct; there is plenty of precedent for that. But on the factual issue there is no evidence at all that Ms Waters laid those charges. She might have been very pleased that the charges were laid. She may, under Mr Trevethan's instructions, as appears from the evidence, have been very happy that the charges were laid. The ASC may have thought that she was part of the laying of the charges so as to make her guilty of contempt of parliament. The solicitors who acted for her for the ASC and Mr Trevethan may have given that impression. But if in fact she did not lay the charges—and she did not on that evidence—we should not find her guilty of contempt of parliament.

I consider—and I take it that everyone else in the Senate does also—a finding of contempt of parliament or a breach of the privilege of this house to be a very serious matter. We should not lightly make a decision that Ms Waters has done that unless the evidence is clear. If there is any doubt about it, it should be resolved in her favour. People will be speaking after me, and I give a challenge to them now to find any unequivocal statement which contradicts the clear evidence that I have given and which points to Ms Waters having laid those charges. She helped in the preparation of them and she got instructions from the Government Solicitor—she did all those things—but she did not lay the charges.

Why should Ms Waters go down on a charge of contempt of parliament when Mr Dobelsky from the Australian Government Solicitor's office, who gave advice on this and, in fact, who physically drew the charges, does not? Why should he not go down? Why should we be picking Ms Waters out? The reason why we do not put Mr Dobelsky down is that he did not lay the charges; he simply prepared them. That is the position. It is quite a worrying position, if one takes these charges to be a very serious matter, to find somebody guilty on the basis of this evidence.

I do not want to go back to the way the solicitors performed in this matter, but Senator Teague said that the ASC implied that she was guilty. The ASC acted through the solicitors, whom I do not name but who appear on the record. It worries me that somebody should be found guilty of contempt of parliament on the basis of documents prepared by the ASC, for whom she works, on the ASC's say so and on the basis of what the solicitor does when he is acting for the ASC and for her as well.

In my view, Ms Waters should have been independently represented, and the fact that she was not should not be used as evidence to put her down. In fact, it should be used as evidence to the contrary. If people were making an admission on her behalf—there is no evidence that they did, but if they did—which they should not have done, it should not bind her. Again, I challenge anybody speaking after me to show any statement from the ASC that does, in fact, contain that admission. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The James Gaffey matter was referred to the privileges committee on a motion of mine and I speak in that capacity, and as a member of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, rather than as a member of the privileges committee. It is reasonably clear that there is no dispute about the fact that the charge that was laid against Mr Gaffey for providing evidence to the corporations and securities committee which was at variance to the submissions made by the representatives of the chairman of the Australian Securities Commission to the same committee does constitute contempt of the Senate. It is quite clear that that applies to the commission as well as to Mr Trevethan.

PARA.TAB: The matter in dispute, through the minority opinion provided by Senator Cooney, is whether the same judgment should apply to Ms Diana Waters, who, as Senator Cooney has so clearly outlined, was essentially an instrument of the will of the commission and was acting under the instructions of Mr Ronald Trevethan. I must say that, having

SPEECH.PARA: examined carefully the report of the committee and having listened very carefully to Senator Cooney's exposition of the facts and, at this stage, having not heard any rebuttal of the facts as he has outlined them, I would be inclined to support the amendment that Senator Cooney has moved.

PARA.TAB: On the other matter that is specifically before the Senate today—that is, the statement made on 30 September by Senator Short—I wish to briefly express regret that Senator Short has seen fit in his statement, under several mistaken assumptions, as has been outlined by Senator Baden Teague, to comment on Mr Gaffey's relationship with his employer, the ASC. In the process, I believe he has given the impression that in that relationship it was Mr Gaffey who was entirely at fault and that his behaviour was not all that could be wished for by his employer.

I think it is regrettable that Senator Short has found it necessary to do that, because it is quite clear that these matters have no bearing on the report of the Privileges Committee and the finding of contempt against Mr Trevethan. It seems rather unfortunate that Senator Short, in the mistaken belief that he needed to save Mr Trevethan from the imposition of a penalty, saw fit to make derogatory remarks about Mr Gaffey. I shall not repeat them; that would only compound the damage that was done to Mr Gaffey. I simply repeat that I believe it is unfortunate that that happened. I trust that the damage to Mr Gaffey is not extensive on that score. I have little more to add, except to say that, as I have indicated before, I will be supporting Senator Cooney's amendment if he chooses to press it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support, particularly, the statements made by Senator Teague. He has really summarised the case very adequately. I have been a member of the Privileges Committee for 10 years. During that time, many distinguished senators have served on the committee. It is a unique committee because all of us are trying to be fair and just. We are impacted with the gravity of making very serious decisions, as Senator Cooney has said, and this case is no exception. We had 26 meetings over 12 months, so it is a serious matter.

PARA.TAB: I think the term `Senate Committee of Privileges', in the public mind, means privileges of senators or something, but I believe that the opposite is true. The vast majority of cases can be put into two categories: firstly, the right of ordinary Australians to reply to statements made in the parliament; and, secondly, most importantly, and applying to this case, the right of parliament to protect its own witnesses. The protection of witnesses who appear before Senate committees is vital to guarantee basic human rights and to give ordinary people the right to have their two bobs' worth of opinion expressed without fear and without penalty. We are only as strong as the ability of those people to come before Senate committees and have their say. I think that is important because it applies in this very case.

Unfortunately in this case, Senator Short has accepted the Trevethan side of the argument and that forces me to go into some detail of the evidence. While I support what Senator Teague has said, I think I have to say things in a much sharper way than would otherwise be necessary to deny the situation that has arisen where Mr Gaffey has been put on trial. I accept that Senator Short has raised this like any of us would—a constituent makes a complaint or tells us a story and we articulate that story. Unfortunately, it is wrong, as Senator Teague has pointed out, and it is particularly wrong when one looks at paragraph 2.34 of our report which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the effects of laying the charge are unlikely to be serious is because of the action taken by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, by Senators responding to matters raised by Mr Gaffey after that Committee's report was tabled, by the Senate in referring the matters to this Committee, and by the Committee of Privileges in undertaking this inquiry and reaching the present conclusions.
In other words, what clearly happened is not as Senator Short said; in fact, it was because of the actions taken by the Senate committee that the matter was withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short's strident defence of Mr Trevethan is summed up by his comments in the debate on the report of the privileges committee on 30 September. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Having heard from some of those involved and understanding the chronicle of events, I have come to be strongly of the opinion that Mr Trevethan was and is innocent of any intent to hold this Senate in contempt—that his endeavours to administer his office in a wholly appropriate manner inadvertently led to his becoming involved in this way.

I regret that, because of statements like that, I have to explore more sharply Mr Trevethan's role in this matter. I would have preferred to leave the carefully crafted report to stand alone. Mr Trevethan's conduct, to quote the committee, was not appropriate. On page 22 the report states:
. . . officers within the Victorian Regional Office had at least left themselves open to criticism of their inept personnel and management practices and inadequate record-keeping.
More seriously, on page 40 it states:

The Committee believes that officers at such a senior level of an organisation with a direct relationship with a parliamentary committee should have been aware of parliamentary privilege and contempt. Therefore the Committee would not normally regard lack of knowledge in these circumstances as warranting mitigation of penalty. The Committee considers, however, that the public exposure of the officers' limited understanding of the parliamentary aspects of the legislative framework within which they were operating, and the embarrassing details of the administration of the Victorian Regional Office, is in itself a penalty.

I put it more bluntly: here we have a senior legally trained officer, with a direct relationship between a parliamentary committee and his commission, pleading ignorance as an excuse. Tell that to all the company directors of Australia who deal with the Australian Securities Commission. They would love to adopt such an excuse. Officers at a senior level of an organisation with a direct relationship with a parliamentary committee should have been aware of parliamentary privilege.

PARA.TAB: I thought I would have more time than the 10 minutes I have—and I will try and keep to it—but I must now turn to the position of Mr Gaffey. He contacted me after Senator Short's speech. I have never in my life spoken to him outside the official committee hearing. But he said that he had been injured by Senator Short's speech. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement by Mr Gaffey which I have shown to honourable senators.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: JAMES M. GAFFEY
BARRISTER AND SOLICITOR
6 October 1993
Senator Bruce Childs
Australian Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator
Re: Speech of Senator Short to the Senate, 9.35 p.m. 30 September 1993

I write to request your assistance against the misinformed comments in the above speech of Senator Short. The speech was made in an attempt to exonerate Mr Trevethan and Ms Waters, the Regional Commissioner and General Counsel respectively of the Victorian Regional Office of the ASC, from the contempt findings made against them by the Committee of Privileges (the Committee) in its 42nd Report.
1:Senator Short's speech refuted by the Report and underlying evidence
1.1 Senator Short's speech represents me in a fashion refuted by the findings in the Report, that part of the evidence before the Committee which was shown to be accurate, and the facts.
1.2 I was not consulted by Senator Short. Nor was I invited to cross examine his informants.
2:Background to contempt findings in the 42nd Report not addressed in Senator Short's speech

2.1 In October 1991, with the written permission of the Victorian Regional Commissioner of the ASC Mr Ron Trevethan, I participated in the presentation by a Law Institute Committee of a submission to an inquiry of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities (the Joint Committee). The submission was invited by the Joint Committee.
2.2 The submission I was involved in differed from the submission of the ASC.

2.3 I was later charged by Mr Trevethan and Ms Waters with misconduct under the Public Service Act. The charges included the charge subject of the Committee's contempt findings, which was that I had given a submission to the Joint Committee which differed from that given by the ASC. The ASC ultimately withdrew all the charges.
3:Senator Short's comments contradicted by the facts and the Committee's findings
3.1 Set out below are some of the material facts which contradict certain of Senator Short's direct and indirect attacks upon me. Many others have been omitted in the interests of brevity:

the Chairman of the ASC, Mr Alan Cameron conceded that all of Mr Trevethan's action against me—not merely the charge subject of the contempt finding—was taken in "error" (Hansard, page 319, Report paragraph 2.17)

PARA.TAB: On 8 February 1993, the ASC and I agreed (Hansard, 325) to inter alia the:
(a)ASC's withdrawal of all of Trevethan's (remaining) misconduct charges
(b)payment of a considerable (pre-tax) sum of money to me by the ASC and
(c)the agreement by me to not sue the ASC (for defamation, malicious prosecution etc)

SPEECH.PARA: the Committee specifically made no findings concerning the substance of the charges and allegations which Senator Short referred to in his speech (Report, 2.46), and merely found that, on the evidence, it was not established that they were motivated by contempt. (Report, 3.7, subpara2(b))

the allegations are now being used in an attempt to exonerate the contempt, after the Committee had rejected Mr Trevethan and Ms Waters' previous defences. Senate Short's informants do not appear to have referred to the rejection of their previous defences. (Refer Report para 2.26)
4:Impact of Senator Short's speech

4.1 Senator Short's attempts to exonerate the conduct of Trevethan and Waters effectively re-penalises and injures me, and compounds the contempt. This occurs notwithstanding the withdrawal of the charge subject of the contempt, and the apology of Mr Trevethan and Ms Waters.

4.2 The attempted exoneration also does not deal with the fundamental issue of the rights of Parliament's witnesses to Parliament's protection, or the Committee's findings, (which I accept, even though I do not agree with all of them).
5:Tendency of Senator Short's information to negate ASC apologies and undermine the ASC Members' attempts to educate against contempt

5.1 I am concerned by the manner in which Senator Short's speech effectively negates the apology (seen by the Committee as a mitigating factor) extended to me by the ASC, Mr Trevethan and Ms Waters for laying the charge in contempt.

5.2 The speech also contradicts the apology of the Chairman of the ASC for all the action taken by Mr Trevethan against me (including the charge subject of the contempt finding) which he conceded was taken in "error" (Hansard, page 319, Report, 2.17).
5.3 The ASC appears to have accepted the finding of contempt against itself, and is taking steps to educate its officers about contempt. This is commendable.
6:Request
6.1 In view of the above, I request your:

PARA.TAB: (a)defence of me in the Senate against the misinformed comments made by Senator Short on 30 September 1993, and
(b)continued support for the recommendations of the Senate Committee of Privileges set out in the Committee's 42nd Report.

SPEECH.PARA: Do not hesitate to call me at your convenience on (03) 497 4383 should you wish to discuss the above.
Yours faithfully,
James Gaffey

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, what Senator Short has said has disadvantaged Mr Gaffey. I briefly refer honourable senators to that document and point out in the few minutes I have remaining that, according to Mr Gaffey, Senator Short's speech is refuted by the report and underlying evidence. Mr Gaffey points out, firstly:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.1 Senator Short's speech represents me in a fashion refuted by the findings in the Report, that part of the evidence before the Committee which was shown to be accurate, and the facts.
The second point he makes is:
Background to contempt findings in the 42nd Report not addressed in Senator Short's speech—
Of course, that is absolutely true. The third point he makes is:
Senator Short's comments contradicted by the facts and the Committee's findings—
He then sets them out. The fourth point he makes is:
Impact of Senator Short's speech—

I must make the point here that there was a settlement of the dispute in the ASC; there was an apology by the chairman of the authority. Unfortunately, that settlement and that apology have been abrogated by the statement made by Senator Short. Of course, Senator Short is probably unconscious of the fact that, when he made that speech, he seriously disadvantaged Mr Gaffey. I do not have time to go through the details of Mr Gaffey's statement, but I commend it to honourable senators. It is unfortunate that a person who comes to this Senate seeking redress should become the victim and not be protected by the findings of the privileges committee of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Briefly, I cannot support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Cooney. As far as I am concerned, Mr Trevethan and Ms Waters were joined together in their actions throughout the case. The ASC and its lawyers did not seek to separate them; nor did Ms Waters seek to separate herself at any point. So, from my point of view, I do not think there is any question that the whole picture is one in which Ms Waters—I quite accept she had a slightly lesser role than Mr Trevethan—has been joined with Mr Trevethan, and only at the 11th hour did the authority try to take to itself the responsibility of the two officers. So I cannot support the amendment. I ask honourable senators to support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take up the challenge laid down by Senator Cooney, but only for a couple of minutes. He spoke following me. Senator Childs, in the latter part of his speech, directly responded to Senator Cooney's remarks. I wish to reiterate the appropriate remarks made by Senator Childs and to appeal to Senator Cooney and Senator Spindler to understand the basis on which the privileges committee found with regard to both Mr Trevethan and Ms Waters.

PARA.TAB: In the submission made by the ASC, they were the two responsible officers. After that submission had been received by the committee, both Mr Trevethan and Ms Waters appeared in person in front of the committee. The whole tenor of their testimony individually to the committee was to accept the submission and the descriptions made by the ASC, in part reflecting upon their own positions.

Mr Trevethan was the Regional Commissioner of the ASC in Melbourne. He had some 200 staff for which he was responsible. His lawyer in-house, his main legal adviser, was Ms Waters, the Regional General Counsel. She had some 40 lawyers responsible to her; at one stage Mr Gaffey was one of them. When they laid charge F—

TALK.START.PARA: —When he laid charge F.

—I hear Senator Cooney saying, `When he laid charge F', but I deliberately say when they laid charge F, it was as a result of a conversation between these two senior officers, deliberately engaged in by both of them. It is not possible for the committee to determine which one of the two officers formulated the concept of that charge, initiated the laying of that charge. Therefore, we in the committee determined that the two officers together, both senior officers, were directly involved in initiating the charge and in the laying of the charge.

PARA.TAB: Certainly we will make a very big distinction between these two officers and the Government Solicitor, whom they subsequently asked for the precise technical wording of the charge that they laid. A judgment has to be made in these respects. The judgment has been made by six out of seven of the members of the Privileges Committee that with regard to both Mr Trevethan and Ms Waters the findings should be made in the way that we have set out to the Senate in our findings and our recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I simply continue my challenge. Senator Teague has not answered it and neither has Senator Childs—two senators for whom I have the greatest admiration. I quoted passages from the evidence which showed that Ms Waters did not decide to lay the charge. It was not, as Senator Teague has said, a joint judgment. The evidence is quite to the contrary. I want to put on record that none of those who have spoken in favour of convicting Ms Waters has been able to quote any evidence from the transcript in Hansard to show that she was in any way implicated.

—I was not going to enter the debate, but given Senator Cooney's re-intervention, I feel I should at least defend my position on the Privileges Committee as to why I agree with both officers being included in the report. The committee debated this matter for many hours at the time the report was drafted several months ago.

PARA.TAB: My simple point is that although Senator Cooney is right that it was only Mr Trevethan's signature on the formal charge, it was a joint action which included Ms Waters. I am upset that anybody has to be recommended for a motion such as the one before the Senate, but six of the seven members of the committee did decide that it was a joint action—despite the fact that there was only one signature on the charge, as was the requirement of the Public Service regulations.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry by the Select Committee on Superannuation into the Queensland Professional Officers Association Superannuation Fund had its origins in an MPI debate late last year. During that debate Senator Kernot raised her concerns about the goings-on in that fund during the years from 1986 to 1991. Interestingly, neither the persons she named nor the organisations to which she referred elected to exercise their right of reply under the standing orders of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot then raised the matter with the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. That committee, which had received a submission from a member of the union's governing council, properly used its adverse evidence procedures to write to those four persons named as illegal beneficiaries of the extraordinary withdrawals seeking their response. To the best of its ability, and to the best of the evidence available, the committee has got to the bottom of the QPOASF operation. The committee has not taken political sides. It could easily have slipped into this mode.

Here are the facts as exposed in this detailed report. The four beneficiaries—Mr Martindale, Mr Rutherford, Mr Daly and Ms Kinder—were given access to their superannuation funds when the trust deed barred such access. To obtain access, they had to resign from the service of either the QPOA or the QPOA Credit Union. None of them did this. To legitimise this access, the trustees made a retrospective amendment to the trust deed. As they had not resigned, they had to get the authorised signing officer—who, according to witnesses at the hearings, was Ms Kinder—to sign that they were resigning.

Amazingly, the committee could not obtain a copy of the four benefit request forms, or BRFs. They have been either lost, given back to other agencies, or not copied. The QPOASF had no record. The NML had no record—and it was the administrator. The Cooke inquiry did not keep these records—although it kept other records; it returned them to the NML, which, of course, has no record of the forms.

I ask the Senate to make its own conclusions about the conduct of those who signed the benefit forms and whether they had an interest in deceiving the fund administrators into paying the benefits. I also invite the Senate to consider whether persons involved in one or a number of those agencies entrusted with the BRFs had an interest in ensuring that the forms were lost or unable to be tendered as evidence to the superannuation inquiry.

This case amply demonstrates the need for reform of superannuation funds and the legislation which governs their operations. In this case, the Commonwealth was powerless to do anything about the wrongful conduct of the QPOASF trustees. The Queensland government could have done something. It did not. Perhaps it will. Over to the Attorney-General!

When the SIS legislation is passed, the ISC will have the power to intervene and properly protect superannuation funds. The only way that members of the QPOASF could have acted to bring the trustees to account was to go to the Queensland Supreme Court with a swag of lawyers—we even had a QC attend our hearings—and sue for a breach of trustee fiduciary duty, which is a costly and time consuming process.

The outcome of the inquiry is that the committee exposed the wrongful actions of the trustees and the wrongdoings regarding the BRFs. The committee has recommended that the Queensland government investigate the loss of the documents. The committee has identified principles which it will use to test the superannuation industry supervisory legislation when it considers that package of bills in coming weeks. The committee has shown that persons will go to enormous lengths to cover up a trail of evidence which shows wrongdoing.

These problems could have been solved if those who had received overpayments exceeding a total of $30,000 had simply written out a cheque and paid the overpayment back to the fund. They could still right their wrong. Instead, the result has been three inquiries: the Senate inquiry; the Cooke inquiry, which was aborted; and the Towers Perrin review.

Thousands of dollars have been channelled into the coffers of the Queensland legal profession to erect a barrier to prevent the committee and the public finding out the truth. The QPOA and the QPOA Credit Union have expended members' funds to the tune of $34,000 in ensuring that the superannuation fund is properly funded. Investigating the deficiency in the Towers Perrin report cost $20,000. Legal costs are estimated to be in excess of $150,000.

Finally, where are we now in this sorry affair? The committee chair, Senator Watson, has forwarded a copy of the report to the Queensland Attorney-General, Dean Wells, advising him of the relevance of the recommendations to the administration of justice in Queensland. To my knowledge, the report has been received—at least, it has been debated in the Queensland parliament by the opposition—but the minister has not responded.

Mr Wells, this chamber needs to know the answers to the following questions. Is it your intention to ignore a multipartisan report on the QPOASF affair? Are you not concerned that documents may have been lost in order to evade the processes of the law and the search for the truth? Are you satisfied with your government's policy on archiving, or is it your view that documents can be selectively archived to ensure that certain matters are not allowed to be placed in the spotlight of truth? If you choose to ignore these questions, then yet again, the task of ensuring honest conduct in public affairs in Queensland will be left to a small group of beleaguered individuals, such as Mr O'Neill and Mr Lindeberg, who took great personal risk in initiating and appearing before the Senate inquiry. Mr Wells, I am sure that I am not alone in my interest in hearing your response. I, therefore, appeal to your sense of fair play as the custodian of justice in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993, which is now before the chamber, contains a number of amendments of the Customs Tariff Act 1987. I will briefly outline the amendments.

Sections three to ten, thirteen to seventeen and subsection twelve two of this bill contain amendments which will remove from the principal act references to schedule five. This schedule contains the legislative means to administer quota restrictions on imported goods. As quota restrictions on textiles, clothing and footwear were abolished on the first of March 1993 and the administration of cheese and curd quotas has been transferred to schedule four by this bill, there is no requirement for the subject legislation. These changes will operate on and from fourteen days after this bill receives Royal Assent.

The Customs Legislation Amendment Bill 1993, which will be introduced during these sittings, will amend the provisions governing the rules of origin for imported goods in the Customs Act 1901. Section eleven of this bill provides a consequential amendment to section eighteen of the principal act to cater for the changes to the rules of origin. This amendment will operate from the day that the new provisions take effect.

Subsection twelve one and schedule six of this bill will operate on and from the first of July 1993. These changes give effect to the government's decision to reduce the coverage of the Australian System of Tariff Preferences (ASTP). This decision applies to chemicals, plastics, rubber and leather goods, sugar, textiles, clothing, footwear, fruit juice, canned food and dried fruit from countries listed in schedule one to the Customs Tariff Act, except Forum Island countries and fifty one countries and places identified by the United Nations as being least developed.

The list of countries affected by the change is shown in section twelve one of this bill. The developing country rates of duty for these goods have been fixed at the pre-first of July 1993 level until the general rate falls to that level. Thereafter the general rate of duty will apply.
Schedule one of this bill is operative on and from the first of January 1988 and provides a free rate of duty for needlecraft kits of heading 6308.

Schedule three was operative between the thirteenth of October 1992 and the twenty-eighth of February 1993. It provided for the continued duty free importation of certain handkerchiefs under a concessional item in schedule four to the principal act. This provision was a short term measure, bridging similar concessions accorded by the tariff concession system prior to the thirteenth of October 1992 and the customs by-law system after the first of March 1993.

Schedule four of this bill is operative on and from the first of March 1993. The Canadian margin of preference on certain carpets is being phased out following agreement between the Australian and Canadian governments. The Canadian rates of duty for these goods have been frozen at the pre-first of March 1993 level until the general rate falls to that level. Thereafter the general rate will apply.

Also, this schedule contains amendments to implement changes to the concessional arrangements for textiles, clothing and footwear in schedule four to the principal act. This follows an enquiry into the efficacy of the customs by-law system in relation to TCF goods.

Schedule five contains amendments to recognise the newly created independent countries of the Czech Republic and the Slovak Republic. These changes accord the benefits of the Australian system of tariff preferences to the new countries and have effect from the tenth of March 1993.

Schedule six is operative on and from the first of July 1993. The 1991 industry statement contained initiatives to assist local manufacturers of passenger motor vehicle components. These government initiatives exclude certain goods of a kind used as replacement components in passenger motor vehicles and which had a rate of duty of fifteen per cent on the first of July 1992, from the general phase down of tariff rates. The changes in this schedule implement that decision in relation to those goods imported from Canada.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 contained a rationalisation, operative from the first of July 1993, of tariff subheadings covering certain spirits and spirituous liquors of chapter twenty-two. The amendments in this schedule apply the February 1993 consumer price index adjustments to the newly rationalised subheadings.

The schedule also contains a reduction of 3.103 cents per litre in the customs duty on aviation gasoline. This portion of the duty collected on aviation gasoline was attributed to aviation authorities to perform services on behalf of the aviation industry. The reduction is a reflection of lower Commonwealth costs due to the transfer of aerodromes to local ownership and the direct levying of charges for services previously provided by Commonwealth agencies on aviation industry users.

Item fifty three in schedule four to the principal act was created to provide a phasing regime for certain goods which were not components for passenger motor vehicles but were encompassed by the passenger motor vehicle components initiatives. Under these initiatives the goods would have had a duty rate of fifteen per cent. The present amendment to split item fifty-three provides appropriate phasing rates of duty for these goods, some of which are subject to the government's decision to reduce the coverage of the Australian system of tariff preferences.

Schedule seven of this bill is operative on and from the fifth of July 1993 and amends the table to item fifty-three A to redefine those tariff subheadings excluded from claiming the concessions accorded by this item.
This bill also contains a number of other minor technical and administrative changes
Summaries of the amendments contained in this bill have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable senators.
I commend the bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH LEGISLATION (PROFESSIONAL SERVICES REVIEW) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Schacht) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill gives effect to the undertaking given in the Budget to introduce new measures to combat overservicing in the Medicare program, including pharmaceutical benefits.

The Bill represents the first instalment in a series of measures that will be taken by the Government to minimise abuse of Medicare. Further measures to deal with fraud and with audits, and to prevent "double-dipping" by visiting medical officers against public hospitals and Medicare benefits, will be implemented progressively. Legislation for new fraud measures is expected to be introduced into the Parliament by the end of the Budget Session.

The amendments to the Health Insurance Act outlined in this Bill reflect the outcome of a close consultative process with the Australian Medical Association (AMA). The AMA has played a key role in the development of the new measures and, in so doing, has demonstrated that it takes seriously its expressed belief that it has a duty to co-operate in ensuring that the public resources earmarked for health care are appropriately utilised.
The new measures in this Bill are necessary because the existing mechanisms for dealing with overservicing have come under question and have not been shown to be effective.

The strengthened professional review process in this legislation should not concern the vast majority of practitioners. However, it should cause those practitioners who misuse or deliberately abuse the current benefits arrangements to reflect on their activities.

The review process is not to be invoked lightly. It is the Government's intention that no practitioner will be subjected to the review process until he or she has been seen by a Medical Adviser of the Health Insurance Commission. The practitioner is to be advised of the Commission's concerns about the practitioner's practice and given a chance to consider his or her position, which could include seeking the advice of his or her professional colleagues. Only if the practitioner's practice continues to cause concern will he or she be referred for review.

The Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) found in its "Audit Report No. 17, 1992-93, Medifraud and Excessive Servicing: Health Insurance Commission" that Medical Services Committees of Inquiry, the current bodies responsible for dealing with excessive servicing, were not operating satisfactorily and needed to be strengthened.

The ANAO concluded that specific action needed to be taken to deal adequately with gross levels of overservicing. One of the principal complaints about the existing mechanisms for dealing with overservicing has been that they do little to discourage the provision or initiation of excessive services. They are not effective deterrents because, in many instances, the level of benefits recovered from practitioners has been totally eclipsed by the level of overservicing actually engaged in.

A major factor in the inability to impose penalties commensurate with the extent of a practitioner's overservicing is the current lack of power to make decisions on the extent of overservicing on the basis of generalised evidence. At present judgements about overservicing can only be made on the basis of individual services, that is, recovery of benefits and the imposition of penalties can only be made in respect of each service separately determined to have been excessive.

A further criticism of the current overservicing detection arrangements relates to delays in finalising cases, including delays occasioned by practitioners under review declining to appear at hearings because existing penalties for non-attendance are insufficient to ensure attendance.
The Audit Office report suggests that the minimum requirement to make Medical Services Committees of Inquiry more effective are:
increasing the amount of repayment, and/or penalty, required to be paid by practitioners found to have engaged in excessive servicing to reflect more closely the actual extent of moneys involved;
power for the Committees to access medical records;
appointment of additional Committees to help reduce time delays;
follow-up counselling to be taken by the chairpersons of the Committees; and
appointment of a full-time Manager to oversee the operations of Committees.

While the provisions contained in this Bill do not provide a continuing role for Medical Services Committees of Inquiry, they do address the Audit Office's views on what is required to make dealing with excessive servicing more effective.

The Bill provides for the replacement of Medical Services Committees of Inquiry by Professional Services Review Committees. Whereas the basic composition of Committees of Inquiry remains constant regardless of the nature of the services that are the subject to examination, the composition of the Professional Services Review Committees will vary according to types of services that are subject to review. For example, the empanelling of a Committee to review the rendering or initiation of services by a specialist in a particular specialty, would be on the basis that the majority of the Committee would be specialists in the same specialty. This means that there should be little cause for a practitioner to question the Committee's competence to deal with the matters referred to it.

A significant change in the Bill is the replacement of the concept of "excessive servicing" with one of "inappropriate practice". Whereas excessive servicing is currently defined as the rendering or initiation of services not reasonably necessary for the adequate care of the patient, the concept of "inappropriate practice" goes further. It covers a practitioner engaging in conduct, in connection with the rendering or initiating of services, that is unacceptable to his or her professional colleagues generally.

Another significant change is that the Bill provides for the application by Professional Services Review Committees of the findings from a statistically valid sample of services rendered or initiated by the practitioner under review, to the whole class of services that are of concern. This will constitute a far greater deterrent than the application of the current excessive servicing benefits repayments and penalties. The statistical procedure for making the necessary calculations has been developed on advice from the Australian Bureau of Statistics and protects adequately the rights of the practitioner under review.

A further important change lies in the penalty that will result from the refusal of a practitioner to attend a hearing or to produce documents when required to appear before a Professional Services Review Committee. If a practitioner refuses twice to comply with the requirements of a written notice of hearing, that practitioner will be fully disqualified from the Medicare until such time as he or she agrees to comply. The inclusion of this provision reflects a view shared by the Government and the AMA that a practitioner whose conduct in the rendering or initiating of publicly funded services is open to question should be required to participate in a professionally oriented process of review.

The Bill provides for the creation of an independent Director of Professional Services Review. The occupant of this position will be responsible for considering referrals for review from the Health Insurance Commission and deciding whether to empanel a Professional Services Review Committee from members of a Professional Services Review Panel drawn from the relevant fields of professional practice. The Director will also have the power to dismiss a referral or to impose, but only with the consent of the practitioner who is the subject of a referral for review, a partial disqualification from Medicare.
The Director, who will be in effect the manager of the entire review process, will be required to report annually to the Parliament.

The Health Insurance Commission will no longer be responsible for providing the secretariat. However, the Director may make an arrangement with the Health Insurance Commission or another Commonwealth authority for officers of the authority to be made available to assist the Director in the performance of his or her duties.

The Bill gives the profession substantial autonomy in examining and reaching findings on inappropriate practices. At the same time, proper care has been taken to ensure that the practitioner under review receives natural justice. At every major point in the review process the practitioner is given the opportunity to make submissions that could influence the review process and outcome.
The Bill provides for the separation of the three elements of the decision making processes which are:
the referral for review;
the review hearings and findings; and
the determination of any penalty.

The Health Insurance Commission prepares and refers a case for review to the Director of the Professional Services Review who decides whether to empanel a Professional Services Review Committee. The Review Committee reports on its findings and, if the findings are adverse to the practitioner under review, a Determining Officer, who must be a person holding an office or appointment under the Public Service Act, must determine one or more of the following courses of action:
a reprimand;
counselling;
repayment of benefits to the Commonwealth;
payment of a penalty to the Commonwealth; and
complete or partial disqualification from the Medicare scheme.

The Determining Officer will be required to provide the practitioner under review with a draft determination on which the practitioner will have the opportunity to make submissions before it becomes final.

The Bill retains the current appeals mechanisms, with an appeal to the Professional Services Review Tribunal, which will replace the Medical Services Review Tribunals and the Optometrical Services Review Tribunals. The new Tribunals will function in the same manner as the existing Tribunals, and there will continue to be provision for appeals on questions of law to the Federal Court.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Schacht) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend various acts relating to Transport and Communications, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Schacht) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill makes amendments to 16 acts administered within the transport and communications portfolio. The amendments do not introduce substantial new policy schemes, although a number of the amendments do introduce some new policy arrangements and initiatives.

PARA.TAB: In addition, the bill makes a number of technical amendments to a range of portfolio legislation. These amendments correct technical drafting defects and typographical errors which have been discovered since the original passage of the relevant bills. These include deletion of duplicated words, mistaken references to other legislation, spelling mistakes and grammatical errors. The amendments in this respect are all minor technical matters which have no policy significance or impact. I will not address the minor technical amendments in this speech, but will refer to the more significant amendments individually.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988

PARA.TAB: One of the conditions attached to the release of funds provided under the Prime Minister's One Nation Statement of 26 February 1992 for upgrading Australia's national intercapital rail network was that the Commonwealth receive appropriate recognition of these funds as equity in the National Rail Corporation Ltd.

The bill amends the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1998 to enable the Commonwealth to receive this recognition. Under the amendment the Commonwealth will be entitled to shares in National Rail equivalent to the value of payments made in respect of certain nominated railway projects. The actual issue of the shares, however, must be agreed to by the shareholders of the company in accordance with the intergovernmental shareholders agreement.

The amendments correct a technical restriction in the Australian Land Transport Development Act allowing this equity recognition. The act previously allowed for the payment of grants. This is to be amended to allow funds to also be used for capital contributions, which would entitle the Commonwealth to equity recognition, but only with the agreement of shareholders.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983

PARA.TAB: The bill amends penalty provisions relating to actions which intentionally or recklessly endanger the safety of a train and increases the maximum penalty that may be prescribed for offences against the by-laws or regulations from $500 to $1,500. In addition, the bill also amends sections 69 and 70 of the act which require the commission to provide to the minister reports of accidents that occur on railways `operated by the commission' and provide that the minister may establish a board of inquiry to inquire into such accidents.

The precise scope of the phrase `railways operated by the commission' is somewhat ambiguous, particularly where the operational control and management of a railway owned by the commission may be exercised by another railway authority under a contractual arrangement such as a lease, licence or running agreement. The amendments extend the safety reporting requirements under sections 69 and 70 to cover railways `owned or operated by the commission' thus ensuring that in the event of any rail safety accident or incident occurring on any of the commission's railways the reporting and inquiry obligations will apply.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Civil Aviation Act 1988

PARA.TAB: The main amendments to the Civil Aviation Act 1988 will enable Australia to give effect to article 83 bis of the Chicago convention when it enters into force internationally. The amendments will facilitate the oversight of leased, chartered or interchanged aircraft by enabling a contracting state to enter into bilateral arrangements transferring some or all of its obligations relating to the airworthiness and safe operation of aircraft registered with it to the state in which those aircraft are based.

These arrangements will permit closer and more effective oversight of the safety of such aircraft. As a corollary of these amendments, the Air Navigation Act 1920 is to amended to provide for Australian ratification of article 83 bis. The amendments will also clarify the authority's ability to properly regulate foreign registered aircraft which are employed in domestic commercial operations.

The final set of significant amendments to the act will empower the authority to provide safety regulation and other services to other countries and agencies under contract. Such a move has the potential to be an important area of export activity for Australia. Moreover, it has the potential to assist harmonisation of air safety regulation in the Asia-Pacific region, whilst underpinning Australia's regional influence in the area of air traffic management.

On 1 July this year, the Commonwealth took over responsibility for issuing licences to pilots of ships transiting the compulsory pilotage areas in the Great Barrier Reef. This bill will insert a new part in the Navigation Act 1912 to enable the Commonwealth to licence pilots operating in the Torres Strait. It will also provide for regulations to be made about a number of operational matters connected with pilotage, such as safe working practices and pilot liability. Some other provisions of the act already applying to ships' crews, such as dealing with abuse of alcohol and drugs, are being extended to include pilots.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992 and to the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Levy Act 1992

PARA.TAB: The bill makes several technical amendments to the compensation act. The most significant are: firstly, distinguish company trainees—who are in the direct employ of an individual employer—from industry trainees for the purposes of claiming compensation; secondly, allow employers to insure their liabilities with state insurance offices;thirdly, rationalise provisions relating to compensation for travelling expenses incurred in seeking medical treatment;fourthly, ensure that injured seafarers are not required to be examined by a medical panel; and, fifthly, increase compensation for funeral costs in line with recent amendments to the Commonwealth Employees' Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act.

The amendments to the levy act give effect to an undertaking by the former Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The undertaking related to limiting the power to prescribe a particular rate of levy, to be paid by employers of seafarers, in the event that the industry fund ceases to operate and the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Authority assumes the fund's functions and liabilities.

The amendments provide that, before the minister advises the Governor-General about the making of a regulation in relation to the rate of levy, the minister shall consult the authority, which includes employer representatives, in respect of: first, the need to ensure the fund has adequate financial reserves for the purposes of its prudential management; secondly, reasonable estimates of present and future liabilities under the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992; and, thirdly, the cost of administering the authority in connection with the performance or exercise of the fund's functions, powers and obligations.These amendments ensure that in assessing the relevant rate of levy to cover the authority's costs and liabilities in administering the fund's functions and obligations the minister must take account of relevant financial matters before advising the Governor-General. As the rate will be prescribed by regulations, the specific rate of levy and the adequacy of consultation would be subject to parliamentary scrutiny and, if considered appropriate by senators, disallowance.

These amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1991 deal with two matters—numbering and protection of the content of communications. The ability to access and use numbers for telecommunications services is an important aspect of the government's reforms in telecommunications. To this end the government transferred the responsibility for managing numbering from Telecom to Austel in 1991.

Consistent with the Telecommunications Act, Austel has produced a numbering plan which provides a framework for the allocation and administration of numbers. Within this framework, it is important that the providers of telecommunications services have the flexibility to supply innovative services and packages to meet the needs of consumers. These amendments are to remove some unintended consequences of the current act that reduce this flexibility. For instance, the amendments remove any restrictions on the further allocation of numbers by persons to whom they have been allocated and remove any doubt that carriers and other persons can charge for numbers they allocate. Accordingly, the amendments ensure that a service provider who has been allocated a number by a carrier can further allocate that number to its customer. If that customer wants a particular number—which the carrier or service provider has been allocated—because, for example, it has a memorable sequence, the carrier or service provider can charge a fee. It was always intended that the legislative reforms to telecommunications in 1991 would not prevent such charging of fees for special numbers.

The amendments also provide consumer and competitive safeguards through enabling Austel to impose conditions on the use and allocation of such numbers. For example, Austel proposes to prevent fees being charged for the standard numbers allocated for the standard telephone service. It could also be used to enable customers to retain their existing telephone number, where feasible, when they elect to have another carrier provide that service.

Such conditions will be in the form of a disallowable instrument. These amendments have been prepared in consultation with Austel's Numbering Advisory Committee, which includes the representatives of carriers, users and consumers. Austel is expected to continue to consult with its Numbering Advisory Committee before determining any conditions.

Section 88 of the Telecommunications Act protects the contents of communications carried by telecommunications carriers and the suppliers of eligible services. Section 88 creates an offence for unauthorised disclosure or use of any fact or document that relates to contents of communications carried, telecommunications services supplied or the affairs or personal particulars of a person.

The bill amends section 88 to provide greater consistency with information privacy principles 10 and 11 of the Privacy Act 1988, which place limits on the disclosure and use of personal information. The amendments will ensure that section 88 protects `information and documents' instead of `facts and documents'. The amendments also make it clear that the protection given by section 88 extends to non-factual information, such as opinions.

The amendments to the Civil Aviation Act 1988, which will expand the Civil Aviation Authority's ability to export a range of aviation related consultancy services overseas, will enable the authority to enter into agreements with other countries or agencies for the

SPEECH.PARA: provision of consultancy services in relation to air safety regulation and other matters in which it has expertise. The amounts involved will depend on the contracts which the authority successfully negotiates with such countries or agencies. Being able to provide an expanded range of services to overseas countries and agencies should increase the authority's prospects of gaining a number of contracts in the region. The other amendments are not expected to have a significant impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that consideration of the messages in the Committee of the Whole proceed forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering messages 122 and 123 from the House of Representatives relating to the Senate's request for the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993.

PROCTEXT.PARA: EXCISE TARIFF (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That requests Nos 1, 3, 4, 5 and 6 be not pressed.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the substantive issues have been quite exhaustively canvassed in the debate earlier today. The only question that remains to be resolved is whether there is still a majority in this place for the requests to be pressed. That question can be tested by this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that that is the question because, in the terms that Senator Gareth Evans has put the motion, I would have thought that an even vote, for example, would be lost. He has put it in negative terms and that would mean that it is still the view of the Senate that the requests be pressed. I would have thought that would logically follow. On the merits, I certainly hope that there is still a clear majority in the Senate that is determined to pursue this matter. Earlier in the day the Senate said that, in relation to excise increases on rail and maritime fuels, it is not in Australia's best interests and therefore it should not be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: These amendments were part of the government's tax increases in the budget which, as far as they related to increases in fuel costs, have the effect of making Australian business less competitive or, alternatively, certainly not encouraging the growth that is necessary to provide jobs. It really is deplorable that, with a million Australians unemployed, this government would impose fuel taxes that would make Australian business even less competitive.

The coalition argued against the whole of these fuel tax increases but we were successful only in relation to rail fuel and maritime fuel increases. That is disappointing because, as Senator Panizza so eloquently put earlier in the day, increases in the costs of road transport, for example, will have a major and detrimental effect on the competitiveness of Australian industry and business. Unfortunately, the majority of the Senate was not prepared to go in that direction.

The government wishes to increases taxes to cover its lies during the last election campaign. The Australian Democrats—a high tax party—invited the government to break its promises in relation to the tax cuts after the election. It is not surprising that they come in here and argue for increases in taxation, notwithstanding the detrimental effect that it has upon business and employment prospects. The Greens, to give them some credit, took a different view. They wish to make rail and shipping transport costs more competitive vis-a-vis road transport, because they feel that that is an environmentally sound direction to take. We are trying to reduce the costs on all of them.

As I said at the outset, I certainly hope that now that the Senate has the chance to vote again on the issue of rail and maritime fuel taxes it will stand firm and that all senators who voted for it this morning—and voted for it on its merits—will still be with us tonight and the chamber will defeat the motion put by the minister. By defeating the motion the chamber will continue to press the request that we made earlier in the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let Senator Hill's continuing accusation that we are a high tax party pass without some qualification. As I indicated earlier today, we are an extremely low taxed country. We are the lowest taxed of all OECD countries. We recognise, as pointed out by the Burdekin report which was released today, that there are desperate needs in this country which are not being met and for those reasons we voted against the tax cuts which the government sought to pass into law last year.

PARA.TAB: We said quite consistently that the country could not and should not afford those tax cuts. We were quite consistent after the election, despite the promises of the government, to say to the government, `It is in the best interests of the country that you break those promises'. Every single economic commentator whose articles I read at the time told the government that that is precisely what it should have done for the benefit of this country—it should have broken its promise and not granted the tax cuts. We are in the mess we are in now precisely because the government has gone ahead with those tax cuts.

The greater interest of the country should be served and it is not being served by these tax cuts. The opposition is one of the very few groups in the community that does not seem to recognise that. Quite clearly the opposition is being driven by greed. There is no other word for it. These tax cuts go to the middle and upper income groups.

As a party we are not here to simply support the naked greed of the opposition. Having said that, we stay exactly where we were before; that is, we will be supporting the position of the government in relation to these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly was not going to say any more because I said it all this morning when we were debating this matter in committee. This is the second time today that Senator Coulter has misled the chamber. It is probably not the second time; it is probably more like the 20th time. This morning Senator Coulter told us that there had been no major oil discoveries in Australia in the last 20 years. I could not sit here and listen to that misrepresentation.

PARA.TAB: The same applies to his statement that Australia is the lowest taxed country of the 23 OECD countries. That is totally wrong. He knows as well as I do that other countries have other things included in their taxation. Senator Coulter knows that in terms of straight income tax, Australia is well up on the list. He knows that and yet he got up and made that misrepresentation.

I will now refer to the other fallacy in Senator Coulter's speech which was about the `greed' of opposition. When we vote for or against a measure, Senator Coulter jumps up and says that the opposition is greedy. I do not know exactly what he means by that. Perhaps he knows that we represent the people of this country who want to keep small and large businesses going and get the important export income that Australia so badly needs because nothing else is keeping this country going. So to him that is greed.

If we want to tax people on their profits so be it.
