But when we impose a tax that increases the cost of production that is a totally different story because only those individuals who buy fuel pay that tax. When it comes to tax we tax the profits. This measure increases the costs of production. What is greedy about our position?

Senator Coulter must think that employers employ people for the fun of it. Senator Coulter probably has never employed a person in his life. I do not think anybody on the other side of the chamber has employed a person and paid them by personal cheque in his or her life. If those opposite have, they should put their hands up. There are not many. Peter Walsh used to put his hand up when he was in the Senate. Those opposite should realise that one does not employ people for the fun of it. One employs people in order to produce, export and manufacture. If one does not have a profit, one just does not employ people, one puts more people on the unemployment scrap heap. Senator Coulter wants to blindly increase costs. That will lead to unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —He hasn't run a business.
—He has never run a business. He has never paid a person a day's pay in his life. He has never paid superannuation on anyone's behalf. He has done nothing like that. He lives off the taxpayers.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter cannot say that by wanting to keep costs down the opposition is supporting greed. The opposition is supporting business so that it can employ more people. That is the only way to get Australia going again. I hope this is the last time tonight that we have to put up with that sort of story.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly want to support what Senator Panizza said and lament again how the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot, and Senator Woodley continue to cause detriment to the people of my state. I simply ask why they hate country people so much that they will join with the Labor Party. We know the Labor Party has no regard for people living in remote areas, but the Democrats are trying to pretend that they are the party for country people. Yet they go around agreeing with the Labor Party every time it increases the cost of living for country people.

PARA.TAB: It is surprising to me that they did not move amendments to this bill to further increase the amount of fuel tax paid by country people. Before the election they wanted country people, and everyone else in Australia, to pay an additional 16.5 per cent fuel tax. That would make the cost of fuel in most parts of Queensland about $1 a litre. Why the Democrats have such disregard for the people in remote parts of Australia I do not know.

As often as I can I will expose the hypocrisy of the Queensland Democrat senators who, when it suits them, run around trying to pretend that they are supportive of people who live in remote parts of my state, but when it comes to an issue like this they again join with their mates in the Labor Party and make things more and more difficult—indeed, impossible—for people living outside the capital cities.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I will say now ought to be applied to all of the other requests to which the House of Representatives has not agreed. I believe that it was important for this chamber to express its view quite strongly today about these measures and the effect they will have on the economy of Australia, on individual people within Australia and individual business people within Australia.

PARA.TAB: I am quite confident that the action we took in sending requests to the other place would have been desired by the people of Australia. I am not going into whether or not the government had a mandate on these particular matters. I can understand the opposition's continuous viewpoint on this matter in voting against measures to increase indirect taxation. Although these are excise measures, they are a tax on individuals and businesses throughout Australia. They will be bearing these burdens. The opposition quite rightly is incensed. During the election campaign, as we all know, the government belted the opposition over the head about its GST proposal, which was said to be and which was, in fact, a regressive approach to taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the compensation package.

—I was just about to say that. It did not have a compensatory package. I will not argue that matter here. All I am pointing out is that it can be readily understood how the opposition feels now, faced as it is with a situation where the government is introducing measures which will increase indirect taxes. The government has put this forward on the basis of its long-term—and indeed short-term—deficit reduction strategy.

PARA.TAB: I supported the move by the opposition this morning and this afternoon in the vain hope that the other place would have regard to these questions and would consider them maturely. I do not know whether any honourable senators saw what the other place did. I made it my business to have a look at what it did to these particular measures. At about 8 o'clock tonight, the other place considered these measures and they were guillotined through. A motion was moved by the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) on each occasion to not agree to our requests.

The requests were peremptorily dealt with. It was obvious to everyone, including me, that the government had no intention at all of agreeing to any of these requests. It was clear in the manner in which the government dealt with them that, no matter how many times we send those requests back to the other place, we would get the same result. In that circumstance, it is a waste of time to send these requests back to the other place. Therefore, I am not going to vote for those bills to be sent back to the other place at all tonight. The clear attitude of the government is to reject them out of hand. The question now is whether the bills pass this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the view that this chamber should persist. The government has no mandate for what it is doing. Senator Gareth Evans regularly lectures this chamber on what he calls unprincipled behaviour on this side of the chamber, and Senator Evans is nodding his head. I wonder whether there was any greater example of unprincipled behaviour than that of Senator Evans and his colleagues in the four weeks prior to 13 March. I wonder whether anywhere in postwar history have we seen more unprincipled behaviour than when the Labor Party—
—You are a very bad loser.
—I know Senator Evans is embarrassed about it, and so he should be.
—You came second.

—Of course, but Senator Evans lied his way into office and, as a result, he has no moral authority whatsoever. No wonder there is a lot of horse laughing around this chamber every time he gets up and talks about a political principle. I put it to Senator Evans and to Senator Harradine: if Silvia Smith, who won the seat of Bass by 42 votes, had gone around in the election campaign and told the truth, that the cost of maritime fuel would in fact rise substantially, would the seat of Bass have been won by the Labor Party? Of course, it would not.
—Of course, it would.

—Hope springs eternal on the Labor Party backbench! The fundamental issue here is that the government has no mandate for this. I put it to honourable senators that this place does have a mandate to attempt to keep the government honest.
—I don't think you heard what I said.

—I may not have heard all that Senator Harradine said, but the bottom line of this issue is one of political principle and one of mandate. If I am wrong and if, during the election campaign, Senator Evans went around and said that fuel taxes were going up and wholesale sales taxes were going up, and if he went out to central Victoria and said that wine taxes were going up, then I am ready to get up in this chamber and apologise to him. The same offer applies to Senator Schacht and to Senator McMullan. If one of the Labor senators can stand up and tell me that he or she said during the election campaign that this vast range of taxes were going to raise some $3 billion, more than the net effect of the goods and services tax, as a number of writers have pointed out—in fact, the net effect of this is worse than the GST in terms of the money raised through indirect taxes—
—Let me ask you a question, Shayne. You are a new man in this chamber.
—Order! Senator Kemp, the use of personal descriptions is an attractive and endearing virtue, but you should refer to Senator Murphy by his proper title.

—Senator Murphy is new to this chamber. I have asked three of his colleagues whether they mentioned during the election campaign that maritime fuel was going to rise and adversely affect their constituents in Tasmania. Is it possible for Senator Murphy to stand up and indicate to us whether he promised his constituents that, if they voted for him, he would have a mandate to impose an extra cost on everyone in Tasmania who purchased any goods which are imported from the mainland. Of course, he did not; no-one did.

PARA.TAB: The Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill is shabby. It is a gross broken promise. This chamber should continue to press that the increased excises, which have now come back from the other place, should be rejected. There are great matters of principle here. I regret to say that, as a result of the Australian Democrats and the Greens, the government can draw the conclusion, as this budget proceeds, by and large, amended only slightly, that it can go to the election and promise one set of tax policies and emerge some three or four months later and impose an entirely different set of policies. I think this chamber fails in its task by not continuing to press this matter.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Gareth Evans's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS TARIFF (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: I move:

PARA.TAB: That the requests be not pressed.

SPEECH.PARA: Again there is no need to canvass the substantive questions, simply to test again whether there is still a majority or not for pressing the request in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the motion. I think it is worthwhile canvassing some of the issues again. I am sure that Senator Gareth Evans would like to be reminded that all this started with the government's lies at the last election. Remember, there were going to be tax cuts—l-a-w, law. There was no doubt about those; not promises, and it would not require any tax increases. Magically the deficit was going to come down as well. All lies, lies to the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: The Australian people know that that is what happened. Senator Evans thinks that this is something to be proud of. Those opposite laugh at us because we were honest and lost. Well, they lied and won. That is really something to be proud of. What has happened is that this has caught the government out. After the election what it had to do, knowing that there were no way the deficit was going to go down, was to come in and increase taxes. That is what the government did. It put up the wine tax, the wholesale sales tax and the fuel tax, and then retrospectively taxed accumulated annual leave and long service leave.

What a great achievement this budget is. It is regressive and hurting those Australians who can least afford it. That did not worry the government. What a reward for the true believers after the election to come in and find that their fuel taxes were going up. And, of course, as for the poorer with leaded fuel, their taxes were going up even further. What a reward for a government that lied to the people at the last election, thanked the true believers for their support and then brought down a budget in these terms.

I know that those opposite are proud of their achievement. They have taken politics in Australia to a new low. They can be pleased that the Australian Democrats say that it is quite legitimate to lie and in fact invite those opposite to break their promises. No doubt the Democrats will get up and try to justify that again in this debate.

We took a principled position after this budget was brought down; that is, that we would do our best to bring a bit of honesty into this debate. If the Democrats were not prepared to do it, we were going to. We were not going to let those opposite easily get away with lies. This will be the last test as to whether the parliament as a whole is prepared to let the Labor Party get away with its election lies or not. It will be an interesting vote in that regard.

We have come to the last of the taxation deficit reduction bills which contains the final taxes on fuel—taxes that will make Australian business and Australian productivity less competitive at a time when there is nearly one million Australians out of work. What a brilliant strategy! Australian business needs to grow. But what does the government do? It puts up their on-costs. That is very smart government.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have never been in business.

—That is right, none of them have been in business. It is all academic or comes out of the ACTU. Those opposite put up taxes on business on-costs and somehow or other believe that will create jobs—what totally naive nonsense.

PARA.TAB: This is the last opportunity for the Senate at least to vote against increases in taxes on maritime and rail fuels. Unfortunately, we could not get the numbers for anything else. The government will now put up costs in the road transport industry as well as increasing the cost of industrial oils and fuel oils. At least this morning the Greens and Senator Harradine were prepared to say, `We won't let you put up tax on rail fuel and on maritime fuel'. This is the final test as to whether they will stand with us on that so that the numbers will be here to at least save the Australian people from some of the tax imposts created by this government. I urge those who were with us this morning, those who were prepared to be part of this protest, those who were prepared to demonstrate to this government that it would not totally be able to get away with lies, to stand with us now and vote down these pernicious taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. This morning in an editorial in the West Australian a lot of credit was given to the two Green Western Australian senators about how they saved so much for the farmers and for the rural and remote people of Western Australia. Maybe Senator Margetts was held up getting down into the chamber. As honourable senators know, by the rules of this house if someone is held up by misadventure, then they can rise and claim that they could not get to the division through misadventure and we can then have another division. Of course, we will support Senator Margetts if she wants to go that way.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts has to remember that she holds the balance of power in the Senate with her confederate Senator Chamarette, who did turn up and ran the flag up for us. Senator Harradine also declared his position, showed up and indeed voted.

TALK.START.PARA: —He sat on the other side.

—He voted on the other side but at least he had the courage of his convictions to make his explanation, come in and vote with the government. I do not admire him for voting with the government, but at least I admire the courage of his convictions.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Margetts had problems in getting here, perhaps she should stand up and tell us. As Senator Margetts and her confederate have the balance of power—especially as both honourable senators come from Western Australia—they should think very hard as to how they use that responsibility. This evening, unless Senator Margetts did not get here by misadventure, she has let Western Australia down and in particular the Pilbara area that she claims to represent. After all, I claim that I am the most active representative after Senator Ian Campbell and maybe Senator Crichton-Browne and Sue Knowles, but I think we would be on an equal par, on how we represent the Pilbara.
Senator Crane interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crane has been up there once in the last three years. Senator Margetts has claimed in the West Australian that she is the senator for the Pilbara. I admire her for getting that two-page spread with all the time she spends in Karratha.

PARA.TAB: Tonight I did a prerecorded radio program—I will probably have to ring and tell the station not to run the tape in the morning—saying how the coalition saved those fuel rises in the north-west and other places, ably assisted by the two Greens senators from Western Australia. Fortunately, it is early enough that I can ring and tell the station not to run that tape, otherwise I will be told that I am running a mistruth.

The problem is that this morning the Greens helped us to defeat the measure which would stop those rises in the country. At the time I got up, thanked them and gave them due recognition. Senator Margetts gave us recognition that our 36 votes had got us there. But she has not supported us this evening. I am very disappointed. I am afraid that in the morning I will have to tell the West Australian what really happened. Hopefully, Senator Margetts did have a misadventure and will stand up, claim misadventure and we will have another division.

TALK.START.PARA: —This really is a black day or we are rapidly moving to a black night. On the other side of the house we have a bunch of conviction politicians, convicted of blatant political dishonesty. The poor old true believers are being taken to the cleaners by the true deceivers. The fact is that those opposite could only get away with this treachery because of another little outfit that now seems to be dedicated to keeping the bastards dishonest. It is a particular shame that at least one of the Western Australian Greens seems to have gone a brighter shade of yellow. I would not have thought that anyone would want to see us, in any shape or form, be party to measures that are clearly designed to punish those true believers; those people who once thought the Australian Labor Party stood for something worthwhile, instead of its being a bunch of opportunists without principles.
—Like you.

—That is dead right. If we were guilty of anything in the last election, it was of being honest and spelling out what needed to be done for this country. During the campaign those opposite ran around and spent all their time knocking anything that moved. They never came up with a constructive policy. Their only solution to anything was to knock off the GST. Now they have the cheek, the unmitigated gall, to try to pretend that somehow their policy approach in this bill and the other bills is justified. In fact, it is precisely the opposite to what they promised the people before the last election.
—Why do you want to celebrate your losses?

—We are not celebrating losses. We are, tonight, commemorating seven months of deceitful and dishonest government—a government that has been comprehensively exposed since the election. The government is an outfit that has no commitment—

PARA.TAB: Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it should be clear to all concerned that what we have in this bill is a classic example of measures that are designed to punish ordinary Australians for the benefit of a party that quite unscrupulously believes that somehow this is the road to salvation at the next election by pretending that by 1996-97 it can get its budget deficit down to one per cent of GDP. The government also believes that somehow it needs to punish all those people who used to think the Labor Party represented their interests.

PARA.TAB: I have always been fascinated by a statement Senator Richardson made when we asked him why it was that with those original tax cuts there was no reduction in the lowest marginal rate which, of course, is 20 per cent and, under Fightback, was going to be 16.2 per cent. His basic proposition was, `We don't need to worry about that lot. We did a lot for them in the 1980s. We have moved on. There are votes in the middle income groups now, so we won't worry about those people'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what I said.
—It is a rough paraphrase, but—
—Pretty rough.

—Pretty right, too. It is a good cynical assessment by a classic numbers man who judged that the government could get out there and say that it had done a lot for those people over the years and as a result did not need to do much more for them this time around. I do not think people in their wildest dreams thought the government would go from merely not helping them to kicking the guts out of them. That is basically what it has done with these measures. Then the government has the cheek to think that somehow this can all be justified in the interest of some sort of fiscal rectitude. It is an appalling proposition. To think that the Australian Democrats, who came into being on a single premise—if ever a party was founded for a particular purpose, if ever a party had a slogan or a theme—
—Nobody is listening to you.
—Senator Collins will be.
—You've lost us.

—The trouble is that there is nothing Bob Collins and I can talk about these days. We want to ask him Mabo questions and he is not allowed to answer them. He has been gagged. We ask him about pay television and, of course, that is all to do with Beddall. I do not know why he bothers turning up. he is probably just here for the TA back to Darwin every weekend.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, what we have now is a party in the Australian Democrats that has completely and utterly repudiated its single core value. It was set up solely for the purpose of keeping a particular group in a particular position. All they have done is aid and abet dishonesty and treachery. I would have thought that if the Democrats were on about social justice, whatever they think that means, they would recognise that these measures in no shape or form—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is caring policies. It is policies of the heart.

—By jove, Senator Kernot is sounding like a colleague of mine. I am very pleased to hear her espousing Liberal policies. Apart from that aberration, the Democrats' fundamental problem is that they do not seem to recognise that not only are they rewarding infamy and villainy, but also the measures they have managed to wring out of this government are tokenism at best. What they have ended up doing is punishing the very people that they purport to have an interest in.

PARA.TAB: Let alone keeping them honest, the Democrats are ensuring that those in the government will continue to be as dishonest as possible wherever possible. That is a tragedy, I would have thought, for the country. That is why we have been so trenchant in our views and so consistent in our position and why we have, time and again, made it clear that we will not be party to this felony. We are not going to stand back and allow this government to get away with saying one thing before the election and another after it. On that basis we have absolutely no choice but to stick to a position of principle. The great tragedy is that there are not enough other principled politicians in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I particularly want to address my comments to members of the government, who are back in here because of the lies they told during the election and the way they deceived and misled the Australian public. They did it quite openly and quite blatantly, but now they should reflect on it. I was particularly involved in the seat of Swan. Mr Beazley, who sits in the other place, won that seat by 130-odd votes and he did it on a lie. It is very sad and it is very unfortunate. The Australian public is now paying the price for believing that lie.

PARA.TAB: I will make some brief comments on the position of the Democrats. There is no doubt—what we have known for quite some time has been confirmed—that the Democrats are no more than the left wing of the Labor Party. They have consolidated their position of where they sit in politics. The Australian public needs to be aware of that and to judge them on that standard at the next election.

Every time it comes to the crunch on an issue in this place, we know precisely and exactly where and how the Democrats are going to vote. It is absolutely pointless for them to go through the charade they go through in this place every time they come in here, pretending they are going to do something for the Australian public, pretending they are going to address the real issues, because they line up with their buddies on the other side of this place every time, without fail.

Tonight Senator Margetts obviously deliberately stayed out of this place so that her vote would not be recorded. She did not take a principled position on this particular issue. I certainly will make it my business to make sure that what she did here tonight is relayed to every household possible in Western Australia. In politics, if one takes on the responsibility of representing a state, one has to be prepared to come in here and make a decision. One cannot squib out by staying on the other side of the wall. That is what Senator Margetts did tonight. She did not have the courage of her convictions. Her action has let down an enormous number of people in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole of Australia.

—And Australia, but I am referring to Western Australia because that is where she comes from. I agree that her action has let down the whole of Australia, but it has let down Western Australia in particular. Western Australians must be made aware that when the crunch comes, when it really matters, when you have to stand up, she cannot bring herself to make a decision and have her position recorded by the way she votes. It must be remembered and we shall remind them—

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. We are debating a motion that the requests not be pressed. I wonder whether Senator Crane is relevant to that motion. If he is, then his comments regarding Senator Margetts are not really conducive to her voting with the opposition in respect of the matter that we are dealing with. We do not know what delayed Senator Margetts.

—On the point of order, the fact that Senator Margetts chose not to enter the chamber and chose to abstain from voting is a very important matter for Western Australia. It is totally germane to this debate and, clearly, Senator Crane is being extremely relevant in this matter. Dee Margetts needs to come into this chamber and tell the committee and the people of Western Australia why she chose not to vote on this matter which affects her constituents.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. The point of order should be relevant to the matter before the Senate.
—Order! The only question before the chair is whether or not Senator Crane has been relevant. In terms of the conventions of this place, he has been.

—Thank you very much, Mr Chairman. What I am saying is relevant to this debate for a very simple reason. I am throwing down the challenge to Senator Margetts to come back here into this place to vote when we have the next vote. I request her to have the courage of her convictions with regard to what she has said to the Western Australian public on these matters.
—And what she said in debate in here.

—And what she said in the debate in here. The next vote is her opportunity to correct what happened in the last vote. I remind Senator Margetts how she got into this place at the last election. She piggybacked into this place on Liberal preferences; that is why she is here. She also should remember that when we come to the next election. Senator Margetts now has the opportunity to come back into this place at the next vote and vote in the way in which she has led the Western Australian public to believe she would vote.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Deputy Leader of the National Party said, it is a sad day for Australia—and everyone would have to agree with that—but it is an even sadder day for rural Australians who have to face tremendous costs now that the overall Senate has let them down so badly. From this moment there will be a $580 million tax on rural Australia. The increase on fuel alone will be $108 million. It will reduce the average farm net income by four per cent, when we all know that many farmers are already struggling to make ends meet.

PARA.TAB: The National-Liberal party started out with great intentions to stop on-costs flowing on to rural producers and primary industry. It took its position one or two days after the budget. It has remained rock solid on that position while the Democrats and the Greens have pivoted around like wind indicators in an ever changing breeze, not knowing from one day to the next what will happen. This will put an extra 15 per cent cost on rural Australia and reduce rural incomes by four per cent.

Overall in Australia the cost of a trolley of groceries on average will go up by $3 to $4, but in Western Australia it will go up by $5 to $5.50. So the people who came into this place by having been piggybacked in on Liberal Party preferences have sadly let Western Australia down.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Australia.

—They have let all Australians down, but particularly Western Australians and Northern Territorians in whose areas fuel and extra costs are so important to the average family; they have completely sold them out.

PARA.TAB: I would add another dimension to this debate because it seems to me that it is a bit of a conspiracy. I am not a great believer in conspiracy theories, but we have battled away and sought to move amendments. We had the Greens with us one minute and then they dived; then the Democrats dived; and then we had them both with us and they dived. We have battled away over the last four days and all we have done is provide a forum for watching the Democrats do double-twisting somersaults and backflips. It is just a conspiracy of the Democrats, the Labor Party and the Greens working together, trying to say, `We're here to save the world; we're here to help you. I'm from the government; we're here to help you'. Then they dived, and then they came back and the Democrats dived. So it goes on and on. For four days we have not achieved one thing because they have just sold out, done deal after deal with the government, and the government has them in its pocket.

TALK.START.PARA: —So much for principle.

—They would not know what the word principle was all about. But that last trick, where one came in and the other stayed out, was kindergarten class. I have been in this place for 12 years and I have seen some stunts in my time, but that takes the cake. It is so naive. They can go over to Western Australia and say, `Yes, but we voted; we were there; I was there, and the other one did not turn up'. If they think the Australian public are that naive and that stupid—
—They said they were going to make naivety a virtue in politics.

—If they are trying to make naivety a virtue, I do not think they can ever achieve that. But if they believe they can sell that to the Australian people—that they can split their vote, take a dive, change the whole vote and then come out of it smelling like roses—then they are treating the Australian public as fools. They will be treated with contempt at the next election, and I hope that the Liberal Party considers where it puts its preferences next time. It has been a bad day for Australia, but it has been a terrible day for rural Australians who will have to wear the brunt of the conspiracy, the double-dealing and the tricks that the Democrats and the Greens have staged tonight.

PARA.TAB: Let us make it very clear that the Democrats now are becoming completely indistinguishable from the Labor Party. At least the Greens are showing some sort of difference; they might be naive, they might be funny, but they are different. But the Democrats now are completely the same colour and type as the Labor Party, except a little more to the Left.

I conclude my remarks on that note, but I am disappointed. I am disappointed with the Greens; I am particularly disappointed with the Democrats who will go out to those in rural Australia and say that they are supporting them, when at every stage they let them down badly. There could be no worse way to let down rural Australians than to increase the cost of fuel that they find so necessary to use out there for their production, getting their products to market and their food to the table. It is one of the unkindest things that I have ever seen the Democrats perform. I really am quite disgusted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to clarify a few points on this issue because a very significant vote has taken place tonight. The fact is that the Greens—or one of them—have just willingly imposed on all Australians higher fuel taxes.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. We seem to be having an awful lot of post mortems about the previous vote and not much attention being paid to the content of the motion before us, which is really on a quite different subject, a different set of requests. I would ask you to rule that, as fascinating as these exchanges may be, particularly Ronnie Boswell's, I think it is getting time to focus on the substantive issues.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. We have had a chance to witness the kinder, gentler Gary Evans tonight—and I put it to you that it probably will not last all that long. But the point of order is that Senator Evans is the last person to speak about content of speeches. If we had known the real content of Labor Party policies in the last election, we would not be faced with this particular dilemma now.
—I am certain that Senator Knowles is warming to the subject and she has only just started.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. Yes, I value your comments there because I am just warming to the subject of the whole issue of the taxes. The taxes that we are actually considering now are just as significant as the fuel tax on which the Greens have just suddenly decided to ditch. I am very concerned that the impression may be given that there was some unavoidable delay that Senator Margetts chose to have so as not to come in here and vote. Credit should probably be given to Senator Chamarette who actually tried to get Senator Margetts to come in here. Senator Chamarette zoomed in; Senator Margetts chose to stay out.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the fact that the misadventures or otherwise of Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts do not bear upon the consideration of the request now before this chamber. I ask you to rule accordingly. That point simply is not relevant.
—I think that Senator Knowles should, as far as possible, restrict herself to the bill, but I understand the general point she is beginning to make.

—Had I been able to finish my sentence, I would have actually said that I was really hoping that Senator Margetts would choose this time to come in and vote, having decided not to come in and vote the last time, making that active—
—That is a new sentence. You are finishing a paragraph.
—There were lots of commas in that sentence. There is a desperate need for the Democrats and the Greens now to be true to what they have said out there in the electorate.
—You're asking a bit much.

—I know it is a bit rich, but the fact is that only a few weeks ago there was an article in the West Australian newspaper about how Senator Margetts was, in fact, going to be a senator for the north-west of Western Australia. The legislation that we are considering tonight is particularly the type of legislation that affects the very people that Senator Margetts was purporting to represent.
—She betrayed them.

—Tonight she has betrayed them, lock, stock and barrel, quite intentionally. I hope that on the next vote Senator Margetts comes in and has the courage of her convictions to actually speak and act in the way in which she has been out there blabbing on—
—And in here.

—And in here—Senator Tambling is quite right. Every single, solitary news item that we see says that they are going to stand up for the little people. Well, stand up for the little people they have not, and I hope they do later tonight. The conversation that I heard of Senator Chamarette simply saying, `You must vote', and Senator Margetts saying that she would not, and then not coming in and voting, really must make sure that she does come in and vote at this next division to ensure that that is a significant vote for the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Reid) put:
That progress be reported.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be long. I was reminded this evening of the feminist claim that marriage is rape. The Greens decided tonight that they were going to get married to the Labor Party. What happened? They got their morality raped. But there is one little problem. They found that the Australian Democrats were already in bed with the government. So, as a consequence, we now have on the other side of the chamber a little menage a trois.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Not only are those remarks manifestly offensive to honourable senators in this chamber, they are quite inappropriate for the debate and this chamber. I suggest they be withdrawn under the standing order that deals with constituting offence against particular senators. It is a calculated offence and it ought to be withdrawn.

—Order! Senator O'Chee, I do not think it is an expression which enhances the standing of the chamber. It might be appropriate, given that it has offended some senators, that you withdraw those remarks.

—I withdraw. But I find it quite surprising that Senator Gareth Evans, who is always abusive and offensive, is so keen on this occasion to try to have remarks withdrawn because they strike too close to the truth in this case. We have a situation—
—I suggest that the withdrawal be absolute and comprehensive and not qualified in that way.
—Mr Chairman, on the point of order: Senator Gareth Evans may be twice the size of Senator Button, but he is only half the man.
—Senator O'Chee, I believe that you did withdraw in an unqualified way. But as a result of my ruling, you should not reflect on a point of order taken by another senator.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I shall not reflect on it any more. We all know what we think of it. We do not have to say it any more. We have a menage a trois on the other side of the chamber. They are all in bed together at the same time. They are all out there for a common purpose. We know what it is all about. I suggest to the Democrats and the Greens that they consider taking the opportunity this evening to go for a divorce, because getting married to the Labor Party—
—I wouldn't want to be in bed with you. What a disgusting thought.

—I do not want Senator Kernot in bed with me. As a single man I am trying to keep my virtue clean on this side of the chamber. But perhaps the Democrats and the Greens should consider a divorce from the Labor Party. The only thing I would suggest is that, when they file for the divorce, they do not file for half of the assets because what they might get is half of the liabilities—and, goodness gracious, the Labor Party, with all its lies in the election campaign, is toting around a hell of a lot of liabilities.

PARA.TAB: Looking at the credibility of the people on the other side of the chamber, one can see the extent of the liabilities that it has. Look at the people on the other side of the chamber. Finding any who have any credibility in the electorate is a pretty good achievement.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did that vote cost tonight?

—That vote cost hundreds of millions of dollars, not just in Western Australia, which gave them two votes, but all of Australia. It has cost the shipping industry, the rail industry and all the people whose support they tried to get millions and millions of dollars. We had a Greens sell-out of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is quite interesting that today one of the Greens senators had a little badge on her lapel saying `Black on Thursdays. A protest against rape and violence'. Senator Faulkner clearly did not read it, because when the Greens came in to vote on that division, he went over and put the heavy on them and said, `You've got to sit on this side with us'. We are sick and tired of the intimidation from the Labor Party and this nonsense that we get from the other side. We believe that there ought to be bit more honesty in politics at the moment.

When we look at this bill, the request and the motion moved by Senator Gareth Evans on the request, we have to ask ourselves what the effect on the transport industry in this country will be. What will be the effect on prices in remote areas? There will be an increase in prices in remote areas such as the Northern Territory and Western Australia. Prices might be an extra 25 per cent higher as a result of the additional fuel tax that will be imposed tonight. That is what we are talking about. Every Thursday we will be wearing black. I suspect that many people in regional Australia will be wearing black because they will be mourning the death of morality on that side of the chamber.

Senator Margetts came into politics and said that she was going to make a virtue out of naivety. As Senator Boswell said, they had to be pretty naive if they thought they could sell to the Australian population a stunt like the one we saw tonight. One of them came in and voted with the coalition—so they can say that they voted with the coalition—and the other sat outside the chamber and denied the coalition the vote it needed to keep on representing the people who live in regional Australia. It is naivety, but it is not virtue. I want to know which of the two Greens is naive and which one is virtuous. I have my own beliefs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep them to yourself.
—I will keep them to myself.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. This tirade of offensive abuse is not only intolerable from that point of view; it is also manifestly irrelevant on grounds about which you have previously ruled. The voting patterns on previous motions have nothing to do with the particular request that is before the chair. I ask you to rule accordingly and make Senator O'Chee get back to the point in issue.
—Mr Chairman—
—Order! Senator O'Chee, are you speaking to that point of order?
—Yes, I am. If Senator Gareth Evans had not been so rude in interrupting me mid-flow—I know that he never listens to what other people have to say—
—Order! Senator O'Chee, if you have a point of order, you should express it promptly.
—He would have realised that I was saying that this motion is the opportunity for the Greens to amend their voting record, which is what ought to happen.
—Order! Senator O'Chee, I have been tolerant tonight in allowing the debate to drift some way past the substance of the motion. It is not unreasonable that you address your remarks to the bill.

—The relevance to the motion is that Senator Evans is asking the chamber to forget about morality and not to press requests for amendments which the Labor Party thought this morning were quite important. So what are we supposed to do? Believe in one thing in the morning and forget about it in the evening? Are we supposed to believe that something is important for Western Australia in the morning and not important after 10.30 p.m.?
—That is how they operate.

—I know that that is how the Labor Party operates, but I do not think that other honourable senators believe in that. That is why we on this side of the chamber are opposed to what Senator Evans is trying to get the Senate to do and why we believe that all honourable senators ought to be opposed to it. We have a bit of morality, virtue and honesty. That is something members of the Labor Party have a lot of difficulty comprehending. But they will comprehend it when they leave this chamber tonight or tomorrow and go out to the Australian people, who will say, `What did you do to us tonight? You sold us out'.

—I invite the committee to examine what we are doing tonight. We are considering a motion not to press the requests that we made earlier today. We are doing that in the expectation that either that motion will be carried or that it will not be. The opposition, of course, would want it not to be carried. It was my understanding, before the merciless bagging that was taking place on the Greens, that they in fact were going to vote with the opposition on this matter. They will make up their minds, no doubt, on the merits of the situation. I respectfully make a recommendation to the opposition that it desist from this bagging of the Greens and just see what they might do on this occasion.
—They have already shown what they are going to do.

—Quite clearly, I thought they were going to vote against the motion not to press the requests. They may not have seen, as I saw, what happened to our requests in the House of Representatives. I think the requests are appropriate; I think they have merit. Otherwise, I would not have voted for them this morning. But having seen what happened in the House of Representatives, it has convinced me that there is absolutely no purpose served—
—Are you going to let the House of Representatives put it over the Senate?

—I ask Senator Ferguson to listen to what I have to say. There is no purpose served in carrying on with this charade. It was a charade in the House of Representatives and the House is going to stay there, presumably, to knock back the requests every time. Everything the opposition is saying in this debate, with respect, is nothing to do with the motion that is before the chair but is rather everything to do with the third reading. That is the test. I suggest that we forget about this. It is an absolute waste of time to keep pressing the requests. Let us get on to the vote on the third reading.

—I beg to disagree with Senator Harradine. I consider that the Senate has an entirely different role from that of the House of Representatives. Members of the House of Representatives are elected on a different franchise from us. We are elected state by state. Since 1 July 1993 in the Senate we have been in a unique situation with the voting strengths of the parties and the independents. Very soon after 1 July 1993, some of the people who actually hold the balance of the vote, the balance of power in the Senate, were representing outlying states.

PARA.TAB: We have Senator Harradine, who has just spoken; Senator Chamarette, who represents the outlying state of Western Australia; and Senator Margetts who represents the same distant state from which I am proud to come—Western Australia—some 3,000 kilometres from where we are now. This is a unique position. Senator Harradine is telling us that this committee should not seek to reassert the decision that was made this morning. I am saying that the Senate should do that. If we are fair dinkum about representing our states' interests—and of course we have all read the history of the Senate—

TALK.START.PARA: —When have we ever done that as a Senate? It is a party house and you know it.

—Senator Burns would have us believe that the Senate is purely a party house. There is no doubt that the founding fathers did envisage that the Senate would quickly form into a party based house. Those very same founding fathers recognised that senators would have big influences within their party forums. I am putting it to the Senate—and it is perhaps the first time it has been put publicly—that we now have a situation where the two major parties may well represent the party room positions, and very rarely will they differ from that.

PARA.TAB: Very rarely will we see a Liberal or a National Party senator break from the considered, philosophically sound position that is determined in that party room—even though there may have been occasions in the last couple of years where some may have chosen to do that. Rarely will we find a Labor Party senator breaking from party ranks to vote against his party and in the interests of his state. We have seen this here, with senators from outlying states not voting to press these requests.

Here tonight we have a very special situation in which three independent senators—two Greens from Western Australia and one Independent from Tasmania—represent outlying states that are specifically and particularly disadvantaged by the increases in taxes that this government promised we would not have but which it has brought in with this budget. Here we have a chance for the Senate to stick up for the outlying states. Senator Harradine has that opportunity, Senator Margetts has it and so does Senator Chamarette.

I think Senator Harradine was correct in saying that the Greens had indicated that they would be voting to press this request. That is why some of us on the opposition benches are perplexed and incredulous at the fact that Senator Margetts abstained from the last vote. I think that was very sad. Through my colleague Senator Panizza, we offered Senator Margetts the opportunity to explain why she abstained from voting. The reality is—and I will try not to go down the irrelevant track of reflecting on former votes—that if she were to choose to abstain from the next vote on the matter we are considering in committee then, effectively, it is a vote for the Government's position.

It is very similar to the position that we put to the people of Western Australia during the 1993 election, particularly the Senate election. Some Liberal senators—and I know I did on occasions—suggested to the people of Western Australia that a vote for the Greens was indeed a vote for the Labor Party. On most occasions, in the years I have been here, the Greens do vote with the Labor party. I think the statistics show—I have not seen them lately—that on something like 92 per cent of occasions the Greens vote with the Labor Party on divisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —You voted 85 per cent.

—Senator Coulter should be pleased that I have turned my voting analysis to the Greens, not to the Democrats; I will turn it back to them if he likes. His record, particularly when he was leader—before he was rolled by Senator Kernot—was to vote with the government on just about every occasion; he very rarely voted with the opposition. I emphasise the importance of this measure for Western Australia, and I go back to the point I was making about Senator Harradine. The Greens should be voting for their state.

PARA.TAB: Western Australia will suffer enormously under these measures. Just about every grocery item that is not imported into Western Australia goes across the Nullarbor on the railway. These measures will put up the cost of groceries and will affect Western Australians a lot more than they will affect Senators Evans's constituents in Melbourne or citizens living in Sydney or virtually any other state. The fuel imposts will have a worse impact upon Western Australia than they will on just about any other state in Australia, on my reckoning. I refer to rail and also to shipping. We are a long way from the capitals in the eastern states. The constituents of Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts will be disadvantaged by this move.

Senator Margetts has to consider very carefully how she will vote on this amendment. She must remember that the people of Western Australia will know—if they do not already—that abstaining from this vote will be voting with the Labor Party. It will ensure the Senate does not press this important request which does, in a very real way, stick up for the interests of the outlying states.

We can reflect on whether or not the Senate has supported the interests of the outlying states in the 92 years since federation but we know very well that this request we are making very honestly sticks up for the rights of the outlying states. I implore Senator Margetts to vote on this motion and to vote with the coalition parties. Another thing that needs to be reflected upon is what I think was quite a cruel case of intimidation by Senator Faulkner on that vote when we sought to—

TALK.START.PARA: —How would you know? You make the assertion and you don't know.
—I will make the assertion and Senator Ray can defend it if he so wishes.
—That's not the way this place operates. You can't just throw wild spears that other people have to respond to.

—Perhaps the Hansard record needs to show, even if there was no intimidation, that when we last sought to report progress on this matter, the two Green senators entered the chamber and sat on the aye side of the aisle. Shortly thereafter, Senator Faulkner approached them and they moved to the no side of the aisle. That needs to be recorded in Hansard because that is what happened.
—Having told them what the nature of the vote was.
—That should be put in the record—Senator Faulkner having told them what the nature of the vote was.
—Namely, a vote on the adjournment, not the substantive issue. Put that in the record.
—I have put that in the record. According to Senator Evans, Senator Faulkner approached the Greens and told them what the nature of the vote was.
—It was on the adjournment, not on the substantive issue.

—Exactly. The fact that that is on the record is to show that the Greens are sitting in their offices, probably looking at my ugly mush, trying to figure out what I am saying. But the fact is that they did not know what they were voting on. I guess that is no shame on them because on many occasions I am sure all of us have come in here and not been exactly sure what we were voting on. It is probably harder for the Greens because we can follow our colleagues, as can members of the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: The Greens do need to keep a very close eye on what is happening in this chamber. I hope they are doing so now. I genuinely say to the Greens that this matter is similar to the wine tax, as it specifically affects Western Australia. It is very important that they vote in the interests of those people in Western Australia, particularly those who live in remote and regional Western Australia. It is important that the Senate makes a stand and reinforces the stand it made earlier this day.

EMPHASIS.TAB: A division having been called and the bells being rung—

TALK.START.PARA: —Another bag of money, Faulkner!
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Chairman. I ask Senator Ian Macdonald to withdraw that thoroughly offensive remark.
—Order! Senator Evans, I did not hear Senator Macdonald.

—The remark in question was addressed to Senator Faulkner along the lines of, `Another bag of money, Senator'. I ask you to put that to Senator Macdonald to see whether he is prepared to concede that that is what he said.
—Order! I am sure that if Senator Macdonald said what you said he said and that if it was intended to offend and it did offend, he would withdraw.
—I certainly did say that, Mr Chairman. If you are asking me to withdraw, I will withdraw.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Gareth Evans's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the requests be pressed.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an unprecedented situation that we now confront—an equal vote on a motion that the requests not be pressed. It is a situation that has never previously arisen in the history of this chamber. It requires accordingly an unprecedented way to resolve it. It was not unanticipated that this situation might arise at some stage during the consideration of these bills, and a good deal of thought and attention has accordingly been given to the appropriate way in which we might move forward in this situation. The course that I am proposing is to test in a different way and in a way that will—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. The minister is not entitled to move to another motion because the matter has now been resolved. The Senate has had a vote and there has to be a consequence that flows from that vote. The government chose to put its original motion in the terms `that the request not be pressed'. There was an even vote and under the terms of the constitution it should be resolved in the negative and therefore the requests should be pressed. There has to be a consequence that flows from every vote that is taken. Therefore, you should rule, as I have said, that the requests are pressed by virtue of the vote of the Senate that has just taken place. Mr Chairman, I put to you that it is the only logical conclusion on the basis of the vote of the Senate and the minister is not entitled to get up and move another motion.

—The situation we are confronting is an unprecedented one and it demands an unprecedented approach in order to clearly identify in a way that has not been clearly identified, I would suggest so far, what precisely the will of the Senate is so far as this issue is concerned. Whatever else the equal vote that we have just got means, it clearly does not indicate that there is a majority for pressing the amendment in question. What it does mean is ambiguous. What it does mean will be much less ambiguous if the motion is put in the alternative way—in a way that makes it clear. If the motion is that the request be pressed, and that is resolved in the negative, clearly the will of the chamber is that the motion not be pressed. Putting it another way, clearly there is not, when tested in this way, a majority for the request to go forward.

PARA.TAB: The issue has been addressed in an indirect way by Odgers in the sixth edition of Australian Senate Practice when he says:

SPEECH.PARA: What has yet to be tested is the position which would arise if the motion that the amendments be not insisted on be negatived by an equal vote. It could hardly be deemed that the Committee had resolved that the amendments be insisted on, because the Committee was equally divided. In such circumstances, probably the Chairman would state that position and invite a motion that the amendments be insisted on.

Odgers is referring there to amendments not requests, but I would suggest to that extent that the analogy is perfectly apt and the advice is perfectly good. If we test the matter in the alternative way and we get an equal vote again, as is perfectly possible, because on this occasion even though I am moving that the request be pressed, the government will, of course, be voting against that resolution and there is nothing in the standing orders to inhibit that particular course being taken.

PARA.TAB: If the motion is negatived again, then there will be a different situation, a much clearer situation, than the one we are now confronted with and we can deal with that at the time, and no doubt the Chairman will. Mr Chairman, I take it you want to rule on the point of order, or are you letting me proceed with the speech on the motions?

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Gareth Evans read out from Odgers was in fact in relation to amendments.
—I just acknowledged that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Alston

TALK.START.PARA: —I know. Of course that is not the issue that is before the chair. Let me just say, in relation to that particular proposition, that it firstly does not follow that because Odgers says `it could hardly be deemed the committee had resolved the amendment be insisted on because the committee was equally divided', is true. That is acknowledged.

PARA.TAB: What happened was that we got a clear result. What we now need to know is what follows from that result. Mr Chairman, I refer you to page 613 of Odgers where it addresses this precise matter. It states:

INTERJECT.PARA: A point of procedure to be noted is that, if a motion that the request be not pressed is negatived, the result is the request be pressed.

That is the clear and unavoidable logical outcome of that decision. So the only authority that you have, Mr Chairman, is the point in Odgers that precisely addressed this matter. What Senator Evans had to say about amendments is utterly irrelevant. I therefore invite you to follow the ruling that has effectively been given by way of advice in Odgers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Harradine

TALK.START.PARA: —The point of order that was raised by Senator Hill was that Senator Evans could not move another motion that the request be pressed. I invite you to look at standing order No. 141, which says:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) Messages from the House of Representatives referring to requests by the Senate which do not completely comply with the requests as originally made or as modified shall be considered in committee.
(2) If a bill is returned to the Senate by the House of Representatives with a request not agreed to,—
or agreed to with modifications, any of the following motions may be moved:

TALK.START.PARA: —Any one of.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Harradine

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it says:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . any of the following motions may be moved:

PARA.TAB: (a) That the request be pressed.
(b) That the request be not pressed.
(c) That the modifications be agreed to . . .

INTERJECT.PARA: It does not say `any one of', as was suggested by Senator Alston. It says `any of'. That is what the standing orders say and that is what they mean. Therefore, without going into its merit, the motion of Senator Evans is in order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that there is some considerable doubt about the procedures that we are adopting, surely, under the circumstances of a vote having been taken, the appropriate course is for the bills to go back to the House. They can then be returned and Senator Evans can put his motion that the bills be pressed, if he so wishes. That is a procedure that will take perhaps 10 or 15 minutes. That procedure will put us beyond any doubt whatsoever. That is the only proper circumstance for this chamber to follow.
—I do not want to repeat the arguments. Mr Chairman, when you make a ruling on the point of order, can I ask you to rule as to the effect of the vote that has just taken place?

—Order! I have listened carefully to the debate being presented to me from both sides. I am satisfied that under standing order 141 a number of motions can be moved, including the motion that has been moved and the motion that Senator Evans sought to move; it is, therefore, in order to move both those motions.
—What is the effect of the last motion?
—The last motion was negatived.
—Under standing order 145, I lodge my objection in writing.
—Mr Chairman, the rest of us were not party to that exchange between yourself and Senator Hill. Could you enlighten us?

—Senator Hill asked me the effect of the last vote. I said that, as the vote was divided equally, the resolution was to be cast in the negative. The effect of that was, therefore, that the rest of the motion would not be pressed. Senator Hill has now kindly handed me a piece of paper objecting to my ruling. Under standing order 145 I am required to immediately leave the chair and report to the President, who no doubt will contemplate the dissent from my ruling so early in my career.

PARA.TAB: The President having resumed the chair—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I report that a motion of the Senate was moved dissenting from my ruling that under standing order 141 any of a number of motions can be moved, including the two motions to press or not to press requests, and that the motions were in order.
—Order! Under standing order 141, either or both of the two motions can be moved. The Chairman's ruling is therefore correct.
—Mr President, I ask for clarification. The Chairman said that no consequence flowed from the last vote. Is that part of your ruling as well, Mr President?
—Yes.
—Senator Evans does not give him the answer. Let him answer himself.
—Yes, that is correct. The motion was negatived.
—The matter having been laid before the President and senators having addressed themselves to it, did you give the Senate the opportunity to address the issue, Mr President?
—It is in order for me to hear further argument.

—Mr President, may I put further argument to you. The basic proposition that we have to begin with is that it cannot possibly determine the fate of a particular amendment the way in which the amendment is put. The issue before the Senate is whether the request will be pressed and go back to the House of Representatives. There are two ways in which this issue can be tested under the standing order. One way it can be tested is for a motion to be put that the request be pressed. If that is an equal vote and it is negatived on the basis of equality, it is clear that the request will not be pressed. It is also very clear that there is no majority for the request to be pressed. That is what I seek to test now by putting the motion in the way that I proposed.

PARA.TAB: If the motion is put the other way—that the request not be pressed—and that is greeted with an equal vote, as it has been, what we have is a formal negativing along the lines that the request not be pressed. Two negatives do make a plus when it comes to algebra, but I suggest that when it comes to determining the validity of a Senate vote, that is an insufficient precision or an insufficiently strong foundation on which to proceed.

I think the key point is, if there is a tied vote, whichever way the motion is put, however else we choose to characterise it, there is not a majority of senators for the basic proposition in issue, which is that the request be pressed. However we twist and turn, juggle and weave, there is not a majority for the request being pressed.

If the Senate wants to do something as dramatic and important as pressing a request in circumstances that we are now confronting, there ought to be a majority for that particular course to be taken. The absence of a majority is very clear. If we put the motion in the form that the request be pressed, the absence of a majority for that proposition is rather less clear. It is rather more ambiguous, it is rather more disguised, if we simply leave it on the basis in which it has been put so far. It was for that reason that the Chairman very properly ruled that no consequence should be regarded at this stage as flowing from that first resolution.

It was proper that the matter be tested by a second resolution in the affirmative form which would produce a result which would clearly not be ambiguous but which would clearly articulate the Senate's position. It is for that reason that the Chairman's ruling and the President's confirmation of that ruling that no consequence followed from that last vote was perfectly correct. It is for that reason that the course of action that I suggest that we follow is the rational one.

That is the course suggested in the passage of Odgers that I read out in the context of amendments, at least, if not requests. It was addressing the particular question of whether or not there is a majority to press an amendment when there is an equality of votes. It is an analogous situation. It is not exactly the same situation, but it is by far the closest passage in there to the situation we are confronting. The suggestion in Odgers is that, under those circumstances, we should put the vote again the other way. Standing order 141 clearly allows the President to do that. That is exactly what has happened, and I suggest we proceed on that basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. The argument of Senator Gareth Evans is really novel. He has said that this matter is of such importance that it must require a majority vote now that it has come around a second time. That is all very interesting, but it is not the case. Senator Evans chose to put his motion earlier in a particular way. The result of the vote was equal. It was negatived in terms of the constitution and a consequence must flow from that. The consequence is clearly that the requests are pressed. That is exactly what is said in Odgers. It is clearly and unambiguously spelt out there. It is no good for Senator Evans to say, `There is another part of Odgers that talks about amendments'. We are not talking about amendments; we are talking about requests; and we turn to the bible and there it is in print.
—Bible!

—I would put Odgers ahead of Senator Evans every day. Senator Evans is really saying, `Disregard Odgers because Odgers is not serving my purpose—the government's purpose'. It is as simple as that. The Senate is entitled to have a consequence flow from the vote that was taken. The only consequence that can logically flow from it is that the requests are pressed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Alston

TALK.START.PARA: —I pursue the matter briefly. What Senator Evans said in the first instance was that because his motion failed to secure a majority, no consequence then flowed. But he would then argue that if it is put in another form and we achieved precisely the same result, somehow a consequence flows from that. I would have thought it is a nil all draw either way we put it for precisely the same reason that he indicated in the first instance; that is, that the outcome cannot be dependent capriciously upon which side of the case is put first.

PARA.TAB: The end result is that whichever way you approach it you end up not being able to advance the matter at this stage. The critical thing is that you are then left with the original decision of the Senate that the matter be pressed, that the request be pressed. Nothing has occurred since that time to indicate that the Senate has a contrary view. It is not as if the term of the Senate has been altered or the composition of the Senate has been altered. The Senate has made a decision by a majority view that it wanted the request pressed, and nothing has happened to alter that majority view. Nothing has happened either way. So you are left in that position.

This is critically important if we are going to take any notice of anything other than raw numbers or who represents what in this chamber, if we are to be guided by precedent. The quotation that Senator Evans referred to—we are in heated agreement on this—relates to amendments. The part of the passage he did not go on to read is this:

INTERJECT.PARA: If that motion too were negatived on an equal vote, it would be best if the Committee reported progress, asked leave to sit again, and gave further consideration to the matter on another day.

So that quotation from Odgers is in no shape or form arguing that a consequence flows from that decision. It simply says, `Put it in the too-hard basket, go away and hope that maybe the numbers change or someone else forgets not to come in at the critical moment or for some other reason something happens to bring about a different result'. That quotation makes it crystal clear that there is no consequence that flows from this other than that in respect of amendments you go away and have another think about it. Therefore, all you are left with in terms of precedent and Odgers, which is, as Senator Hill rightly said, the bible, is a clear and unambiguous statement. Mr President, I ask you in responding to please explain why that sentence is not conclusive of this debate.

PARA.TAB: A point of procedure to be noted is that—all I need to reiterate is the following—if a motion that the request be not pressed is negatived, the result is that the request be pressed. That, Mr President, is crystal clear, and it is crystal clear for the logical reason that the Senate has made its position plain by a majority view that in respect of this bill it wanted the request pressed, and nothing has happened since that time to indicate that the Senate wishes to change its mind. So the Senate's position is clear. Odgers confirms that and there is no authority to the contrary. Mr President, I cannot see how you could possibly rule against our submission.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: might I ask you now to take this opportunity to give a ruling on all the matters in issue in this debate, not simply those that are relevant to the immediate dealing with the particular dissent motion that is now before you. Since the other issues have now been raised by Senator Alston, not by me—I was prepared to take it one step at a time—and since honourable senators might well appreciate the opportunity to hear a considered view on the whole combination of issues that interlock and that will need to be addressed in the course of this ongoing debate, might I invite to you make such a ruling. I do so in the knowledge that some prior attention has been given—
—What standing order?
—I am speaking on a point of order. I still have the floor, if the honourable senator would not mind sitting down and letting me finish.
—Order! Senator Evans has the floor. He is talking to a point of order.
—He just popped up on his feet and started speaking—

—On a point of order. I will complete the point of order. I invite the President to make a ruling addressing all these issues: the issues of procedure, the issues of order, the issues of the proper interpretation of the standing orders which must be resolved if this issue is going to be able to be sensibly dealt with.
—Is this in order?
—Yes, it is.

—I was concluding my remarks and my submission to you, Mr President, with the following single sentence: I know that you are in a position to make such a ruling because, as the opposition well knows because its members have been circulated copies of a draft, the matter has been given some considered prior attention in the anticipation that this situation might well arise at any time in this place. So, in the knowledge that you have such a ruling that has been the subject of careful consideration by you, careful advice to you by the Clerk, I invite you to put it before us now.

—I would like to say that under the standing orders, Mr President, I presume you are going to listen to the argument, the full argument, before you accept the invitation of the minister to make a ruling—145.
—Order! It is in my power to now make a ruling.

—I do not wish to contest the proposition that you have the power to make a ruling, Mr President, but can I make a plea to you—and this is very important—that any ruling you make, Mr President, ought to be a considered one. Now, as Senator Evans rightly says, we have been circulated a copy of advice provided to you by the clerk.
—I have not seen it.
—All right. But this is critically important. It is not correct to say that the debate tonight and the points raised have been considered in advance—
—By the President.
—They have not.
—How do you know whether they have been considered by the President or not?

—Because unless you think the President is about to dictate off the top of his head a very carefully worded judgment, taking account of all the points of order, what you are in fact inviting him to do is to read out this ruling that has been prepared in advance. If you do that it is a travesty of justice because that contains the quotation from Odgers that is clearly not relevant to this debate and it does not in any shape or form deal with the precise point. The point in Odgers that deals precisely with this issue is not mentioned in that draft ruling, so you cannot possibly proceed to hand down that draft ruling with an irrelevant quotation and not in any shape or form deal with the precise sentence that goes to the heart of this issue, and if you do it is a travesty of justice.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, if you do propose to make a ruling on this, Mr President, I submit to you that you are duty-bound to give this careful consideration, not to do it on the run, not to do it tonight. In fact, if you are as a result of the debate to hand down a decision on this matter, it ought to take account of all the points that have been made—

TALK.START.PARA: —He should listen to further argument.

—There should be further argument, absolutely. Mr President, you should then go away and reflect on what you read about what has been said tonight. If you proceed to trot out this piece of paper, you will be completely disregarding the debate, you will be ignoring the critical quotation that we have put to you from Odgers and you will make a farce of these proceedings.
—This is incredible.

—Order! This position has been put to me over the last week. This is not a situation that we are just judging tonight. I have sought advice on this issue from a number of people. Therefore, I think that I should rule on both issues.
—Mr President—
—Order! I am ruling.
—But there is a point of order before you.
—Order! I will listen to argument afterwards. I want to rule now.
—I want to speak to the point of order, Mr President. You have a point of order before you. I want to speak to it.
—What I am doing is making a statement now, Senator Bishop, and you will resume your seat.
—Mr President—
—Resume your seat. Senator Evans made a submission to me. It was not a point of order.
—He spoke on the point of order—
—Order! Resume your seat. Under standing order 141, either or both of the two motions can be moved—resume your seat.
—Mr President, on a point of order. I am entitled to speak to a point of order that is before the chair.
—There is no point of order before the chair. I have disposed of that.
—You did not. It is before the chair.

—Order! Resume your seat. This position is not something that just arose tonight. It has been considered for some time. I want to make two points. Under standing order 141 either or both of the two motions can be moved. I rule that the chairman's ruling, Senator Crichton-Browne's ruling, is therefore correct.

PARA.TAB: I also want to make another statement. It is now necessary to consider the effect of a situation in which the Senate has voted to amend a bill received from the House of Representatives, or to make a request for an amendment to the House of Representatives, the House of Representatives has declined to agree to that amendment or accede to that request, and a motion in accordance with the procedures of the Senate to determine whether the Senate should persist with its amendment or request has been negatived by an equally divided vote.

The effect of such a vote cannot be held to depend upon which of the alternative methods permitted by the standing orders for determining such a matter is used, that is, a motion to insist or a motion not to insist on an amendment, or a motion to press or a motion not to press a request. This situation has not arisen in the Senate in the past. It is therefore necessary for me to consider the effect of the Senate's vote and the course of action which should follow from it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I respectfully intervene and say that that opinion you are now reading to support your ruling was on the basis that the second motion had been put—
—I am sorry, Senator Hill, can I finish?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have been invited to rule on a substantive issue and I am ruling on it. At page 495 of Australian Senate Practice, 6th edition, the following statement is made:

INTERJECT.PARA: What has yet to be tested is the position which would arise if the motion that the amendments be not insisted on be negatived by an equal vote. It could hardly be deemed that the Committee had resolved that the amendments be insisted on, because the Committee was equally divided.
