In such circumstances, probably the Chairman would state that position and invite a motion that the amendments be insisted on. If that motion too were negatived on an equal vote, it would be best if the Committee reported progress, asked leave to sit again, and gave further consideration to the matter on another day.

It will be noted that this passage refers to an amendment and not a request. A similar observation is not made in the work concerning requests. The passage also does not distinguish between an amendment or a request which must be carried by a majority and the omission of a clause of a bill which may be made on an equally divided vote.

PARA.TAB: The interpretation of the Senate's vote and the suggestion made in the passage is unsatisfactory in that it leaves the fate of the bill in question undetermined and does not provide a means of resolving the situation. I consider that a more rational interpretation of the effect of the Senate's vote resolves the situation and allows the Senate to consider further the legislation in question.

At the initial consideration of a bill, a majority vote is required to make an amendment or a request for an amendment to the House of Representatives. If the House of Representatives declines to agree to the amendment or the request, the Senate must reconsider the matter. If on the motion to determine whether the Senate should persist with its amendment or request there is not a majority, this indicates that there is no longer a majority in favour of making the amendment or request; the amendment or request no longer has the support of a majority of the Senate. I consider that in that circumstance the amendment or request is disposed of and the bill should proceed without the amendment or request in accordance with the standing orders.

The situation would be different if a clause of a bill had been negatived in committee, which could occur by an equally divided vote. The standing orders require that, where a bill is treated as one which the Senate can amend under section 53 of the constitution, every clause of the bill must be carried by a majority, and if a clause is negatived it is left out of a bill. If a motion not to insist on such an amendment were to be negatived by an equally divided vote, this would indicate that the clause still lacked the support of a majority and that the amendment was confirmed.

Where an amendment or a request must be made by a majority in the first instance, however, a decision to persist with the amendment or request should require majority support at the later stage. This interpretation gives rise to a complexity, in that there are two categories of amendments with a different rule applying to each, but that distinction rests upon the requirement for a majority to carry an amendment in the first instance, and the requirement for a majority to carry each clause of an amendable bill.

I believe that this interpretation best preserves the integrity of the Senate's proceedings, and also avoids a situation of the Senate being unable to make a decision on a stage of a bill, and the fate of the bill being left undetermined. This interpretation also does not inhibit the right of the Senate to dispose of a bill which has been the subject of a request, because it is still open to the Senate to reject the bill at the third reading, which must be carried by a majority.

In relation to an amendment to a bill other than the omission of a clause, if the Senate regards its passage of the bill as conditional on the amendment, this is a matter for the Senate to consider in deciding the fate of the amendment. I therefore rule that the request now in issue is disposed of and the bill must proceed without the request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, Mr President, you have got it all wrong.
—Sorry Noel, you have got it all wrong.

—No, the President has gone a next step further. He has assumed that the next vote has been taken as well. I take objection to the ruling under standing order 198. I lodge my objection in writing and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate dissent from the President's ruling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I do not know that we have heard your ruling. Did I hear you rule that the requests now in issue are disposed of? Are we not considering Senator Evans's motion that the request be pressed? Is it a bit early to make that ruling?
—Senator Harradine, I have made a ruling. It is necessary, therefore, if we go back into committee that Senator Evans's motion be determined one way or the other; thank you.

—We have got a little ahead of ourselves. But I suggest that the ruling is nonetheless perfectly apt in its present terms. The course of action I was proposing before was to put the question absolutely beyond doubt.
—Mr President, on a point of order: I do not know on what basis he is on his feet.
—I am in support of the President's ruling on the point of order which you raised.
—What point of order?
—The point of order that you raised.
—Can I speak to the point of order? I was not given a chance to speak to my point of order.
—Senator Harradine has put a point of order. I am speaking to that.
—Why wasn't I given a chance to speak to it?
—Order! Senator Evans is speaking in support of the statement that I made. He can speak to it.

—Might I suggest, on the point of order, Mr President, that there are two ways of dealing with the situation now—a short way and a long way. The short way is to take your ruling at face value as you have just put it.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order—

—Might I finish my point of order, Mr President, by saying the short way is to accept your ruling at absolute face value to say that the resolution that has been passed is not one that conveys a majority for the request to be pressed. Accordingly, under those circumstances, you could regard the matter as now disposed of and the bill able to proceed without request. A longer way of getting, I would suggest, to the same result is to say that that is the prima facie indication that has been given by the resolution that has already been passed—that there is a majority lacking for the request to be pressed—but that is better tested by having another resolution first.
—What is your point of order?

—The point of order is that your ruling, Mr President, is perfectly apt and applicable as it presently stands, but it might be even more apt and applicable if you had another vote as well. It is up to you to determine.
—Can I speak to Senator Harradine's point of order, because I do not know what Senator Evans was up to?
—Yes, you can speak to assist the chair.
—Mr President, the point is that you made a ruling a few minutes ago that this matter is now disposed of. You did not say there was any need for any further resolution.
—Didn't you listen?
—No, no. Mr President, the mistake you made—I wish somebody would listen to us.
—I ruled on a substantive issue as it had been canvassed.

—Mr President, can I put my argument. The situation is that you had assumed that Senator Evans's second motion would have been put and disposed of and would have been an equal vote also and come out in the negative; then you would have said that there were two votes in the negative on inconsistent motions and that, therefore, the matter cannot be left up in the air. But that has not happened. It has not happened because we are trying to have the question settled—
—He is not even listening to you.
—Listen to him, Mr President, will you?
—Order! Yes, I have ruled about a situation which—

—I am nearly finished. That has not occurred because we are trying to have settled what is the consequence of the vote that has taken place. We were expecting a ruling from you on that issue. I do not think that we have one. Is that not correct?
—We have a pro forma ruling.

—We have not got a ruling yet from you on that matter. Mr President, with respect, the Clerk's advice did not address that question because it was assumed that the second motion would be put first, but we have put a different question to you. And the question we have put has led us to Odgers to find out the consequence of the vote that we have already carried. The consequence of the vote that has taken place is clearly and unambiguously stated in Odgers to be that the requests be pressed. If the vote is in the negative on the motion that the requests not be pressed—which was the choice of Senator Evans; he decided to go down that path—the determination, according to Odgers, is that the requests are pressed.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, that is the issue that we asked you for a ruling on. You have given a ruling, with respect, Mr President, on something else—a set of circumstances that have not taken place, but a set of circumstances which, if they take place, will fortuitously fall into the hands of Senator Evans because he will then say that the matter is up in the air because there are two inconsistent resolutions. But we do not have to get to two inconsistent resolutions because the vote of the Senate that has taken place has to have meaning, and the meaning is as stated in Odgers. The government has lost this one, Mr President, and you should rule on that issue. You should rule in accordance with the advice that you are given by Odgers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would it assist the chair, Mr President, if I were to suggest to you that you treat the advice that you have just given and read out in full as being contingent upon the passage of the other motion. I say that because I invited you, Mr President, in order to assist the Senate, to spell out the sequence of events which would follow if all the steps were spelt out and available to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Your ruling does stand on its own feet as applicable to the situation as it exists now because it is clear that there is not a majority to press the request. It will be even clearer that there is not a majority to press the request if the motion is put again in the alternative form, which the chairman has already ruled is the course that is appropriate to follow by my motion being put. It will be clearer then than it is now. Under those circumstances, that is probably the sensible course to follow.

If it assists the matter for you, Mr President, I suggest that you indicate that what you are dealing with is anticipating the situation that would thus arise and go back and conclude the consideration of the matter that is now before the chair. Matters are complicated enough without the opposition seeking to make them even more complicated and impossible.

This is an unprecedented situation. It is not one that is addressed in Odgers. There are different ways in which a motion can be negatived and equality of votes is one of them; a clear majority is another. This situation has not arisen before. It is not the subject of any direct advice in the Odgers volume. For that reason, we do need to work creatively and sensibly together to produce a constructive and rational result which does not produce an obvious stalemate. Under those circumstances, Mr President, I suggest it is possible for you to rule and move the debate forward.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Alston

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, what has just been put to you is this: we find the prisoner guilty; we would now like to hear the evidence. You cannot possibly go back and consider a second motion without vacating your ruling, which was clearly utterly premature, and is conceded to be so by Senator Evans in all but express terms. In other words, you have delivered a pro forma judgment which assumed that both propositions had been put, that neither had a sufficient majority and that both were therefore negatived.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, it is very important that we appreciate what is before the chair. A motion that the requests be not pressed was moved by Senator Evans. It did not secure a majority. The chairman ruled that it was negatived but he then said that no consequences flowed from that. We have put to you authority from Odgers, and I wish to put further authority to you. I find it astounding, I must say, that there has been no response to this to date. Page 613 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: A point of procedure to be noted is that, if a motion that the request be not pressed is negatived, the result is that the request be pressed. For example, on 20 October 1981 motion was proposed that the requests be not pressed—in connection with the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos. 1A to 9A) 1981. The motion was negatived, 26 votes to 28. In reply to a point of order, President Young ruled that it was Senate practice that, if the question that the request be not pressed is negatived—
and that is precisely what has been ruled tonight—

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the vote—26 to 28?
—Yes. The point of order was to elicit what the consequences were of a motion being negatived. It has been ruled tonight—
—Negatived by majority vote, not negatived by an equality. This is an unprecedented situation.

—It does not matter how you get there. You can get to a position by a number of roads. If the end result is that the chairman rules that the motion is negatived, then you have a clear and express ruling from a former president, Sir Harold Young, that—the question that the request be not pressed having been negatived—the result is that the Senate has resolved that the request be pressed. He did not say, `only where there is a majority'. He said `if the result is that the request be not pressed is negatived'. That is precisely the position that we have reached tonight but by another route. That is all that is different; we have got there by another way.

PARA.TAB: The end result is one that we are in heated agreement on—the end result that the request be not pressed is that it is negatived. That was the decision of the chairman. It does not seem to have been quarrelled with. The only thing we have quarrelled with is the further interpretation that that is meaningless, that no result flows from it. We are saying—that is why we moved dissent—that that cannot possibly be right because all the authority is to the contrary. Yet what we have now is a ruling that utterly presumes events that have not occurred and that in no shape or form deals with that precise ruling.

Mr President, you cannot let the matter stand on the basis of a ruling that is utterly hypothetical, ignore the precise point which is before the chair and then proceed to ignore a ruling of a predecessor of yours. We therefore invite you not to do what Senator Evans invited you to do; that is, give an off-the-cuff ruling and get it wrong. We invite you to go away and consider this matter after there has been full and adequate debate.

If this is a unique situation, if this is an event without precedent in the history of the Senate, there surely deserves to be a careful consideration of the issue. We have just had a classic example of what happens if you try to do the opposite. Mr President, if you try to pretend you have listened to and heard most of what the clerk has to say and none of the debate and then proceed to read out a piece of paper which was prepared days ago on the basis of events which have not occurred, you are bound to get it wrong. That is what happened; you got it wrong. It would be unfair to this chamber, unfair to the parliament and unfair to the community for you to proceed in that fashion. You cannot possibly let your ruling stand because the ruling has nothing to do with any matter that is before the chair.

Mr President, you ought to vacate your present ruling, go back to the matter in issue before the chair—that is, what consequences flow from a result that the request be not pressed is negatived—and you ought to do that after careful and mature consideration based on careful reading and analysis and on advice which you take on the debate and the points that have been raised in this debate tonight. If you do anything other than that, it is a charade; it is simply a programmed result that has been number crunched, irrespective of the merits of any of the argument.

Mr President, if you want to go down in history on that basis, go right ahead but you will not be doing anyone any favours. I suggest that you will do everyone a very big favour if you go away and have a good think about it after you have heard all of the submissions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue before me is the ruling that Senator Crichton-Browne made on standing order 141. I decided, on the invitation of Senator Gareth Evans, to rule on the substantive issue because it had been canvassed by the opposition speakers. I have also ruled on the ruling of the chairman, Senator Crichton-Browne, concerning standing order 141. If my rulings are upheld, the committee will resume and Senator Evans's motion will be determined.
—Where the confusion is coming in, I think, is that there are really two sets—
—Are you on the point of order?

—I am speaking to the point of order; I am trying to be helpful. There are virtually two concurrent rulings occurring here and I think we should go back to where we were about 40 or 50 minutes ago. The sequence of events was that Senator Crichton-Browne ruled, an objection was put in to Senator Crichton-Browne's ruling, the President ruled on and that and then debate went on to a whole range of things. The President has now made a second ruling, which the opposition argues is anticipatory.

PARA.TAB: We should set aside for the moment the second ruling and go back to the question in the debate of whether the opposition wants to dissent from the President's ruling, which reinforced Senator Crichton-Browne's ruling. It is then open to the committee to decide whether it wants to report progress. It can think about it, proceed or do whatever you like. If we do that in a logical order, we will not have this debate running in nine different directions as it is at the moment. I suggest, Mr President, that you reiterate your ruling on Senator Crichton-Browne's ruling. Then it is open to Senator Hill to put in an objection in writing, which I understand he has done, and we can proceed from there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with what Senator Ray has said. In other words, Mr President, he is inviting you to vacate your ruling—
—Not to vacate it, just to set it aside.

—All right, set it aside—and then to go back to where we were; that is, we take issue with the proposition that no result flows. In order to make a ruling on that, Mr President, you cannot simply do it off the cuff if you are to do justice to it. You have to do it on the basis of the submissions we have made to you quoting authority, referring you to instances in the past. You have to take account of all those matters. You cannot do it on the run. You cannot do justice to this issue unless you properly consider the consequences of that ruling.
—The President gives rulings all the time.
—This has never arisen before, I thought you were saying. Why do you think a draft ruling was prepared four days ago?
—Not on this, but on the first debate.

—Precisely. That is the whole point. We have not got to that stage yet and that is why it is equally important that the stage we are at now be given the same degree of consideration as the stage that those opposite would like to be at, which has led to a three-page advice. But you cannot do one on the run when that is the issue before the chair and then have a carefully prepared answer to something which has not yet arisen. I therefore invite you, Mr President, to set aside your ruling, to then listen to the debate on the point before the chair and to give that proper and reflective consideration.
—I was asked to rule on Senator Crichton-Browne's ruling. I have ruled that Senator Crichton-Browne's ruling is correct. Unless dissent is moved on that—
—I have.
—we will move back into committee.

—I have a point of order, Mr President. I presume it is all right for people other than those who have spoken to take a point of order. Some considerable period of time ago, Senator Hill pointed out to you that in considering this matter you had to hear debate. We are now at the point of hearing debate. You refused to listen to debate and read out a prepared ruling.
—If you let your leader move the motion, we will listen to you.
—I moved it 20 minutes ago. Why don't you read it?

—Mr President, the point of order is that Senator Alston has invited you to go back to the position we were at previously when Senator Hill made his point of order, saying that debate needed to be listened to and heard. Mr President, Senator Evans invited you to make a creative ruling. I put it to you that a creative ruling is about as acceptable in this chamber as creative accounting. I put it to you also that you are bound to at least give equal consideration to the arguments that are being put by Senator Hill and by Senator Alston as you have to the pre-prepared nonsense that was done in advance of Senator Evans having thought he would get his procedure right. What he is really saying to you, Mr President, is: `I have got it all messed up. Can you help me out please, brother in the Labor Party?'.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) put:
That the question of dissent requires immediate determination.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, part of the argument has of course been canvassed, but this will enable us to complete the debate. The principle flaw is the fact that in your ruling there does not seem to have been any consequence that flowed from the previous vote. If there were a consequence, then whether or not Senator Gareth Evans is entitled to move another motion would depend on whether it is inconsistent with that consequence.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I do not know whether you have thought about this. I am surprised that your ruling did not address the question of the consequence of the last vote. Something has to flow from a vote of the Senate, so what is the argument? Is it Senator Evans's latest exotic argument that a negative vote that is achieved because of an equal vote is different to a negative vote that is achieved because the number of votes is different from the other?

TALK.START.PARA: —Very creative.

—It is creative; it might suit Senator Evans's purpose, but he has forgotten the constitution. The constitution provides that the vote is of the same consequence—an equal vote is a vote determined in the negative.
—That doesn't follow from that.

—Well, Senator McMullan could participate in the debate. He might have a better argument than Senator Evans. He has not put a good one yet. With respect, Mr President, that is where the flaw was built into your ruling. Your ruling was premised on the fact that there would be another motion before you having been resolved in terms of an equal vote also. You would have had before you two negative determinations to inconsistent motions. As I said a little while ago, that is a very convenient situation for the government, but it is not what has occurred tonight. What has occurred tonight, Mr President, is that there is only one resolution before the chair and you have to determine what is the consequence that flows from that resolution on its merits. That is what we have not got from your ruling. We therefore move dissent.

PARA.TAB: What you have said, Mr President, is that under standing order 141 Senator Evans is entitled to move to another motion. But he is only entitled to do that if it is not inconsistent. I am not sure he is entitled to do it anyway, but he is certainly not entitled to do it if it is inconsistent with the resolution of the Senate that has just passed. If the consequence of the resolution which has just passed is, according to Odgers, that the Senate has decided that the requests be pressed, how can Senator Evans now get up and move a motion that the requests be pressed? That matter has been dealt with and disposed of.

It is no good for me to appeal to you any more, Mr President, because you have made a ruling. So I guess I am appealing to members of the minority parties, who have been conspicuous by their absence in this debate. Are they going to allow this false interpretation to be written into the record of this place? Are they going to allow former President Young's ruling to be overruled because the President was making a ruling on a different set of circumstances from the ones that were before him? Surely the minority parties are not going to allow that to occur tonight.

Senator Alston was right. When the President realised that he was addressing a different issue, he should have been prepared to take it away and address it carefully on its merits and listen to all the arguments, including what is stated in Odgers in relation to requests, which was not included in the advice that he got from the Clerk because the Clerk's advice was on a different set of circumstances.

It is because of the fact that the argument on the issue before the Senate was not properly considered that I suspect, with respect, Mr President, you have made a mistake in your ruling. You are not going to put it right. The responsibility now is for the Senate to put it right. That is the purpose of this vote. That is the reason that I have moved dissent—in order that the Senate can right the wrong that has occurred here in interpretation of the practice and standing orders of this place. It cannot be allowed to rest in its current form. So it comes back, as it should, to a determination of the Senate.

The government, of course, gets its instructions and does not care if it is passing a ruling that is wrong, but I would like to think that the minority parties, which see themselves as having an important responsibility in this place, will ensure that the President gets it right. They have an opportunity now to do so. If the consequence of that is unfortunate for the government in terms of its numbers on that last vote, that is part of the practice. We all have to operate under the one set of standing orders. If we lose under that set of standing orders, that is too bad. They are the rules of debate. That is the basis upon which we enter these debates.

I know it will irritate Senator Evans, because he will then have to take other procedural steps and perhaps come back next week. I do not know. There are many options open to him, but that is what he has to do, because the consequence of a negatively determined vote is that it is lost. The consequence of that, as clearly stated by Odgers and reinforced by President Young, is that the requests are pressed. I invite the Senate to take the position that I have put tonight in argument and to correct the error in the ruling that you have made, Mr President.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very quickly, very simply, the real substantial issue before the Senate is whether we are going to press these requests—whether there is a majority in this place for that particular proposition. If there were a majority for that, that would be the end of the matter. When we first debated this issue some time ago, there was a majority and there was no argument about it. Now that majority has disappeared and there is an equality of votes. So it is a difficult situation to decide how to respond.

PARA.TAB: If the motion is put in one way, as the Senate has just done, that the request not be pressed, and that is voted on in an equal way, we get the strange result that the request not be pressed; we do not get a clear demonstration of a majority sentiment prevailing that the request be pressed. That would be even more clearly revealed, of course, if the motion were put the other way around, with the vote on the motion that the request be pressed. If there is an equality there, manifestly there is no majority to proceed with the request.

The short point, as I said some little time ago, is that the outcome of a matter as important as this cannot depend on the procedural oddity as to the order and sequence or the choice of the way in which the same substantive issue is actually put to the Senate. It cannot depend on a verbal quirk.

The reason I moved it the way I did is that that is the standard government motion. I did not want to be accused of playing ducks and drakes, or smart alecs, or anything of that kind. I put it that way in the expectation that the Senate would agree, as Odgers somewhere suggests, that in that sort of situation one proceeds to put the motion the other way around, as the standing orders entitle one to do, in order to test just a little bit more clearly whether there is or is not a majority.

There is no point quoting that previous situation that arose that is dealt with on page 613 in Odgers where the proposition is stated that the negativing of a motion to not press a request means that the request is pressed, because in that situation there was a clear majority for the negativing of the motion in question. The votes were 26:28, with 28 senators in favour of the request not being pressed and 26 the other way around. Clearly, if the vote had been put the other way around, there would have been a very clear majority for the request actually being pressed in that situation.

The problem is that, when an equality of votes arises, where there is a degree of ambiguity, that ambiguity can be much more readily tested by putting the motion the other way. The Chairman, Senator Crichton-Browne, ruled that that is exactly what could happen. That is the ruling that has been confirmed by the President and put to us now. It is on that basis that I urge that the President's ruling be upheld and that Senator Hill's motion not be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I express a view on this issue—I believe that there is a very real issue—to put the position of the chamber beyond doubt on the matters that are before us. We have had two votes on two indisputably linked bills. We already know, from an understanding of standing order 141, that either or both motions could have been moved using either wording.

PARA.TAB: We had two bills where the identical wording was given by the government, which I believe was appropriate. However, when that same motion was put, each time there was a different outcome—one in which there was a clear majority and one in which there was an equality. I suggest, therefore, that it is appropriate that a second motion, of different wording, is appropriate to clarify the outcome because of the links between those two bills and the need to clarify the position of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette has based her argument on the presumption that it is established that it is possible under standing order 141 to move more than one of those motions. That is precisely what we are dissenting from. I put to you, Mr President—I hope that Senator Chamarette will also listen—that if that ruling is upheld and you take that to its logical conclusion, we could go on and move all six of those motions.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly, a reading of the standing orders indicates that one makes a choice as to which is applicable to the particular set of circumstances. If there is a modification, one moves one of the modification options. If it is a request, one moves one of them. Otherwise, by saying that both can be moved, first the negative and then the positive, one is virtually recommitting the motion and the question to the vote, and they are mutually exclusive.

My colleague Senator Kemp will make a very strong constitutional point. Very simply, when the vote was taken and it was negatived, we had elected which of those motions was to be moved. Mr President, to simply rule that you can then go on selecting from that list and move all six clearly makes a nonsense of the standing order. Any logical reading of it will tell you that you are meant to elect the one motion which is appropriate to the particular circumstance of the bill that we are dealing with.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Kemp

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to base my comments on Odgers, the standing orders or precedent; I base my comments on section 23 of the constitution, which is absolutely crystal clear. It states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Questions arising in the Senate shall be determined by a majority of votes, and each senator shall have one vote. The President shall in all cases be entitled to a vote; and when the votes are equal the question shall pass in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, Mr President, who are we supposed to be listening to—Gareth or Senator Kemp?
—Order! Would senators resume their seats.
—Yes, come on, Evans; back to your seat.
—Order! There are senators to my left who are also not in their seats.

—Mr President, there are occasions when standing orders have to be interpreted and occasions when precedents have to be built on. But, Mr President, this is a clear case where you and your rulings are bound by the constitution of this country. It is not a matter of choice on your part. The vote has been drawn and the matter has been negatived.
—Going to the High Court, are you?
—I know that Senator Schacht likes to sneer at the constitution, but I put it to you, Mr President, that in your particular role you have a responsibility.

PARA.TAB: Another fundamental point is that if this ruling is sustained—the Independents, the Greens and the Democrats should pay particular attention to this—a major change has been taken in the nature of voting in this chamber. The reason the drafters of the constitution decided on this clause was to protect minorities in this chamber. I put it to Senator Harradine, the Greens and the Democrats that if they agree to this ruling they will be undercutting their own authority in this chamber, because the next time a vote is negatived, people will immediately stand up and refer to Odgers and the standing orders and attempt to overturn the vote by a different motion.

I put it to Senator Kernot, Senator Harradine and Senator Chamarette that this precedent goes far beyond this particular vote and this particular bill. This will be a precedent which future drawn votes will be built upon. If they decide to vote to overturn this constitutional ruling, they will undercut their own authority in this chamber and the authority of those who follow after them. It is a very big issue. Mr President, I put it to you that it goes far beyond the particular bill that is before this chamber today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to what Senator Kemp said about section 23 of the constitution. I would have thought that a more significant section in these circumstances is section 53. Mr President, a reading of the fourth paragraph of it supports the ruling that you have made and the advice given by the Clerk. It states:

PARA.TAB: The Senate may at any stage return to the House of Representatives any proposed law which the Senate may not amend, requesting, by message, the omission or amendment of any items or provisions therein. And the House of Representatives may, if it thinks fit, make any of such omissions or amendments, with or without modifications.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what I said, Barney.

—It says `may at any stage'. Once it has gone through the process of being considered by the House of Representatives, that is the end of that process. When it comes back here, if we want to do any more about it, we have to make a request. That is what is meant by `at any stage'.
—Then it comes back and Senator Gareth Evans can change his mind; we don't mind.

—If Senator Watson were listening, he would learn that one could return a piece of legislation at a number of stages. But it does contemplate that there will be returns at different stages and on different occasions. Where a request has been made by a majority of the Senate to amend a bill, it goes to the House of Representatives and comes back. If the House of Representatives does not accept that request, the only way it can be dealt with is to make another request—under section 53. Unless that is done—
—When it comes back again.
—Yes. But unless we can produce another request to attach to the bill tonight, it will come back again.
—No, no.

—Senator Bishops says `no, no', but how does she overcome the thrust of section 53? It does not go on to say in this section—I take up what Senator Kemp has said—that if there is an equality of voting the request persists. Section 23 has nothing to do with section 53. The plain reading of section 53 is in accordance with what has been determined here. The original request was exhausted when it went down and was not accepted in the House of Representatives. The bill came back again. If one wants to attach something to the bill to take the next step, one has to attach a request, which requires a majority. That becomes quite plain if one reads section 53 of the constitution.
—With the greatest respect to my friend Senator Cooney, the point he made is not relevant to the question at issue. We are dealing with the whole matter raised in relation to standing order 141.
—Standing order 141 doesn't override the constitution.

—I know that. But Senator Cooney understands as well as I do that the constitution provides what we can and cannot do. But the manner in which that is to be resolved is a subject of the standing orders—just as the law says what one may or may not do but the rules of court say how it must be done. That is what the standing orders are.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, Senator Cooney's point is not relevant. What is relevant is to say that this Senate has previously passed a request for amendment that has not been agreed to by the House of Representatives. It is incorrect for Senator Cooney to say that the House of Representatives, not having agreed with the request, can dispose of our request. The House of Representatives does not have the power to dispose of our request; it has the power not to agree with our request. But our request must stand.

It follows also that the Senate having decided to request an amendment, that can be overturned by only a positive vote on the correct motion to overturn it or a tied or otherwise negatived vote to further press it. It was up to Senator Evans as to which motion he would move. He moved a motion that the request not be pressed. Senator Evans has made a grievous mistake because if he had moved the other motion, it might have been resolved in a different fashion, but he moved the wrong motion.

The problem then comes when we say he has to have a second chance to get the same result. Of course, that cannot occur. The matter has already been decided. In fact, Senator Kemp is correct; section 23 of the constitution is the relevant one because it states that, when the votes are equal, the question shall pass in the negative. So what Senator Evans is seeking to do is to reopen or to recommit a matter which has already been decided. It is not competent for Senator Evans to merely move another motion to recommit that matter. That matter has been decided and if Senator Evans wishes to recommit that matter, he has to follow the appropriate standing orders in relation to the recommittal of a matter to the Committee of the Whole.

I take this opportunity to point out one other matter. If Senator Evans is now allowed to move a motion that the Senate press the request and that is resolved in the negative then, in effect, Senator Evans will be seeking to rescind a vote of the Senate. As you quite correctly said in your ruling tonight, Mr President, it is necessary to look at the substance of the decision of the Senate. It is therefore also important to look at the substance of what Senator Evans seeks to do. What he seeks to do is to overturn a matter which has just been decided by the Committee of the Whole by moving a motion of contrary effect.

The question is: is that a motion which rescinds the vote of the Senate or is it some other motion? I do not believe that the only motions of recision of a vote of the Senate are motions which contain the word `rescind'. That is quite clearly wrong at law. The law requires us to look at the substance of a matter rather than merely the form. The substance of the vote which Senator Evans seeks to move is to rescind the effect of the previous vote of the Senate.

May I explain it in a slightly different fashion. Suppose there is a vote that the debate on a bill be adjourned and it is resolved in the negative. It is not competent for any other senator to then move a motion that the debate be not adjourned, have that resolved in the negative and, therefore, say that the debate has been effectively adjourned, because that second motion would be a motion which rescinded the first motion. That is, of course, what Senator Evans seeks to do here.

Even if the Senate decides in this dissent motion that your ruling is correct, Mr President, I foreshadow that I shall immediately be taking a point of order to determine the nature and the timing of a subsequent vote and whether Senator Evans requires seven days notice because he is seeking to move a motion rescinding an earlier vote, and whether the Senate requires a majority vote of at least half of the whole number of the Senate which, under standing order 87, is the manner in which the standing orders set out the Senate should deal with motions for the recision of a question. It says that that cannot be done except by giving seven days notice and it shall require an affirmative vote of at least half of the whole number of senators except where there is a correction of an error, in which case one day's notice is required.

In either case, even if your ruling is correct, Mr President, it is, of course, not competent for Senator Evans to move that motion tonight. He is required to give seven days notice and he requires an affirmative vote of half of the whole of the number of the Senate. I foreshadow that point of order if this dissent motion is not satisfactorily resolved as far as we are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will any senator raise a hand and suggest that there is a majority in this chamber to press the request?
—Or not press.
—There is one. Can he explain to me, in practical terms—in commonsense terms—whether there is a majority of the Senate present in this parliament building who wish to press the request? There is not.
—Do you suggest there is a majority who does not want to press it?

—That is precisely the reason why it is important to have the motion proposed by Senator Evans. I do not always agree with Senator Evans, but on this occasion I do. Everyone in this chamber must realise that the standing orders of any organisation must ensure the proper functioning of meetings and ensure that those standing orders are such as to reflect the majority view of that particular meeting.
—But that is not the constitution.
—I know precisely what Senator Kemp is talking about with regard to the constitution and what it says about a negative vote.
—But it was a negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Harradine

TALK.START.PARA: —But a negative vote does not mean the positive; it never does. If it comes to the third reading tonight and there is an equality of votes to the proposition that the bill be read a third time, that is lost, is it not? That is negatived. That is all that that means. What does Odgers say about it? He does not say what Senator Kemp is saying about it, except in regard to the vote where there was a two majority. He virtually says, although not in these terms, `Perhaps we ought to adjourn and have a beer and somebody might change his mind'. That is what Odgers means in short. With due respect, Senator Kemp has been quoting Odgers but he did not put that point. Odgers virtually says that it may be desirable for the chair to adjourn and, presumably, senators to change their votes.

PARA.TAB: Frankly, that is not a satisfactory way to proceed. I think the ruling that has been made by the chair on this occasion is quite proper and it conforms to the literal meaning of standing order 141. Standing order 141(2) states:

INTERJECT.PARA: If a bill is returned to the Senate by the House of Representatives with a request not agreed to, or agreed to with modifications, any of the following motions may be moved . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Then you can move all six consecutively.
—With due respect, that is where Senator Bishop has misinterpreted this. Motions (c), (d), (e) and (f) refer specifically to modifications.
—No, that is a nonsense, Brian.
—Order!
—They do not refer to what (a) and (b) refer to. I suggest, Mr President, that your ruling is in order and I intend to oppose the motion of dissent.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the Senate dissent from the President's ruling.
Question so resolved in the negative.
The Chairman thereupon resumed the chair—

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the chair is Senator Evans's motion that the requests be pressed.

PARA.TAB: Senator O'Chee—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. In the earlier debate I foreshadowed to the President that I would raise a point of order pursuant to standing order 87. My point of order is that the motion which Senator Evans now moves is a motion which seeks to rescind an earlier vote of the Committee of the Whole. It seeks to overturn that vote. I am sure those on the other side of chamber will argue that a motion of rescision must contain the word `rescind'. That is not the case. As I demonstrated earlier, if there is a motion which is resolved and one moves a contrary motion which is also resolved in the negative, what one is seeking to do is to rescind or overturn that earlier vote.

Accordingly, the motion which has been moved by Senator Evans—being a motion of rescision—is not a motion which can be moved at this point in time. A motion to rescind an earlier vote of the Senate must have seven days notice. It also requires at least half of the whole number of senators voting in its favour. Accordingly, I submit to you, Mr Chairman, that, although the Senate has decided that Senator Evans does have the power to move this motion, he is not empowered to move the motion at this point in time; he must give seven days notice. At that time it will require, pursuant to standing order 87, a vote of at least half of the whole number of senators.
Senator Gareth Evans—Mr Chairman, I wish to speak to the point of order.
Senator McMullan—They are desperate.

Senator Gareth Evans—I embrace those interjections. Senator O'Chee has just acknowledged that the motion that has just been lost was one of dissent against the Chairman for ruling that I was competent to move the particular motion now before the chair and, indeed, competent to move it right now. The substance of the ruling was that successive motions could be moved at the same time under standing order 141(2)(a) and (b).

The very matter that Senator O'Chee is now seeking to put in issue has been resolved by the chairman ruling as he did. That being dissented from, that dissent motion was lost. I ask you now, Mr Chairman, to rule, not as Senator O'Chee requests, but that the very matter that Senator O'Chee puts before you has already been dealt with. It is impossible to characterise what I am now moving as a rescision motion if it has already been accepted and endorsed that it is competent for this motion to be moved, notwithstanding that the preceding motion in 141(2)(a) has already been moved and resolved tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee, my previous ruling was in respect of standing order 141. I ruled that Senator Evans was able to move two motions. The ruling that Senator Evans is entitled to move his second motion has been resolved by a vote of the Senate. Therefore, there is no point of order.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Gareth Evans's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the resolution dealt with by the committee I propose to report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Resolution reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Chairman of Committees, Senator Crichton-Browne, reports that the committee has considered message No. 122 in relation to the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and has resolved that the requests be not pressed and has considered message No. 123 in relation to the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and reports that two questions—that the requests not be pressed and that the requests be pressed—were both negatived by an equal dividing vote. I now confirm the ruling, which I foreshadowed, concerning the effect of the Senate's vote in committee. That ruling applies to each and to both of the votes.
—I object to that ruling and I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate dissent from the President's ruling.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the question of dissent from the ruling requires immediate determination.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clearly wrong, Mr President. It could not be better demonstrated than by the fact that to achieve his objective Senator Evans actually had to vote in a different way from that in which he moved.
—Exactly what you suggested earlier this evening—I should have done in the first place.
—No, I did not say that. What you have ruled, Mr President, has totally disregarded the decision that was first made by the Senate.
—Wrong again, Robert.

—We are right; there is no doubt about that. The government might have the numbers, but it is wrong. In the first instance there had to be a consequence for the first vote. The first vote was negative and that should have been the end of the matter. The advice of Odgers is clear, unambiguous and straightforward. The consequence was that the requests would then be entitled to be pursued. We were never given the opportunity to have the consequence that naturally flowed from the vote that was given in the first instance. Now we have this farcical situation in which the Labor Party moves one way and votes the other way in order that it might create a situation of inconsistency so that Senator Evans can then argue that it is impossible to reach a solution. He then takes another step; there is no evidence to it. The next step is that, because there is an inconsistency, we can assume that the requests have been defeated. How does he get to that step as well?
—Not very convincing.

—I do not think those opposite understand what is going on. On the basis of that, Mr President, I again urge the Senate to join with us and recognise that the precedent that you are establishing in this instance is quite wrong. It does not stand. It is inconsistent with former President Young's previous ruling. In fact, that has never been addressed by you. You have never, if I might say with respect, Mr President, said that you are overruling the previous order that was made by former President Young.

PARA.TAB: It is late but there is still a chance that the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine can help us to put it right. There is not much chance in view of the votes we have had so far, but there is a chance. They should vote for us because it is right.
With great respect, the argument that Senator Chamarette put previously was somewhat exotic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Somewhat what?

—Exotic. What I heard Senator Chamarette say was that because the vote was different between the first vote and the second vote, the second vote needs to be addressed by a different type of vote in order that it might be clarified. That does not make any sense at all. If Senator Chamarette agrees with what I say, she will agree that she has misunderstood the consequences of what she was doing.
—You are getting tired.

—No, I am actually getting another wind. Senator Chamarette now has another opportunity to join with us and get it right. There is a debate about the consequences. Senator Harradine talked about the fact, which is probably correct, that there is not a now majority in this place that would vote in favour that it be pressed, if that was the issue. That might be right, but that is not what has happened here tonight. What has happened here tonight is quite wrong and, as a result, it should be put right, even at this very late moment. Therefore, we have moved dissent. We have urged the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine to join with us and, even at this late moment, put it right to ensure that we are not putting in place a precedent that will be forever wrong.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, you will not be surprised to hear me say that I urge all honourable senators to support your ruling, not necessarily every part of it, by the way. There is an unresolved issue for another day about the impact of an equal vote to omit a clause in the case of an amendable bill. I would certainly wish to reserve my position on that and not be taken as having put that beyond doubt because there is a question as to whether bills should be dealt with in a different way. Having reserved my position on that and coming back to the particular question that is before us, it has taken us a very long time and a very circuitous route to get to where we are right now, but what we have had right now is a clear and unequivocal demonstration that there is not a majority now in this place to press the request. It is not a matter of demonstrating some inconsistency between this vote and the previous one.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. On listening to Senator Evans's comment upon your ruling indicating that he wished to uphold only part of your ruling, would you care to rule as to whether or not you will split your ruling and we can deal with it in two separate parts?
—Order! I think that Senator Evans is perhaps saying that he has a reservation about part of my ruling. Therefore, I will let him continue.

—The reservation was not about part of the ruling. The reservation was about part of the reasoning by which the whole matter was spelt out, dealing with that part of the reasoning which dealt with the matter not before us now; namely, not a request bill but an amendable bill and not a situation where a clause was being amended but rather where it was sought to be deleted. It is just one category that is spelt out in the document and because this is a situation that might be of some seriousness in a future case, I simply reserve my and the government's position on that.

PARA.TAB: Your ruling, Mr President, was that the requests now in issue are disposed of and that the bill must proceed without those requests. That is a ruling that I absolutely and unequivocally endorse and I urge the Senate to do likewise for the reason that it is the only rational way to proceed, short of creating an impossible stalemate and bringing the proceedings of this place into even more ridicule than is the norm outside.

The proceedings of this place on matters as important as this, the outcomes of our procedures, cannot be made to depend on the vagaries of the particular language used in order to secure a result. The substantive matter in issue is whether or not there is a majority to press the request. That matter was left in some doubt. There was some degree of ambiguity about the way the motion was first phrased, although it was clear that there was no majority in fact for either of the side of the equation. The matter is now beyond doubt that there is no majority for that, as a result of the vote that has just been put in the way that it was in the form that the request be pressed.

For all those reasons, because this is the only rational way, Mr President, I applaud you for having taken the trouble, in the way that you did, to consider this matter very carefully over the last few days and to take the advice of the clerk which, in this instance, on this particular matter, I think was admirably rational and balanced. We are dealing with an unprecedented situation. Although it has taken an unmercifully long time to deal with it, it is important to address in a considered, measured and thoughtful way the particular problem with which we are faced and with which we might conceivably be faced on a number of future occasions. It has been worth it to get it right. Your ruling was right and it ought to be endorsed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a variation on the O'Chee syndrome. What we have here is a proposition which is directly contrary to the earlier process of this place. —Order! There is no point of order because there has been no decision agreed upon by—

—I thought the ruling was, in the first instance, that the motion, being that the request not be pressed, resulted in an equality of votes, and it was ruled by the Chairman that it was in the negative. So there has clearly been a decision on the matter. In those circumstances, the same committee has dealt with two completely opposite propositions.

PARA.TAB: That is precisely the point of 144(3), and Senator Evans just conceded virtually as much by saying they may be contradictory on their face. That is a polite lawyers way of saying, `They are plainly contradictory, but I am inviting you to ignore that plain fact'. You cannot do that and, therefore, that stops us from proceeding further. You should take that into account before we proceed further to consider this current motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question was negative and no decision was agreed upon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the motion, very briefly, moved by Senator Hill, dissenting from the ruling that is set out in these three pages. The particular paragraph that I refer to is the third to last in which, Mr President, you said:

SPEECH.PARA: This interpretation also does not inhibit the right of the Senate to dispose of a bill which has been the subject of a request, because it is still open to the Senate to reject the bill at the third reading, which must be carried by a majority.

I put it to the Senate and, in particular, I put it to Independent senators that these two situations are not the same. If this ruling is accepted, it is not the same to negative the third reading by an equality of votes because the earlier situation of keeping a request is lost if this ruling is upheld.

PARA.TAB: I put it to Independent senators that if this ruling is accepted, there is a genuine loss by anyone who is forming an outcome by an equality of votes. Mr President, I do not believe that this paragraph gives any indication that the matter can still be in the hands of half the Senate by subsequently seeing the third reading of the bill negatived, because that is a different question. I return to the middle section of your ruling, Mr President, where you say:

SPEECH.PARA: I consider that in that circumstance the amendment or request is disposed of and the bill should proceed without the amendment or request in accordance with the standing orders.

That is a statement without any precedent, without any logic. The ruling could equally have been that because the status quo is that the Senate has made a request, and there has been no majority to upset that situation, that request decided earlier by a majority of the Senate still stands. The status quo is that the Senate has put a request to the House of Representatives. Therefore, noting that that is a logical position that could be adopted by ruling, I put it to Independent senators in particular that they should dissent from this ruling and so leave themselves the option of maintaining a request.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, a moment ago in addressing the point of order that was raised by Senator Alston pursuant to standing order 144(3) you very clearly stated that a question that is not resolved in the affirmative has not been decided, and on that basis you said that it was possible for Senator Evans to move a contrary motion. In other words, you said that the first motion was not passed, therefore there was no decision, therefore standing order 144(3) did not apply, and therefore Senator Evans could move the second motion. But the second motion was not resolved in the affirmative either.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, it follows that we have no decision in relation to the second motion. If that is the case, then all the proceedings of the committee are a nonsense. Either we had a decision the first time around, in which case the second motion is clearly contrary to the standing orders; or there was no decision the first time, therefore there was no decision the second time, therefore the committee could not report back.

It seems quite illogical to say that the first motion which was not resolved in the affirmative has not been decided, but the second motion which was not resolved in the affirmative has been decided. That is illogical in consistency. Therefore, I support the motion moved by Senator Hill dissenting from the ruling. A negative is always a decision. There is grave danger for the smaller parties in the Senate chamber to go down this track. What if we get to the third reading and, instead of Senator Evans moving that the bill be read a third time, he moves that the bill be not read a third time and we get a tied vote? Is that a vote in the affirmative? This is the same sort of logic. To follow your ruling, with great respect, is to turn the procedure of the chamber into a nonsense and to descend into chaos. There are logical ways to solve this, and the logic falls on this side of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to the logic of Senator O'Chee's previous statement. The first time, he said that the question was not resolved in the affirmative because there was an equality, and I agree. The rephrasing of the motion meant that it was not resolved in the affirmative either; however, it was possible to negate it. That is why when the second phrasing was used it was more appropriate and clarified the position. I believe that there is a dilemma that is caused by a confusion of grammar and democracy and I want to explain why the Greens hold the position they do in relation to Senator Hill's urging.

PARA.TAB: The difference between grammar and democracy—and both operate in these motions—is that grammar says that a double negative makes a positive while democracy says that negativity means you do not do something and a majority means that you do. Therefore, it is only appropriate that an action be taken when more people vote for it—that is, a majority. We have not gained that in either of the motions with the different phrasing. So when there is no majority, it does not happen; when there is an equality, it is negated to go with the status quo. The only status quo we have is not to act and not to insist. Therefore, the Greens will not be supporting the opposition in the position it is maintaining.

SPEECH.PARA: 12 October 1993
Senator the Hon Kerry W Sibraa
President of the Senate
Mr President
PROCEEDINGS ON BILLS: EQUALLY DIVIDED VOTES

During the passage of the taxation legislation, the question arose of what would happen if there were an equally divided vote on the question in committee of the whole that a clause be now passed without requests. This question is put under standing order 140 in lieu of the normal question for amendable bills, that the clause stand as printed, because the Senate cannot leave out a clause of a non-amendable bill. The effect of negativing the question that the clause be now passed without requests is that consideration of the clause continues. This raises the possibility of the Senate being unable to proceed to the subsequent clauses of the bill. The view to which I came is that, in this situation, the Chairman of Committees should indicate to the committee that if there are no further requests to be moved the clause is passed without requests and the committee proceeds to the next clause. The rationale of this ruling would be that making a request is the only action the committee can take on the clause of a non-amendable bill. The situation did not arise and this advice was therefore not offered, but I consider that I should record it.
There is still the possibility of a potentially more serious problem arising during the further consideration of the bills.

The Senate has made amendments and requests for amendments to the taxation legislation. It is possible that the bills will be returned from the House of Representatives with the amendments and requests disagreed to. The bills and the messages are then reconsidered in committee of the whole, and any of the following motions may be moved:
.that the amendments be insisted on
.that the amendments not be insisted on
.that the requests be pressed
.that the requests not be pressed.
Normally the government moves a motion that the amendments not be insisted on or that the requests not be pressed, as the occasion requires.
It is possible, the numbers being as they are in the Senate, that there will be equally divided votes on these motions.
Section 23 of the Constitution provides that where the votes in the Senate are equally divided the question is resolved in the negative.
The question arises as to the effect of equally divided votes on one of these motions in relation to an amendment or a request. This situation has not arisen in the Senate in the past.

It cannot be concluded that, if a motion that an amendment not be insisted on or that a request not be pressed is negatived by equally divided votes, this means that the amendment is insisted on or the request pressed, because, on that interpretation, the opposite result is achieved if the motions are moved in the alternative forms provided by the standing orders.
There are two other possible interpretations:
.the fate of the amendment or request, and therefore the fate of the bill, is left unresolved by such a vote, or
.the amendment or request is lost and the bill proceeds.

The first interpretation is suggested by Australian Senate Practice. It is obviously unsatisfactory as it leaves the Senate potentially in a situation of being unable to make a determination in relation to a bill.
The second interpretation is more rational, and I recommend that you rule to that effect.

The basis of the ruling would be that an amendment or a request must be made in the first instance by a majority of the Senate, and an equally divided vote on the subsequent question would indicate that there is no longer a majority in support of the amendment or request, which is thereby disposed of. An exception would be made in relation to an amendment by way of leaving out a clause of a bill, which can occur on an equally divided vote, and therefore an equally divided vote on the subsequent question would indicate that the clause still lacks a majority and is therefore not passed.

This interpretation is rational in that it rests on the requirement for majority support for an amendment or request, other than the omission of a clause, and is more satisfactory in that it avoids the situation of the Senate being unable to make a decision in relation to a bill.

It may appear to be a complication that there are two categories of amendments with a different rule applying to each, but that distinction also rests on the principle of the requirement for a majority for an amendment in the first instance, and the requirement for majority support for each clause of an amendable bill.

It is still open to the Senate to negative the question for the second or third reading of a bill by an equally divided vote. In the case of non-amendable bills the Senate has an opportunity to vote on the third reading after requests have been finalised; such an opportunity does not arise with amendable bills, because they are passed as amended and only the amendments are dealt with in the subsequent proceedings.
Attached is a draft ruling whereby you could give effect to this interpretation.

I suggest that if a question that an amendment not be insisted on or that a request not be pressed is negatived by an equally divided vote in committee, the opposite motion should be moved, and if that question is also so negatived, the Chairman of Committees report to the Senate. I think that it would be desirable to have both questions put to demonstrate that the vote is not changed by the opposite question, in case there is a legal challenge to the passage of the legislation. When the Chairman reports you could then make your ruling.

There have been suggestions in the press of new amendments being moved to the taxation bills in the Senate. When a bill is returned from the Senate with requests or amendments disagreed to, the proceedings are confined to the matter at issue between the Houses, and amendments unrelated to that issue cannot be moved. In the case of bills to which requests have been made, when the Senate has decided to treat such bills as non-amendable, and applied to them the procedures for non-amendable bills, it is clearly not open to the Senate to make amendments to such bills at a later stage. This principle is not affected by the declaratory resolution passed by the Senate in relation to certain bills.

As this is a difficult and complex matter which may cause some controversy, I suggest that you consider it before the Senate next meets. If you agree with the proposed ruling, I suggest that it be provided to Senators at an appropriate time, after the bills have been returned from the House, so that Senators are not taken by surprise and have an opportunity to consider the rationale of the ruling.
(Harry Evans)
EQUALLY DIVIDED VOTE ON INSISTING ON AN AMENDMENT OR PRESSING A REQUEST
Ruling by Mr President

It is now necessary to consider the effect of a situation in which the Senate has voted to amend a bill received from the House of Representatives, or to make a request for an amendment to the House of Representatives, the House of Representatives has declined to agree to that amendment or accede to that request, and a motion in accordance with the procedures of the Senate to determine whether the Senate should persist with its amendment or request has been negatived by an equally divided vote.

The effect of such a vote cannot be held to depend upon which of the alternative methods permitted by the standing orders for determining such a matter is used, that is, a motion to insist or a motion not to insist on an amendment, or a motion to press or a motion not to press a request.
This situation has not arisen in the Senate in the past. It is therefore necessary for me to consider the effect of the Senate's vote and the course of action which should follow from it.
At page 495 of Australian Senate Practice, 6th edition, the following statement is made:

What has yet to be tested is the position which would arise if the motion that the amendments be not insisted on be negatived by an equal vote. It could hardly be deemed that the Committee had resolved that the amendments be insisted on, because the Committee was equally divided. In such circumstances, probably the Chairman would state that position and invite a motion that the amendments be insisted on. If that motion too were negatived on an equal vote, it would be best if the Committee reported progress, asked leave to sit again, and gave further consideration to the matter on another day.

It will be noted that this passage refers to an amendment and not a request. A similar observation is not made in the work concerning requests. The passage also does not distinguish between an amendment or a request which must be carried by a majority and the omission of a clause of a bill which may be made on an equally divided vote.

The interpretation of the Senate's vote and the suggestion made in the passage is unsatisfactory in that it leaves the fate of the bill in question undetermined and does not provide a means of resolving the situation.
I consider that a more rational interpretation of the effect of the Senate's vote resolves the situation and allows the Senate to consider further the legislation in question.

At the initial consideration of a bill, a majority vote is required to make an amendment or a request for an amendment to the House of Representatives. If the House of Representatives declines to agree to the amendment or the request, the Senate must reconsider the matter. If on the motion to determine whether the Senate should persist with its amendment or request there is not a majority, this indicates that there is no longer a majority in favour of making the amendment or request; the amendment or request no longer has the support of a majority of the Senate. I consider that in that circumstance the amendment or request is disposed of and the bill should proceed without the amendment or request in accordance with the standing orders.

The situation would be different if a clause of a bill had been negatived in committee, which could occur by an equally divided vote. The standing orders require that, where a bill is treated as one which the Senate can amend under section 53 of the Constitution, every clause of the bill must be carried by a majority, and if a clause is negatived it is left out of a bill. If a motion not to insist on such an amendment were to be negatived by an equally divided vote, this would indicate that the clause still lacked the support of a majority and that the amendment was confirmed.
Where an amendment or a request must be made by a majority in the first instance, however, a decision to persist with the amendment or request should require majority support at the later stage.

This interpretation gives rise to a complexity, in that there are two categories of amendments with a different rule applying to each, but that distinction rests upon the requirement for a majority to carry an amendment in the first instance, and the requirement for a majority to carry each clause of an amendable bill.

I believe that this interpretation best preserves the integrity of the Senate's proceedings, and also avoids a situation of the Senate being unable to make a decision on a stage of a bill, and the fate of the bill being left undetermined.

This interpretation also does not inhibit the right of the Senate to dispose of a bill which has been the subject of a request, because it is still open to the Senate to reject the bill at the third reading, which must be carried by a majority.

In relation to an amendment to a bill other than the omission of a clause, if the Senate regards its passage of the bill as conditional on the amendment, this is a matter for the Senate to consider in deciding the fate of the amendment.
I therefore rule that the request(s)/amendment(s) now in issue are disposed of and the bill must proceed without the request(s)/amendment(s).
14 October 1993
Senator the Hon Kerry W Sibraa
President of the Senate
Mr President
PROCEEDINGS ON BILLS: EQUALLY DIVIDED VOTES PART 2
Further to my note of 12 October 1993, there is a further potential complication in the proceedings on the taxation bills.
It has been suggested that the government may propose further amendments in substitution for the Senate's amendments or requests.

In that circumstance, normally a motion is moved that the Senate does not insist on its amendment, or press its request, but agrees to the amendment made by the House of Representatives in place thereof.

If this motion were to be negatived on an equally divided vote, assuming that the ruling as proposed is accepted, this would mean that the Senate would not insist on its amendment or press its request but would also disagree with the amendment made by the House of Representatives in substitution; in other words the bill would go forward in its original form (it is clear that a motion to agree to a substitute amendment made by the House of Representatives must be carried by a majority). This could well be an unintended outcome.

The solution to this problem is that a senator could ask for the question to be divided under standing orders 84(3) and 144(2) and (7); such a request is always granted, unless the question is incapable of division. The question would then be put that the Senate does not insist on its amendment or press its request. If that question is negatived by a majority, the amendment is insisted on or the request is pressed and the second part of the question is redundant. If the question is negatived on an equally divided vote and the amendment or request, on the proposed ruling, is thereby lost, the senators can then consider their vote on the question that the substitute amendment made by the House of Representatives be agreed to. Senators who unsuccessfully voted to insist on the amendment or press the request could then vote for the amendment suggested by the House of Representatives as a second-best choice. If that second question is also negatived the Senate would have rejected the amendment proposed by the House of Representatives in substitution for its own amendment or request.
Senators would also still have the option of voting against the third reading of the bills to which requests have been made.

There is also the potential complication of substitute amendments or requests being proposed in the Senate on the return of the bills, which is permitted by standing order 141. That procedure, however, does not raise any similar difficulties of interpretation. Any such amendments or requests would require a majority to be carried.
(Harry Evans)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise to draw your attention to the fact that we have spent the last four hours on matters which illustrate the point that was raised in an article written in the Australian newspaper on 21 October—now yesterday—by Mr Frank Devine. I commend him on that article. He drew to the attention of the public the decerebration—I think that is probably the correct word—that occurs among members when discussing issues within this Senate. PARA.TAB: That we should be here at 23 minutes past two on a Friday morning is a reflection on the government itself that it cannot organise its business.
