ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Insurance: Regal and Occidental Life Group

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Regal and Occidental Life Group of companies:

(1) Has the disputed $65 million been recovered and was another legal matter also successfully pursued by the judicial manager; if so: (a) has the money been recovered by the judicial manager; and (b) how much money has been recovered.
(2) Is the Government satisfied with the outcome of the judicial management of the Regal and Occidental Group; if not, which aspects are unsatisfactory.
(3) What is the outcome for the investors.
(4) What return, expressed in cents in the dollar, will members receive and if there is a range of returns, what is the range.
(5) Does this loss show that the current system of prudential control in the life insurance industry, even after the amendments in 1991, is inadequate.
(6) Was the special levy allowed under the 1991 amendments ever imposed; if so, at what level.
(7) How much money has been collected and how much has been disbursed to policyholders.
(8) How big will a loss have to be before the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC) recommends to the Treasurer that such a levy be imposed.
(9) Is this the same model which the Government is proposing for the prudential supervision of the superannuation industry.
(10) Is the ISC oversight of the industry effective, given that investors make losses such as those described.
(11) Have individual policyholders been allowed to make individual choices about the destination of their funds; if not, why not.

(12) With reference to the case of a SuperCache regular contribution personal superannuation policy offered by Occidental, in which this policy provided that as long as five annual contributions were made no penalties would be incurred over the life of the contract, have the investors been given an opportunity to fulfil their contractual obligations.

(13) Is it a fact that differing investors having identical policies, that is, identical starting times and contributions are being told that their policies have differing transfer values; if so, why.

(14) Are policyholders, or at least some policyholders, being forced to pay fees to Regal and Occidental, in effect early cancellation fees, when the policy is compulsorily transferred to the new insurer.
(15) Should the investors be further penalised in this manner when they have no say over the destination of the funds.

(16) Are examples quoted by Anne Lampe in the Sydney Morning Herald of 17 April 1993 in which policyholders have continued to make contributions under their contract and have been worse off because of this compliance; if so, is this result within the law and why is it possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

PARA.TAB: (1) The $65M that was misappropriated at the time of the attempted sale of the Occidental Life Insurance Company of Australia Limited and Regal Life Insurance Limited was recovered. The other major recovery by the Judicial Manager was a doubtful debt of $55M loaned to the Goldberg group of companies. In each case, the recovery included legal costs as well as forgone earnings on the funds. In the misappropriation case the amount collected was around $90M and in the Goldberg Loan case the recovery was also $9OM.

(2) The Government is pleased that the recovery has been sufficient to provide full value for policyowners in six of the eight Statutory Funds operated by the companies. In the remaining two Statutory Funds operated by Regal Life, the recovery is expected to be between a minimum of 79% and a maximum of 87% for one and between a minimum of 94% and a maximum of 95% for the other, depending upon resolution of some outstanding matters including taxation issues.

(3) The Judicial Manager has negotiated the absorption of Occidental Life and Regal Life policies by Mercantile Mutual Life to provide policyowners with contracts as similar as possible to those previously held. Mercantile Mutual have also undertaken to credit special bonuses to continuing policyowners. Such a scheme provided the best possible solution for policyowners in the circumstances.

(4) The arrangements, which are considered to be the most advantageous to the general interests of policyowners in accordance with the provisions of Division 9 of the Life Insurance Act (1945), are intended to provide policyowners with Mercantile Mutual policies as closely related to their Occidental or Regal policies as possible. Assessment of the "return" to policyowners requires consideration of their entitlements under the Occidental or Regal policies that have been replaced. The "returns" to policyowners vary between full cover for six of the eight Statutory Funds and from a minimum of 79% to a maximum of 87% and a minimum of 94% to a maximum of 95% for the other two, depending on resolution of outstanding matters. While policyowners did not receive investment returns for the year to 30 September 1990 they have received interest credit since then.

(5) No. Given that it was a fraud which led to the demise of these companies the eventual outcome is much better than expected. The 1991 amendments provide the Government with the ability to intervene in a proposed change in life company ownership or control of this nature. There has also been an increase in the level of supervision of life companies including introduction of on site inspections of their operations. Even so, prudential regulation cannot eliminate fraud: it can only increase the chances of early discovery.
(6) The levy provided for in the Policy Holders' Protection Levies legislation has not been raised. A final decision on the levy is not possible until the resolution of the outstanding matters.
(7) Because no levy has been called, no money has been collected or disbursed.

(8) The levy legislation only allows for the calling of a levy to provide returns to policyowners of up to 90%. In the only Statutory Fund where it would be possible to call for a levy the range of levy amounts is a maximum of $6M to less than $lm depending upon resolution of some outstanding matters including the income tax treatment of some receipts. It is unlikely that a levy will be raised, especially if the outcome is at the lower end of this range.

(9) No. The Bills which will provide for financial assistance to trustees of superannuation funds that find difficulty in meeting benefit obligations following fraud or theft, while providing for the collection of a levy, is different in mechanics and purposes. In those circumstances, the trigger for collection of the levy is different as is the quantum of the levy which is limited to 0.05% of assets of other superannuation funds in any one year. In contrast, the Policy Holders' Protection Levies legislation related specifically to policyholders of the two named companies. It may be triggered if available assets are insufficient to provide Occidental Life and Regal Life policyowners with up to 90% of their entitlements. Further, the total aggregate levies on Life Insurance Companies had a monetary maximum upper limit of $65M; the individual company payments being calculated as the appropriate proportion of assets.

(10) The ISC oversight of the industry is appropriate especially following enactment of the Insurance Law Amendment Bill 1991 and the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill 1991. These Bills have improved the financial and prudential standards which must be satisfied by life and general insurance companies and provide a mechanism for the prior screening of changes to the ownership and control of life and general insurance companies. As previously mentioned there is now a programme of on site inspections of life offices and general insurance offices.

These improvements to supervision of the insurance industry will afford policyowners increased protection while not overly restricting the benefits of a free and competitive industry. However, it is not possible or appropriate for the supervision to be so heavy to ensure there will never be losses to policyowners.

(11) The arrangements negotiated by the Judicial Manager for the acceptance of all the Occidental and Regal policies by Mercantile Mutual has been assessed by experts, the ISC and the Federal Court as the most advantageous for policyowners generally. The transfer has now been effected and policyowners are free to transfer their policies elsewhere or otherwise deal with their policies as they wish and not incur termination penalties on their new Mercantile Mutual policies.

(12) The policy conditions that provided for Occidental Supercache contributors to limit the level of expense charges required cross subsidies from either shareholders or other policyowners. In the circumstances it is not possible for these cross subsidies to be continued by Mercantile Mutual or other Occidental policyowners, but the extent of any disadvantage to these policyowners will in any event be small and, if future investment earnings in Mercantile Mutual are above average, there will not be any disadvantage.

(13) Similar policies should have similar transfer values, but differences will occur if life insurance cover existed as part of the policy. Another reason for a difference might he different tax treatment for policyowners in dissimilar circumstances. The principles of the calculation of transfer values have been confirmed by the Federal Court, which has also directed that if errors in calculation have occurred, such errors are to be rectified.

(14) In the normal course of events, the charges taken from the policy account pay for the ongoing administration of the policy as well as recovering the considerable costs of policy establishment which include agent commissions and related agent and policy issue costs. Theoretically the transfer to Mercantile Mutual could have been done on the basis that the policy value and the balance of unrecouped costs were transferred separately. Alternatively, a net balance could be transferred with correspondingly lower charges in the future: the net balance method was adopted.
Either approach would be expected to provide the same immediate surrender benefits and the same longer term maturity benefits after transfer.

However, transfer of separate components would have required Mercantile Mutual to change existing computer and administration systems to be able to cope with the many types of policies being transferred. It was decided that the additional costs of such a transfer to Mercantile Mutual, and eventually the policyowners, should be avoided. The commercial reality was that neither Mercantile Mutual nor any other company would accept transfers on a gross of unrecouped cost basis.

While the immediate charges taken from policies may look unattractive in appearance the transfer value is in almost all cases no less than would have been available under the existing policy and projections show that in each future year policyowners are likely to receive at least as much from their new Mercantile Mutual policy as from their old policy.

As explained in 13, the calculation of the transfer value takes into account unrecouped establishment costs; however the calculation establishes the present value of each policy rather than imposing cancellation fees.

(15) There is not intended to be a penalty on the transfer, rather the calculation of a present value. Transfer of business to Mercantile Mutual was agreed to for the benefit of policyowners generally. Policyowners will shortly have control of their policies and be able to deal with them in the normal way.

(16) Policyowners who continued to make contributions maintained their life cover, avoided new contract establishment costs and retained their tax advantages and concessions. Collectively, policyowners achieved a better result on eventual transfer of the business by maintaining their contracts than would have otherwise have been achieved. However, as normal policy conditions have applied, in some cases, policy values have been increased by less than the additional contributions made.

All the criticisms received by the Judicial Manager were explained to and discussed before the Federal Court. The issues were complex and many policyholders misunderstood the considerable information that was sent to them. The Judicial Manager held meetings with policyholders and responded individually to the many queries. There was considerable misunderstanding in the press. Life Insurance policies are complex and varied in type: some degree of misunderstanding, while regrettable, has to be expected. The measures that I announced on 14 July 1993 will do much to improve public understanding of life insurance policies.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice on 1 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is DDT still being used in Queensland to control termites.
(2) Does Australia import DDT or any other organochlorine pesticide.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) DDT has never been approved for the control of termites in Queensland and its use for any purpose, other than laboratory purposes, has been totally prohibited in Australia since June 1987.

(2) The importation of organochlorine pesticides into Australia is controlled under the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. Those Regulations were amended in December 1987, such that a permit is now required from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy before any organochlorine pesticide listed in Schedule 9 of those Regulations can be imported.

No DDT has been imported into Australia since then, apart from small quantities required for laboratory analytical work. At present the only organochlorines imported into the country in commercial quantities are heptachlor, chlordane and lindane. Small quantities of a range of organochlorine pesticides are occasionally imported for laboratory analytical purposes.
The Agriculture and Resource Management council of Australia and New Zealand decided in July this year that no further imports of heptachlor should be approved after 30 September 1994.
